According to statistics, an effective collection area of 43.3% per unit area can be achieved in the receiving mode, which provides a reliable guarantee for subsequent high-quality signal processing.
ieee_keywords: ['Optical sensors', 'Optical waveguides', 'Optical switches', 'Optical crosstalk', 'Antennas', 'Phased arrays', 'Transmitting antennas']
author_keywords: ['Optical phased array', 'transceiver integration', 'silicon photonics integration', 'beam steering']

abstracts: This paper presents a novel experiment to verify acupuncture as science by observing the signalling molecules, their migration and conducting pathways. Two-photon microscope was used for in vivo molecular imaging. A piezoelectric driven vibrating needle produces a propagating acoustic shear wave that activates Ca2+ in the skeletal muscle tissue fibers. Calcium paths and waves were measured unambiguously in vivo in mice for the first time. Acupuncture may now be considered as a scientific tool.

Compared with the existed 2-step algorithms, the proposed QSF algorithm reveals two advantages: First, it reduces the influence of the inaccurate estimation of background intensity on the phase retrieval quality, thereby improving the effectiveness in 2-step PSI. Second, it releases the restriction of the required number of fringes in the interference pattern, because the blind phase shift estimation procedure in the proposed QSF algorithm is not directly related to the fringes number.

An ultra-broadband optical filter based on step-chirped multimode waveguide Bragg grating (SCMWBG) with low insertion loss, high sidelobe suppression ratio (SLSR), compact size and relaxed fabrication accuracy is demonstrated on SOI platform. The grating length of SCMWBG is divided into grating segments with constant periods, and the period of each segment increases in a fixed step length of 1 nm. Each grating segment of the proposed SCMWBG is designed according to the phase-matching condition. The device is fabricated by a 193 nm DUV lithography, and employs complementary lateral-misalignment apodization to suppress the sidelobes. The measured insertion loss, SLSR and 3-dB bandwidth of fabricated SCMWBG are 1.2 dB, 17 dB and 72 nm, respectively.
ieee_keywords: ['Gratings', 'Optical waveguides', 'Couplings', 'Arrayed waveguide gratings', 'Chirp', 'Optical device fabrication', 'Resonator filters']

abstracts: Grating couplers (GCs) are important for light to couple between optical fibers and photonic integrated circuits (PICs). The Bound State in Continuum (BIC) waveguides offer new functionalities for PIC. High-Q resonators, electro-optical modulator, and photodetectors can be built on it without etching steps. Due to the special waveguide geometry of BIC waveguides, a high efficiency GC is still missing. In this work, we demonstrated a subwavelength grating (SWG) GC for BIC waveguide with a coupling efficiency of 8 dB and a 1 dB bandwidth >70 nm. The device shows ultra-broadband behavior which is extremely useful for BIC-based PICs.

Polymer waveguides are considered to be good candidates for optical interconnects application due to their advantages such as flexibility, good compatibility, and versatility for realizing 3D and micro structures. However, constrained by the limited degrees of freedom provided by template-based design approaches, there lacks a satisfying solution which achieves small footprint and low loss simultaneously. Inverse design has been proposed to improve the performance. However, most inverse design methods target at silicon-based optical devices optimization which has a relatively high refractive index difference. In this paper, we demonstrate an ultra-compact low loss polymer wavelength (de)multiplexer with spot-size conversion structure to interposing Si and optical fiber using gradient-based topology optimization and downhill simplex method. The 2-channel wavelength (de)multiplexer displays an excess propagation loss of 0.84 dB and 1.06 dB at 1310 nm and 1550 nm, respectively, with a total footprint of 245 × 35 μm 2 . The 4-channel wavelength (de)multiplexer for coarse wavelength division multiplexing applications with 20 nm spacing (1270, 1290, 1310, and 1330 nm) with an excess waveguide propagation loss of 1.72 dB within 271 × 50 μm 2 has also been demonstrated and all the output ports of the polymer wavelength demultiplexing structure achieved a conversion efficiency over 90%.

It has been challenging for the generation of optical frequency combs with a stabilized CEO, an ultra-dense (< 1 MHz) frequency spacing, and a large spectral bandwidth (>1 THz). Because this would require mode-locked lasers with impractically long cavities (>few hundred meters). Here we demonstrate a simple, yet very powerful method for the generation of CEO-stabilized combs with a spacing that is programmable from 250 MHz down to 250 kHz over a 5-dB bandwidth of 10 THz.
ieee_keywords: ['Bandwidth', 'Phase modulation', 'Optical harmonic generation', 'Optical mixing', 'Broadband communication', 'Phase noise', 'Spectroscopy']
author_keywords: ['Noise characterization', 'Optical frequency comb', 'Talbot and self-imaging effects.']

abstracts: We propose and demonstrate an ultra-fast tunable ODL based on cascaded silicon microdisk resonators (MDRs). By exploiting the free-carrier dispersion effect on silicon, the proposed ODL can be tuned with an ultrahigh speed. Multiple MDRs are connected to increase the time delay. As a demonstration, integrated ODLs with 5 and 10 MDRs are designed and fabricated, which provides an ultra-short response time of 989 ps, a low power consumption below 0.58 mW, and a small footprint of 0.13 mm2.

The proposed PIN-photodiode receiver offers a performance being competitive to receivers using single-photon avalanche diodes. The advantages of much less circuit effort and easier handling offer new perspectives for optical receivers. The used photo-charge integration principle may also be interesting for application in many advanced sensor applications.

To the best of our knowledge, ultra-short pulses with high repetition frequency are rarely reported in plasmonic systems. In this paper, we demonstrated the femtosecond pulses with THz repetition frequency in a transmission system consisting of plasmonic resonator and quantum emitters (QEs). Also, the pulse width and the repetition frequency can be freely controlled by the incident light intensity and the QEs number density, a phenomenon that is rarely reported before.

An ultra-thin and broadband single-layer metasurface (MS) is proposed, which can achieve the circular polazrization (CP) conversion with an efficiency of approximately 22% for both reflection and transimssion from 6.2 to 15 GHz, with a relative bandwidth of 87.1%. The full 2? phase shifts of the CP waves for full-space can be realized. As proofs of concept, anomalous refraction, focusing and vortex beam generation can be achieved.
This work presented the circadian performance optimization of laser-based lighting by GA, some useful results can be found.

We propose and fabricate an ultrafast and high extinction ratio 1 × 4 optical switch based on a cascade, dual-output Mach–Zehnder interferometer (MZI) on the lithium niobate platform. The optical switch consists of cascaded, identical, dual-output MZI structures, and each of them includes a Y-branch waveguide, two parallel interference arms (electrode action area), and a 3 dB directional coupler. Four output optical paths can be switched through three groups of electrode hierarchical modulation. The test results of the fabricated device show that the insertion loss of each port is less than 7.1 dB and that the maximum extinction ratio is higher than 39.3 dB. The optical switch can achieve a high extinction ratio greater than 20 dB within the 50 nm wavelength range. The measured half-wave voltage is less than 4.13 V, and the minimum switching rise and fall times reach 125 ps and 250 ps, respectively. This result shows that the proposed and fabricated 1 × 4 integrated optical switch on a lithium niobate platform has the advantages of a fast response rate, high extinction ratio, and low switching voltage.
author_keywords: ['1 × 4 electro-optical switch', 'dual-output MZI', 'optical waveguide', 'ultrafast and high extinction ratio']

abstracts: We have investigated the optical properties of multilayered plasmonic nanocavity with deep subwavelength size in all three dimensions by numerical simulations. We utilize the HMM to achieve the small mode volume. And the properties of these cavities, can be tuned by the geometrical parameters, such as resonance wavelength, Q factor and Vm. These properties can be demonstrated by rationally the geometrical parameters and may have potential applications in light-matter interaction.

This study analyses the ultrasonic modulation of diffracted light in Raman-Nath acousto-optic diffraction, and determines the source of the periodic variations of the ultrasound-modulated light intensity with time and along the ultrasound beam. We find that the frequency shifts of the diffracted light cause the temporal variation, while the phase shifts of the diffracted light result in the periodic variation along the ultrasound beam.

With the traditional multilayers coating, it is difficult to achieve broadband and wide-angle antireflection optical properties simultaneously. As one of the most promising candidates for omnidirectional and broadband antireflection coating, the moth-eye structure has gained considerable attention in the past several decades because of its excellent optical performance and self-cleaning function. The challenges in the use of this technology, namely, its manufacturing cost and mechanical structural stability, limit its popularization. In this paper, a moth-eye structure surface combined with a residual layer of an identical material is proposed; the proposed composite structure can be formed by a one-step process of half-etched technology. For the design and optimization of the composite moth-eye structure, composite structures were compared by performing effective medium approximation (EMA) and rigorous coupled– wave analysis (RCWA). The structural parameters of the micro–nano surface were optimized to increase the mechanical stability considerably. The results showed that the optimized composite moth-eye structure has high transmittance for incident angles from 0° to 80° in the infrared spectrum. Furthermore, the transmission diffraction at high orders was suppressed efficiently at super-wide incident angles.
author_keywords: ['Subwavelength structures', 'nanostructures', 'antireflection coatings', 'effective medium approximation', 'rigorous coupled-wave analysis']

abstracts: We consider three main challenges in underwater laser-based communication between moving vehicles: beam steering, beam widening, and scanning. We introduce a system concept based on optical phased array (OPA) antennas to electronically steer a laser beam in two dimensions, and to simultaneously control the beamwidth.To the best of our knowledge, we provide the first numerical evaluation of an underwater communication system using OPA technology.
ieee_keywords: ['Laser beams', 'Optical transmitters', 'Antenna arrays', 'Phased arrays', 'Optical receivers', 'Wireless communication', 'Lenses']
author_keywords: ['Laser applications', 'optical phased array', 'pointing and acquisition', 'underwater optical wireless communication']

abstracts: Optical wireless data transmission from an autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) to a sea-surface buoy has become a viable solution to support the increasing needs for many applications in the field of marine technology. Despite having unique characteristics and advantages, underwater wireless optical communication remains a challenging field due to the difficulties associated with the harsh marine environments and severe attenuation caused by the bubbles and particulates. This study aims to evaluate the uplink UWOC system in the presence of particles and bubbles under various wind speeds. To calculate the link distances and signal loss between a transmitter and a receiver of the UWOC system, simulations were performed with the inputs of the water optical properties obtained from the Bay of Bengal and Southern Ocean waters and bubble properties derived from the Hall-Novarini (HN) model. Consequently, the normalized received power were calculated for the different receiver configurations and oceanic conditions without and with bubbles. Our results showed that the received power decreased with the increasing wind speeds and smaller bubble populations. The angular and spatial distributions of the received beam increased for smaller bubble populations under high wind speeds. When compared to the clean bubbles, the received power slightly decreased for the non-absorbing coated bubbles with different film thicknesses (0.01 ∼ 1.0 μm) and increased for the absorbing coated bubbles with higher thicknesses (≥1 μm). These results will significantly help the system designer to develop and optimize an UWOC system under different bubble populations and wind speed conditions.

The new class of plane-focusing microprism Fresnel lenses have been proposed that principally differs from the traditional point-focusing devices. They can form a homogeneously irradiated light spot of any diameter at the stated focal distance. Such lenses are very effective for application in photovoltaic modules for concentrating the sunlight. Other possible area is the automated control systems with four-plane photodetectors, when the optimal direction-finding characteristics are necessary.

Effect of cerium codoping on Stokes or anti-Stokes luminescence of BiOCl:Er 3+ crystals, which were controlled by a special photon avalanche (PA) mechanism under 980-nm excitation, was investigated. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis indicate that Ce 3+ ions were successfully doped into BiOCl lattices. However, in PA photoluminescence behaviors, the doped Ce 3+ ions did not present efficient resonant energy transfer (ET) processes between the Er 3+ ions as generally reported. As a result, the intensity of visible PA upconversion emission and 1.54μmdownshifting near-infrared (NIR) emission of Er 3+ ions shows the same concentration dependence of cerium dopants. This phenomenon can be understood by the influence of cerium dopant content on the magnitude of internal electric field in layered BiOCl crystals, which may play a more important role on the upconversion (UC) and NIR luminescence of Er 3+ than the traditional ET between rare-earth (RE) ions. The results of our work may offer a different understanding for the method to control the emissions of RE ions.

A flexible first-order OAM modes generation in ring-core fibers (RCFs) based on a mechanically-induced long-period fiber grating (MLPFG) is proposed. By directly fusion splicing a standard single-mode fiber (SMF) and RCFs, the anti-resonant reflection guidance mechanism (ARRGM) is introduced in the RCF, leading to the guided-core modes, so-called anti-resonant modes (AR modes), which have a Gaussian field distribution and are confined in low-refractive index central core of RCFs. A mechanical long-period fiber grating is used to couple the AR modes into the OAM modes propagated in the high-index ring core of the RCF. Results show that the generated OAM modes are the combination of two orthogonal linearly polarized (LP) modes with ±π/2 phase shift in the ring core. The mode conversion efficiency of OAM +1 and OAM −1 can reach 95% and 94%, respectively, indicating promising applications in sensing and communication of the RCFs.
ieee_keywords: ['Optical fiber polarization', 'Refractive index', 'Optical fiber sensors', 'Optical fiber theory', 'Fiber gratings', 'Optical variables control', 'Optical refraction']
author_keywords: ['Anti-resonant reflection guidance', 'long-period fiber gratings', 'orbital angular momentum', 'ring-core fiber']

abstracts: We report for the first time on specific features of vector modulation instability (VMI) in highly birefringent fibers with circularly polarized modes. These include dependence of the polarization state in the VMI bands upon fiber birefringence and behavior of the critical power beyond which the VMI cannot exist upon modes ellipticity. Our findings were confirmed experimentally by observation of isotropic-like VMI in the spun side-hole fiber with relatively high circular birefringence 2×10^-6.
author_keywords: ['Vector modulation instability', 'circularly birefringent fibers', 'highly birefringent fibers']

abstracts: We define a new kind of radially polarized twisted sinc-correlation Schell-model (RPTSCSM) source and establish the source parameter conditions necessary to produce a physical beam. With the help of the extended Huygens-Fresnel integral, Several typical numerical examples are provided to study the influence of the source parameter and turbulent parameter on the statistical properties of such beams on propagation. It is shown that the intensity profiles of such beams always exhibit rotation and self-splitting on propagation, which is caused by the twisted phase of the beams. Moreover, the light intensity splits into an array and maintains its array distribution in free space. While the array gradually evolves to a hollow distribution with a dark core in a turbulence medium, indicating that the light beam may automatically restore the radial polarized light intensity distribution in atmospheric turbulence after a certain distance of propagation. Compared with the intensity, the impact of the twisted factor on the degree of polarization is to produce noticeable distortion around its distribution centre. When propagating in a turbulent atmosphere, the degree of polarization of such beams exhibits well-turbulent resistance. The degree of coherence would also experience self-splitting and rotation caused by the twisted factor, and a turbulent atmosphere has an important influence on the degree of coherence. Our results will benefit multi-particle manipulation and free-space optical communication.
author_keywords: ['Coherence', 'vector partially coherent beams', 'sinc-correlated structure', 'statistics properties', 'turbulent atmosphere']

abstracts: In this work, we present a partially tapered ridge waveguide Fabry-Perot laser with a vertically coupled twin-waveguide structure. It's fully compatible with the standard anufacturing technology of the conventional RW devices. Numerical simulation result shows that the divergence angles of the proposed laser can be reduced to 13 14. And no appreciable degradation as compared to the reference FP laser has been found through the static and dynamic performance simulation.

A novel autostereoscopic display utilizing Composite Lenticular Lens array (CLLa) and Saddle Lens array (SLa) has been proposed, which generates two symmetrical viewing zones within the field of view. A 7.9-inch LCD panel with a pixel density of 324 PPI was utilized in this experiment. The results indicate that the field of view (FOV) can be expanded by 16.2%, crosstalk level is reduced to 0.8%, and spatial resolution is doubled without increasing lens width or reducing focal length.

The accurate target detection under different environmental conditions and the real-time target positioning are vital for the successful accomplishment of underwater missions of Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs). In this paper, we propose a vision-based underwater target detection and positioning approach to detect and estimate the position and attitude of artificial underwater targets. The proposed approach is composed of an underwater target detection algorithm YOLO-T and a target positioning algorithm. Firstly, we modify the structure of YOLOv5 algorithm using Ghost module and SE attention module to improve the calculation time of target detection. Secondly, a series of image processing operations are performed on the improved YOLOv5 detection results to increase the detection accuracy. Thirdly, a cooperative marker is designed as the artificial underwater target, and the corresponding positioning algorithm is presented to calculated the position and attitude of the target according to the geometric information of the designed marker. We validate our approach through experimental tests respectively in a water tank, an anechoic tank, and the sea trial in Huanghai Sea in China. The results demonstrate the accurate performance of the proposed detection and positioning method.
ieee_keywords: ['Object detection', 'Feature extraction', 'Convolution', 'Image color analysis', 'Deep learning', 'Kernel', 'Three-dimensional displays']

abstracts: This paper aims to employ a neural network method of extreme learning machine to solve the problem of laser beam cleanup under the dynamic non-uniform-intensity distribution. This neural network is used to fit the corresponding nonlinear relationship between the slope information detected by the wavefront sensor and the recovery voltage of deformable mirror under the dynamic non-uniform-intensity distribution. The simulation results show that the beam quality after correction is improved from 1.7 to 1.3 times diffraction limit. And the residual wavefront after correction for the proposed method has been reduced by 55%, while the direct gradient method is 17%.
ieee_keywords: ['Laser beams', 'Neurons', 'Predictive models', 'Measurement by laser beam', 'Training', 'Power lasers', 'Numerical models']
author_keywords: ['Extreme learning machine', 'the non-uniform-intensity distribution', 'laser beam cleanup', 'diffraction limit', 'wavefront correction']

abstracts: Compared with traditional sensing techniques, plenoptic system has its unique lightfield information capture ability, so it has great potential for distinguishing and eliminating the influence of obstacle on wave-front sensing. Base on this superiority, in this manuscript, we propose and demonstrate a new wave-front achieving method by exploiting a plenoptic configuration to realize the wave-front achievement using partially occluded and extended scene target as reference.

I propose new platform for a realization of novel nonvolatile optical photodetectors and activation function units devices that takes an advantage of high field confinement provided by plasmonics and multi-state programming capabilities of chalcogenide phase change materials. A high reduction in the overall energy consumption consists of a high field enhancement provided by plasmonic that allow to lower the energies and implementation of PCMs that allow to operate under zero power consumption.

Transverse mode wavelength dependence in the gallium nitride (GaN) laser cavity is a new topic. Modal analysis simulations are run to optimize the blue GaN-based laser diode with a wavelength of 400, 430, and 460 nm. It is shown that the optical confinement factor (OCF) has a strong dependence on wavelength of emission and electron-block (e-block) thickness. The OCF can be changed from 4.9% at a 460-nm wavelength to 7.6% at 400 nm, which is a 55% difference. The effect of adding an e-block layer of different widths is also investigated with results showing that an e-block layer can change optical confinement by 14% at 460 nm wavelength and 13% at 400 nm wavelength. The bottom n-GaN layer thickness is optimized between 0.1 and 7 μm. It is found that a thin buffer layer improves optical mode distribution by reducing the ghost mode.
ieee_keywords: ['Optical buffering', 'Laser modes', 'Gallium nitride', 'Semiconductor lasers', 'Optical waveguides', 'Waveguide lasers', 'Optical variables control']

abstracts: We propose a cost-effective wavelength reused scheme for bidirectional short-reach access network utilizing mode-division-multiplexing (MDM). Compared with other wavelength reused schemes, the signal qualities on two directions are independent in the proposed scheme and symmetrical bidirectional transmission without residual re-modulation crosstalk can be achieved. To reduce bidirectional Rayleigh backscattering noise, different sideband for US and DS transmission is also proposed.
ieee_keywords: ['Amplitude modulation', 'Passive optical networks', 'Optical receivers', 'Optical amplifiers', 'Optical filters', 'Optical fibers']

abstracts: We present the first arithmetic algorithm for multiwavelength interferometer that has a theoretical maximum range of the lcm, the resolution of a single-wavelength interferometer, and achieves the theoretical maximum noise tolerance of an algebraic approach. Our experimental setup is also the first to employ the techniques of simultaneous phase shifting interferometry, enabling phase extraction with high precision.
ieee_keywords: ['Wavelength measurement', 'Phase measurement', 'Optical interferometry', 'Phase shifting interferometry', 'Robot sensing systems', 'Three-dimensional displays', 'Metrology']

abstracts: It is generally impossible to maintain tight focusing over a long distance because of diffraction; this so-called Rayleigh's curse may be broken for a femtosecond laser if the wavefront curvature varies with laser wavelength. This paper reports on a nonlinear technique to produce a wavelength-dependent wavefront. We reveal a wavelength-dependent wavefront mechanism that is induced in optical parametric chirped-pulse amplification (OPCPA) where the crystal effect of group-velocity mismatch (GVM) dominates. Both analytical and numerical investigations show that the sign of the produced wavefront can be changed by GVM, and the magnitude can be enhanced by multistage OPCPA. The results suggest that the Rayleigh range at a fixed beam waist size can be significantly increased by the OPCPA-induced wavelength-dependent wavefront.

We theoretically propose and investigate the resonant wavelength-selective optical filters based on the subwavelength metallo-dielectric nanopatch cavities and the metal slot waveguides. Using the temporal coupled-mode theory and three-dimensional finite-difference time-domain simulations, we analyze the optical coupling efficiencies and filtering characteristics, which are optimized by adjusting the waveguide-cavity distance to modify the decay rates from the cavity. The proposed optical filters can be extended to multiport channel-dropping filters while maintaining subwavelength-scale dimensions including the coupling regions.

Weak optical signal processing based on nonlinear effects offers new approaches for imaging through scattering media. A novel incoherent optical signal amplification method based on spatial modulation instability is proposed for imaging through fog. We experimentally demonstrated the amplification and recovery of degraded weak incoherent optical image signals after passing through dense fog in a photorefractive crystal. Our experimental results indicate that the intensity profiles of the output images can be redistributed from disordered to ordered when the nonlinear strength exceeds the threshold of incoherent modulation instability, which shows that the partially disordered incoherent probe light intensities are orderly transferred to enhance the signal intensity profiles and the residuals become a uniform background. The restored nonlinear output images with high visibility were observed for a proper optical thickness of fog, and weak optical imaging from undetectable to detectable with relatively poor visibility for a larger optical thickness was also realized in the experiment. This incoherent optical signal amplification method based on modulation instability has a potential application for image recovery in atmospheric scattering imagings.

The major contribution of the paper is deriving the integral formulas for a Youngs diffractive wave scattered from a spatially deterministic medium. The results extend the current knowledge of the weak scattering of light from a deterministic medium. The results also contribute to determining the scattering potential of a unknown scatterer. Future researches may rely upon our results, for example, probing the structural parameters of a random medium.

The operation of the fiber laser stabilized by a whisper gallery mode resonator reported previously is labile due to the lasing mode competitions among excitable WGMs and the signal to noise ratio is less than 55 dB. Here, we propose a hybrid cavity for mode stabilization of the fiber laser, and experimentally demonstrate stable, single-mode lasing emission with high signal to noise ratio (up to 61 dB), narrow linewidth (low to 5 kHz) operation.
ieee_keywords: ['Optical resonators', 'Laser modes', 'Optical fiber sensors', 'Lasers', 'Optical fiber communication', 'Couplings', 'Optical fiber couplers']

abstracts: We demonstrate a novel measurement technique of the intrinsic modulation responses of semiconductor lasers. Our technique exploits the optical pumping of a semiconductor laser under test and the lock-in detection of its response, which can measure the intrinsic modulation response with high sensitivity in a wide modulation frequency range. Therefore, it can be a powerful tool for evaluating wide-bandwidth semiconductor lasers required for such as optical communication and photonic computing.
ieee_keywords: ['Modulation', 'Optical modulation', 'Semiconductor lasers', 'Optical filters', 'Frequency modulation', 'Optical receivers', 'Optical pumping']
author_keywords: ['Semiconductor laser', 'modulation response', 'coherent optical spectrum analyzer', 'lock-in detection']

abstracts: A new photonic-assisted instantaneous frequency measurement system is presented. It overcomes the latency problem in the reported structures based on the frequency-to-time mapping technique or the frequency-to-power mapping technique that involves a long length of fiber, and at the same time, enables the incoming microwave signal frequency to be measured over a wide frequency range with only small errors. The system generates three low-frequency signals. The phases of the three low-frequency signals are compared. One of the two low-frequency signal phase differences is used to estimate the incoming microwave signal frequency unambiguously over a wide frequency range and the other is used to provide accurate microwave signal frequency measurement. A proof-of-concept experiment is set up. Experimental results show, by measuring the phase difference of two low-frequency signals, the frequency of the input microwave signal can be determined unambiguously in 15 GHz and 500 MHz frequency ranges with errors below ±220 MHz and ±10 MHz respectively. Hence, by using two low-frequency signal phase differences, the input microwave signal frequency can be determined accurately over a wide frequency range. The new photonic-assisted frequency measurement system has a fast response time, which is an order of magnitude shorter than that of the systems based on the frequency-to-time mapping technique and the frequency-to-power mapping technique with a kilometer-long fiber.
ieee_keywords: ['Frequency measurement', 'Radio frequency', 'Microwave measurement', 'Modulation', 'Optical fibers', 'Optical polarization', 'Optical reflection']
author_keywords: ['Optical signal processing', 'microwave measurement', 'fiber optics links and subsystems', 'radio frequency photonics']

abstracts: 1.A hybrid structure of hollow core photonic crystal fibers is proposed. 2.Numerical simulation is conducted on the proposed optical fiber and the confinement loss is effectively reduced by combining the claddings of antiresonance and photonic bandgap guidance mechanisms. 3.The excellent mode property of hybrid structure hollow core fiber is calculated and analyzed. 4.The outstanding bending resistance of proposed fiber is studied and demonstrated.
ieee_keywords: ['Claddings', 'Photonic band gap', 'Electron tubes', 'Optical fiber losses', 'Bandwidth', 'Optical losses', 'Bending']

abstracts: We propose a single-layer graphene-supported metamaterial absorber with a combination of square, circular, and cross-shaped meta-resonators, exhibiting an outstanding absorption of more than 90 % from 2.3 THz to 6.4 THz.

An ultrathin and wideband reflective cross-polarization converter is presented in this paper. The design consists of a pair of modified dumbbell shaped resonators which are connected together with a conductive strip. The proposed single-layer THz metasurface achieved a high polarization conversion ratio (PCR) of≥95% in the operating frequency ranging from 1.76–4.26 THz. This wide-bandwidth cross-polarization conversion is obtained by exciting multiple closely spaced resonant frequencies at 1.98 THz, 2.61 THz, 2.95 THz, and 3.93 THz. The working mechanism of the proposed structure is analyzed and the polarizer exhibits an excellent angular stability upto 400of incidence. Further, the proposed cross-polarizer exhibits continuous tunability of PCR over the operating frequencies when photoconductive silicon (Si) is filled in the gap between pair of dumbbell-resonators. The wideband characteristics and the switchable property show that the proposed reflective cross polarizer is an excellent candidate for manipulation and control of polarization in THz communication systems.

Achieving efficient and large bandwidth optical coupling in grating couplers is a long-standing problem. Unlike optimizing the coupling efficiency and bandwidth merely at single wavelength, we introduce an approach with a more global perspective, namely a multi-wavelength matching method that considers both effective index matching and leakage factor matching simultaneously, which greatly improves the coupling efficiency and bandwidth of the grating couplers at multiple wavelengths.

A tunable continuum with multiwatt output power is demonstrated for the first time through the pumping of cascaded fibers by using a continuous-wave (CW) ytterbium fiber laser. The central wavelength of the output continuum can be tuned continuously and monotonically by varying input pump power, with a wide wavelength-tunable range from 1.2 to 1.4 μm and a 3-dB bandwidth of tens of nanometers. Two configurations of the cascaded fibers both display the power-dependent wavelength tunability. The output spectral characteristics are presented, and the generation of the CW-pumped tunable continuum is tentatively attributed to the seed-dependent Raman amplification.
ieee_keywords: ['Optical fiber polarization', 'Laser excitation', 'Optical fiber dispersion', 'Optical fiber communication', 'Fiber lasers', 'Quantum cascade lasers']
author_keywords: ['Wavelength-tunable optical source', 'supercontinuum (SC)', 'photonic crystal fiber (PCF)', 'stimulated Raman scattering (SRS)']

abstracts: Presents corrections to affiiation information in the above named paper.

Presents corrections to the paper, "Investigation on the stability of WSe2-PVA saturable absorber in an all PM Q-Switched fiber laser", (Guo, C.), IEEE Photon. J., vol. 8, no. 5, Oct. 2016, Art. no. 1503612. Vol. 8, No. 6, December 2016.
ieee_keywords: ['Laser stability', 'Optical fiber networks', 'Optical fiber polarization', 'Fiber lasers', 'Chaotic communication']

abstracts: Presents corrections to the paper, “Characterization of Hybrid InP-TriPleX photonic integrated tunable lasers based on silicon nitride (Si3N4/SiO2) microring resonators for optical coherent system,” (Lin, Y., et al), IEEE Photon. J., vol. 10, no. 3, Jun. 2018, Art. no. 1400108.
Presents corrections to byline information for the above named paper.

Breakthroughs in Photonics is a Special Issue of the IEEE Photonics Journal that brings a compilation of short reviews describing significant accomplishments in selected areas of Photonics within the last year. Breakthroughs in Photonics 2012 contains 14 invited comprehensive, refereed reviews written by experts that cover progress in the areas of Coherent Photon Sources; Photonics materials and engineered photonic structures; Ultrafast, attosecond, high field, and short wavelength photonics; Nano-photonics; Photovoltaics; Biophotonics; Sensors; Imaging and Visualization; Integrated Photonic Systems; and Quantum Computing. The selection of the topics and invited contributions is carried out by the IEEE Photonics Journal Editorial Board. The articles in this focus issue highlight the increasingly dominant role of photonics in unraveling fundamental science and, at the same time, enabling applications in, for example, sensing and visualization, nanofabrication, photovoltaics, fiber optics, and quantum photonics. The adoption of article numbers versus page numbers by the IEEE Photonics Journal in 2013 enables, for the first time, publication of each article from Breakthroughs in Photonics 2012 independently in IEEE Xplore, providing more visibility to authors and enhanced readership.
The five papers in this special issue cover the various approaches to achieving optical non-reciprocity on a chip.

Summary form only given, as follows. Breakthroughs in Photonics is a Special Issue of the IEEE PHOTONICS JOURNAL that contains a compilation of short reviews describing significant accomplishments in selected areas of Photonics within the last year. Breakthroughs in Photonics 2011 is comprised of 19 invited comprehensive refereed reviews written by experts that cover progress in the following areas: Coherent Photon Sources, Photonics Materials and Engineered Photonic Structures, Nanophotonics, Biophotonics, Silicon Photonics, Solid-State Lighting, Photovoltaics, Sensors, Imaging and Visualization, and Integrated Photonic Systems. The selection of the topics that make up the Special Issue lies entirely with the Editorial Board of IEEE PHOTONICS JOURNAL. In a process that starts in December, the team identifies topics and experts in key areas of Photonics that mirror the scope of the JOURNAL. With the support of the editorial staff and the editorial office, Breakthroughs in Photonics is published online Open Access annually every April. As a prelude to changes that are about to be implemented, I take this opportunity to announce that starting July 2012, IEEE PHOTONICS JOURNAL is moving to an Bopen access[ publication model. Open access capabilities, coupled with an average time of 5 weeks from submission to online publishing, will provide authors with enhanced visibility and a much wider readership of their published articles. I am grateful to the authors, the IEEE PHOTONICS JOURNAL editorial board and editorial staff, and IEEE Publications for their invaluable contributions to Breakthroughs in Photonics 2011.

The articles in this special section brings a compilation of short reviews describing recent advances in selected areas of Photonics.Breakthroughs in Photonics 2014 contains 11 invited comprehensive reviews written by experts that cover progress in the areas of Photon sources from far infrared to x-rays; Photonics materials and engineered photonic structures; Nano-photonics; Ultrafast, attosecond, high field, and short wavelength photonics; Imaging and Visualization; and Optical communications technologies.

Pixel isolation in monolithic GaN micro-light emitting diode displays is a common issue. One method of pixel isolation is to etch down to the insulating substrate. In high pixel density devices, it is difficult to bridge these high aspect ratio trenches with interconnects. Here we present an efficient method of planarizing high aspect ratio isolation trenches with a hard baked, inert photoresist layer, allowing for interconnect formation on a smooth, continuous surface, solving this issue.

I submit a correction file for a previously submitted paper. The original paper demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally the model of double-clad Yb doped fiber amplifier under CW and pulsed operations. This model solved the propagation equations of Yb doped fiber and the coupled nonlinear Schrodinger equations simultaneously to show any distortion that might occur inside the fiber.

Breakthroughs in Photonics is intended to highlight major accomplishments across the broad spectrum of Photonics Science and Technology within the year. This Special Section is also intended to draw the attention of readers and authors to the topics that are within the scope of the journal. Breakthroughs in Photonics 2009 contains 17 invited peer-reviewed briefs written by worldrenowned experts. These briefs cover progress in the areas of Coherent Photon Sources, Ultrafast Photonics, Nonlinear Photonics, Terahertz Photonics, Nano-Photonics, Silicon Photonics, Bio-Photonics, Magneto-Photonics, Photonic Materials and Engineered Nanostructures, Photovoltaics and Sensors, and Integrated Photonics Systems. These selected topics represent a subset of the much broader and intense activity in the generation, control, and utilization of radiation that takes place worldwide.

The papers in this special section focus on progress in photonic spin-order interaction (SOI). Spin and orbital angular momenta (SAM and OAM) are two distinct components of light beams. The SAM is associated with polarization of the light, whereas the OAM is related to a helical wave front, which has an azimuthal dependence of phase and can be described by a topological charge. These two different forms of AM are independent of each other within the boundaries of paraxial propagation in space. However, they become intertwined when the light beam is traveling through inhomogeneous and anisotropic media, or is tightly focused beyond the paraxial condition, leading to the photonic SOI. The photonic SOI underpins many optical processes, thus playing a significant role in the modern optics. The photonic SOI has led to such intriguing optical phenomena, as photonic spin Hall effect, orbit Hall effect, spin-orbit Hall effect, optical Skyrmion, and interconversions between the spin and the orbital terms, among others. Importantly, the photonic SOI also holds promise for potential applications in nanophotonic devices, quantum information processing, precise metrology, and optical (including quantum) sensing.
ieee_keywords: ['Special issues and sections', 'Photonics', 'Optical polarization', 'Hall effect', 'Adaptive optics', 'Micromagnetics', 'Geometrical optics']

abstracts: The Photonics in Switching Conference was held in Florence, Italy, in September 2015. The Conference was exciting, with a large number of original works invited and presented. The Convitto della Calza cloister stimulated many fruitful discussions carried out, even when walking towards social events inside the extraordinary context of the city of Florence, with its rich history, art, and culture. All the attendees enjoyed a traditional collegial atmosphere of the Photonics in Switching Conference. Although this special section is not a proceeding of the conference, the idea for a Special Issue on this topic was devised in the program committee. The role of photonic technologies and techniques has grown in the past few decades within the optical networks scenario. At the same time, system and subsystem innovative solutions, together with novel network segments and architectures, represent the building blocks in the Internet of Things era: communication and connection everywhere, any time, at high quality, low cost, low power consumption, and low environmental impact. This is the ambition of the Photonics in Switching Conference, and this Special Section is evidence of the strong efforts that the scientific community has made in the field.

This paper illustrates the combination of the classic static VAr compensator and the dynamic compensator into a hybrid compensator topology. An overall control procedure for the hybrid compensator is proposed and a novel technique for the control of the dynamic compensator is also proposed and illustrated through computer simulation and experiment. Operating results of the experimental hybrid power compensator is presented.

Educational thinking in higher education has undergone a rapid change. The ability to remember facts loses importance whereas the capability to solve problems becomes more and more the main focus of teaching. At the Technikum Wien Project Based Learning (PBL) was introduced in various subjects of our IT course. The basic approach of PBL originated from the University of Maastricht in the Netherlands where it is reported to be highly successful [1-4]. The specific problem the authors tried to solve, deals with the motivation of students. The main motivation of students is -of course to achieve good test results and only the lesser focus lies on the specific contents of the subject. The authors tried to develop a method, which allows the students to focus their intrinsic motivation onto the study project itself and not onto the extrinsic motivation, namely test results.

Mr. President and gentlemen, I feel it an honour to be called upon, as a mere stranger, to read a paper before members of this Institute. I have only been in the country about three months, and already I have been given an opportunity of addressing you — as I say, I consider it an honour. As this paper has been written, or rather these tests taken and graphs drawn, at very short notice, I hope you will excuse its obvious deficiencies. I can hardly call it a paper, as I only propose to show some graphs drawn from test figures taken during the last three weeks, and point out their chief characteristics.

This paper describes the computer-aided design and evaluation of a 1 000 kV resistive impulse voltage divider intended for operation at an altitude of 1 425 m. Measurement errors are assessed at low voltage by comparison with a commercial high-voltage probe (ratio 1 000: 1, bandwidth 75 MHz). It is shown that the divider can acceptably measure non-standard full lightning impulses with front times as short as 0.5 μs and front-chopped impulses with chopping times down to 0.5 μs.

Power for generation of high frequency magnetic fields (in for example industrial heating applications) is usually generated using valve oscillators. During recent years high frequency devices notably MOSFET's and SIT's have found application in the 100 kHz to 1 MHz frequency band. Various circuit configurations can be used [1] with some converters such as the class E amplifier [2] being able to function in tbe low MHz range, though it seems that for power application larger than 1 kVA the series resonant converter fed by a voltage source inverter (SRV inverter) and the parallel resonant circuit fed by a current source inverter (PRI inverter) are the major contenders.

The above Engineering Unit has been formed to provide part-time military training for those Engineers and tradesmen who are engaged on essential work and, therefore, cannot be released for full-time service in the field.

While the 1881 International Electrical Congress was of importance to the electrical world, the result of a later one, held at St Louis, USA in 1904, cannot be underestimated. As part of the Congress, on Tuesday, 13th September, 1904, a meeting of the Chamber of Government Delegates to the International Electrical Congress met at the Hotel Jefferson. Two committees were set up to examine international electromagnetic units and international standardization. The following day, once again at the Hotel Jefferson, a further meeting of the Chamber of Delegates was held to receive the reports from these committees.

It was in London, on 26th June 1906, that the preliminary meeting of the IEC was held. Thirty-three delegates from 14 countries were present to discuss the proposed Rules for the Commission which ‘endeavoured to place every country on an absolutely equal footing, to accord each country perfect freedom to arrange the affairs of their respective Local Committees and also to keep the Constitution of the Commission as simple as possible’. The IEC's first Sub-Committee was then formed, with one representative from each country as members, to study the proposed Rules and report back to the Commission the following day.

The year 1981 marks several important anniversaries for the electrical world — the 150th anniversary of Michael Faraday's discovery of electromagnetic induction on 29th August 1831; the centenary of the world's first International Electrical Congress in Paris in 1881 where the first inter-national agreement was reached on electrical units; and the 75th anniversary of the constitutive meeting of the IEC in London. The IEC Bulletin, in this special anniversary issue, pays tribute to Faraday, reports on that important 1881 International Electrical Congress, and describes the initial steps taken by the world's leading electrical engineers of the time in founding the IEC.

More than ten years ago the SAIEE launched a project to adapt its publications to the requirements of its membership. This resulted in the previous Transactions (prior to 1986) being split into two publications, i.e. “Elektron” and the Transactions of the SAIEE. In keeping with current international tendencies, the “Transactions” was then planned as publishing current research and development activities, subject to international peer review. An international editorial panel of associate editors was set up, and in January 1985 the first issue of this new style publication of the SAIEE saw the light (vol. 76, No. 1).

This paper describes a typical experiment performed by 3rd-year electrical engineering students at the University of Stellenbosch. The experiment takes 6 weeks to complete. It is shown that with a high crossover frequency of the drive system open-loop transfer function, and a current-loop that is much faster than the speed-loop, it is possible to use simplified s-domain motor transfer functions to design both the current-loop and speed-loop controllers. The simplifications allow students to concentrate on the task of designing the controllers without being distracted by unnecessary mathematical analysis. Experimental results show that satisfactory drive dynamic behaviour can be achieved despite these simplifications. During the testing of the current-loop performance, students get to appreciate the importance of the current controller as a protective feature.

SF 6 Gas insulated switchgear installations for modern pager plants cause minimum disturbance to the landscape, and easy maintenance access increases availability of the installations. This paper describes an installation with new design concepts using SF 6 GIS busbars in vertical shafts.

The present paper describes the conception and design of a 12 kW/ 250 KHz series resonant converter for induction heating applications. The developed generator works above resonance in a continuous conduction mode in order to avoid the problem associated with the reverse recovery current of the MOSFETS's antiparallel diodes. Both short circuit protection of the inverter and the real output resonant circuit are described.

R. R. GILMOUR (Associate Member) (contributed): I was surprised to learn of a grid system and, moreover, one operating at as high a voltage as 66 kV, in Northern Rhodesia. Mr Douglas has, therefore, revealed not only electrical progress in this territory but also, consequently, apparent major general development.
The paper describes the interconnection of the four power stations supplying the mines in the copperbelt of Northern Rhodesia.

Computer laboratories used in engineering education are investigated by considering the requirements, constraints and infrastructures involved. Three primary requirements are identified: to provide access and connectivity, to support the teaching and learning process and to provide assessment facilities. The use of fat client and thin-client infrastructures in engineering education is discussed using two computet laboratories at Wits University as a case study.

I, Jacobus Petrus Roux the sixth, am the son of Jacobus Petrus Roux, the fifth. We are direct descendants of that brave and talented and outstanding French Huguenot Paul Roux, he is the great, great, great, forefather of all the early Rouxs' in South Africa. This marvellous French Huguenot and his party of French speaking Huguenots left the town of Orange after they had fled from France in 1688. Paul Roux, the first, in South Africa was Teacher, Doctor and Church Minister for this first group of French speaking Huguenots. He had seven children and made the earnest request that in each generation at least one son must be named after him, namely Paul. This reasonable request was carried out faithfully and consequently, my son, Dr Paul Roux, is Paul Roux the tenth, i.e. ten generations from the first Paul Roux our great and gifted leader of 1688.

With Web-based open and distance learning students can study and train when and where they want - even from home. Based on a database, CORBA middleware and Web frontend, we have implemented an interactive database and CORBA tutorial to allow for efficient, interactive student training. Our system also supports the testing of the student's application in a distributed environment together with a real-life database. Students can concentrate on their main tasks and need not waste time and effort learning to use complicated tools and configuring environments. Consequently, they grow familiar with complex e-commerce technologies in a convenient way.

The piper outlines the basic mechanisms of switching surge generation when switching inductive toads, and emphasises the importance of a full understanding of the transient interactions amongst the relevant system parameters. The need for wave-shaping principles of surge suppression, rather than overvoltage limitation, it demonstrated with particular emphasis upon the advantages of resistively damped surge capacitors. A co-ordinated approach illustrating a method for arriving at optimised solutions to surge suppression problems is also briefly described.

The address deals with some aspects of the distribution of electricity in urban areas, with a bias towards Municipal Electricity Undertakings in South Africa and, in certain particular respects, relating to that of the Durban City Council.

At the outset, let me express my appreciation to the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers and the University of the Witwatersrand for inviting me to read a paper on radio telephony to-night, on this memorable occasion.

A simple cascade synthesis procedure for the exact synthesis of lossless distributed microwave filters with Darlington type A, B and C sections and unit elements is presented.

As for flying or a possible visit to the moon, anyone with such ideas would have been a fit patient in a mental asylum.

This paper presents a technique for technique for power system stabilisation using Power System Stabilisers (PSS). The method encompasses the main problems associated with the use of PSS. Three problems are addressed, namely the optimal locations of the PSS, the most effective signal for stabilisation and the determination of values of the PSS parameters. Novel concepts such as exciter penalty factors, modified coupling factors and power system decentralised fixed modes are presented. The method is implemented on a benchmark network and the results are presented.
ieee_keywords: ['Power system stability', 'Couplings', 'Mathematical model', 'Stability analysis', 'Generators', 'Power system dynamics', 'Numerical stability']

abstracts: The majority of papers on code synchronization loop design for DSSS communication systems concentrate on noncoherent schemes employing binary spreading sequences. These loop structures comprise early and late arm structures with squaring devices which are very prone to arm imbalance effects. In this paper a combined coherent carrier recovery and Decision-Directed Delay-Lock-Loop (DD-DLL) synchronization scheme for a DSSS communication system is proposed. The novelty of the technique lies in the fact that it extends the structure proposed by de Gaudenzi et al [1] to enable synchronisation of systems employing both binary and complex spreading sequences. Typical advantages include features such as less sensitivity to arm imbalance problems due to the elimination of squaring devices, improved tracking capability and simplified hardware by requiring only two correlators in stead of four in the DLL structure. The simplified loop structures is the direct result of the novel use of difference signals in both the spreading, demodulation/despreading and DLL processes, leading to the elimination of unwanted cross product interference terms when employing complex spreading sequences. The loop response is analysed analytically and its performance verified through computer simulation in the presence of AWGN and typical non-stationary channel effects, employing both binary as well as a relatively new family of complex Linearly and Non-Linearly Root-of-Unity (L- and NL-RU) filtered spreading sequences, including a recen tly introduced subclass of Analytical Bandlimited Complex (ABC) spreading sequences [2].

For a single-input controllable system the solution of the pole-placement problem, (using a linear feedback combination of state variables), results in a unique set of feedback-weighting coefficients. These coefficients may be calculated by a number of methods including matrix trace techniques. For multi-input systems there are a theoretically infinite number of combinations of feedback coefficients that satisfy the pole-placement condition. In practice, the choice is much more limited if the feedback coefficients are to be of acceptable magnitudes; thus there is a need for constraining the problem so that a practical design is produced. A semi-systematic way of achieving this goal is via the dyadic method [1] in which the feedback matrix is a product of two dyads. If the value of one of these dyads is specified, this is tantamount to assigning a weighting on each of the inputs, then the other may be found systematically by way of a “fictitious” single-input system model. This paper uses the dyadic method, in combination with matrix-trace techniques, to design feedback systems for the longitudinal flight dynamics of a helicopter, an observer for a single-input system (observer design is usually a multi-input problem), and to achieve both zero- and pole-placement for a particular, restricted class of system.

A horn antenna that is designed as a match between a rectangular metal waveguide and free space is described. The antenna has a very low return loss and low sidelobes. The design is based on the taper described by Hecken.

This paper describes a novel balanced transmission line antenna where the maximum separation between the two conductors is only a fraction of a wavelength at the lowest operating frequency. The balanced transmission line is formed by exponentially extending the ridges of a double-ridged waveguide. The poor VSWR and patterns caused by reflections from the tips of the ridge extensions are improved by a combination of aperture matching and the use of microwave absorber. Measured VSWR, radiation pattern and gain data are presented for this compact, broadband antenna over the 2 to 11 GHz frequency range.
ieee_keywords: ['Broadband antennas', 'Ions', 'Transmission line antennas', 'Power transmission lines', 'Conductors', 'Broadband communication', 'Aperture antennas']

A review of redundancy techniques including error control coding, triple modular redundancy and standby spiring is presented, and the improvement in system reliability obtainable for each technique it evaluated.

A review of redundancy techniques including error control coding, triple modular redundancy and standby spiring is presented, and the improvement in system reliability obtainable for each technique it evaluated.

(Member) : The thanks of the members are due to Mr. Renner for putting so much information, which must have involved a large amount of time and trouble, at their disposal. Mr. Heather has remarked that at the present juncture facts are what are called for rather than the estimates on which the paper is based, but it would appear that for the purpose of drawing a useful and illuminating comparison between the two systems of winding the judicious use of assumptions based on such facts making the comparative performances clearer, in the manner adopted by the author, is of great value.

Professor W. Buchanan (Member) : The present paper reminds one of the many discussions that took place some 15 to 20 years ago regarding the relative merits of alternating and direct current supply for town lighting, but it must now be admitted that considerable success has been attained with both systems. Since both the Ward-Leonard and the Three-Phase systems of winding seem to contain the elements necessary for success, the present controversy regarding their relative merits will no doubt reach a perfectly satisfactory conclusion. Although we may agree that it is preferable to use electricity instead of steam for all winding plants, it is very improbable that any one electric system will give the most economical results under all working conditions, — each case must be considered as a special problem, maximum economy being obtainable only by a careful study of the particular features and details of each system.

(Member) : Mr. Renner's paper deals with a problem of the greatest importance, in which many of us are most keenly interested. It must be expected, therefore, that the paper will lead to an extended discussion, and it is to be hoped that this discussion will be of great practical value to all those who are dealing with the problem in question. We have to thank the author for his task in gathering together such a large amount of valuable information based on facts and figures found in actual practice. Unfortunately, I was prevented from being present at the last meeting, and the paper only came to hand yesterday. Naturally, I have had no time to look into the paper in detail, and I cannot, therefore, express any opinion on the figures given to-night.

The author assumes that members are already acquainted with the essential features of the Ward-Leonard and Three-Phase systems, and this paper is, therefore, confined mainly to a comparison of costs. The great advantages of the Ward-Leonard system, particularly safety and ease of control, are well-known and generally admitted, but the opponents of the system frequently consider its apparently high first cost prohibitive. The author proposes to show that even granting that the first cost is higher than for the Three-Phase system, in very many cases this is largely counterbalanced by the difference in working costs It would, of course, be impossible m a short paper such as this to institute comparisons between all possible cases, and the author is well aware that in many instances the working costs of the Three-Phase may be as low as those of the Ward-Leonard system but he is of opinion that in the majority of cases, and more particularly where hoists are installed for winding from deep shafts and at high speed, the determining factor must be by all means that of safety and not of cost, although the author holds that the latter are more favourable with the Ward-Leonard, as will be proved to you later on. It will no doubt be possible to so improve the Three-Phase control as to make the system as safe as the Ward-Leonard, but a comparison of executed examples of each undoubtedly points to the superiority of the latter m this respect.

(Member) : In introducing this reply to the discussion on my paper, I find it necessary to emphasise some of my original remarks, because I observe that some of them have been misunderstood. I cannot lay too great stress on the fact that, for the purposes of fair comparison, the two systems were considered with reference to a modern well-equipped winding installation, shaft and underground arrangements working under economical conditions, such as, in my opinion, may reasonably be considered attainable. In my reply to Mr. Ewing's contribution to the discussion, I have endeavoured to shew how, in the far simpler case of the cylindrical drum tail rope winders cited by him, departures from the assumed economical conditions affect the situation.

Power amplifiers have long been very important pieces of apparatus, but as long as the distortion introduced by primary and terminal apparatus such as microphones and loudspeakers has been considerable, it was pointless to devise amplifiers which were entirely free of distortion. However, in recent years with the advent of very high-grade microphone and improved loudspeakers, the demand for better power amplifiers has increased.

In the article the processes in a generic single pulse high frequency resonant converter is discussed and investigated The detailed mathematical and computational analysis is carried out and it is compared with experimental results. A good agreement between theory and experiment is observed for all modes of the converter operation, illustrating that this type of converter can be analysed without recourse to extensive numerical computer network simulation packages.

The development and operation of an algorithm for computer-aided diagnosis of lung cancer is described. The algorithm uses a tunable difference of averages edge detector and a template matching procedure in its operation of lung cancer nodule detection. Feature extraction is performed on the resulting correlation surface and suspected nodule sites are encircled in the final stage. Preliminary results of this detection scheme are included.

This paper describes the basic principles concerned in the design of an airborne line scanning system, together with a method of theoretically evaluating system performance. It also describes a computer software model that was constructed for the calculation of scanner performance parameters. This model was validated by comparing its predictions with the manufacturer specifications for a number of commercially available scanners. 6 Summary and conclusions The operation of a basic line scanner has been described and its performance characteristics derived from Planck's radiation law and electro-optical principles. A computer model was constructed to calculate performance parameters from component and system specifications. This model accurately predicts scanner performance in that calculated NETD's agree well with those provided by manufacturers.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Detectors', 'Computational modeling', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Optical detectors', 'Stimulated emission', 'Software']

abstracts: Asymptotic tracking of setpoints in Internal Model Control (IMC) structures is ensured by imposing a set of criteria based on derivatives of the transfer function [1-q(s)g(s)] when designing the IMC module q(s). Simpler algebraic constraints on the numerator polynomial of q(s) that give a particular Type Number for the final IMC system are developed here. An application to the design of feedback controllers for a servo motor demonstrates that the proposed algebraic constraints produce asymptotic setpoint tracking, and that the IMC performance is not sensitive to modelling accuracy.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Transfer functions', 'Tracking loops', 'Stability criteria', 'Design methodology', 'Asymptotic stability', 'Process control']

abstracts: This paper deals with two fairly distinct aspects of the mercury-are rectifier, namely (a) methods of connecting it to the A.C. supply, and (b) methods of controlling its D.C. output by means of grids; and it may be felt that there is little relation between these two subjects. However, in order to be able to understand the second section, some knowledge of the first is required and it is partly because of this that it is included in the paper.

Recent research, both experimental and mathematical, has shown that arc phenomena are considerably more complicated than was previously thought to ho the case. The advent of the high speed cathode ray oscillograph has brought to light much useful data on the subject of arcs in their relation to arcing in circuit breakers. The most recent researches on the general subject of arc extinction and reignition (in the case of the a.c. arc) has emphasised the lack of and need of more information concerning the conditions existing in an a.c. are during the interval of current zero. In particular, experimental data is required on the problem of the rate of rise of arc voltage after the current zero to a value which produces reignition of the arc and the flow of current in the reverse direction.
A knowledge of the characteristics of the ionosphere is of both scientific and commercial value.

This paper examines the more important factors which have influenced the design of telephones and internal switching systems. Present-day trends in design, as determined by these factors, are given consideration and possible future developments in this field are indicated. Details of actual design are not treated exhaustively but some examples are quoted for the purpose of illustration.

It is only when a particular type of equipment starts giving excessive trouble that its importance to the community becomes apparent. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the case of electric cables — normally taken for granted by the average engineer and quite certainly to be buried and forgotten. However, when cables start failing in the early hours of the morning, disrupt important services and disturb the peace of the supply authority, then their importance is appreciated. We, in South Africa, had this brought home to us in no uncertain manner when there was an epidemic of troubles, experienced on 11-kV cables in particular, which gave rise to many learned dissertations and theories propounded in club, committee and consulting rooms and a loss of sleep to many engineers. Catch words and phrases such as ‘surges,’ ‘altitude derating,’ ‘aspiration,’ ‘inferior cable manufacture’ and ‘careless installation and workmanship’ became the order of the day.

A digital system simulator is described which hat been designed to execute on a minicomputer with limited memory capacity. It is interactive, fast in execution, and capable of modelling networks comprising many hundreds of logic elements. The language used for the symbolic representation of the network is defined in terms with which the digital systems design engineer is familiar. The system has facilities for comparing the logical states derived by simulation with those occurring in the hardware implemented system. This feature permits automatic fault diagnosis to be performed on constructed hardware.

It is interactive, fast in execution, and capable of modelling networks comprising many hundreds of logic elements.
