The paper presents the results of the original analytical and experimental work carried out on a new form of drive for electric locomotives. The drive, incorporating two motors and a differential gear, is being developed initially for use in mining trolley locomotives, for which application it is compared with the conventional series locomotive, and its special features are noted.

The problem of determining the torque-speed curve of an induction motor is discussed and a digital method is described. Torque-speed curves using three different methods are compared. Improvements to the digital instrument are suggested.

This paper describes the arithmetic section of a digital correlator, which is used in conjunction with a mini-computer to perform real time spectral analysis of radio astronomy spectral line signals, having bandwidths of up to 5, 12 MHz. The radio astronomy signals are both noiselike and deeply buried in noise, much of which is contributed by the receiving system. The correlator employs 1 024 identical ‘channels’ to calculate correlation coefficients for 1 024 different values of delay. Each channel is capable of performing a multiplication and addition every 97,6 ns. The input signal is coarsely quantized into three levels (–1, 0 or + 1) in order to simplify the correlator circuitry at the expense of signal to noise ratio. By varying the clock rate, spectral bandwidths from 40 kHz to 5, 12 MHz may be analysed. The instrument may be used as a single 1 024 channel, dual 512 channel or quad 256 channel correlator. Both auto-correlation and cross-correlation may be performed on up to four signals or pairs of signals. After Fourier transformation of the correlation function, in the mini-computer, a power spectrum or cross-power spectrum is obtained, At present 256 channels are in operation. Results of observation of the formaldehyde absorption spectral line are presented.

The provision of variable frequency and voltage from a fixed frequency and constant voltage supply by the combination of two solid state switching converters is described. No intermediate dc link is employed and it is shown that the output voltage and supply currents contain no harmonic components below 300 Hz in a 6-step system. The converters are force-commutated and bi-directional and therefore capable of direct regeneration to the supply. Frequency is continuously variable from zero to a value which is only limited by the switch and motor losses. The results of a numerical analysis performed on a 3,5 kW, 3-phase induction motor when fed from the output of this converter, are described. It appears that the energy stored in the leakage reactance is usefully added to the output of the machine during the ‘free wheel’ period when the phases are commutated to produce a frequency change.

Neither software engineering nor software design qualifies as a discipline, but software architecture might. Action-centered design is proposed as the means to build software architecture by joining the two.

A unique feature of DS-CDMA cellular networks is its universal frequency re-use concept In other words, neighbouring cells operate on the same frequency channels. Because of this universal frequency re-use concept, the admission of a user into the network affects the level of communication quality of all the other users. Call admission control then becomes critical and a new user will be accepted only if the additional interference that it creates does not degrade the overall communications quality of the already admitted users beyond some acceptable level. Most of the call admission control schemes that have been analysed in the literature are centralised in nature and there has not been much work done on distributed or decentralised schemes. This paper proposes a distributed call admission control protocol for DS-CDMA cellular networks. In this distributed scheme, channel access decisions are made by the mobiles based on information broadcast from the base stations. This is different from the access strategies that have appeared in the literature where call requests are processed solely by the base stations. Teletraffic performance measures that are considered are the probability of blocking calls, probability of forced termination, grade of service and outage.

In spread spectrum data transmission systems employing pseudo-random type signals and microprocessor realizations. FFT techniques are indicated for computational economy. This offers the possibility of combining the functions of channel equalization and character recognition. This study concentrated on the aspect of channel equalization as representative of most of the functions required in a fully fledged system. The results indicate that (I) even if only equalization is considered, the use of a bit slice processor supported by a fast hardware multiplier is imperative; (2) such a processor could alternatively provide a weighted DFT output instead of a filtered time sequence to that the subsequent processor may affect character recognition without reprocessing the filtered time sequence and (3) for the particular processor considered time domain filtering is about twice as fast as frequency domain filtering.

In the first instance I am dealing with R. Waygood ∧ Co.'s electrically-operated passenger lift. The large diagram, which is reproduced, shows the electrical equipment and connections for a dual control lift—that is, a lift that can be operated either by a pilot in the car, or by throwing over a switch can be operated from the floors or from the car by push buttons. The motor is 12 h.p. D.C. shunt wound, and runs at either 755 or 410 revolutions per minute ; the driving is effected by a winding drum, this method being used on account of there being no slip, and so the positive automatic cut-off can be adjusted to stop the cage at the various floors without any difficulty.
On the visit of this Institute to Kimberley during July the statistics now printed were presented at the Congress of the South African Association for the Advancement of Science.

The object of this paper is to outline the work done by the Telecommunications Research Laboratory of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, in establishing a frequency prediction service for Southern Africa for HF (high frequency) radio communication.

An application of fuzzy logic in controlling the speed of a dc machine drive (DCM) is proposed. The control system relies on cascaded speed and voltage control loops. The inner fuzzy logic phase-locked loop for voltage control operates without detecting the line voltage. The outer speed control loop is based on a fuzzy logic controller. A rule-based algorithm speeds the start-up performance. Simulation of the entire system is performed on computer and the results show good dynamic and steady-state behaviors.
author_keywords: ['Fuzzy Logic Control', 'DC Machine Drive', 'Phase-Locked Loop', 'Three Phase Rectifier Bridge']

abstracts: Recent research has shown that curvilinear Yagi-Uda antennas are able to improve on the performance of linear Yagi-Uda antennas. This study used published tables to design a three element gain-optimized Yagi-Uda. The design was simulated numerically using NEC2, then built and measured. Both the numerical and experimental results confirmed the claims made regarding superior performance and indicate that this new type of curvilinear antenna has potentially important practical applications in communications engineering in the VHF and UHF frequency bands — typical TV frequencies.

The paper is a general description of the Orlando Power Station which came into operation, to a limited extent, in January, 1942. The paper also includes some details of operating results and costs for the year ended 30th June, 1944. Before pro ceeding with the paper proper it may be of interest to touch briefly on the factors leading up to the necessity of, and the preliminaries for, the construction of the Orlando Station.
A genetic algorithm is used as the basis for a new impedance matching algorithm. The new algorithm obtains similar results to published techniques in most cases despite not requiring transformers.

The essence of noise control is suppression at the source, and the problem of noise abatement should be approached with this object in mind. However, this is unfortunately not always possible, and the solution to a noise problem requires a knowledge and understanding of noise propagation and transmission as well as of its basic nature and the subjective effect on the ear of the listener.

This paper discusses the operation in parallel of two alternators driven in tandem. The set is installed in the Brak-pan station of The Victoria Falls amp; Transvaal Power Company, Limited, where one single cylinder type turbine, capable of developing a continuous maximum output of 20,000 kw. and a most economical output of 16,000 kw. when running at a normal speed of 3,000 r.p.m. is directly coupled to a 20,000 kVA generator known as the “A” unit, and coupled to the latter is another 20,000 kVA generator designated the “B” unit. Beyond the “B” unit and driven on the same shaft are two compound wound exciters, one for the “B,” the other for the “A” unit. The total overall length of the set from the extreme end of the turbine to the sole-plate at the exciter end is 63 feet 8 12 inches, and the average width across the sole-plate of a generator is approximately 12 feet. The first two photographs show views of the set in the engine room at the Brakpan Power Station.
As requested by the President at the Annual Banquet, the following reminiscences and anecdotes have been received from Golden Anniversary Members and are printed herewith.

In this paper a two dimensional hybrid coder is presented. The coder has performance comparable to that of the Discrete Cosine Transform while using a reduced blocksize for transformation. This makes it especially suitable for real time implementation. The discussion closes with the results from objective and subjective evaluations of the algorithm.

A description and explanation is given of an electronic device which indicates the presence of lightning within some 20 miles and which gives anticipatory warning of imminent flashes in the near vicinity.

Results of rain-attenuation prediction on earth-satellite paths in the USA, utilizing a rain-rate model based on southern African extreme rain-rate data, are presented. The model, based on Lin's extreme-value theory, was used to provide 5-minute rain-rate distributions. These were then used in an existing attenuation model to provide the attenuation distributions for a total of 16 earth-space paths, at frequencies of 11 to 29 GHz. Good agreement with the experimental distributions is obtained over a range of climates. These results, together with earlier results obtained with the prediction of 5-min rain-rate distributions in the USA, have brought about a high degree of confidence in the method for rain-attenuation prediction. The method should be useful, not only for the continental USA, but also for southern Africa. The method is easy to use. The rain-rate model requires only the mean annual rainfall and a designation of the location as climatically coastal or inland.

The author wishes to thank those who contributed to the discussion on the broken-conductor problem at road crossings by overhead transmission lines. The deficiencies in his method of arriving at the sag under broken conductor condition are fully appreciated and were, in fact, detailed fairly fully in the paper. It is maintained, however, that the formula described gives a quick and ready means of checking whether sufficient clearance is obtained provided the user is aware of its limitations. It should not be overlooked that calculations of this nature are usually made for the maximum designed working temperature of the conductor whereas, it may be reasonably assumed, the line will trip out on a break occurring and the resulting cooling off of the conductor will cause it to lift by an amount which in most cases more than compensates for the optimistic result obtained with the formula.

In this paper a basic mode! for the cumulative probability distribution of the k-factor, commonly used in radio propagation studies for communications, is proposed. Available South African and Namibian data is used to test the model. Further investigation using regression analysis results in a set of coefficients, which could be used to predict the cumulative probability for various values of the k-factor in South Africa. It is clear from the analyses that there may be climatic factors, which must still be incorporated in the proposed model in a statistical manner. Although the available data is limited in terms of the numbers of observational sites, the proposed model suggests that it may be possible to make significantly better predictions of the k-factor than the simplistic 4/3rds earth approach, and thus to extend the limited coverage of the available observations

An efficient algorithm for determining the local oscillator waveforms of a diode mixer is described. Provision is made for an exponential diode with non-linear barrier capacitance embedded in a linear network of arbitrary complexity.

This paper examines the problem of designing an underground mine so as to optimise the development and haulage costs. It focusses particularly on the costs associated with the ramps and shafts which provide passage to and from the ore zones. This mine optimisation problem is modelled as a weighted network. The controls (variables for the optimisation process) and operational constraints are described. A main constraint in mining networks is that all ramps have gradients no more than a given maximum value m. In this paper we describe the mine design problem as an optimisation problem, and prove that under reasonable conditions the cost function of an underground mining network with maximum gradient constraint m is convex. The convexity of the objective function ensures the existence of minimum cost mining networks, and theoretically any descent algorithms for finding minimal points can be applied to the design of minimum cost mining networks.

A new modelling method for copper losses in magnetic circuits is presented. The analytically based two dimensional technique is capable of analysing and optimising the winding design all magnetic components used in present day power converters. A key feature is that the method, since it uses analytical equations, requires less computing power and can be implemented on smaller desk top computers. Predictions on the frequency dependent resistance of coils are compared to measured values and predictions by the classic equations of Butterworth.

A new set of criteria to compare rival converter topologies on a scientific basis are introduced. Power transmission effectivity of components is addressed which compares the power handling capability of components against the active power delivered by the converter. This method of rating is then applied to some single switch topologies as used in induction heating, involving a detailed modelling which includes time domain simulation, analytical modelling and experimental verification.
ieee_keywords: ['Topology', 'Switches', 'Insulated gate bipolar transistors', 'Integrated circuit modeling', 'Analytical models', 'Inductors', 'Capacitors']

abstracts: The object of this paper is to introduce a new and simple method of constructing the circle diagram, from data which can usually be easily obtained, viz., the maximum power factor, and the full load stator current of an induction motor.

(Associate Member): Mr. Adams bases his construction for the circle diagram on the full load stator current and maximum power factor — which is assumed to occur at full load. This latter assumption is rather a big one to make, as it is not often that such a condition holds good. The more difficult problem is to determine this power factor, and with ordinary instruments practically an impossibility, as about full load the variation of power factor is exceedingly small and cannot be determined in the ordinary way. A further requirement, surely, is the efficiency of the motor, but this seems to be neglected: without this, how can the performance of the motor be determined ? Unfortunately, no test figures have been given to show how this method agrees with test results.
ieee_keywords: ['Reactive power', 'Loss measurement', 'Current measurement', 'Hysteresis motors', 'Stator windings', 'Short-circuit currents', 'Hysteresis']

abstracts: IN 1942 MR W. FENWICK READ A PAPER BEFORE THIS Institute on the field testing of high-voltage bushings. In the paper he described the instruments used for power factor or loss angle testing on the Victoria Falls and Transvaal Power Company's system which is now the Rand and Orange Free State Undertaking of the Electricity Supply Commission. These instruments were a 100-kV Schering Bridge and a 10-kV test set the latter manufactured by the Doble Engineering Corporation of America. The Schering Bridge lacked portability and it was later given on permanent loan to the University of the Witwatersrand. A second Doble set was purchased subsequently and these two sets have been used for many years to test thousands of high-voltage bushings.
The task of the loudspeaker is to convert the current oscillations in the anode circuit of the last stage valve of a receiver into audible sounds.
A method is described by which the minimum field strengths necessary for the satisfactory operation of the Decca navigator system under South African summer conditions have been determined.

If you look up our January, 1910 Journal you will find that on page 12, our first President, in his inaugural address, refers to the importance of electric signalling arrangements in our mines. What Mr. Campbell said seven years ago holds good to day, yet it is surprising to have to record the scanty discussion we had in connection with my paper. It is all the more surprising because such a large number of our members are directly connected with the mines.

Noise is best defined as ‘unwanted sound’ and the most obvious reason for its abatement is the annoyance factor, because this is generally the yardstick by which the average person classifies and determines whether a sound is, in fact, noise. Unfortunately, from the point of view of physical science, annoyance criteria are very difficult to establish as so much is dependent upon the psychological effect on the individual and the appropriate circumstances, that hard and fast rules based on fact or precedence are most difficult to co-relate. Nevertheless, in recent years physicists in co-operation with psychologists have made considerable progress, in relating mans' reaction to different types of noise in various situations1. The results of this type of work are extremely important for the purpose of community planning and the design of corrective measures should the annoyance factor be present. By this is implied that although it is theoretically possible to eliminate an annoying source of noise, it is seldom economical to do so completely; the most effective design, therefore, is that which reduces the overall effect of the noise to a point where it ceases to be annoying. The establishment of criteria of annoyance are therefore essential to the art of effective abatement.

The optimum conditions for maximum power transfer are described and relatively straightforward formulae developed for designing a transductor to get maximum power output for the smallest physical size of the as yet relatively expensive core material. It is shown that for most applications solution of the matching problem given by conventional circuit analysis does not hold.

The design of a double balanced image recovery mixer is described. The mixer features a fully planar implementation of the wide band RF and LO baluns. The conversion loss of the mixer is less than 3, 5 dB, and the image rejection better than 15 dB. With an IF amplifier noise figure of 2.0 dB, the overall mixer noise figure was 4.8 dB. Die ontwerp van 'n dubbel-gebalanseerde beeldherwinningsmenger word bespreek. Die menger is van planêre konstruksie. Die omsettingsverlies van die menger is minder as 3,5 dB, en die beeldverwerping meer as 15 dB. Met 'n tussenfrekwensieversterker met 'n ruissyfer van 2 dB, is die ruissyfer van die menqer 4.8 dB.

A brushless, doubly-fed stand-alone generator system can have advantages over both conventional as well as converter-based approaches. This paper introduces and discusses the characteristics of a stand-alone generator system based on a brushless, doubly-fed machine (BDFM). Results of steady-state studies are presented for different load and speed conditions. Experimental results using a low power laboratory prototype are presented to illustrate system viability.

The use of an explicit, residual-based, a posteriori error indicator for directing a single-level p-refinement of the finite element method analysis of a waveguide filter is investigated. Hierarchical, curl-conforming elements of various orders are employed. It is shown that substantial improvements upon uniform element polynomial order discretizations can be obtained in terms of accuracy versus number of degrees of freedom.
ieee_keywords: ['Finite element analysis', 'Microwave filters', 'Waveguide discontinuities', 'IIR filters', 'Error analysis', 'Refining', 'Rectangular waveguides']
author_keywords: ['Finite element method', 'Mixed order vector basis functions', 'A posteriori error estimation', 'Adaptive analysis', 'Waveguide discontinuities']

abstracts: The field of electrical machinery is so vast that the present paper has been confined to an analysis of themore common faults in induction motors only. It is hoped that in the future, furfher papers dealing with other types of equipment may be prepared.

It is, I think, generally accepted that all machinery which has td operate' underground in a gold mine has to withstand the most severe conditions, as well as in some cases very rough handling—sometimes unavoidably—in getting the particular piece of apparatus to the site of operation. These conditions apply in full to induction motors. Many cast iron motor frames are broken or cracked, especially at the feet, while being tra.nsported for installation underground in the most awkward pla.ces. It would therefore a.ppear that the fabricated steel frame has a definite advantage over the cast iron frame for this particular application.

Available data for the cumulative probability of occurrence of various values of the radio refractive k-factor fot South Africa have been subjected to regression analysis in terms of a proposed equation to describe such a distribution. The results presented have considerable promise in predicting the average cumulative trend of the k-factor in the inland summer rainfall areas. The model is expected to be of value in predicting large values of the k-factor, which may only be exceeded relatively rarely, but which could give rise to long-range interference in radio communication systems.
ieee_keywords: ['Regression analysis', 'Earth', 'Mathematical model', 'Refractive index', 'Analytical models', 'Analysis of variance', 'Market research']

abstracts: Research on parametric amplifiers in the National Institute for Telecommunications Research has been concentrated on the use of the semi-conductor diode as the variable reactance element. This work has led to the development of a practical amplifier at 600 Mc/s with a noise figure of 1.2 dB and a gain of 16 dB, which has been successfully applied to operational radars. The paper sets out briefly the basic theory and describes the amplifier. A detailed analysis of its performance in the laboratory is given and the problems of applying such an amplifier to a radar are discussed. The performance of the complete radar receiving system is given, indicating that the overall system noise temperature is 262°K, of which 145°K can be ascribed to the parametric amplifier, 88°K to aerial temperature and 29°K to losses in the TR system and circulator. Details are given of the extremely infrequent interruptions in service of this system over more than two years of operation, and details are given of a similar amplifier used on a different type of radar during many thousands of hours of service.

The protection of electric power systems is a subject that has received very great attention in Britain, and one on which much pioneering work has been done. It may be remembered that the forerunner of the many present-day protective systems of the so-called differential kind is the Merz-Price system, which was developed and first installed on the Newcastle Electric Supply Company’s system near Newcastle-on-Tyne in 1905. Other notable achievements are the first system of carrier-current protection, which was installed in the British grid system in 1931, and, more recently, import- ant advances in the art of busbar-zone protection.
This paper was primarily inspired by the President's inaugural address, and particularly by that part of the address which refers to winding equipment.

The object of this paper is to provide a survey of some of the major advances made in the realm of electrical engineering applied to medicine. The main accent is upon instrumentation and devices used in cardiology. A brief history of electrocardiography is presented and plethysmography (volume flow measurement), electromyography (muscle activity measurement) and endoradiosonde (telemetering capsules) devices are dealt with. An engineering view is adopted in the explanation of some of the physiological mechanisms. Finally some general remarks are made about education in this sphere of activity.

Until recent times, investigations of the gastrointestinal tract and the internal examination of the stomach were performed essentially by means of tubes, gastroscopes and gastrocameras. These methods are, however, not entirely satisfactory for reliable diagnosis of internal behaviour, as they are most uncomfortable and, more important, physiologically abnormal. In addition, there are many regions in the human body which are inaccessible to study under normal conditions. It thus became evident that some form of wireless telemetering was necessary.

The normal methods of starting induction motors are well known but the theory of these methods is usually taken for granted. This paper is an attempt to supply in simple form a practical theory directly applicable to the majority of everyday problems and compare the various methods of starting commonly employed. Theoretical accuracy has been sacrificed to practical utility and simplicity. It is hoped that the result will appeal to the practicing engineer. The stickler for accuracy and mathematical exactitude is warned that this paper is not for him. The general induction motor theory is reduced to a theory of the rotor current and torque. Direct-on-line and star-delta starting are considered and the load-torque-speed limitation of the latter noted. Devices for use in the stator circuit are reviewed in some detail and compared. Devices for use in the rotor circuit are similarly reviewed and compared. Finally, a new method of designing a rotor starting resistance is described.

It is customary for the Presidential Address to be related to the President's life's work. While considering the possible subjects for this address, I thought it probable that as it is the Institute's fiftieth birthday this year, many of you would find a review of the early history of the Institute and the progress in electrical engineering in the last fifty years of interest. This address will broadly cover this period.

In common with most lighthouse administrations the South African Railways found the post-war period devoted to the introduction of technical improvements and to overcoming a backlog of maintenance and installation work.

The history of electric vehicles and the present situation regarding there vehicles are discussed, and design parameters such as the field of application, trip statistics, power requirements, power source and range are mentioned. Possible future battery systems are also discussed, with reference to a number of aqueous, metal-air and high temperature batteries. Traction systems are dealt with, and reference is made to the general considerations of a typical controller for a motor with separate field excitation, as used in battery-driven vehicles. Economic considerations are mentioned and the purchase costs, operating costs and total costs of the electric vehicle are compared with that of the patrol-driven vehicle. The possible applications and future role of these vehicles in South Africa are considered. The advantages of battery-driven vehicles for countries dependent on overseas energy resources and the expected extra load on the supply network are briefly mentioned.

The question asked is why select carbon for a brush. Briefly the answer is that carbon lays down a skin or patina on the metallic collector surface, has excellent commutating properties, due to its contact drop, and is a solid lubricant These features reduce the wear of the collector surface to a minimum.

It is very appropriate that this commemoration number of the Journal of the S.A. Institute of Electrical Engineers should, on the “coming of age” of the Institute, contain an account of the Municipal Electrical Undertakings of the Union, since practically every community in a position to finance a scheme has now fallen into line by establishing its own undertaking, and in many of the large towns the Electricity Departments are looked upon as being one of the best of the trading departments.

In choosing a subject for this address, it seemed desirable that I should be guided by custom and follow in some respects the general pattern of the addresses presented by the late Mr C. Griffith in 1938 and Mr J. A. F. Michell in 1950 and to extend and bring up to date some of the data given by them.

A fixed voltage dc to dc converter, featuring bidirectional power flow, is presented. It functions as a DC transformer, and to be cost effective the number of components in the circuit is reduced to an absolute minimum by making the circuit self oscillating. Kilowatt ratings at mains voltage levels are made possible by carefully optimising the circuit for effective base drive and snubbing of the transistors.

The following brief reference to the properties of the circle diagram was prepared, at the request of your Council, to form an introduction to the contribution given by Mr. Adams, which investigates this important subject.

This work describes the development of a multiparabolic (MP) ionospheric model and compares the results at vertical incidence with those of the equivalent Dudeney model in the absence of the geomagnetic field. The MP model is extended to a multi-quasiparabolic (MQP) model in order to obtain analytical expressions for the variation of communications range as a function of elevation angle in the absence of the geomagnetic field and collisions. Results compare very favourably with those obtained using the equivalent Dudeney model and numerical ray-tracing. The MQP model can be applied in a number of HF communications problems, notably single site location HF direction finding and HF ionospheric radar.

Discussions with industrial and mining electrical engineers on many occasions have revealed that there is a real need for a very simple and inexpensive device which will give complete protection against single-phasing and overload conditions in circuits supplying 3-phase motors.

A simple algorithm to determine the generic rank of a structural matrix is described. The algorithm uses symbolic Gaussian elimination whilst minimizing “disruptions”. Although a successful outcome is not guaranteed, the algorithm has been tested on a large number of matrices without a single failure. Its operation is explained via examples.

In this paper, a simple hidden Markov model (HMM) is derived as an aid to characterising the performance of slotted medium access control (MAC) code division multiple access (CDMA) protocols over correlated multipath Rayleigh fading channels. The HMM is based on a simple two-state (fade, non-fade) channel scheme used in conjunction with a simple threshold model to map the channel state onto the user's observed slot (packet) error process. The parameters of the HMM are obtained both from simulation results and from a theoretical analysis based on functions of the correlation properties of the Rayleigh channel. The HMM is tested for a simple slotted direct sequence CDMA (DS-CDMA) ALOHA protocol, where results show that, despite it's simplicity, the proposed HMM is fairly accurate in modelling packet error sequences.
ieee_keywords: ['Hidden Markov models', 'Rayleigh channels', 'Multiaccess communication', 'Interference', 'Random variables', 'Numerical models', 'Markov processes']

abstracts: In real-time systems, computer programs must respond to external asynchronous events in an appropriate and timely manner. Real-time programming addresses the design and development of these programs. Our research into distributed real-time computing has identified a need for a personal computer-based real-time system executive to facilitate the simulation of distributed realtime processes. This paper describes our initial work towards building such a small and extensible non-preemptive system executive. We also discuss the philosophy behind the design and implementation of the system executive. The approach taken is to extend the C language to support concurrency while maintaining a high degree of portability. The library of C functions which support the system executive is described. An example is used to illustrate some of the fundamental concepts of real-time concurrent programming.

A non-uniform transmission line model of thick, loaded wire antennas was developed for their rapid analysis over a wide frequency range. Both a lossless line, with radiation effects modelled as a termination impedance, and a lossy line with radiation accounted for by series resistance were investigated. Input impedance and radiation efficiency results over a 10:1 frequency range are presented for thick loaded dipoles. These results indicate that the lossy line technique is suitable for the design and evaluation of loaded dipoles. The time to analyse electrically long dipoles is reduced by orders of magnitude in comparison with Method of Moments procedures.
author_keywords: ['Cylindrical dipoles', 'loaded dipoles', 'loaded dipole impedance', 'loaded dipole efficiency', 'transmission line method']

abstracts: The front of a wave produced by a surge generator is mainly dependent on the spark resistance and the inductivity. Considering these facts, H. Schering and W. Raske, Hannover, constructed a wave generator with an inductivity as small as possible, attained by a careful design with a zig-zag arrangement of plate condensers (Fig. 1) and a very small spark resistance. The latter task was accomplished by putting the gaps into compressed gas.

This paper develops and investigates the operation of a small prototype brushless dc motor. An automobile alternator was converted to run in this mode. Results obtained for the brushless dc motor are compared to the predicted results for a conventional dc motor, and found to be similar.

This paper presents a detailed simulation model of an SSSC for the simulation package EMTDC. The model includes a detailed representation of a three-level, 24-pulse voltage source inverter as well as the SSSC controls around it. The SSSC simulation model is first benchmarked against known results from the literature and then used to analyse the potential for an SSSC to cause network resonance.

As the traffic on a LAN increases, the response deteriorates and the rate of increase in the throughput also decreases. One of the most frequently used methods of alleviating the problem is to divide the LAN up into two or more LANs linked by bridges. This paper shows that a bridge may not necessarily improve the performance on LANs, but compound the problem. A LAN bridge atempts to limit traffic to those LANs linking the LAN of the source station and that of the destination station, but the bridge also introduces a delay, for packets passing from one LAN to the other. This may not give the improved performance that was expected from the bridge link. Several of the key load and device related factors, which must be considered in assessing bridged-LAN performance, are discussed. The causes and effects of the bridge discarding frames are also examined.

A presentation of refractivity variation, based on radiosonde measurements carried out in Maun, northern Botswana, is reported. It is observed that highest afternoon values of surface refractivity occur in February, while the lowest occur in August. It is also noted that for post-midnight periods, the highest value of average surface refractivity occurs in November. A comparison of the average values of surface refractivity, and AN plots, with ITU-R contours, shows reasonable agreement, which can be improved upon with more measurements. Atmospheric ducts, which lead to deep fades and serious interference between radio links, are most prevalent during February afternoons and during the post-midnight periods of November.

The instantaneous power theory was used to obtain the different load power components. The possibility of compensating for detrimental power components by means of different compensating modes, using hybrid power electronic active filters were investigated in order to obtain the most economical compensator topology.
ieee_keywords: ['Energy storage', 'Mathematical model', 'Distortion', 'Topology', 'Static VAr compensators', 'Reactive power', 'Active filters']

abstracts: The behaviour and characteristics of a simple regenerative snubber circuit, which is applied in a chopper circuit, are investigated. Mathematical descriptions for the switching transients are formulated and used to describe the limitations that the snubber circuit impose on the allowable switching frequency of the main power device. It is shown how the upper switching frequency limit is exactly determined by the snubber element sizes, the switching time of the main device and by the magnitude of the additional voltage and current stresses. The results are confirmed experimentally.

(Member): The authors of this paper have brought forward a most interesting subject, and I think we must all agree that in doing so they have displayed much ingenuity and enterprise. In bringing before this Institute an unproved attempt to solve this very difficult problem, they court criticism, and will, I am sure, be the first to welcome comments, whether favourable or adverse, from the members. As our President has repeatedly pointed out, the value and efficiency of the Institute depends very largely upon a full and careful discussion of the papers read, and I should like to point out that it is particularly necessary in the case of a paper, such as that now under discussion, that members should express their views, so that the matter may be left clear. An Institute like ours should stand for the consensus of opinion of local electrical engineers, and it is, therefore, up to us to criticise the views held by the authors of this paper openly and freely.

(Member): I will first suppose that this machine is able to produce an E.M.F. and consider what some of the results will be following from the design. First, we have a 12 pole field producing bunches of lines running more or less radially through what might be termed the field distribution ring; and passing very rapidly through these bunches we have numerous very large and quite solid armature teeth — surely these teeth will heat up very considerably. Then conversely when the machine is running and the rotor is excited the armature teeth will carry round bunches of lines which will produce eddy currents in the field distribution ring. Again the excited rotor poles will, in proportion as the reluctance of the complete magnetic path rises and falls, generate an increasing and decreasing current in the field coils of the stator, and since all these coils are in series and wound with fine wire, the potential at the terminals will probably be excessive. Now most of these effects could be obviated by using a one coil field construction which would give a smooth field distribution, and such a design, based on the inventor's line of thought, can be made very much more simply and cheaply. I made a small rough model to see if any effect whatever could be obtained, but though I forced about 3 amp. through the fine wire windings there was no tendency to turn in either direction, nor could one feel any sense of lag when turning the model and then switching on the current.

The President : I should like the authors to answer one or two questions in connection with this paper. Will they tell us what good they think will result commercially from the practical application of a dynamo made in the way they suggest. Do they think that the troubles which are experienced to-day with commutators and brushes on high class D.C. machines, particularly those with inter poles, are so great that the extra expense which their particular machine would no doubt entail in manufacture, would be warranted. In this country, at any rate, what would be the practical use of a machine such as they have described. As you all know, we are using here nothing but three-phase machines, and D.C. motors and dynamos can be bought at scrap prices.

(Associate Member) : Before replying to the various remarks made by members on the paper under discussion, we wish to thank members for the kind interest they have taken in the subject ; and more especially to thank those who have taken part in the discussion, as their remarks, more especially those of Mr. Ingg's, have had the result of inducing us to slightly alter the design of the machine.
(Visitor): The ingenious and interesting machine brought forward by the authors would appear to be but another addition to many similar forms which have proved impracticable.

One of the first points to note in internal combustion motor operation, whether of the reciprocating or turbine type, is that we are dealing with a mechanism operated directly by forces developed by “explosion” or “combustion.” These two terms “explosion” and “combustion” provide the keys which are being used today to unlock the mysteries of the phenomenon known as “detonation.” Whatever may be the true explanation of this elusive characteristic in fuel reactions with air or oxygen, the reason for its annoying effects on internal combustion motor performance is clear enough. We know that to obtain sweet performance of any mechanism there must be conformity between the rate of application of the force applied at any instant and the velocity of the mechanism at that instant, otherwise much of the energy delivered will be dissipated in impact losses. The more rapid the application of the force and the slower the moving mechanism the greater will be the magnitude of that energy loss. The factors which contribute towards detonation effects are numerous, but those most directly involved may be summarised in order of importance as follows

This paper is a sequel to that entitled ‘Lightning investigation on an 88-kV transmission line in Southern Rhodesia’ which was presented before the Institute in 1948, and now outlines more definite conclusions in respect of the characteristics of lightning, its frequency of occurrence and its severity. The effect of geological formations, heights of towers, span lengths, etc., are discussed, and the performance of an instrument for recording lightning strokes is described. Part II of the paper compares the actual with the estimated performance of the 88-kV line and curves and data are included to indicate the probable performance of typical lines of various voltages up to and including 220-kV. Recommendations for outage levels are made and the earthing conditions to meet them are discussed. Standard impulse insulation levels for transmission lines are suggested, and the factors governing the design of lightning-resistant lines are enumerated.

Standard impulse insulation levels for transmission lines are suggested, and the factors governing the design of lightning-resistant lines are enumerated.

The failure of software development projects has been a cause for concern for a long time. South Africa's software development industry is no exception. In fact, in South Africa the majority of the software development organizations are small to medium sized. Some even have one developer developing large systems. As is common with software development organizations, most of the applications are developed without following any development methodology and sometimes without following any project management methodology. This scenario leaves the South African industry prone to failures and catastrophes that have devastated the software industry for many years. This review aims to bring an awareness of an emerging software development discipline called Agile methodologies that claims to deal adequately with issues such as the social side of software development, where the interactions among developers, users, customers, managers and the proposed system actually affect the quality, cost, and time of software development.

Delta Modulation (DM) is a means of encoding analog signals in communication and control systems. The output of the delta encoder is a single-weighted digital pulse-train which may be decoded by a linear network at the receiving end to reconstruct the original analog signal.
ieee_keywords: ['Ions', 'Feeds', 'Delta modulation', 'Switches', 'Low-pass filters', 'Single photon emission computed tomography', 'Read only memory']

abstracts: The theory of ground wave propagation and the determination of effective ground conductivity by field strength measurements are discussed. The field strength survey of South Africa, at frequencies below 1 mc/s, is described. The results are presented in the form of a map showing the effective ground conductivity at 500 kc/s, and a curve showing the average relation between ground conductivity and frequency.

A methodical approach to the analysis and design of controllers for nonlinear processes, which utilizes existing controller design and analytical methods is presented. The method is systematic, simple to use and is applicable to a very large class of nonlinear processes. The method, which is based on an analysis of the system's equilibrium points, is illustrated using three examples, including one which exhibits chaotic behaviour. Using the proposed methodology, the design of controllers for such systems is shown to present no great difficulties, provided that the desired modes of the linearized process are controllable.
ieee_keywords: ['Process control', 'Xenon', 'Lyapunov methods', 'Systematics', 'Linear systems', 'Closed loop systems', 'Asymptotic stability']

abstracts: The paper describes the production of harmonic fields in induction motors and their influence on the torque-speed curve. A technique it developed for assessing the merits of slot combinations and winding arrangements with regard to the production of harmonic asynchronous and synchronous torques. The method is applied to a number of motors and the validity of the assessments made are checked by examining the measured torque-speed curves of these machines.

This paper describes an instrument developed in South Africa which, while measuring the apparent change of gravitational forces inside the conveyance in a mine shaft, transmits these quantities electrically along the winding rope to the surface, from where they are transmitted to the engine room, interpreted automatically and recorded as the actual acceleration and deceleration of the conveyance. The description of the instrument is followed by a discussion on test results which indicate the accuracy and usefulness of the apparatus for mechanical and electrical braking adjustments and for the investigation of winding problems generally.

Quite a number of protective snubbing cicuits have been proposed in the technical literature in the past. Few, or none of these have been compared to one another, making it difficult for the designer to find the one most suitable for a specific application. As opposed to commutation circuits for thyristor-based inverters, a method for objectively comparing various snubber circuits for voltage source inverters, has not yet been proposed. In this article such a method is proposed and three well known snubber circuits, which have been applied in practice, are compared objectively. From the results obtained, it is clear that some snubber circuits have better overall performance than others.
ieee_keywords: ['Snubbers', 'Switches', 'Switching circuits', 'Legged locomotion', 'Switching frequency', 'Voltage source inverters', 'Mathematical model']

abstracts: Voltage regulators may be divided into two general types. In one the output voltage is continuously variable over a wide range; in the other it is fixed and not readily alterable. This paper deals with a circuit (Fig 1) of the latter type. The circuit has been described elsewhere1, but a full description of its theory of operation and of design procedures does not appear to have been published. This paper analyses the performance of the regulator and establishes design procedures. A specific design of a regulator for 12-volt 1-amp max is then considered. Experimental and theoretical performance characteristics are compared.

A widely used method for error correction in digital communications is the Reed Solomon code, a type of BCH code. Reed Solomon and BCH codes are applications of the algebra of finite polynomial fields to the problems of how to encode the information, correct errors, and then decode to recover the information. This article is a tutorial on the methods and the mathematical fundamentals of these codes.

This paper covers the work performed for an Electronic Engineering final year undergraduate project. A DC to AC inverter for fluorescent lamps was designed and constructed. The inverter employed resonant elements and operated first at one frequency, to preheat the lamp cathodes, then at the resonant frequency of the circuit, for starting and running of the lamp. Important design factors were the efficiency of energy conversion from electrical input to light output, and the cost-effectiveness of the electronic circuitry. A prototype circuit was constructed and was found to perform to the satisfaction of the sponsors.

SOME DECADES AGO IT WAS CUSTOMARY FOR TRAVELLERS from Europe to remote parts of the globe to present papers to learned societies in which they recorded their observations and experiences with the inhabitants of strange countries. Today the opposite takes place. The years of World War II and those preceding and following it have changed the picture and social structure of Europe to such an extent that travels on that continent are now able to offer very much more interest than that previously afforded by sightseeing and social visits. Even more so, journeys across the so-called Iron Curtain are frequently regarded with the interest and awe previously accorded only to explorers' travels. It is to be regretted that the wartime catchword of the Iron Curtain has remained, because it accentuates an administrative separation between the people of various nations between whom there are no natural barriers.

The Engineering of Real-Time Systems requires specification, design, implementation of software components, within a project development framework for optimal development effort, re-use and maintainability. This multitude of requirements lead to a suite of languages which addresses the engineering aspects of real-time systems. The data flow architecture was chosen as a generic architecture based on the investigations into system architectures. The work is important as it provides a suite of languages which can support the real-time engineering process from specification to implementation and at the same time an unambiguous description of each software component at each development level. The paper examines the multiple dimensions required to describe a software component, proposes languages for the purpose, looks at the inter-relationship between the languages and closes with an example application.
The object of this paper is to throw some light on the every-day problems associated with the starting of a.c. motors up to 200

An 18 - 40 GHz omni-directional antenna capable of receiving horizontally and vertically polarised signals was developed and is reported on as an upgrade to many ELINT systems which operate up to 18 GHz only.

Modern ESM systems require frequency coverage up to 40 GHz. This paper describes the development of a small 18 - 40 GHz spiral antenna that can be mounted alongside the antennas of lower frequency ESM systems to extend the bandwidth thereof.

The earliest report on contact rectification dates back to 1874 when Braun published the results he obtained from experiments with natural metallic sulphides and also with some specially prepared compounds suitably arranged between contact clamps. Branley subsequently studied the rectifying properties of copper oxide in contact with different metals. In 1904, Midgley described a detector consisting of an asymmetrical junction between a metal such as silver and a metal oxide such as silver oxide or copper oxide. In the following four years the crystal detector appeared and reports on the characteristics of crystal detectors or rectifiers were published by Dunwoody, Pearce and others. In 1908 Thompson patented the first copper oxide rectifier. This consisted of a small copper disc on the one edge of which an artificial layer of oxide was produced by the action of heat. This was pressed against a soft metal electrode of lead or tin. In the years following up to 1925 may types of contact rectifiers were described and patented The latter year saw the commercial development the contact rectifiers. The two principal developments were the cupric sulphide rectifier described by Ruben, and the copper oxide rectifier described by Grondahl and his associates. The former type is of the low resistance class and is mainly used for high current densities. This type has received scant treatment in the literature on the subject. The latter type is of the high resistance class and is better adapted to the case where the current to be passed is small.

In hierdie artikel word gekyk na die gebruik van 'n versadigbare kapasitor as 'n afskakelgapser, wat 'n aan/af-skakelende elektroniese drywingskomponent beveilig. Hierdie gapserbaan tree as hulpstroombaan op deur die lokus van die drywingskakelaar tydens die afskakeloorgang gunstiger te dwing. Alhoewel daar tot dusver uitsluitlik gebruik gemaak is van lineêre kapasitore – dit is kapasitore waarvan die kapasitansie konstant bly – word in hierdie artikel aangetoon dat die gebruik van 'n nie-lineêre kapasitor, waarvan die kapasitansie spanningsafhanklik is, groot voordele inhou, veral vanuit 'n energie-oogpunt beskou. Ná 'n inleiding oor die gebruik van gapsers by hoëfrekwensie-drywingseiektroniese energie-omvorming, word daar eerstens na die nie-lineêre kapasitor gekyk. Hierna word hierdie versadigbare kapasitor as nie-lineêre gapserelement beskou deur dit kwantitatief met die bekende lineêre kapasitor te vergelyk. Uit die ontleding blyk dit duidelik dat die nie-lineêre kapasitor as die algemene geval beskou kan word, met die lineêre kapasitor as die spesiale (onversadigde) geval. Berekende krommes wat die gestoorde energie in die kapasitor as 'n funksie van die spanning aantoon, asook die invloed van die nie-lineêre afskakelgapser op beide die afskakelverlies in die drywingskakelaar en die totale energieverlies in die stelsel weens die skakeloorgang, word getoon. 'n Eksperimentele meting is ook uitgevoer om die gesimuleerde resultate te toets. Uit al die resultate blyk dit dat kommersiële keramiese kapasitore met 'n ongekompenseerde ferroelektrikum, wat goed versadig word d.m.v. 'n relatiewe groot spanning, sowat 1/10 van die hoeveelheid energie stoor wat 'n ooreenkomste lineêre kapasitor by dieselfde eindspanning stoor. Terselfdertyd word kwantitatief aangetoon dat die nie-lineêre afskakelgapser ongeveer dieselfde gapsing vir die drywingskakelaar verskaf in vergelyking met die lineêre gapser, veral vir groter relatiewe kapasitansiewaardes. Die artikel word afgesluit met 'n kritiese beskouing van die voordele en beperkings verbonde aan bestaande nie-lineêre kapasitore vir gapsertoepassings.

W L GRANT graduated from the University of the Witwatersrand with a BSc (Cum Laude) in March, 1948. In 1957 he was awarded a DSc by the same University, his MSc (Cum Laude) having been gained in the interim at the University of Pretoria.

The paper began by reminding those present of the work of the Institute's first Lightning Investigation Committee under the direction of Dr B. F. J. Schonland, F.R.S., which was the fulfilment of a policy originated by Dr Bernard Price when he was President. This policy committed the Institute to supporting a piece of basic physical research in an electrical field, and the work of the Committee, and what followed from it, indicated clearly the need for close cooperation between the electrical engineer and the pure physicist in problems in such a field. Each has a definite and distinct contribution to make before a satisfactory solution can be found, and both are needed for this solution. Following this policy the local Committee had asked a physicist to give the inaugural paper on basic researches at present in progress.

Lightning Phenomena. — In a paper recently presented before the Franklin Institute Dr. C. P. Steinmetz said that lightning is one of the most important uninvestigated phenomena of electricity. In the early days, he said, lightning was explained as a discharge from the clouds. The clouds being positively and the ground negatively charged, a spark jumps from the clouds to the ground.

Report of the Special Committee on the Use of Electricity in Mines. — In their report to the Home Secretary, the Special Departmental Committee appointed to inquire into the working of the existing specia rules for the use of electricity in mines, point out that the conditions have altered considerably since the rules came into force some five years ago and that they need revision. Whereas the early installations were all direct-current plant the tendency now is to adopt the three-phase system and this the Committee consider to be a change in the right direction. After receiving evidence from a large number of representative witnesses, the Committee have drawn up a proposed new code of rules which, they suggest should apply to metalliferous mines as well as coal mines. The rules relate to apparatus below ground only, with the exception of the switchgear at the pit-head controlling the underground distribution system.

Nickel Alloys for Use in Electrical Resistance Work — Some new nickel alloys for use in electrical resistance work have recently been patented by Wilbur B. Driver, of East Orange. N.J. (U.S. Patent, 993,042, May 23, 1911). The alloys and their properties are described by the inventor as follows : — "Various allovs have been known and used for electrical resistance, having more or less high electrical resistance, but as a rule the melting-points of these alloys are comparatively low, and many of them are not stable in their electrical properties, and besides are liable to deteriorate from rust, etc.

Electric Power in Colleries. — A paper by Mr. F. Anslow, entitled, “Some Considerations affecting the installation of Power at Collieries,” was among those discussed at the meeting at Dunfermline of the Mining Institute of Scotland, on June 17th. Mr. Anslow, in dealing with existing steam plants at collieries, said that these were often destitute of condensing plant, partly on account of difficulties in running winding engines condensing, but he showed that in most cases, except where increased power is required, the cost of adding condensers to improve the economy was not justified. Where extensions are required, however condensing plant and exhaust, or mixed turbines driving electrical generators, will render considerable extra power available without extra steam being required from the boilers. Details were given of a case where an extra 500 KW. was thus made available. Even where a large proportion of steam plant is already condensing, considerable extra power can be obtained by the installation of mixed pressure turbo plant, and particulars were given of an example to illustrate this.

A New Variable Resistance. — A new form of tubular variable resistance has recently been placed on the market by the Göttingeu Rheostaten und Schalttafelfabrik, under the name "Rheogött." The rheostat is of the well-known tubular form (see Fig. 1), provided with a sliding contact block as shown, but the construction employed is simpler and more durable than is frequently the case in this class of apparatus. Again, the insulation resistance between the successive turns of resistance wire a and the metal framework b is so high that a potential difference of 10,000 volts applied between these parts is said to cause no appreciable leakage current (even when the whole is heated by continued operation at overload).

Remote Control Switches. — It is in many instances highly desirable to effect the control of circuits from a distance without the necessity for having to handle the ponderous circuit breakers which are essential for breaking heavy currents in air. In motor control work, remote operation removes the more or less inexpert workmen to a position well away from the electrical apparatus.

The Action of the X-Ray in Large and Small Doses. — Since the discovery of the X-rays and their application to therapeutics, many and various results have been obtained from their use, results often quite contradictory in character, the explanations of which have at times been distinctly puzzling. It has been difficult in many instances to explain why in one case the use of the rays would cause degeneration and at others regeneration of similar tissues; why, for example, in one patient superflous hair would be removed and in another the use of the rays on a smooth skin would result in a profuse hirsute adornment. In recent years, however means have been devised of regulating the dose of the X-rays and of estimating in units the amount of radiation being administered in each case. This has made the study of the action more accurate and has enabled the illumination of several obscure points. In the Berliner klinische Wochenschrift for May 23, 1910, H. E. Schmidt reports a small series of experiments into the effect of various doses of the X-ray upon cell growth. Having soaked a number of beans in water for six hours he treated the different beans with different doses of rays, and then planted them. His results were quite uniform and demonstrated two points of interest. Whereas those beans which were treated with large doses of the rays were partially or completely inhibited in their growth, as compared to untreated control beans, those which received very small doses were distinctly stimulated; not only were the plants larger and more vigorous, but the flowers were larger and the resulting crop of beans better. From these findings Schmidt suggests that the same principle may apply to animal cells, and experiments which he carried out on an ulcer on the arm suggested that this is the case. If this be so, it is evident that in treating conditions in which healing is desired, as a sluggish ulcer, very small doses of the X-ray should be used, whereas in cases of malignant growth, where tissue destruction is required, large doses are needed, and small doses instead of destraying the neoplasm may do harm rather than good by stimulating it to renewed activity. — Electrical Review and Western Electrician, July 30. 1910, p. 234.

Electric Power in Colleries. — A paper by Mr. F. Anslow, entitled, “Some Considerations affecting the installation of Power at Collieries,” was among those discussed at the meeting at Dunfermline of the Mining Institute of Scotland, on June 17th. Mr. Anslow, in dealing with existing steam plants at collieries, said that these were often destitute of condensing plant, partly on account of difficulties in running winding engines condensing, but he showed that in most cases, except where increased power is required, the cost of adding condensers to improve the economy was not justified. Where extensions are required, however condensing plant and exhaust, or mixed turbines driving electrical generators, will render considerable extra power available without extra steam being required from the boilers. Details were given of a case where an extra 500 KW. was thus made available. Even where a large proportion of steam plant is already condensing, considerable extra power can be obtained by the installation of mixed pressure turbo plant, and particulars were given of an example to illustrate this.

The Design of Mining Switchgear. — The rapid increase during recent years in the number of collieries equipped with electrical plant underground, and the consequent increased demand for plant of a special nature to suit mining conditions, has resulted in there being now upon the market a very large variety of so-called “mining” switches, motor-starters, ∧c., and in passing these in review one cannot help thinking that their designers have, in some cases, very little idea of the actual conditions under which the results of their labours will be called upon to operate.

Electric Power in Collieries. — A paper with the above title was read before the Ruby Engineering Society by Mr. J. Miller on January 19th In the author's opinion, it is generally more profitable to instal generating plant at the colliery, but if the load consists mainly of haulage, with little pumping and ventilation, the load factor may be very low indeed, and the plant be running at low efficiency, so that it may be cheaper to take power from a supply company. The author gives figures for a 250-kw. colliery set. which gave a total output of some 25,000 units per month. The capital charges amounted to 0.725d. per unit, and the running costs to 0.438d. per unit, giving a to ta of 0.725d. per unit. These figures refer to a period when the set was only about a quarter loaded. Power was originally taken from a local supply company at the price of one penny per unit.

Control of Electric Winders. — In a paper read before the Manchester Section of the Institution of Electrical Engineers on December (5th Dr. E. Rosenberg (British Westinghouse Electric ∧ Manufacturing Co.) dealt with the control of electrically driven main winders. The author pointed out that, besides starting and stopping ordinary loads, it is often necessary to lower unbalanced loads, in which case the motor, if it be used at all, must work as a generator. If no tail rope is used, and the load on the up-going cage is just balanced by the load on the down-going cage, then the rope weight will, in the first half-trip, exercise a positive, and in the second half a negative torque, and the winding machine has at first to act as a motor and then as a brake.

Remote Control Switches. — It is in many instances highly desirable to effect the control of circuits from a distance without the necessity for having to handle the ponderous circuit breakers which are essential for breaking heavy currents in air. In motor control work, remote operation removes the more or less inexpert workmen to a position well away from the electrical apparatus.

It has been difficult in many instances to explain why in one case the use of the rays would cause degeneration and at others regeneration of similar tissues; why, for example, in one patient superflous hair would be removed and in another the use of the rays on a smooth skin would result in a profuse hirsute adornment. This has made the study of the action more accurate and has enabled the illumination of several obscure points. In the Berliner klinische Wochenschrift for May 23, 1910, H. E. Schmidt reports a small series of experiments into the effect of various doses of the X-ray upon cell growth.
