From these findings Schmidt suggests that the same principle may apply to animal cells, and experiments which he carried out on an ulcer on the arm suggested that this is the case. If this be so, it is evident that in treating conditions in which healing is desired, as a sluggish ulcer, very small doses of the X-ray should be used, whereas in cases of malignant growth, where tissue destruction is required, large doses are needed, and small doses instead of destraying the neoplasm may do harm rather than good by stimulating it to renewed activity. — Electrical Review and Western Electrician, July 30. 1910, p. 234.

Earth Return. — For more than a year a Commission of the Swiss Electrotechnical Society has had under observation the use of the earth as a return conductor between St. Maurice and Lusanne, and l'Industrie Electrique, quoting from a report of the Commission; states that the system has worked satisfactorily from the moment when it was put in regular service, without a single derangement. Direct current at 20,000 volts is used on the Thury system, with a single line conductor, the second line conductor having been idle during the past 14 months. No complaints have been made by the engineers of the Federal Railways, the compensating batteries installed at certain stations having absolutely prevented interference with the railway signals. — The Electrical Review, November 4, 1910, p. 764.

Electricity in Mining. — In the course of a paper on “Coal-Mine Equipment,” presented at the Bluefield meeting of the West Virginia Coal-Mining Institute, W. S. Meyers gave a résumé of his experience of the trend of electrical progress in mining work. An abstract of the author's conclusions follows: In the application to work inside the mine there is no form of energy which compares to that of electricity.

Licensing of Wiremen. — Some discussion took place at the annual meeting of the Victorian Institute of Electrical Engineers in Melbourne regarding the licensing of wiremen. Mr. Noel Murray, a member of the Council of the Institute, desired that the municipal authorities be approached in the matter, as at present there was an enormous amount of bad work being put in. The only way to obviate this, in Mr. Murray's opinion, was to issue licenses to the wiremen in the same way as is done with engine drivers and plumbers. which would give the authorities control over the men. If a man wired a building in a faulty manner, then he should have his license suspended for six or twelve months, and this would be the means of raising the standard of work in the wiring world. A man should also be made responsible for the material used as well as for the work done. Mr. P. Rosling, the newly-elected president of the Institute, stated that the committee had considered the matter, but nothing could be done without passing au Act of Parliament. He therefore suggested that the matter should be left over until the wiremen's wages board was settled. Mr. E. H. W. Westwood said that in Wellington (N.Z.) no wireman was allowed to touch the Council's mains unless he held a license, but he believed the whole thing had proved a failure. It was eventually decided to bring the matter before the council, who would report upon it at the next meeting. — The Australian Mining Standard, March 29, 1911, p. 310.

(C.) 435/10. Arthur Martin Ludwig Dammrich (1), Charles Hansen (2) Improvements m means for conveying and distributing water or other liquids in mines and the like. 3.9.10. This invention relates to means for conveynig and distributing water or other liquids in mines or any other place where the conditions met with are more or less similar to those in underground workings. The special object that the inventors have ha in view is to lay out or provide a water service in a mine, or any other place where the conditions are analogous, in such a way that the pipe system shall not be subjected to excessive hydraulic pressure whatever may be the vertical distance between the points of supply and the lowest point of the distributing system. It is claimed that the improved system is applicable for conveying and distributing water or other liquids to any depth without exceeding a safe pressure, such pressure, if so desired, not to exceed, say. 50 lb to the square inch or thereabouts. Briefly stated, the invention consists of supply tanks in each level fitted with a float, an electric contact for signalling when the tank is empty a tap for drawing off the water as required, and an overflow pipe near the top of the tank to act as an air vent and overflow outlet The main supply pipe is taken from the surface to the bottom of the first tank, and from a point in this tank, below the level of the overflow pipe, a pipe is taken to the bottom of the second tank which acts as the supply pipe to that tank. Similarly, the water is taken from level to level throughout the mine. It will be obvious therefore, that as long as the capacity of the overflow pipes fitted to the tanks is greater than that of the mail supply pipe, the hydraulic pressure in any section will not be greater than that due to the vertical head between the tanks in the levels above and below the section in question.
The following statement of policy No 1 has been issued by the Soulh African Council for Professional Engineers.

The flat-plate physical optics approximation to the calculation of the electromagnetic backscatter of a cylindrical body constructed of curved surfaces is evaluated and compared to the exact diffraction theory. Curves showing the magnitude of the error as a function of frequency are included.

Constant current angle control of the reluctance synchronous machine can be considered as the control of the machine at near optimum efficiency. This paper describes an accurate constant current angle control technique for a digital current controlled reluctance synchronous machine drive. Using finite element calculated results accurate decoupled dq current regulators are designed and used in a digital controlled system using the TMS320F240-DSP. In the design of the controller the effect of dynamic inductances, due to saturation and cross magnetisation, on the performance of the ∗∗∗PI-controllers is taken into account. Complete analysis, digital simulation and measured results are presented.
ieee_keywords: ['Current measurement', 'Synchronous machines', 'PI control', 'Current control', 'Couplings', 'Mathematical model', 'Voltage measurement']

abstracts: The development of a fully interactive and virtually foolproof software package for the accurate approximation and synthesis of discrete and distributed element filters of high order and narrow bandwidth, is discussed. The network elements accommodated in the synthesis are the Darlington A, B and C sections and the commensurate quarter wavelength transmission line element. Nearly all filters required for a specified amplitude frequency response may be designed with these elements. The developed software runs on IBM and compatible microcomputers equipped with a 8086 processor and 8087 mathematical coprocessor. Die ontwikkeling van qebruikersvriendelike interaktiewe programmatuur vir die akkurate benadering en sintese van punt- en verspreideelement filters word bespreek. Die filters wat hiermee ontwerp word, bestaan uit 'n kombinasie van Darlington A, B en C - seksies, en die kwartgolflengte transmissieelement. Byna alle filters wat vir 'n gegewe amplitude-frekwensieweergawe gespesifiseer word, kan met hierdie elemente gerealiseer word. Die program is geskik vir IBM en versoenbare persoonlike rekenaars wat toegerus moet wees met 'n 8087 wiskundige koverwerker.
ieee_keywords: ['Band-pass filters', 'Filtering theory', 'Software', 'Finite element analysis', 'Bandwidth', 'Microwave filters', 'Poles and zeros']

abstracts: The partial differential equation which is associated with the loss-free line by electrical engineers was first developed in an investigation of the stretched string. Its properties were well known long before any electric lines were used in practice. With the use of circuit theory, however, this equation was investigated further, and when electrical engineers concerned themselves with acoustics (as a result of progress in electronics) the electrical acoustical analogies enabled these investigations to be applied to acoustic problems.

When broadcasting commenced in this country in 1924, broadcasting studios were housed in ordinary office buildings and operated from these for 10 years. Very little attempt was made to exclude noise from the studios with the result that, not infrequently, extraneous noises were broadcast. Such occurrences were sometimes embarrassing but more often than not highly amusing.

The paper reviews some recent work in the subjects of acoustics and electroacoustics. Among the topics covered are certain educational aspects, important factors in architectural acoustics, examples of modern transducers and measuring techniques.

This paper presents an integrated active snubber (IACS) to be used with IGBT modules in power converters, applied in utility devices. The IACS is a compound component, consisting of all active and passive components necessary to change a hard-switched converter into a soft-switched converter, i.e. the auxiliary resonant commutated pole (ARCP) converter. The IACS mounts directly onto standard IGBT modules. Although the IACS does not provide perfect soft switching, the switching losses are reduced such that IGBT's can be used at their maximum current and voltage ratings and frequencies of up to 20 kHz.
author_keywords: ['Power Quality', 'Integrated Active Snubber', 'Auxiliary Resonant Commutated Pole']

abstracts: An energy related approach for the interpretation and subsequent compensation of electrical power networks is introduced. It is proposed that optimum supply utilization is brought about by the correct time distribution of the energy drawn from the source, and supplied to a load. A time-domain based, digital adaptive control technique for TCR's, for implementation in proposed hybrid compensation schemes, is further described. An ‘optimum reactive current’ is calculated in the time-domain and a linear extrapolation predictor is further implemented in real-time to estimate future values of the firing angles for the thyristors in such an energy redistribution device (i.e. compensator).

This paper investigates a dual carrier phase and frequency correction strategy, specially adopted for application in a Four-Dimensional Quadrature Phase-Shift Keying (4D-QPSK) modem. The modem is intended for asynchronous V/UHF digital land mobile communications, with Time-Division Multiple-Access (TDMA) or Slow Frequency-Hopped Multiple-Access (SFHMA) transmission scenarios. Performance results are presented to illustrate the efficiency of the Dual Carrier Phase Frequency Kalman Estimator (DCPFKE) strategy under typical mobile channel conditions, excluding the effects of multiplath and deep amplitude fades.
ieee_keywords: ['Time division multiple access', 'Synchronization', 'Phase shift keying', 'Bandwidth', 'Modems', 'Frequency modulation', 'Doppler effect']

abstracts: Since I read my Paper on Electric Furnaces before this Institution, the progress in this art has advanced by leaps and bounds. The last decade was conspicuous with inventions, but if asked which was the most important invention of all, I would be undecided between the aeroplane and the electric furnace. The former is more sensational, striking the everyday man, but the latter, with its future possibilities, is equally striking in its scientific and practical aspects.

This paper describes work performed for an Electronic Engineering final year undergraduate project. Several different systems were investigated for the incorporation of additional sound channels on a PAL television transmission system. The pilot tone system similar to that employed in FM stereo radio was found to be the most suitable and a prototype system providing two additional audio channels was designed and constructed. The proposed system is fully compatible with existing TV transmissions, whilst ensuring sound quality equal to that of the existing audio channel. The prototype was tested on a commercial television set where signal-to-noise ratios, total harmonic distortion and crosstalk were measured.
ieee_keywords: ['Frequency modulation', 'TV', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Low-pass filters', 'Band-pass filters', 'Frequency division multiplexing', 'Decoding']

abstracts: Your Chairman has read out to you the Resolution of Council passed on 5th June creating the Cape Western Local Centre. I wish to pass to you very sincere congratulations from your Council, and especially from myself.

ieee_keywords: ['Meters', 'Standards', 'Process control', 'Roads', 'Random access memory', 'Power generation', 'Liquid crystal displays']

abstracts: A conference organised by the South African Federation of University Engineering Students and the International Association for the Exchange of Students for Technical Experience, was held at the University of the Witwatersrand in August, 1977. The conference title ‘Africa to Africa: Modern technology and its effectiveness’ indicates the relevance of the papers presented, and with a view to extending the readership it has been decided to publish these papers in the belief that they will be of great interest to members. According to a survey published in 1974 (1) the energy resources of Africa compare with those in the rest of the world as shown in Table 1. This table indicates that, in terms of energy content, Africa possesses about 4,4 per cent of the world's recoverable reserves of nonrenewable resources consisting of solid fuels, oil, natural gas and uranium, and more than 20 per cent of its ‘installed or installable’ hydro resources.

Conducted common mode EMI in switchmode power supplies originates due to an excess or deficiency in charge required by the physical circuit structure, in order to attain the operational potentials. As the operational potentials change during switching conditions, the required charge must be drawn from an external source, giving rise to a common mode current. The physics of this process is explained, and a simple but effective experimental procedure is described in order to determine the charge distribution, and self-capacitances of points in a physical circuit. Mitigation of the common mode current problem by means of an internal charge balance is presented.
author_keywords: ['Electromagnetic interference', 'Common mode EMI', 'EMI Mitigation', 'Switching power supplies']

abstracts: It was a great and unexpected honour to me to be invited to give this memorial lecture tonight in honour of Dr Bernard Price. One of the reasons for this invitation was, I understand, that I had some acquaintance with Dr Price in the years toward the end of his life. It would be true to say that I owe to his wisdom and generosity in founding the Bernard Price Institute of Geophysical Research a large fraction of my academic life and I found that his continued interest in the work going on at that Institute made it always a pleasure to describe what we were doing, or what we proposed to do, in the prosecution of our researches.

Jet Engine Modulation (JEM) of radar returns is caused by the rotation, relative to the aircraft, of the turbine and its blade assembly. It is the aim of this work to determine the viability of using the modulated returns to recognise aircraft. Data obtained from three aircraft, two jets and a Cessna, was used for the experiments conducted. Classification performance of up to 87% was attained for this limited population.

Airport lighting is a very specialized art which involves a great many problems that do not occur in most other fields of electrical illumination. Present-day systems have gradually evolved from work carried out during the past 30 years in many different countries of the world.

This report discusses the measurement of mean square value of a time varying quantity by means of a companding analogue-to-digital converter and minicomputer or microprocessor. An algorithm based on a table look-up technique it described. Since no multiplication it involved reel time operation at sampling rates of tens of Kilohertz is possible. Storage requirements for the table are modest (384 bytes).

On 27 September last year, a gaily painted, streamlined train slid silently into Geneva's Cornavin Railway Station. It was the long-awaited ‘Train à Grande Vitesse’ (High Speed Train) of the French National Railways (SNCF), linking Geneva to Paris in 4 h and 20 min as opposed to 6 h in the pre-TG V era.

A specially developed electrically driven motor car, which may well change the pattern of local traffic, was exhibited for the first time at the Electrical Engineers' Exhibition at Earl's Court, London, in March.

It is the intention in this paper to discuss certain aspects of a.c. track circuiting with special reference to its further application in the urban and suburban areas. In particular, the modern practice of phase controlled track circuits will be considered.

The shortcomings of conventional pulse amplifiers for radar with respect to ringing, shortest pulse still amplified and signal-to-noise ratio are investigated. Integrating methods using the gating technique are shown to eliminate ringing, make the amplification of shorter pulses possible and improve the signal-to-noise ratio. The improvement in signal-to-noise ratio is achieved at the expense of the speed with which information can be received. The amplification of d.c. pulses is investigated by the simple gate, the double gate and the phase-modulated gate. All three methods eliminate ringing and enable the amplification of shorter pulses. With respect to noise reduction, the simple gate is shown to be inferior to the other two methods due to flicker noise of valves at low frequencies. Neglecting flicker noise, the improvement in signal power to noise power ratio, by using any of the three methods, is equal to the ratio of pulse recurrence frequency to the bandwidth of the amplifier following the gate. An experimental double-gate amplifier is described. The measured signal-to-noise ratio was slightly below the theoretical value, but an improvement of 31 db was nevertheless achieved by gating. The application of the gating technique to a.c. pulses is considered and methods to produce the necessary a.c. pulses locked to the leading edges of d.c. modulating pulses are described.
ieee_keywords: ['Bandwidth', 'Logic gates', 'Harmonic analysis', 'Frequency modulation', 'Valves', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Limiting']

abstracts: This paper describes briefly a full-duplex, 8,5 Mbit/s digital radio operating at 3,4 GHz. The design of two of the system's microwave components, namely the temperature compensated impatt oscillator and the fast PIN diode pulse amplitude modulator are discussed in greater deuil.
ieee_keywords: ['Radio transmitters', 'PIN photodiodes', 'Microwave oscillators', 'Local oscillators', 'Impedance', 'Band-pass filters', 'Receiving antennas']

abstracts: Control system design has reached a level of considerable maturity and there exists substantial understanding of “standard” linear control problems. The aim of this paper is to look beyond linear solutions and give a brief introduction to Nonlinear Control. We adopt a practical viewpoint so as to introduce this field to those who may not be familiar with it.

By using an M-ary spread spectrum technique employing “composite” sequences generated by linear feedback shift registers, robust and bandwidth-efficient CDMA communications can be achieved. A threshold decision scheme whereby erasures as well as errors are declared facilitates detection of poor or marginal channel conditions. By combining the multiple-sequence modulation technique and a Reed-Solomon error correcting code, plus incorporating an informationless sequence of the same period in quadrature with the information-bearing sequence, carrier recovery, spreading sequence synchronization, and block code synchronization can all be achieved jointly. Individual symbols can be detected using efficient Hadamard transforms. Also, the system can easily be made to be “downward compatible” with “conventional” spread spectrum schemes.

This paper provides an overview of the basic principles of Smart Antenna techniques as applied to the introduction of Space Division Multiple Access (SDMA) techniques in current mobile radio networks, as well as in Personal Communication Services (PCS), Personal Communications Networks (PCN) and the Universal Mobile Telecommunication System (UMTS). It is shown qualitatively how SDMA techniques can increase the capacity of cellular network. Furthermore, a new SDMA principle based on the non-homogeneous Quality of Service requirements in mobile multi-media networks is introduced with application to systems proposed for UMTS.
ieee_keywords: ['Adaptive arrays', 'Multiaccess communication', 'Spectral efficiency', 'Interference', 'Antenna measurements', 'Transmitting antennas', 'Base stations']

abstracts: The single lumped-element equivalent circuit model fails for inclined strip dipoles near a microstrip feedline. A new three-port S-parameter model for the isolated inclined dipole is introduced. The new model is accurate, but simple, and is used in an iterative design procedure for linear arrays of strip dipoles which are proximity-coupled to a continuous microstrip feedline. Previously available design methods are extended by allowing the dipoles to be inclined in the plane of the substrate. This gives flexibility regarding polarization. The design procedure is accurate if mutual coupling via guided mode scattering dominates coupling via radiation and surface waves. The important case of 45° inclination angle is investigated in some detail. Arrays using dipoles parallel or perpendicular to the feedline can be designed as special cases of the method.
ieee_keywords: ['Scattering parameters', 'Integrated circuit modeling', 'Power transmission lines', 'Microstrip', 'Mutual coupling', 'Microstrip antenna arrays', 'Impedance']

abstracts: The paper gives a lumped parameter circuit to be used in modelling the deep bar effects in rotors of induction motors. This circuit is obtained by dividing the rotor bar into equal sections; an improvement is proposed which divides the bar unequally to have a greater number of smaller sections at the top of the bar where the current will flow under transient conditions. An example shows the superiority of this model compared to the traditional induction motor model.

The paper presents a fuzzy logic (FL) based adaptive control technique for variable speed drives using a recursive-least-square identification algorithm and an original tuning method of the FL speed controller. The input and output gains of the FL speed controller are adjusted on-line according to changes in system parameters, whereas the control rule base and the membership functions of fuzzy sets are kept unchanged. The equations which give the dependence of FL controller gains on system parameters are founded on a parallel study of FL and PI controllers, being used in the tuning process of the FL speed controller. The performance of the proposed adaptive FL control system was tested by simulation studies and practical experiments. Implementation aspects of converter fed motor drive systems are also discussed.
ieee_keywords: ['Fuzzy logic', 'Motor drives', 'Velocity control', 'Tuning', 'PI control', 'Mathematical model', 'Adaptive control']
author_keywords: ['Fuzzy Logic Control', 'Power Converters', 'Electrical Drives', 'Microprocessor Implementation', 'Real-Time Control', 'Recursive-Least-Square Method']

abstracts: The recording of the thermal properties of objects by optical remote sensing is based on the fact that surfaces at natural environmental temperatures emit radiation predominantly at infrared wavelengths. In consequence, airborne thermal infrared reconnaissance is concerned with the 3 μm to 30 μ m region of the spectrum to measure thermal characteristics in a ground (or water) scene. Since practical photographic emulsions are not sensitive at these wavelengths, solid state devices are needed to detect the emitted radiation. An efficient way of producing a thermal image of the scene over which an aircraft passes is to use a scanning radiometer or linescanner. This paper describes some concepts involved in designing a high performance linescanner. Particular reference is made to the design considerations of a custom-made linescanner (21) capable of recording multispectral thermal imagery with high thermal and spatial resolution. Use of this instrument in a geological application is also described and an example of thermal imagery presented. 10 Summary The concepts involved in the recording of the emitted IR radiation from a ground scene as imaged by an advanced IR line scanner operated from an aircraft have been described. In particular the RS-25 IR line scanner manufactured by Texas Instruments is discussed and a detailed breakdown of its optical and electronic design features is given. These non-standard features were incorporated in order to recover IR imagery of the same spatial and radiometric fidelity maintained by the high performance detector system and scan optics. The RS-25 described is presently a unique system, custom-made for the purpose of geological exploration in Southern Africa. An example of a geological application is given in which thermal differences within a geological sequence were recorded. From these differences geological structure not apparent in conventional photography could be identified.

The breaking of most cipher systems relies on the fact that message symbols are not uniformly distributed. In this paper we introduce an adaptive homophonic source coding scheme to alleviate this problem. The adaptive homophonic coder transforms a non-uniformly distributed source into a non-deterministic, uniformly distributed message sequence. This is done by combining homophonic substitution with Arithmetic coding. The adaptive nature of the algorithm allows the algorithm to be used with an arbitrary message source.

Tests on high-speed hf data channels, using transmission test sets which are designed for channels with low error rates, showed that a false indication of a loss of synchronisation was frequently recorded during long error bursts. An algorithm is described whereby the probability of such a false decision can be calculated and set to any acceptable value in a test receiver, while a true loss of synchronisation will be detected within a specified number of data bits.

The ETZ, Volume 56 (1935, page 313), brings a review by H. Neuhaus of the above paper, in which he comes to interesting conclusions regarding the occurrence of of faults and publishes a comparison with other EHT lines of which statistical data are available. These conclusions will, no doubt, be of value when read in conjunction with the original paper and the reply to the discussion, and may be summarised in the following: —
I am honoured by your President's invitation to join in the discussion on M. Pask's important contribution to your Transactions, which raises many points of interest.

The main purpose of this paper is to propose the formation of a South African Association for the study of lightning and allied phenomena. Secondly, to discuss the scope of such an association. Thirdly, to discuss the obligations and limitations of this Institute towards the proposal, and to suggest how the Institute may help to give expression to the idea.
The paper reviews those system characteristics which influence the impulse withstand level of power transformers and outlines the trends in basic insulation levels of recent e.h.v. systems.

A turbulence chamber suitable for optical propagation experiments was developed using off-the-shelf components. It attempts to physically simulate atmospheric turbulence under laboratory conditions. A description of the chamber is presented as well as a characterisation of the turbulence. An application example of image degradation/restoration is also given.
ieee_keywords: ['Temperature measurement', 'Integrated optics', 'Optical imaging', 'Wires', 'Optical refraction', 'Wind speed', 'Heating systems']

abstracts: A computer-based system for undertaking complete functional testing of subscriber cards on the Zimbabwe telephone network is described. The hardware simulates the actions of both the exchange and the subscriber, and is controlled by software through a digital interface to a personal computer. The resulting system has been tested in the production environment, and demonstrated a testing speed increase of about twenty times compared with the manual method previously used.

This project arose from the need for an autonomous controller to test user CAMAC modules in an operating multicomputer, multibranch, multicrate CAMAC system. A block schematic of the CAMAC system is shown in Fig 1.1. The module is required to issue a series of commands A(i 1 ) F(i 2 ) to a user address B(i 3 ) C(i 4 ) N(i 5 ) and to make both conditional and unconditional branches.

This paper presents a split-phase induction generator employing a sinusoidal pulse width modulation (PWM) inverter connected across the auxiliary winding as a static var source. This scheme has the advantage of using the magnitude modulation and the phase angle control of the inverter to regulate and keep the output voltage and frequency constant. The scheme is analyzed using system equations derived from an equivalent circuit based on d-q-o transformation in stationary reference frame. The equations are expressed in terms of flux linkages, and the magnetic saturation of the magnetizing path is modeled by expressing the reciprocal of the instantaneous magnetizing inductance as a function of saturated air gap (magnetizing) flux linkages. The final results are compared with those measured on a practical machine.

Rhodesia depends primarily on electricity for its energy. The manufacturing and mining sectors presently consume more than 70 per cent of the total electrical energy in Rhodesia. These two facts indicate the importance of planning in the electrical energy sector so that the economy's progress is not hindered by a shortage of energy especially at the electrical sector does not possess significant energy storage capability and that it takes considerable time to place new generating plant in operation. The model described in the paper forecasts the future electricity demand for Zimbabwe Rhodesia. The first part of the study deals with economy relationships and forecasts the outputs of the different sectors. The second part deals with energy-economy relationships and forecasts the electrical energy demand based on the forecasts of the first part. Two forecasts are obtained; optimistic and pessimistic. The average of the two forecasts shows that Zimbabwe Rhodesia will need more than four times its present electrical generating capacity by the turn of the century.
With the exception of slow motion; 8-24 hour recording instruments, it is difficult to obtain time-displacement recorders locally.

I am very honoured at having been elected as your President. That being so, I am prompted to make the almost customary dedication that I will do my best to further the interests of the Institute in all its activities and to try to maintain the high standard with which our affairs have been conducted in the past. I am conscious that this will be a difficult task, particularly in view of the events of the Jubilee Year which has just passed. This was an outstanding year in all respects, for which the credit must go largely to Mr Rupert Gettliffe who, if I may be allowed to echo sentiments already expressed, worked with energy and zeal to accomplish the desired end. It is my duty now to see that we return to normal whilst at the same time to see that we profit by the spirit which made last year so successful.

Many researchers tend to employ analysis/synthesis techniques in the coding of speech for use in cochlear implants (bionic ear). In systems employing 6 or 8 electrodes, as in the system described in this paper, the non-linearity of the stop consonants suggests that other features may be utilized for their synthesis. An alternative strategy to analysis/synthesis, is the recognition/synthesis strategy, which is proposed in this paper. We propose a strategy in which a linear mapping of the speech spectrum onto the cochlea is used in the case of vowels, while non-linear recognition/synthesis is used in the case of the stop consonants. Such a strategy ensures that the stop consonants always sound the same and are thus easier for the patient to learn, provided that a correct recognition is performed. Very promising results were obtained and it even suggests the possibility of creating a natural sounding cochlear prosthesis.

Various integral based least-squares methods which identify the coefficients of continuous-time differential equation models from sampled data have been proposed. The behaviour of three of these methods is investigated under practical experimental conditions. Recommendations are given as to the use of the various methods.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Delays', 'Nonlinear filters', 'Maximum likelihood detection', 'Data models', 'System identification', 'Filtering']

abstracts: A brief discussion of the Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) concept is given, with specific reference to the user interface (U-interface). Codes that were considered for the North American ISDN and similar new multilevel line codes that comply with strict transmission channel input restrictions are discussed briefly. A short description of the experimental set up, used to evaluate the new multilevel line codes, is given. Measured eye patterns and spectra of the new multilevel line codes are presented and compared with the line code 2B1Q, which was proposed for North American applications.

An intelligent tool for the design of linear control systems has been built by combining an expert system with a recently developed numerical design technique. The expert system assists the designer in formulating a comprehensive and achievable specification, and in dealing with any constraint conflicts which may arise. The use of the design system by undergraduate students is also examined.

This paper deals with the use of an expert system in the comprehensive design process, in particular for the design of squirrel cage induction motors. A comprehensive design evaluation package had previously been developed and it was felt that the expert system could lead a novice in design to produce meaningful input data for the design of a machine of his choice. This paper describes the expert system and shows how easily induction motors can be successfully designed by being guided by the knowledge base included in the expert system. The value of such systems as a teaching aid is illustrated.

The theoretical performances of the class E amplifier/multiplier with RF choke have been previously obtained under the assumption of an infinite inductance of the RF choke. This paper examines the influence of the RF choke inductance on the class E amplifier/multiplier, giving an explicit design criterion for the RF choke inductance.

A broad review of software renewal as part of the overall software system life-cycle, software maintenance and software reusability is undertaken. The results of an investigation into the current state of software system renewal in South Africa are presented and the implications discussed.

The honour of being the first electrical engineers' organisation in the Transvaal, and the first large one in South Africa, rests with the long since defunct South African Society of Electrical Engineers, founded in May, 1897.

This paper assesses the performance of commercially available systems, noting their strengths and weaknesses and proposes a novel system offering superior performance. The criteria defining the system performance are presented, with particular emphasis placed on an assessment of the volumes of detection. A novel volume of detection offering superior features is discussed along with the horn-lens fed cylindrical reflector antenna combination required to establish this. Comparative tests performed on the new system and a common system using a cheese antenna are given. It is shown that the new volume of detection offers substantial advantages in terms of the important system criteria. Several results from the field trial of the prototype are included to emphasise the substantial improvements, both financial and in performance, of the new system over commercially available systems presently in use.
author_keywords: ['Microwave intrusion detection system', 'horn-lens combination', 'shaped cylindrical reflector', 'volume of detection']

abstracts: Describes improvised apparatus for detecting midget submarines, installed at Durban harbour entranco in 1942. The entrance to this harbour is bet.ween two parallel breakwatBrs some 1 ] 00 yards long and 250 yards apart. Two loops of 6-coro submarine cable each 150 feet wide were laid acros.., the channel with a spacing of 700 foet between cent,ros. Theso two loops of six turns each are connected in opposition, with a Grassot fluxInoter in shunt. A deflection of the fluxmeter is convcrt.t:\d to an audible warning by means of a photo tube, amplifier relay and alarm bell. A midget submarine 50 feet long entering at 3 knots will produce an indication of some 10 seconds duration when ovor either loop; and these indications will be separated by an interval of 110 seconds duration while the submarine is between the two loops. Depth chargo throwers were mounted on the breakwater to doal with any submarino detected.

A model has been formulated and discussed for use in the future planning of higher education. The model incorporates econometric constraints and the goals of education. Unlike other models the model developed in this paper is incremental in nature and contains an updating factor which is analogous to inserting a feedback loop. The model is intended for realistic short term forecasting which is in line with present day needs of accelerated change.

Since the high speed reclosing of feeder circuits has become common, due to the development of the automatic restoring circuit breaker, it has been thought desirable that the electrical circuit to the load should he kept closed during these short interruptions. It is not surprising, therefore, that several such devices have been put on the market. These devices mainly depend on clockwork mechanisms for their time-delay.

An antenna for integrated use with the Non-Radiative Dielectric Waveguide is described. The polyrod radiator is fed by a dielectric waveguide which extends without interruption from the NRD-guide. A tapered section is used to accomplish both impedance and mode matching.
ieee_keywords: ['Dielectrics', 'Antennas', 'Microwave theory and techniques', 'Microwave circuits', 'Microwave integrated circuits', 'Microwave propagation', 'Microwave antenna arrays']

abstracts: The functions, specification and operation of a platform for the development of network service applications is described. Such applications are used to incorporate networking functions, such as bridging and network management into bridging devices in an internet. This provides the internet with autonomous intelligence distributed throughout the internet. The internet platform and application approach is unique in internetworking since it enables specific services or profiles to be handled as internet services rather than Application Layer services. The two novel applications described are innovative router-repeater bridging and direct multi-LAN traffic monitoring.

On reading through the list of papers read before this Institute since 1920, I cannot trace a single paper dealing exclusively with the subject of Electric Accumulators. A few references were made to accumulators in a paper read by Mr. Cyril T. Cocks in 1922, entitled “Some Train Lighting Systems,” and in a paper by Mr. Hotting, entitled “Electric Light and Power Supply Schemes for Moderate-size Towns in South Africa,” read before this Institute in 1926. Mr. Cocks, inter alia, says “the subject of accumulators is a large one and cannot adequately be treated in the comparative few lines that are allotted to it in this paper”.

After touching upon the original Boolean algebra, which was developed about 1847 for the study of logical propositions and syllogisms, the paper goes on to discuss the ways in which the algebra may be adapted to describe the behaviour of electrical switching circuits.

It was with interest I read the paper by Mr. Keller introducing a discussion on lead accumulators, and I think a word of congratulation is due to the author for introducing this very important but neglected electrical engineering unit. Batteries have failed after a few years of service through, in a majority of instances, ignorance and neglect, and I have often heard engineers say that they would not have a battery in the place, as it is too much trouble to look after them, I would like to outline from my point of view what I consider some of the most important points in the maintenance of a battery, I am not going to touch on the technical and chemical details, but more or less try and deal with some of the practical points for maintenance. The most important point to my way of thinking is the steps to be taken when a battery is to be installed new. On the question of erection, in the majority of instances the details are supplied by the makers, detailing the stands, insulators, separators, etc. The battery may be well fitted together, and its electrical connections may be all that is desired, but when this is all done the point is, and the most important point is, what is put into the battery in the way of acid and water. One cannot emphasize too much the correct chemical contents of these two items. If proper attention is not given in the smallest detail to the correct electrolyte, then the battery must suffer in the years to come, and no matter how careful one may be after, the battery is sure to suffer should any trace of iron, etc., be left in the electrolyte.

Principal Raikes, Mr. President, Col. Collins, Ladies and Gentlemen. — The paper which I am reading to-night deals with a subject which has been shrouded in secrecy ever since its development as a weapon of war, and in its applications and intimate technical detail the subject still remains a closely guarded military secret. The general principles are, however, fairly well known and their discussion involves no breach of security. For this reason, permission has been granted for the reading of the paper at this meeting. The paper is obviously limited in scope, but I hope that it may, nevertheless, be of some interest, even though its value as a technical contribution to the records of the Institute will be small. As the whole of this paper is not for publication, I must ask members and visitors please to refrain from taking down any notes during or after the lecture.
I have listened with interest to the paper read by Mr. Flugge-de-Smit on the ventilation of the pump motors situated underground, and have prepared these few notes which may prove of interest.

Members will, no doubt, recollect that the original title of the paper was worded somewhat differently, namely “The Ventilation of Motors in Confined Spaces.” The alteration to the title does not appear at all important, and yet there are two subtle differences Firstly, when your Council suggested the alteration to the title in order to widen the scope for discussion, the writer accepted with glee as he assumed, naturally enough, that someone more competent than himself would be asked to wind up the discussion. It was with considerable diffidence therefore that the task of replying to the discussion was undertaken. Secondly, as will be shown later, a portion of the paper would have been presented in a slightly different fashion to conform to the altered title.

The Aim of this paper is to examine the causes of insulator pm corrosion on d.c. insulators, and to this end experiments were conducted to determine the relative effect of different contaminations on leakage currents, in the presence of moist atmospheres. Further experiments were performed to explain the presence of brush discharge and to examine a few methods of alleviating pin corrosion. It was learned from these experiments that salt was the most important contaminating factor, soot a lesser factor and an acid film the least important factor. The average type of contamination acquired m service, containing neither visible salt nor soot, was of a nature intermediate between a pure salt and a pure soot film. It was thought that brush discharge occurred because of the contaminated condition of the underside of the insulator. With regard to preventive measures it was found that an insulating coat over the pin proved effective experimentally in reducing leakage current, but this has been found unsatisfactory in practice. Conversely a method found to be effective in operation, namely, that of surrounding the base of the pin with a lead washer, did not, under laboratory conditions, reduce leakage current. The conclusions reached were that load washers prevent corrosion by providing an alternative source of metal for electro-deposition; in addition the lead itself is inert to acid or atmospheric corrosion. It was thought that corrosion could be reduced by setting the pin in lead and by increasing the leakage distance of the upper portion of the insulator.

In conducting an investigation on a subject of this nature, the authors have attempted to obtain information relating to conditions met with in practice, and to apply it to what might be termed a “Standard of Safety”.

The presence of a two pole force wave in the airgap of a machine having a frequency matching one of the resonant frequencies of the mechanical structure is investigated. It is shown that when this condition is satisfied, noise and vibration and airgap variations occur giving rise co additional harmonic emfs in the windings.

Mr. President and Gentlemen, Although this branch of the subject does not receive as much notice as the protection of power systems, it is just as important in its own sphere, in as much as it is necessary to protect the delicate and expensive apparatus at the ends of the line, as well as to prevent undue distortion of signals.

I was very much interested by the paper on crystal rectification by Messrs. Damant and Cousins. One of the reasons for this is that I am at present carrying out experiments on crystal rectification in connection with certain research I am engaged upon.
In presenting a reply to the discussion on our paper on crystal rectification, the authors have much pleasure in thanking those gentlemen who have brought forward the results of their own experience.

This investigation of the paints used on the bases of transmission line poles was carried out at the suggestion of Mr. E. L. Damant, of the Electricity Supply Commission, with the object of finding the effect of the paint on the footing resistance. Seven paints used by the Electricity Supply Commission (Natal Central Undertaking) were supplied through Mr. E. L. Damant. The paints were the following

Meteor Burst Communication Links offer the facility for transmitting data via trails of ionised particles, which form continually as meteors enter our atmosphere. Unfortunately, this propagation medium is exposed to countless external disturbances, and is therefore inherently noisy. Most commercial systems have overcome this difficulty by means of Automatic Repeat Request (AHQ) protocols, where received frames containing errors are simply retransmitted. This paper investigates the viability of an alternative system, viz. the Forward Error Correcting (FEC) protocol, where sufficient redundancy is inserted at the transmitter to enable correction of the noise-corrupted bits by the receiver. An accurate simulation of the complete link was implemented in software (C), effectively modelling the encoding, modulation, noise-corruption, demodulation and decoding processes. Four coding schemes were examined (Reed-Solomon, Golay, Viterbi and Iwadare), and comprehensive testing was performed using live trail data. Analyses of our results and tentative conclusions are presented.
author_keywords: ['Meteor Burst Communication (MBC)', 'meteor-scatter', 'Forward Error Correction (FEC)', 'Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ)', 'Reed-Solomon Code', 'Golay Code', 'Viterbi Code', 'Iwadare Code']

abstracts: With reference to the contribution to the discussion on the above paper by Mr. M. J. Grimrod, the following description of an earth resistance tester using the zero method is furnished.

During the past few years, a number of papers have been delivered by Students before this Institution on the subject of earth resistance and the earthing of systems. Their main object has been the investigation of phenomena and problems connected with the earthing of systems, and much valuable data has been collected. The subject has by no means been exhausted, however, and the authors of this paper decided to compare the methods employed for making earthing resistance measurements, It was felt that information on this aspect of the subject might prove of some practical value. The object of this paper, therefore, is to correlate various methods of measuring earthing resistances, and to investigate their relative accuracy.
ieee_keywords: ['Earth', 'Immune system', 'Resistance', 'Electrical resistance measurement', 'Current measurement', 'Transmission line measurements', 'Electric potential']

abstracts: Sequence discriminators have been proposed for use as wide-band quadrature phase shift networks. This article briefly describes the operation of these networks, and derives an expression for the phase shift of a simple RC sequence discriminator. Equiripple quadrature phase shift networks were designed using this expression, and their actual responses compared against the theory. A set of design curves giving equal phase error off quadrature for different bandwidths and network sizes is presented. The sensitivity of these networks were investigated using Monte Carlo analysis and the results summarised. On the basis of these results, a design rule giving the least sensitive network configuration is presented. An active variation of the network is investigated and shown to have a far lower sensitivity.

ieee_keywords: ['Immune system', 'Electrical resistance measurement', 'Voltage measurement', 'Potentiometers', 'Surface resistance', 'Standards', 'Current measurement']

abstracts: When suggesting to Professor Randall the investigation undertaken by the authors one could foresee ninny obstacles in the way of obtaining quantitative results, but one hoped that as a result of the investigation one would obtain some useful information in regard to the manner in which conductors become burnt or damaged as a result of arcing. The authors are to be congratulated on the thorough manner in which they tackled the investigation. It is unfortunate that owing to insufficient time and power they were not in a position to push their investigation sufficiently far for the results to be of general use in solving the problem as to the maximum arcing time allowable on overhead conductors without serious damage being done to these.
These notes detail an unusual operating problem which recently occurred on the V.F. amp; T.P. Company's system, and discuss a special operating combination evolved to overcome the difficulty.

It is not very many years ago that the corrosion of metals was considered, more or less, as an unavoidable evil, but the enormous field for saving directed the attention of the world's scientific workers to this subject, with the resultant development of the electro-chemical theory of corrosion, which is now generally accepted as the one best explaining a multitude of facts concerning the corrosion of metals. This theory suggests that all corrosion is due to the flow of current through an electrolyte connecting the anodic and cathodic areas. It is not the intention of this paper to discuss metallic corrosion in general, but to outline briefly that small, although important section of the problem which affects the life of buried metallic structures, such as cable sheaths, water and gas pipes, concrete reinforcing, etc., and which is commonly known as “Electrolytic Corrosion.”

During the pose-war period, especially during the decade 1965-1975, the spectacular increase in demand for all types of telecommunication service in South Africa highlighted the inadequacy of the national telephone network. The mounting difficulties experienced by the average telephone user are examined. The steps taken by Management in the Western Cape to overcome the problems in that Region's automatic telephone switching system are outlined. Brief reference is made to future electronic switching equipment which is designed to avoid the many problems inherent in the existing electromechanical systems.

Discrete and partially integrated implementations of shift registers for transferring charge from one capacitor to another are well known. (1,2,3,4,5) In 1970 (6) the first integrated device for complete charge transfer called a ‘charge-coupled device’ was announced. In the six years intervening, the development of the charge-coupled device has proceeded at a prodigious rate leading to new applications in signal processing and optical imagers. CCD signal processors are of both digital and analogue versions. CCD digital memories are becoming competitive with RAM's.

An aid for the blind was developed based on the method whereby bats distinguish objects. Apparatus for transmitting ultrasonic pulses and detecting reflections was constructed. Encouraging results were obtained but more development is necessary to obtain a practical device.

A concept is presented which significantly reduces both the time and cost involved when custom bipolar monolithic integrated circuits are designed and manufactured, and which is of special interest when the quantities to be produced are relatively small. Various features of the recently developed uncommitted circuit are described, also aids to enhance its usefulness to designers.

American cities are giving renewed attention to what is, for them at least, a new weapon in the fight against traffic congestion and pollution: public transportation. Until the 1960s most transit systems in the United States were privately owned and managed. City after city has had to take over the financially ailing system, improve services, and try to halt or reverse the decline in commuter usage.

In this paper an attempt is made to explain a wide variety of observed Interference phenomena by means of a theoretical model. A system is analysed in terms of an interference source circuit, an interference receiving circuit and the possible couplings which can exist between the two. Simple equivalent circuits are proposed and the transfer of interference from source to receiver is analysed by means of frequency transfer function techniques. It is shown that earth structures play a very important role in these situations and the role of earth connections, screens etc in suppressing interference is analysed.

In this paper an attempt is made to explain a wide variety of observed Interference phenomena by means of a theoretical model. A system is analysed in terms of an interference source circuit, an interference receiving circuit and the possible couplings which can exist between the two. Simple equivalent circuits are proposed and the transfer of interference from source to receiver is analysed by means of frequency transfer function techniques. It is shown that earth structures play a very important role in these situations and the role of earth connections, screens etc in suppressing interference is analysed.

The paper describes work done towards the construction of a two dimensional analogue field plotter, where the field to be investigated is modelled in electrically conducting paint on conductive paper, or represented by an electrolytic tank. The detecting head of the device moves along any preselected equipotential in the analogue field, and the lines are reproduced on an X-Y recorder, By repeating the process line by line the entire field can be resolved. The process is semi-automatic, in that a preselected line will be followed automatically, but successive lines are selected manually. The movement of the detecting head is controlled from a mini-computer which has as input error signals from the probes on the head.

A few years ago Esaki (1) investigated the effects of heavy doping of a semiconductor junction. The results obtained, contrary to expectation, produced a semiconducting device with a negative resistance characteristic, which could be used as a simple series element to reduce damping in an oscillatory circuit. The correct choice of elements could thus lead to a sinusoidal steady state oscillation.

This paper analyses the transient and steady state behaviour of a three phase induction motor supplied from a current source inverter. It replaces the blocks of stator current by a truncated Fourier series and evaluates the required number of harmonics to use in order to ensure acceptably accurate results. Rectangular as well as trapezoidal blocks of stator current are considered and the results show that the torque pulsations due to trapezoidal current waveforms are smaller than those due to rectangular current waveforms. Commutation circuits in the inverter could therefore be used to ensure required trapezoidal waveforms in order to ensure certain reduced torque pulsations.

The analysis of a hybrid photovoltaic (PV) and single-phase induction generating scheme suitable for producing both controllable load voltage and frequency is the theme of this paper. This scheme has a potential utility in industrial and commercial applications, and in utility as an embedded generator. A battery connected across an array of (PV) cells is connected to a bi-directional, single-phase PWM inverter feeding the auxiliary winding of the induction generator. It supplies the generator reactive power, with the battery either absorbing excess power provided by the turbine or supplying deficit power to meet the active power demand of the load connected to the main winding. This paper presents the dynamic and steady state models for analyzing this scheme and reports the findings of the experimental and analytical cum computer simulation works undertaken to establish the performance characteristics of the generator. Parametric studies useful for optimal design and operation of the scheme are also discussed.
author_keywords: ['Single-phase induction generator', 'Photovoltaic system', 'Inverter', 'Renewable energy generating system']

abstracts: Results of a numerical analysis, using the finite element technique, on a polarizer designed for an S-band slotted waveguide array are presented. The polarizer consisted essentially of an array of waveguides of parallelogram cross-section, with the acute angle 45 degrees. The polarizer had poor axial ratio and the purpose of the analysis was to determine the parametric dependence of the axial ratio on the acute angle. The optimum value for the angle was found to be approximately 39 degrees. With the angle 45 degrees the predicted axial ratio was approximately 1 dB, assuming no phase error. Problems encountered with the finite element technique are also discussed.
ieee_keywords: ['Finite element analysis', 'Electric fields', 'Cutoff frequency', 'Rectangular waveguides', 'Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions', 'Waveguide components', 'Radar antennas']

abstracts: The influence of atmospheric variables on the radio refractive index is discussed. The distribution of the atmospheric refractive index in time and space influences radio system planning through it's effect on the effective earth radius and hence the received signal strength, wanted or interfering. It is suggested that standard practice in relating the effective earth radius to the refractivity gradient over the first kilometre of the troposphere may not be appropriate in all cases and that this has implications for frequency management and radio system planning.

In this paper the influence of a particular snubber circuit on voltage source inverter loads is investigated. The switching transients of an inverter leg, equipped with the turn-on and turn-off snubber as proposed by Undeland and Marquardt, are analyzed for the completely regenerative case. The results are used to calculate the asymmetrical output voltages of a three phase inverter. The implications of the asymmetry for motor drives are discussed. The relative importance of dead time and the influence of snubber circuits on output voltage distortion are treated. The results are confirmed by measurements.

The paper presents a method for analysing the dynamic and transient behaviour of synchronous generators in a multigenerator power system. The method describes the generator as well as the transmission network by their nonlinear two-axis equations, thereby allowing for the effects of shunt and series capacitive network elements. It is completely general and is not only applicable to a predetermined network configuration. The nonlinear equations are linearized in order to carry out an eigenvalue analysis of the system's small signal stability. A computer program has been developed which allows the user simply to specify the network topology, loads and generators of the system. The program then automatically configures the network, sets up all the equations, carries out a load flow solution for steady initial conditions, and calculates the transient response. The results of a two generator case study show the effects of shunt loads and series capacitive elements on the system's response.

Torque vector control strategies on two different types of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machines (PMSM) are investigated, and the performance of a medium power (12 kW) highly responsive surface mount magnet PMSM is practically evaluated under dynamic operating conditions. The machine is fed by a developed oversized 30 kVA PWM current controlled voltage source inverter. The effect of saturation of the inverter at high motorspeeds on the dynamic performance of the drive is discussed and practically verified. The dynamics of the drive is simulated and compared to its performance under operating conditions.
ieee_keywords: ['Torque', 'Rotors', 'Magnetic flux', 'Machine vector control', 'Stator windings', 'Permanent magnets', 'Mathematical model']
author_keywords: ['Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine', 'Torque Vector Control', 'Digital Signalprocessor control', 'PWM Current Control', 'Inverter Saturation']

This paper is intended to provide an introduction to a workshop on the application of ac drives in transportation. AC drives in this paper means drives with polyphase revolving field machines such as induction motors or synchronous motors.

VHF television signals along the Cape West Coast are often degraded by fading and/or ghosts. The problem is analysed from recorded signal strength data and a theory is developed that ducting, caused by a sloping temperature inversion, is the propagation phenomena causing the undesired effects. A meteorological explanation for the effect is given.
ieee_keywords: ['Antenna measurements', 'Ducts', 'Meteorology', 'Fading channels', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Reflector antennas', 'Receiving antennas']

abstracts: The methods and algorithms of the amplitude distribution synthesis used for increasing the Wireless Power Transmission (WPT) efficiency are discussed. It is shown that WPT efficiency increases not only at the uniform or taper distribution but also when the field intensity is raised at the edges of the radiating apertures. In this case the receiving antenna (rectenna) is illuminated uniformly enough and the level of the near side lobes is essentially decreased. Peculiarities of requirements on the field are described. Some numerical results concerning the optimal field distributions on the antenna and in the rectenna plane are presented.

A computer controlled system for the automatic acquisition of cylindrical near-field data is described. Also presented are radiation patterns for an E-plane horn antenna obtained by cylindrical wave transformation of near-field data, by direct measurement and by theoretical analysis using GTD.

abstracts: This paper presents Meteor-burst Communications (MBC) as a viable alternative to radio-telephone and satellite communications for rural environments. The basic principles of MBC operation are presented along with the system considerations for successful rural communications. The cost-effectiveness and performance of MBC systems in rural applications is presented. The M-LINK rural MBC system is described.

abstracts: This paper describes the theory of moving-target-indication (MTI) radar, and how this can be implemented using charge-coupled devices (CCD), or digital shift registers. A weighted 2-pulse canceller with a fixed pulse repetition frequency (PRF) is analysed in detail.

abstracts: A recently proposed extended Huygens' principle for scattering objects in waveguide is reviewed. This technique allows the coupling of a Finite Element discretization with a quasi Method of Moments (MM) surface element approach. Perfectly conducting posts are considered as test cases. Implementational details are discussed and results for the conducting post are presented.

abstracts: The intensive research work into Surface Acoustic Wave (SAW) technology over the last decade has introduced many new possibilities to the system designer. Currently most of the major electronic systems firms in the USA and a large number in Europe, have some research effort devoted to SAW. The aim of this paper is to indicate some of the application areas of SAW devices both in the military and civil fields with specific reference to radar and communication applications.

abstracts: As an introduction to this paper it is proposed to give a brief description of some of the apparatus used, and a general outline of the construction and performance of the photoelectric devices should be of interest.

There are severe limitations to the connection end location of the coils of a tutor winding so that they produce a satisfactory revolving field. The influence of these restrictions can be formulated in terms of modulating functions which yield a series of revolving field components. This technique is readily extended co solid state frequency and voltage converters in which the stator phase connections are continuously altered relative to the supply. Relationships are preserved which enable the calculation of the angular velocities and magnitudes of the revolving fields produced by a practical stator winding when excited by a fundamental and a series of harmonic voltages. Converter output voltages may be calculated and it is shown how motor currents may then be reconverted to find the supply currents.

This paper presents an overview on the lightning research and studies carried out by the Companhia Energética de Minas Gerais - CEMIG (Brazil), in its Lightning Research Programme. This Programme started with the measurement of the keraunic levels (number of thunderstorm days per year) and lightning current intensities on transmission, distribution and telecommunication towers, using magnetic links. Later the Programme was extended to include a lightning-flash counter network (cloud-to-ground flash densities), a lightning research station (Cachimbo Station) and a lightning detection and tracking system (LPATS). In parallel to this Programme, the CEMIG also undertook a systematic survey of soil resistivity and tower-footing resistances, as well as a survey on the lightning performance of power lines and telecommunication stations. The data obtained so far, especially from the research station and the tracking system, are considered as preliminary and are still being carefully analysed.

A transient suppression technique is presented for utilisation in channel simulators which are required to simulate very low fading rates. The fading is simulated by driving specially designed narrow band digital filters with two independent random Gaussian processes, resulting in a Rayleigh amplitude and uniform phase distribution of any signal subjected to (i.e. multiplied by) the outputs of the fading filters. Transients appearing at a filter output as a result of an input sequence before time k=0, when the simulator is switched on, hamper the effective use of the simulators. In this paper a systematic procedure is developed whereby the transients can be eliminated by specifying the initial conditions of the fading filters to ensure a stationary filter output at time k = 0. It is shown that this simple but effective transient suppression technique may also be used to incorporate random Frequency Hopping (FH) in existing fading channel simulators. A well known “step-down” procedure is employed to calculate a matrix which is multiplied by a vector of independent, zero mean, unit variance, Gaussian random variables to obtain the initial conditions of the narrow band fading filters. In order to emulate FH, the proposed algorithm is not only applied during the initialisation period of the channel simulator, but is thereafter re-executed whenever the simulator is required to emulate channel conditions at the next hopping frequency. Results are included to demonstrate that the detrimental effects of frequency hopping in digital communication systems can indeed be effectively and realistically emulated by this algorithm, without any sign of unwanted transient effects.
ieee_keywords: ['Transient analysis', 'Digital filters', 'Filtering theory', 'Filtering algorithms', 'Switches', 'Rayleigh channels', 'Mathematical model']
author_keywords: ['Transient suppression', 'channel simulation', 'frequency hopping', 'digital shaping filters', 'auto-regressive moving average (ARMA)']

abstracts: A gap exists between the technologies of the developed and underdeveloped regions. More important than simply closing this gap is to give technology a new direction that will make it appropriate to the realities of the world today. The engineer is the only person capable of designing this new technology.

A two dimensional Finite Element/Boundary Element (FE/BE) method for solving electromagnetic scattering from human cross-sections has been investigated, implemented, validated and used to investigate — approximately — the electromagnetic interaction of a manpack radio with its operator. Validation has been done by comparing results computed using analytical solutions for scattering from multi-layered right circular dielectric cylinders with line source excitation. The problem of a manpack antenna, which by definition radiates in the very close presence of the operator, has been approximated by a two dimensional model of a representative human cross-section with a line source radiating cylindrical waves modelling the antenna. From the FE/BE method solution one can obtain approximations of the near fields in and around the human cross-section, as well as the far-fields. This enables one to calculate the power dissipated in the human cross-section (the effect of the radio on the operator) as well as the influence of the human cross-section on the far-field pattern of the line source (i.e., the effect of the operator on the radio). We comment on possible applications to radiation hazard evaluation for personnel, and also outline further work required in this field.
ieee_keywords: ['Finite element analysis', 'Antenna radiation patterns', 'Mathematical model', 'Computational modeling', 'Finite difference methods', 'Nonhomogeneous media', 'Material properties']

abstracts: I propose to speak to you this evening about the conduct of an arbitration. And the first thing I want to say is that an arbitration court is a court of law and must be conducted in accordance with the law. It is not a court of equity and the award must be based on the evidence, not on a (possibly mistaken) idea of what is fair. By saying that the arbitration court is a court of law I do not mean that strict court procedure, i.e. the Supreme Court rules, must be followed.

In general arbitration can be described as the reference of a dispute to a person chosen by the parties for the final adjudication of that dispute. While this definition is not complete, it does contain the generally accepted elements of the process. The important fact is that the parties do not employ the usual courts of law, but an adjudicator, the arbitrator, as distinct from a magistrate or judge.

The general problem of neutral earthing on a high-voltage network is briefly considered. The behaviour of a system earthed through an arcsuppression coil is studied for single-phase fault and the effect of coil tuning on the fault suppression efficiency of the coil discussed. Neutral voltages due to capacity unbalances and also the influencing effect of adjacent parallel lines are analyzed. Applications of arc-suppression coils to th 20-, 40- and 88-kV systems of the Victoria Falls and Transvaal Power Co., Ltd., are discussed and difficulties encountered with the application of unit coils to part of an 88-kV transmission network described. Statistics are given of the operating experience with the coils.

This paper presents an explanation on the method of torque production of the rolling rotor motor. Making use of an internal electromechanical speed reduction mechanism this motor is able to produce a high direct torque without the use of a gearbox. The rotor is free to roll around the inside of the stator without bearings restraining it to a fixed axis. Attention is drawn to the robustness and simplicity of the motor, making it ideal for low cost applications, where a large torque at low speeds is required from a compact gearless construction. A finite element analysis was also performed on the motor which gave valuable design considerations.

This paper describes the control system at a pump storage scheme and highlights some of the differences between this system and the controls at conventional power stations. it also describes a custom-built Vectormeter which, as far as we know, is a world-first.

The paper outlines some of the components and techniques available to a network engineer in the design of precision and stable networks with emphasis on stabilization techniques used in carrier transmission networks. Recent developments in methods of obtaining pan-climatic components are discussed and illustrated.

The paper outlines some of the components and techniques available to a network engineer in the design of precision and stable networks with emphasis on stabilization techniques used in carrier transmission networks. Recent developments in methods of obtaining pan-climatic components are discussed and illustrated.

The conversion of an existing petrol vehicle to a battery-driven electric vehicle is described with special reference to the method of speed control. The real performance of the vehicle is compared with the theoretically expected performance, and discrepancies are discussed.

This is a companion paper to one recently published in which benchmark tests were described for the evaluation of LV distribution voltage drop calculation procedures. Monte Carlo simulations are often used when the calculation procedure is based on a probabilistic approach. Many calculation procedures in electrical distribution engineering have been verified using Monte Carlo simulations as a standard. This paper shows that for voltage drop calculations significant inaccuracies may result from this method and that it should be applied with caution
