abstracts: The introduction of the Static Transformer rendered an easy and simple method of producing high voltages, and with the advent of these comparatively high voltages the question of the Electric Transmission of Power received more attention than hitherto, until ultimately it was recognised that power could be transmitted long distances quite economically provided that the voltage was made sufficiently high. That is to say, it was soon recognised that the greatest economy could be effected by the use of high tension currents.

(Associate) : Mr. G. V. Adendorff in his paper says — "It is well known that there is no electric force within a closed conductor, and the obvious method then is to completely surround the line in a metallic shield." This statement, though quite correct when statical charges only are under consideration, is by no means so when dynamical charges are dealt with as in the case of lightning discharges. In order to be sure of this point I have performed experiments (under Professor Buchanan's guidance) in the laboratory of the School of Mines, using a Whimshurst machine and Leyden jars to produce a miniature lightning flash, of the type known as the "B" flash, to use Sir Oliver Lodge's nomenclature. The first experiment was to see if one wire from a tin plate was sufficient to protect a second earthed wire under the tin plate : AB being the tin plate : earthed by means of AC : DE being the wire it was required to protect. When DE was close to AB it was found that a spark could be obtained between E and AB. A second wire was added from B to earth, to make the earthing of AB more symmetrical, but still a spark could be obtained between E and AB. To make the experiment yet more conclusive, the wire ED was surrounded by a metallic conductor — a piece of steel pipe. The connections of the apparatus were as shown in the diagram, Pig. 2. The pipe was connected to the tin plate to which the knob D was fixed by means of three copper wires, the object being to leave a space through which the gap EF could be watched. An electrostatic voltmeter was connected across the small gap EF. On a spark occurring across AB, a "B" flash occurs between C and D, and a small spark can be obtained between E and F. Thus the wire is not protected, although surrounded by a closed metallic conductor. A momentary deflection is produced on the electrostatic voltmeter.

(Visitor): For the design of proper protective gear against lightning it is of the greatest importance to know, if lightning discharges are oscillatory or not, and if oscillatory, whether of high or low frequency. Opinions differ very much about this. Some investigators say, that the lightning is oscillatory and of very high frequency from 500,000 to several millions of cycles per second. Others say, that the lightning is oscillatory, but of a frequency never over 8,000 cycles ; and still others say, that the lightning discharges generally are unidirectional, seldom oscillatory, and if so not of very high frequency. There does not seem to be any doubt, that the lightning is a condenser discharge, and we know, as also pointed out by Mr. Adendorff, that the condition for such a discharge being oscillatory is, that the resistance of the conductor, along which the discharge takes place, must be less than

In replying to the discussion on my paper, I shall deal with them in the order in which they occurred In reply to the contribution of Mr. Kirkland I must first thank him for some illuminating remarks on lightning phenomena, although it seems that he is speaking from the American standpoint rather than that of local conditions. He makes two statements to which I must take exception, firstly, the capacity of a sphere is proportional to its radius and not to the square of its radius as he states, and secondly, I cannot agree with him that a lightning- flash one mile in length, is unheard of. He assumes that most discharges occur as an equalisation of potential from point to point in a cloud and not as in the case of a condenser bursting its dielectric. This seems to be the general opinion with American authorities, and I have no doubt he is quoting largely from their views. For instance, in a paper read before the N.E.L.A., June, 1907, by Dr. C. P. Steinmetz, I find the following statement: “Lightning flashes usually occur within thunder clouds and only rarely from cloud to cloud or from cloud to ground. This seems to sum up American opinion on the subject, but I do not agree with it—not for conditions existing in south Africa, at any rate.

Manufacturers of electric wire and cable in Australia will need to double their output in less than eight years to keep pace with the expanding local demand. The pace of national development is such that usage of cable and wire for domestic, industrial and commercial purposes is increasing by about 10 per cent each year.

The acquisition of rights by an employer in the inventions of his employees is a topic generally apart from the question of giving the employee-inventors rewards for making the inventions in issue. In the United Kingdom and the United States the vesting of the invention in the employer has usually been without reward to the employee-inventor. Likewise, in the case of the ‘shop right’, a licence has usually been royalty free. In Germany on the other hand a special statute governs the reward to be paid to employee-inventors. Reading Mr Adams' contribution one gains the impression that he would not be averse to the introduction of something similar to this country. He has similarly minded supporters among the ranks of professional engineers and patent attorneys. 1 personally prefer the working out of these problems through our common law rather than through the agency of a substantial bureaucracy which is almost certain to develop once a statute of this nature is brought into existence.
In reply, may 1 first thank the speakers for their very kind remarks and repeat that it has been a great pleasure to come to South Africa and speak to you.

It is indeed gratifying to receive, as well as a challenging task to respond to, the thoughtful and comprehensive comments that have been presented by the contributors to the discussion on this paper, and I am highly appreciative of their kind remarks and the extent and scope of their contributions.

In reply to Mr Baker the successful application of SF 6 as an insulant has naturally led to consideration of its use in transformers. There is however a fundamental difference in that the oil in a transformer performs the dual function of acting as an insulator and as a heat transfer medium. SF 6 can be used in transformers, but because of its relatively poor performance for heat transfer purposes, the transformer has to be designed with much lower thermal loading than a conventional oil-filled unit and therefore becomes prohibitively expensive.

It was clearly stated that one of the major objectives of the paper is to provide a simple explanation for the busy engineer in charge of winding ropes, and those interested in the subject as well as the instrument operator conducting electromagnetic rope tests, of the theory applicable to electromagnetic rope testing.

The author greatly appreciates the discussions by Messrs E F Raynham and M F Hadingham. As pointed out, South Africa and Sweden have much in common in the field of power transmission. Both countries have 420 kV networks in operation and are discussing the introduction of 800 kV. Sweden pioneered h.v.d.c. transmission, and South Africa, together with Mozambique, now has in operation the Cabora Bassa-Apollo line with the highest dc voltage used so far in the world. The successful operation of this line is very encouraging for the future of h.v.d.c. systems.

abstracts: Mr Howe suggests that in assessing step and touch voltages consideration should be given to assuming a man's weight to be 50 kg instead of 70 kg. This would obviously lead to lower permissible body currents and consequently the need for more elaborate and expensive earthing arrangements to ensure safety of personnel. Since there arc so many variables involved in calculations of body currents such as skin resistance, tolerance to electric shock, characteristics of crushed stone, soil resistivity and magnitude of fault current, and the typical parameters used for each variable represent the worst possible conditions we feel that the design criteria used are already very conservative. It hardly seems justified therefore to change the design basis to allow for what must surely be considered to be a below-average body weight.

I would like to thank Prof Hellawell for his remarks. He, however, seems to be pessimistic about the chances of survival of an electrode system in the final application of this method of beach protection. The eddy current electrode would be the obvious choice in this application as it merely consists of a single cable. Experience with communication submarine-cables show that their main source of damage is from trawling activities and dragging anchors. At a sandy beach they become covered by a few metres of sand which protects them against the destructive action of the breakers. The sand very rarely scours out to the ultimate depth of the cable and even then it is exposed for a short period only. Such deep scouring may lake place at roughly 5 year intervals only.

He suggests that complex caclulations involving numerous variables have to be made in respect of various design aspects such as corona and radio interference, thermal limits, and steady state and transient stability, to ensure that the optimum design is obtained.

It was not possible for me to cover any more than the system as it stands, if my paper tonight was not to be an excessively long one.

Professor Bozzoli has referred to the effect of humidity on discharges in voids in insulating materials. Humidity will doubtless play a part, but it is probable that gas impurities produced by a discharge will be even more important.

abstracts: Mr Brink worth has drawn attention to the subject of routine maintenance and testing of the governor and overspeed mechanisms. This matter is also mentioned by Mr Hosking and discussed in some detail by Mr Lodwick, with particular reference to the testing procedures adopted by the Johannesburg Electricity Department. No attempt was made to cover this subject in the paper, but I agree that it is a very important related topic. Their contributions in this connection are valuable and are appreciated.

I fully agree with the remarks made by Mr Doepel. It is clear that the tests made on a transient analyser should be improved, the better to reflect the different variable values. It is generally accepted that the appearance in the coming years of much more powerful data-processing machines than those presently available will help in the presentation of values on a transient analyser, at a reasonable cost.

Mr Jack raises the interesting point, that full use should be made of the properties of the polyimide armature winding insulation and states that the film has reversible properties above 200 °C. Increasing the normal maximum permissible temperature of the armature winding to a figure above 200 °C (BS 173 stipulates 185°C for class H insulation) means in effect an increase in the rating of the motor provided the ratings of the field system and commutator can also be increased. As the traction motors of the classes 6E and 6E1 locomotives already develop tractive efforts close to, and in excess of, the adhesion limits (depending on rail conditions), increasing the rating (and with it the hauled loads) means that more wheelslips will be encountered. However, the suggestion of operating a polyimide-insulated armature winding at normal maximum temperature in excess of 200 °C could result in considerable savings in a new design of traction motor. Regarding the class B bonding varnish used with mica in the insulation of the commutator segments, BS 173 stipulates a temperature rise, measured by thermometer, of 90 °C for commutators. Under test (short-time and continuous) the commutator temperature rises of the classes 6E and 6E1 traction motors were of the order of 65 °C. This leaves a fair reserve.
I would like to thank Dr Kühn for the interesting complementary material presented in his contribution.

The discussions following a paper are, to a large degree, a measure of the interest in the subject matter and the fact that so many contributors were present is most gratifying, as this serves to point out the latent and widening interests of persons in biomedical engineering.

I agree with Mr McCrossan that thyristors and transistors are only extra tools in the armoury of our control techniques and that other devices may still be suitable for some applications. However, I feel that the mining industry, which tends for very sound reasons to be conservative compared with some other industries in the field of control, should note what is happening in other industries. There is no doubt that the new semiconductor devices described tonight have almost superseded all other devices. In some cases it is because of fashion, but, in general, it is because the advantages in performance are self-evident and the expectation in reliability, although not yet fully proven, is not less than with other devices.

abstracts: The support for the network analyser voiced by Mr Smith is felt by many power system designers having ready access to a reliable network analyser. This is especially so if stability studies form a small part of the total work. For load flow and fault studies the digital computer has only marginal advantages, the most important being the elimination of the manual setting of the analyser units at the start of a study. As an educational tool the ac network analyser stands unchallenged and it may indeed be necessary to retain small analysers for training purposes even when all serious work is done by digital computers.

Professor Wessels would like to control the two excitations dependently, but as his diagrams do not show the field winding connections which forms a vital link in the argument, I am unable to understand fully his system and to offer detailed comment. At a first glance it would seem that more auxiliary equipment is needed, although his system may have an improved transient response.

Professor Bozzoli expressed concern that, despite enthusiasm on our part, there was a shortage of graduate engineers in the signalling field. One must remember that there are two types of engineer — the dedicated one, who will give all to the job, and the status one, who thinks only of the size of his salary or his prospects. A small government department cannot invite engineers in terms of rands and cents; it can only do so in terms of enthusiasm and dedication, and therefore our neighbours in commerce and industry will continue to attract graduates with salaries which are far above our modest means. It is significant, however, that, with graduates who enter the signalling field, resignation to enter some other field is virtually unknown.

abstracts: I agree with Mr Roberts that it is most unlikely that a tolerable level of PI) related to a given test voltage can be defined and found generally acceptable. His remarks about his experience has shown to be necessary to achieve a background level of 25 pc are most interesting and indicate that a PD test on a large high-voltage transformer is likely to be an expensive operation and therefore can only be contemplated as a development test or possibly a type test. His suggestions for a method of carrying out a PD test are very practical and in general I would agree with them, particularly the stipulation that there should be no measurable increase above the background level which should, I suggest, be specified (say 25 pe). Some discussion took place at the 1968 CIGRE meeting regarding the voltage value for such a test (120 percent or 150 per cent).

abstracts: A.W. Richards: To date very little work has been done on the problem of electrical equipment operating in areas where flammable or explosive substances that burn without an external oxygen source are present. The stability range of such materials is extremely wide and because of this it is difficult to prescribe equipment suitable for general use. Ideally, electrical equipment to be used in such areas should be tailored to suit the environment. In certain cases intrinsically safe equipment may be suitable but it must be borne in mind that the ignition energies of many explosive substances are well below those that may be released in most intrinsically safe circuits.

There is full agreement with the remarks made, and support should be given to the recommendation of close liaison between machine and brush manufacturers. If it is felt that a symposium should be developed, all possible assistance will be given.

Rothert Fig. A showing the comparison of loss factor of a bar taken from a machine after 20 years compared with a spare bar indicated without doubt the excellent thermo-mechanical properties of the coils. Unfortunately, it is not clear whether the bar taken from the machine was in fact a line or in close electrical proximity to a line coil. Had the coil been operating at a potential approaching that of the line coils the effect of discharges, if any, could then be verified without reserve.

First of all Mr Brinkworth asks why magnetic phase shift is used. I have described a well proven circuit which is in current use. Its rate of response is already higher than can be permitted from the point of view of rate of change of current which can be tolerated in machine armature circuits. We are already able to provide transistor control amplifiers for all sizes of phase shifters. The next stage is a semi-conductor type of phase shift circuit. This is developed and will be going into service in the near future. The advantage then will not be so much the fact that still faster phase shift is obtainable but that appreciably more sophisticated methods can be adopted. With very fast phase shift it is possible to dispense altogether with circulating current control on cross-connected rectifiers because immediate transference of current from, say, a rectifying to an inverting anode will be feasible.

Mr Lindley (in reply): I would like to thank Mr Bishop for his comments on the paper and for raising a number of interesting points. The ‘pebble-bed’ reactor is quite a fascinating theoretical concept but in my view suffers from a number or fundamental technical objections. To be economic a power plant must have an acceptable first cost, a satisfactory efficiency, moderate maintenance costs, and a high ‘availability’ (i.e. out of action only for maintenance, etc., for short periods of time in total per annum). If any of these four criteria is grossly violated then the system proposed is most unlikely to be satisfactory for electric power generation. With a plant of high capital cost it is particularly important that the availability should be high and maintenance costs low. The ‘pebble-bed’ plant with its highly radioactive coolant circuit, boilers, etc., will, I feel sure, show a disappointingly low availability and high maintenance costs. In addition to these problems there are a large number of technical difficulties in the design and control of the reactor which remain to be resolved.

To Mr N. M. Georgeson: It must be nearly thirty years ago that Prof. ‘D’ told me how much he suffered from boils on the neck which he had had since world war I. I remarked absent-mindedly that he should give up wearing his radio-active army watch. He did. The boils vanished and he sent me the watch as a present. I handed it back to the Professor some years later at a lecture given in the Physics Laboratory on the dangers of radio-active matter. Prof. ‘D’ never wore the watch again! Mr and Mrs ‘Y’ were engaged some twenty years ago and married 10 years later. They had an MG sports racing car specially fitted with four luminous dials on the dash. Between them the dials gave off over Ir per hour at short range. Mr and Mrs ‘Y’ were proved to be sterile, whilst Mr ‘Y’ has suffered from tummy pains for some years past. Cause not diagnosed!

Dr Hewitt asks whether my Company has published any independent data on the values of various types of terrain for producing a back scatter signal, but, as far as I know, they have not. Investigation of this phenomenon has been carried out for a long time and 1 think it is fair to say that investigation of back scatter on microwaves has been going on since the days of the H2S, which was about the earliest of the vertical incidence radar scanners used on aircraft. Since that time there has been quite a lot of work done, much of it by Government Departments or by firms under Government development contracts, and there have not been very many papers published. Of the papers used by my own organization, the first was produced by Wiltshire, Schlesinger and Johnson entitled “Backscattering Characteristics of the Sea” in the region of 10 to 15 000 megacycles”, that is to say from 2 cm to 30 metres. This was published in the “Proceedings of the I.R.E.”, an American Journal, in February 1957. A second paper was published in July, 1959, by Grant and Yattley on “Backscattering from water and land, centrimetric and milimetric wavelengths”, also in the Proceedings of the I.R.E., July, 1957, and J.P. Campbell also produced a paper on the same subject, April, 1958, which was published by the American Civil Aviation Aeronautical Organization, in April, 1958.

Mr Eagle (in reply): I would like to thank the two contributors very much for their remarks. The only things on which I might comment are, first of all, the suggestion that there are other subjects which should possibly go into the engineering syllabus. I myself would like to see more kinetic theory going into the syllabus. I would like to see more solid state go in — and I must emphasize that I have said very little tonight about solid-state devices but that there is a great deal more in the paper, particularly about thermocouples, which I hope will indicate what part the solid-state physicist is playing in the development of devices. I feel the stage is being reached where some consideration of solid-state structure and solid-state properties is an essential part of the engineering course, and it would begin to seem also that some study of plasmas is becoming an essential, or a near essential, feature of a course for engineers, particularly for electrical engineers.

Dr Posel (in reply): I thank Professor Heymann for the trouble he has taken in preparing his contribution to the discussion. In reply to his statement that a transient analysis of the parallel-T should have been given ab initio and thereafter the steady-state solution should have been extracted from it, I would like to give the following reasons which advocate, in my opinion, the presentation of the steady-state analysis first. The design of the parallel-T will invariably be approached from the viewpoint of the transfer sensitivity under steady-state conditions, and as a result of these considerations certain restrictions can be placed first on the magnitudes of network components and second, certain combinations of components may be grouped together. As an example of the former there is the finding that the value of R 1 should be made equal to that of R 2 , and as an example of the latter there arises the combination of network components which was denoted by “d”. Both of these findings emerged from the steady-state analysis and as a result thereof the transient analysis was given in a form more compact than that occurring if the latter investigation had preceded the former. Furthermore, if a reader wishes to use the parallel-T in the application indicated, and if transient analysis per se happens to be not to his liking, the design is accomplished from steady-state considerations with the assurance that the network behaves itself in the transient operation.

Mr Brummer has described the germanium and silicon rectifiers developed in the United States of America. In England too, silicon rectifiers are undergoing intensive development and experimental cells have been produced which are capable of operating at a d.c. output of 1 kW and a junction temperature of 200°C. The low reverse current of a silicon rectifier compared with that of a germanium rectifier does not seem to offer any practical advantage except in so far as it enables higher operating temperatures to be used. The reverse current of the germanium rectifier is already so low that it has little effect on the efficiency or heating. The possibility of detecting a failing silicon rectifier by the increase in reverse current is attractive; a method by which this can be done in an equipment having a large number of cells in series and parallel will be quite interesting to develop.

abstracts: I am very gratified by the interest shown in this paper. There is surely no better reward for me than to see that the subject has stimulated a discussion of this nature.

Mr Townsend has raised the important question of the safety of the apparatus when used in fiery mining situations. At the beginning of this development programme very little attention was paid to this matter largely because the apparatus was intended solely for use in the non-fiery Witwatersrand gold mines. However, since the development of the important Orange Free State gold mining area where fiery conditions do exist, it has been appreciated that safely precautions will have to be included in any future designs. Until very recently, when this apparatus was tested in a coal mine, it was not realized that this apparatus would be useful in such geological situations and consequently the apparatus was never designed for operation in these conditions.

Mr Barnard has pointed out that peak load reduction by consumers could materially change the shape of the ESCOM load curve. This is obviously true and if carried to the limit could lead to ESCOM having no requirement for peaking plant on its system. Whether this would be the most economic solution for the country as a whole has been debated in the pages of our Transactions and I do not propose to go further into this aspect. In practice I do not think that the ESCOM load curve will change significantly in the next few years but we will of course watch this situation carefully to ensure we do not provide more peaking plant than is economically iustified.

Mr Slatem has queried the oft repeated claim that h.v.d.c. links do not materially increase the receiving ac system fault level and has shown that the contribution from the Apollo star-delta converter transformers alone has raised the earth-fault current from 27 800 to 31 800 A, an increase of 14,4 per cent. While this is acknowledged the influence in this instance is of little consequence because the 275 kV switchgear has a specified single-phase breaking capacity 15 per cent larger than its three-phase breaking capacity.

abstracts: In reply to Mr Elkington's queries we can mention that there is a bright side to system disturbances in that they are extremely effective in reshuffling priorities enabling the power system to be examined from all angles.

Mr Basson has raised a very important point. The complex control systems envisaged in the paper must be very reliable otherwise the delays they cause will more than outweigh the advantages they introduce. To ensure a high degree of reliability and to minimize any downtimes, the availability of good maintenance and operating instructions is essential. Every effort is made to use equipment and schemes which are simple and reliable but nothing is 100 per cent reliable and the more components that there are the more likely it is statistically that there will be a failure. Therefore, the maintenance personnel must be trained and given every facility for instruction. In this direction we agree entirely with the idea of showing the actual build-up and principles employed by the designer in constructing the scheme. Short notes with skeleton diagrams can augment the normal instruction manuals.

It has been a surprise to see the amount of interest generated by what I had imagined to be a very specialised paper. I am most grateful for all the kind remarks, comments and criticisms offered by the various contributors.

Messrs Becker and Grayer make mention of the fact that in the machine tested the rotor bar impedance is of the same order as its resistance. They pointed out that this is not the case in the smaller machines that are typically found in a university laboratory and therefore results so obtained and “extrapolated” could be erroneous. The authors recognised that this could be the case and seeing that the emphasis was on large motors, all the measurements and experimental work described in this paper were thus carried out on large motors. However, as shown in reference 1 below, measurements were also performed on smaller laboratory machines and after having accounted for the different orders of the parameters, very good agreement was achieved between theory and measurement.

Development of communications on the Witwatersrand has necessarily followed the pattern of development in the country as a whole. As the most populated centre, however, it has sometimes led development and sometimes lagged behind that of other centres. Telecommunication technique is constantly changing and new experiments are continually being tried out, generally in one centre, and if successful the new methods arc applied to the country as a whole. The Witwatersrand has been the trial ground of many such experiments.

The contributors have raised a wide variety of questions, and the Authors ask their indulgence if these are answered in relation to subjects rather than with reference to individuals, dealing first with general dielectric phenomena and secondly with engineering matters concerning cable design, installation and operation.

We thank Messrs Breen, Harvey, Robertson, Ashworth, Titterington and Vose for their valuable written contributions and Messrs Brinkworth, Lineker, Brown, Bird, Dr Hewitt and Professor Cormack for their impromptu and interesting contributions to the discussion. As many of the questions asked were interrelated we have chosen to give a composite reply, followed by more detailed comments on the written contributions.

Professor J. M. Meek made the point, with which the authors concur, that the distance of 56 feet assumed for the length of a lightning leader side-flash which would approach a transmission line, might not be accurate. The emphasis on average conditions, perhaps, should have been more accentuated, whereby it would have been appreciated that 50 per cent of strokes having greater than average charges were likely to strike a transmission line from greater distances, and vice versa. The average peak current observed was used, together with assumptions as to the wave form, and critical disruptive gradient for air, to apply Golde's analysis, and the authors believe that these assumptions arc substantially correct, in view of the agreement with other observers over the approximate number of lightning strokes to ground. The calculations should, in any case, provide a greater measure of accuracy than so far achieved in evaluating the comparative performance of transmission lines of differing heights.

Mr Cheek has raised an extremely interesting point concerning the psychological reactions of most mechanical engineers to electronic control, particularly if this electronic control has invaded a domain previously occupied solely by mechanical devices. The only ultimate answer to this is the relative merit of each device. Does the electronic system perform its job more satisfactorily? Is it cheaper? Is it more reliable? If it does fail, does it fail safe? If, after a period of several years’ operation, the answer to all these questions is ‘yes’, then no reasonable person can really have any objection to the system.

The steam turbine governor of James Watt was the first automatic control developed by man. Automatic control is generally understood to mean closed loop control where information is fed around a loop. In the typical automatic control problem the variable to be controlled, called the ‘controlled variable’, is measured. This measurement is compared with a desired or reference value of the controlled variable and the difference or 'error“ is computed. The controller has this system error as its input and on the basis of this error varies the value of the controlling or 'manipulated' variable. This variable is the input to the system to be controlled, the output of the system being the controlled variable. The manipulated variable is varied by the controller so as to keep the controlled variable at or near its desired value. This desired value may be changing according to some schedule.

The reliability of high frequency radio telegraph systems has always been a limitation in international communications. Transmission errors are liable to result from the vagaries of propagation via the ionospheric transmission medium, and from interference. Until recently reliable service for public telegraph traffic has been achieved by high operating standards, with visual inspection of received messages, and correction of errors by repetition on request. This procedure results in poor circuit efficiency, and high operating costs. The demand for international telex and leased circuits in recent years has required the provision of circuits having high transmission accuracy. These demands have given considerable impetus to the development of error correcting telegraph systems. In 1956 at Warsaw the C.C.I.R. recommended the system developed by Doctor H.O.A. van Duuren of the Netherlands for international standardisation. Since that date equipment operating on the van Duuren principle has been installed on most important radio telegraph circuits.
ieee_keywords: ['Standards', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Reliability', 'Redundancy', 'Read only memory', 'Parity check codes', 'Modulation']

abstracts: The natural power factor of the electrical distribution system in that fantastic land served by the Oranjemund Power Station is a mere 0.5. There are a variety of good reasons why this figure should be so abysmally low, but the two chief causes are the persistent longevity of some of the old motors with large air gaps, and the necessity of having motors which occasionally, depending on weather conditions, have to operate at full load, but more often loaf.

One of the most important operations in the control of power station plant is that of connecting synchronous machines or a.c. networks in parallel. This operation is generally known as “synchronising“, and can usually be carried out only when the phase position, frequency and voltage of the two systems are as nearly identical as possible. If the respective generating systems have identical voltages and frequencies, the difference between their voltages at any given instant will be zero provided that their phase positions coincide exactly, but if the frequency is not exactly the same a resultant voltage — known as the beat voltage — varying cyclically between a maximum and zero will be produced. The frequency of the beat voltage gives a measure of the frequency difference between the two systems, and is commonly expressed as the “beat period” or time between two successive zero values on the curve. The beat period will increase in length the closer the respective frequencies become. When the phase displacement is zero, the beat voltage will be passing through zero at the same instant, provided that the two system voltages have the same amplitude. The ideal condition therefore for the perfect synchronising of two systems, whose respective frequencies are approximately the same, is that the breaker connecting the two systems closes at the exact moment when the beat voltage (and phase displacement) is zero. For a perfect understanding of all the conditions governing synchronising, it is essential to have very clearly in mind the distinction between frequency, phase position and voltage and how these influence the process of synchronising.

The paper tends to discount the lost-call theory of on-demand systems with so-called non-waiting arrangements, as well as the grade of service conception deduced therefrom. In its place an outlook is offered based on an appreciation of traffic theory which provides a set of continuous relationships covering the practical problems produced in any on-demand as well as any trunk-line system. The whole sphere cannot be covered adequately in one paper and for reasons of general interest the paper has been limited in mathematical argument. The basic traffic theory has perforce had to be reviewed to build up the outlook.

This paper discusses two aspects of testing of the coders and encoders (codecs) and associated circuits in pulse code modulation (pcm) systems. The first is a method of measuring analogue signal parameters such as mean square levels and dc values. The second, considered in broad terms only, is the generation of suitable test signals. The two techniques are discussed in the context of automatic testing of pcm systems. Pulse code modulation was initially introduced into public telephone networks to increase the capacity of existing inter-exchange connections in densely populated areas. The emergence of fully electronic exchanges using pcm to produce digital signals for switching is responsible for an increase in the number of codecs in use. Future trends towards digital subscriber loops will result in a very large number of codecs situated away from the exchange plant. The need for automatic testing of systems containing pcm codecs will thus increase in future.

abstracts: The rising costs of line plant and switching equipment have accelerated the need to obtain increased speech time on trunk circuits by the provision of equipment incorporating improved switching methods.

This paper describes the method that will be used in developing a software tool to automate the routing of MV cable to interconnect a number of transformers on a CAD-based township map. The method proposes the use of intelligent map techniques to route the cables along roads and stand boundaries, while treating blocks of stands as impassible obstacles. This work forms part of the ongoing research at the University of the Witwatersrand to develop software tools to free electrification designers from as many repetitive and time-consuming tasks as possible.
author_keywords: ['cable routing', 'intelligent map techniques', 'software tool for electrification design']

abstracts: A new approach to the calculation of instability in a transistor circuit under avalanche conditions is presented. The contention that the current amplification factor α has to become infinite for instability to occur, is shown to be incorrect.

In this paper we attempt to model the performance of a LEO satellite system with “m” classes of traffic source (heterogeneous services). Each class is defined by different resource and performance requirements, characterized by different bit rates on the uplink and downlink, and different QoS parameters. The CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) multiple access scheme is used and a mobility model is adopted to represent the relative motion of mobile terminals over the satellite spot beams. We investigate the blocking behavior of each traffic class in the network and consider the impact of sub-optimal re-distribution of band resources between the uplink and downlink. A software for the simulation of LEO system has been developed and the results from simulation study of a three traffic class example are shown.
ieee_keywords: ['Downlink', 'Uplink', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Multiaccess communication', 'Satellites', 'Interference', 'Low earth orbit satellites']

To suspend the rotor of a magnetic bearing a positional control system is required. A suitable compensator it developed by the state-variable feedback technique. The resulting compensator design is verified by simulation of the non-linear system. The compensator was also practically tested on the physical system and the system functioned well with the aid of the compensators.

There are several approaches to calculating the expected voltage drops in residential low voltage feeders. These methods vary according to their treatment of the uncertainty associated with forecast loads. The calculation algorithms are frequently concealed in sophisticated computer packages where output accuracy is often taken for granted. In this paper issues relating to voltage drop calculation methods are discussed and appropriate benchmark tests are developed and presented with their results. A companion paper investigates the practical verification of probabilistic voltage drop calculation methods using Monte Carlo simulation.

Dit is aangenaam om die referent geluk te wens met 'n deeglik voorbereide, helder, duidelike en gebalanseerde uiteensetting van waar die tegnologie van batteryvoertuie vir weggebruik tans staan. Dit is 'n uitgebreide veld, en vordering word op bate fronte gemaak, soos duidelik blyk uit die referaat, sodat dit nie 'n eenvoudige taak was wat hy hom gestel het om 'n gebalanseerde beeld van die geheel te probeer gee nie.

Load data collected in the national load research project in South Africa has shown that residential loads can be modelled as Beta probability distributions, but it has not been evident what Beta parameters should be used. This paper presents a technique for analysing the data to identify the parameters which can best represent the loads and describes how the parameters may be derived from the collected data. Among other things, it is shown that the worst condition for the voltage drop on a radial feeder supplying a finite number of customers depends on both the system demand and the (statistical) variance between the customers, and may not occur at the time of system maximum demand. The selection of Beta parameters for the load model can be associated with the risk that the target voltage drop will be exceeded, linking the load model directly to quality of supply criteria. The techniques can be applied in any country to derive locally appropriate load parameters.

UITTREKSEL 'n Metode word aangebied wat stedelike radiale retikulasiestelsels se betroubaarheidseienskappe met behoud van detail modelleer. Dit bevredig die behoeftes van die praktyk daarin dat die eienskappe van die samestellende komponente nie verlore gaan nie. Die gebruik van kansveranderlikes gee dit 'n groter mate van realisme teenoor metodes wat met gemiddelde waardes werk. Die metode gebruik 'n merkalgoritme en voorstellings (nl merke en boë) uit netwerkteorie, 'n onderafdeling van Operasionele Navorsing of optimeringswiskunde. Die besondere eienskappe van die maksimumvloei-algoritme maak dit geskik om die vloeikarakter van elektrisiteit te weerspieël. Dit stel die metode in staat om nie net primêre foute te hanteer nie maar om ook foute wat daaruit vloei te ontleed. Die voorgestelde metode gee aan beplanners die vermoë om die betroubaarheid van 'n nuwe stelsel of voorgestelde veranderings aan 'n bestaande stelsel voor implementering te evalueer.

The vast majority of steam generating plants have to deal with steam-using equipment, the demand of which varies from hour to hour, minute to minute, or even from second to second. The transference of the steam demand, unaltered, to the steam generating section of the plant imposes a duty on the latter which is frequently very severe, and which seldom permits of the boilers operating at their best efficiency, not to mention the strain placed on the operating staff in many instances. The desirability of approximating as closely as possible to constant-firing conditions, maintained over longish periods of time, is almost self-evident, and this is the object aimed at in what I have termed Boiler-house Load Equalisation.

Overall power economy can be improved in two directions: First, by aiming at steadiness in production, and, secondly, by steadiness in consumption. The demand of energy (heat and power) can be controlled, to a certain extent, in self-contained industries (textile and paper factories, steel works and sugar factories), but in most cases no appreciable advantages are obtainable without danger to the process of manufacture. In the electric supply business no control is possible; all that can be done is to influence consumers by means of the tariff.

This book is an outcome of the six Christmas lectures at the Royal Institution delivered to school children by the author; Dr Allibone is a well-known authority on the subject, and the book is an excellent survey of the field from earliest to very recent times. It is intended for the interested layman, but the more serious student who seeks an overall picture before going into detail will learn much from it. The book is very well illustrated, and this adds considerably to its enjoyment. Beginning with fuel from coal, Dr Allibone traces the history of important nuclear discoveries from Dalton and Faraday. A chapter is devoted to the atom and another to the nucleus. Several interesting experiments at the lectures are described and they enrich ones understanding of the subject. Next fission of uranium, nuclear power stations, the production and uses of isotopes, and power from fusion are dealt with. The book constitutes an admirable summary of basic essentials to date. — R.K.

The British Engineering. Standards Association has just published the last of the series of sixty-one British Standard Specifications for Paints, Varnishes and Paint Ingredients. The concluding Specification is B.S.S. No. 388, 1930, Aluminium Powder for Paints.

The British Engineering Standards Association has recently issued a revision of British Standard Specification No. 91 electric cable soldering sockets for cables from 0.003 to 1 sq. in. sectional area. The design and dimensions of cast and tubular sockets have not been altered as compared with the previous edition of the specification, but an important modification has been made in that hot-pressed sockets are now recognised as standard, whereas formerly cast sockets and tubular sockets were the only types recognised as standard. The material for the manufacture of hot-pressed sockets is specified, as are also the dimensions. A useful feature of the revised specification is the insertion of tables giving the approximate current (at the Institute Electrical Engineer's rating) of the largest conductor for which the different sizes of socket is suitable. A new appendix has been added to the specification, giving the International Standards of resistance for copper.

This address defines broadcasting, gives some information on the South African Broadcasting Corporation and discusses aspects of broadcasting in the developing environment of Southern Africa.

Broadcasting is a technology based industry which is developing fitter than most industries. The present surge of technological change in broadcasting is based on the transistor and its microelectronic derivatives, integrated circuits and semiconductor stores In particular. The transistor and its derivatives have also made computers practical Broadcasting engineers have applied computer technology to broadcasting and as a result more and more signals are being handled in digital form. Transistor technology makes equipment smaller, lighter, cheaper and more reliable. Digital technology makes signal storage, processing and distribution easier white maintaining the original quality unimpaired. The paper discusses how these developments are likely to affect broadcasting and its reception in the 1980s.

It has been common practice for many years to consider an electronic circuit in terms of the function of each stage. This concept has grown to such an extent that functional stages have been developed into Integral units. These units are known as building block units. This short paper discusses a few aspects of these building blocks and indicates their field of application. It is intended to give an appreciation of building blocks, rather than a detailed discussion about them.

AN ENGINEER'S ACTIONS AND DECISIONS ARE BASED ON TWO sources of knowledge: (i) Practice or experience, which is gained from the knowledge of how a thing has always been done or of an established method sometimes handed down from father to son, more often from master to apprentice and memorized after repeated imitation. (ii) Theory, which is the process of reasoning from fundamentals of physics, chemistry, biology or economics and deductions from the experimental data of engineering research, usually requiring calculations and other mathematical aids, and resulting in a conception of the relation between facts.
