A Universal arithmetic cell based on the rules of binary addition and subtraction is developed and applied to arrays for fast multiplication, division and square root processors. Applications of arrays to realise more complex arithmetic operations are also considered. The word is supported by the National Research Council Canada.

As I was lying in bed one night as a boy in 1937, listening to the 9 o'clock news on the Radio, a short message in Morse Code was sent out. With my Boy Scout knowledge 1 interpreted the dot and dash message: ‘Marconi is Dead’. An instant later the SABC announcer confirmed the sad news.

This paper endeavours to cover the economic and technical applications of the various forms of centralised control which have been evolved for use by generating or supply authorities, and which have become increasingly important in view of the shortage of generating plant and the high cost thereof.

In recent years we have seen how automation has taken increasing possession of the plant control sector of our power stations. The Initial controversies on the approach to automation have now given way to more concrete solutions. Manufacturers and power station companies have now benefited by the experience gathered from a large number of automated plants and are better able to correlate the mechanical and operational aspects involved. This paper outlines the result of six years’ experience of thermal power plant automation in Germany.

The “traditional” lecturing style, of presenting students with information during lectures and examining their ability to grasp and retain this information, no longer meets the outcomes for engineering graduates as required by the Engineering Council of South Africa. As a result of the outcomes based requirement and the easy access to electronic information the style of teaching, in the final Electronics and Measurement Systems courses, has been changed to a “workshop” styled system design with the responsibility left to the students to obtain the content information. Initial findings indicate that, although there was initially extreme resistance by the students at the start of the course, their self-confidence improved with better results for the particular course and the design course that it supports.

Present analyses of coupled Non-Radiative Dielectric Waveguides treat only the case where the lines are terminated in matched impedances. In this paper, equations are derived that treat such guides terminated in a general reflection coefficient. Two types of coupled line are evaluated, and comparisons of calculated versus measured properties presented. SAMEVATTING Die huidige analises van gekoppelde Nie-Stralende Diëlektriese golfleier maak slegs voorsiening vir die gevalle waar die golfleiers by elke poort in 'n aangepaste las afgesluit is. In hierdie werk word uitdrukkings herlei wat die gedrag van golfleiers beskryf wat in 'n algemene lasimpedansie afgesluit is. Gemete en berekende weergawe word vergelyk.
ieee_keywords: ['Dielectrics', 'Couplings', 'Microwave filters', 'Reflection coefficient', 'Microwave theory and techniques', 'Microwave circuits', 'Resonant frequency']

abstracts: The International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems (OGRÉ) will hold its next Session from 30th August to 7th September, 1978 in Paris (France) in the UNESCO Conference Building.

“The Scientific Research Panel of the Advisory Council to the British Film Institute is endeavouring to obtain from all possible sources information with regard to the extent to which the cinematograph has been used by scientific research workers, to obtain details of the difficulties encountered in doing so and the ways in winch they are being met. Further, it desires to compile a list of the films that have been made by individuals, especially in connection with scientific observations and experiments, but not put into circulation through the ordinary commercial channels. It is the intention of the Panel, when this information has been collected, to compile a memorandum which would set out the progress made so far, drawing attention to the many ways in which the film might be used, giving information regarding special apparatus that is already available and pointing out how the interest of scientific research would be served by greater use of this medium.
The purpose of this survey is to outline the main problems raised with air-blast breakers when trying to meet the requirements of modern networks, particularly in regard to insulation levels.

In this paper the author proposes to describe briefly the design and construction of the civil engineering portion of the circulating water system of the recently completed Electricity Supply Commission's Power Station at Salt River, on the Table Bay foreshore.

The Johannesburg Public Library urgently needs the periodical parts listed below to complete sets in the Reference Library. The majority of these parts were lost through enemy action and are now out of print. Any member having spare copies either to give or to sell to the library, is requested to communicate with the Librarian or the Reference Librarian.

Proposing the toast of the Union of South Africa, Sir William Clark said ho had no intention of (Sealing with the subterranean aspects of the Union of South Africa beyond mentioning that the mining industry, the mining engineers and, of course, the Minister of Mines, were separately and collectively the backbone of South Africa. (Laughter.) Nor did he propose to talk about the electrical industry beyond expressing the reflection that the Minister of Mines and he had arrived in Johannesburg from Pretoria in an “exceptional blaze of electricity.“

The symposium was opened by Mr Norman, the President of the SAIEE, who emphasized the enormous impact that technological advances have had on society, and said that the microprocessor represented an innovation which would have far-reaching effects on our everyday lives. He encouraged engineers to cultivate an awareness of the consequences that new inventions would have on society in general.

This paper describes the 960-channel, 4-mega-cycle coaxial-cable carrier telephone system and its application to certain routes in the Union of South Africa. A description of the cable and terminal equipment is followed by a discussion on the facilities provided by the system, the building accommodation, power and test equipment requirements and a brief reference to the special aspects of the installation, testing, performance and maintenance of the 600-channel, 2-6-megacycle system between Pietermaritzburg and Durban which is the first coaxial-cable system to be placed in commercial service in the Southern Hemisphere.
In recent years considerable interest has been shown in the subject of earth-leakage protection particularly in so far as it may reduce the number of fatal accidents due to electric shock.

THE SOUTH AFRICAN INSTITUTE OF ELECTRICAL ENGINEERS, CONVINCED THAT THE DEVELOPMENT of South Africa will depend largely on the extension of electrical power supply throughout the country, decided in November, 1943, that a code of practice to unify overhead line construction and maintenance to meet South African conditions generally would assist in carrying out this aspect of the impending expansion of the country’s resources and appointed a committee to investigate the matter.

A recursive relation is derived for calculation of the coefficients of a power series from the roots of a product series. For complex roots the expression evolves into two real recursive relations, one each for the real and imaginary parts of the coefficients. The usefulness of the algorithm is illustrated by calculating the weights of a steerable antenna array from its zeros.
ieee_keywords: ['Antenna arrays', 'Directive antennas', 'Signal processing algorithms', 'Mathematical model', 'Transfer functions', 'Steerable antennas', 'Signal processing']

abstracts: In this work we consider the application of channel coding to cellular DS-SSMA digital radio. A simple, yet effective, model is proposed to evaluate cellular system performance and capacity. Cellular system performance is further investigated with voice activity monitoring and cell splitting under AWGN, Rayleigh fading and multipath conditions typical for personal and mobile communications. Block- and convolutional codes of relative low complexity are investigated when Gold sequences of length 511 and 255 are employed for purposes of PN spreading. The average degradation due to interuser interference is determined by employing exact aperiodic correlation parameters as defined by Pursley [1]. Numerical results indicate that for a given processing gain and number of interfering users, appropriate coding can allow for reliable communication even under multipath fading conditions.
author_keywords: ['Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum', 'Error Control Coding', 'Cellular Communications']

abstracts: The Institute desires to pay its respects to the memory of one of the pioneers of the Electrical Industry, and regrets to record the death of Col. Rookes Evelyn Bell Crompton, who died on February 15th, at the age of nearly 95, having been born on May 31st, 1845, at Sion Hill, near Thirsk in Yorkshire.

This paper presents a description of the 132 000-volt line at present under construction for the Electricity Supply Commission of South Africa between Colenso power station and Durban. Basic design data are given together with details of component fittings used and of the routine office and field work followed during construction.

A ‘selective’ white colour is more functional than the conventional dark grey for transformer tanks if they are standing in the sun. An analysis of model experiments a! the University of Cape Town indicates that worthwhile economies can in many cases be achieved by a careful selection of paint for outdoor transformers.
Sample deliveries of a 90-degree rectangular colour television tube that uses new phosphors to provide brighter pictures are being made in the United States.

Digital data representing an image may be compressed in order to reduce the storage space required by the image. This data is a sequence of numerical information (bits), representing the image pixels scanned through in some order. This scanning order is usually Raster Scanning (left to right, top to bottom). Columnar Scanning is presented here as an alternative to Raster Scanning. Columnar Scanning has been found by the author to provide significant improvements on data compression ratios over Raster Scanning. This improvement is limited to data compression methods which use the relationships between adjacent data in the uncompressed source data; ie methods such as run-length-coding [1] and Lempel-Ziv-Welch coding [2]. It does not improve on such data-sequence-independent methods such as Huffman coding [3]. Columnar Scanning is completely lossless, it does not alter the image data in any way, but makes it more useful to a data compression method. Attention is given to how it improves the data compression of a small black and white image (512×256 pixels).
ieee_keywords: ['Image coding', 'Streaming media', 'Probability', 'Image color analysis', 'Huffman coding', 'Electrical engineering', 'Testing']

abstracts: A new approach to eddy current analysis in foil windings, using a combination of numerical and closed form analytic solutions, is proposed. The method requires less computing power, is faster than finite-element methods and is more accurate than traditional one-dimensional closed form analytic techniques. The method is applied to a foil winding inductor and its accuracy is compared to a finite element solution of the same problem. The method has been successfully implemented in a CAD program.

The Committee wishes to thank all those people who spent their valuable time in preparing contributions to the discussion on the Code of Practice for earth-leakage protection on Mines for a.c. circuits up to 660 volts.

The interaction of the measurements of cost centres and profit centres, and the resultant effect on an organization's profit is examined by applying the Theory of Constraints thinking processes. Two cases are described based on the measurements that a profit centre should maximize profit and a cost centre should at least recover its costs. These cases illustrate that some outsourcing decisions taken in isolation can lead to a spiral of declining competitiveness; and that the attempts by a cost centre to maximize cost recovery leads to a lower profit for the organization. The thinking process logic shows that these negative effects are caused by the application of wrong measurement criteria.

A meeting of the Technical Committee No. 24, ' Electric and Magnetic Magnitudes and Units,' of the International Electro-technical Commission (I.E.C.) was held in Paris on the 17th and 18th July 1950. This meeting was under the chairmanship of Dr J. J. Smith (U.S.A.) and was attended by representatives of the following National Committees of the I.E.C. and other organizations : — Austria, Belgium, France, India, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, U.S.A., Yugoslavia, the International Office of Weights and Measures, and the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics.
ieee_keywords: ['Weight measurement', 'Standards', 'Permeability measurement', 'Extraterrestrial measurements', 'Electric variables measurement', 'Vacuum technology', 'Terminology']

abstracts: This paper discusses in outline the techniques developed over the last decade for the tracking of and acquisition of data from planetary and interplanetary probes launched by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Deep Space Network of tracking stations including the Hartebeesthoek facility is briefly described. Spacecraft are considered in general terms so that the tracking requirements may be defined. The techniques are then covered in terms of the three basic functions: tracking, telemetry and command. The paper concludes with a short survey of probable developments during the seventies.

The development 6f the communications network since the introduction of voice-frequency amplifiers in 1922 between Johannesburg and Durban is described, with particular reference to the period of rapid expansion subsequent to 1936.

The magnitude of the problem of handling constantly increasing traffic necessitates straight thinking years before the projects mature. The progress that is being made to-day is due to the correctness of decisions made by the Department of Posts and Telegraphs and engineers abroad as far back as 1936. This advance planning must go on as a continuous process—at least until there are some indications of satura tion—a state of, affairs which no tele communications man has ever yet exper ienced. Hence, this paper does, I think, afford a timely opportunity to consider briefly the possible trend of future activities. So far as open-wire routes are concerned, it would appear that the conventional type of construction prevents exploitation at frequencies above 150 kilocycles per second, certainly with the equipment that is at present available. Such a route and systems can provide approximately 130 telephone channels between primary centres. Present plans envisage, say, forty tele phone channels between Johannesburg and Bloemfontein and Johannesburg to Pietermaritzburg. It is my own opinion that within a few years certain primary centres may require more than 130 telephone channels linking them. How could this need be met by using systems which are at present developed.

A generalised model of loads and networks is used to assess the accuracy of several different algorithms for calculation of voltage drop in low voltage feeders. The load models include single parameter, Normal and Beta distributions. Benchmark networks include simple and branched feeders with balanced and unbalanced three phase loading, as well as a single phase feeder. The results of the different algorithms are compared with a base case Monte Carlo simulation. The Herman Beta algorithm is found to be the most reliable. The other algorithms tested give large errors of estimate of the voltage drop.
ieee_keywords: ['Load modeling', 'Circuit breakers', 'Diversity methods', 'Monte Carlo methods', 'Indexes', 'Conductors', 'Low voltage']

abstracts: Zero voltage switching in resonant inverters has proven itself as an effective way to minimize the switching losses present in high frequency inverters. The resonant pole inverter has lately been identified as a suitable inverter for larger power levels. Switching times are not directly related to switching losses as in the case for hard switching - a fact which can be used to advantage when selecting devices. On the other hand, larger than 1 p.u. peak device current stresses are present which requires overdimensioning of the switches and could give rise to larger conduction losses in the semiconductor devices. The resonant pole inverter requires an additional inductor which further contributes to losses. In this paper the losses are modelled and the trade-off between the different loss components and suitability of device types are investigated using the hard switched inverter as reference. An important conclusion is that semiconductor power devices need to be designed differently for soft switching application, with more emphasis on reduction of conduction losses.
An examination of the factors affecting the cost of dc transmission should be of value to system designers in assisting them to compare alternative schemes.

This paper presents an overview and comparison of some of the known families of polyphase sequences for Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum Multiple Access (DS/SSMA) communication systems. A comparison between Zadoff Chu (ZC), Oppermann & Vucetic (OV), and Constant-Envelope Root-of-Unity (CE-RU) filtered Generalized-Chirp-Like (GCL) sequences is presented including the special class of Analytical Bandlimited Complex (ABC) spreading sequences. This comparison is based on aperiodic correlation characteristics rather than traditionally discussed parameters like periodic, even, and odd correlations and the emphasis is based on practical considerations rather than rigorous mathematical derivation as found in the most of the literature. This paper is unique in the sense that it also presents the effect of filtering on polyphase sequences by using proper filtering methods. The said classes of the sequences are filtered by using a Nyquist filter, and a Constant Envelope Root-of-Unity (CE-RU) filtering process. It is shown that RU filter performance is better than that of Nyquist filter and also provides a substantial processing gain over Nyqiust filtered sequences. This paper also examines the performance of three classes of sequences using the criterion of mean square values of aperiodic cross-correlation.
author_keywords: ['Generalised-Chirp-Like (GCL)', 'Aperiodic Auto Correlation (AAC)', 'Aperiodic Cross-Correlation (ACC)', 'Constant-Envelope Root-of-Unity (CE-RU)', 'Root-of-Unity (RU)', 'Analytical Bandlimited Complex (ABC)', 'Zadoff-Chu (ZC)', 'Oppermann & Vucetic (OV)', 'Processing Gain (PG)', 'Mean-Sqaure Aulo-Correlation (MSAC)', 'Mean-Square Cross-Correlation (MSCC)', 'Power Correlation Margin (PCM)', 'Constant-Envelope Root-of-Unity filtered Double Side Band (CE-RU DSB)', 'Single Side Band (SSB)', 'Multi-User-Interference (MUI)', 'Bit Error Rate (BER)']

abstracts: A number of control strategies are designed for an industrial rod and ball mill grinding circuit in a lead/zinc concentrator. The structure of the plant is analyzed to determine the optimal combination of single-variable and multivariable controllers required for independent control of its outputs measurements. Step test data is analyzed to derive the transfer function model for a two-by-two subsystem of the plant. Four designs are carried out for the model using Single-variable theory, Direct Nyquist Arrays, Characteristic Loci and Expert systems to control the cyclone feed density and flowrate to setpoints. The designs are compared in terms of closed loop responses and disturbance rejection.
author_keywords: ['Multivariable control', 'Process control', 'Direct Nyquist Array', 'Characteristic Loci', 'Expert system']

abstracts: When starting induction motors directly on line, various system disturbances occur like voltage dips, inrush currents and low lagging power factor. To counteract these disturbances, series and shunt capacitors are sometimes added but they, in turn, may adversely affect motor operation and generate harmonics into the power system. This paper uses different mathematical models for the induction machine to analyse these problems and the results of several case studies are included.

In general, three operating regions are defined in relation to the power coefficient curve of a variable speed wind turbine. These include variable speed operation at a tip speed ratio which ensures maximum power capture, constant speed operation at the turbine speed limit, and variable speed operation at the power limit of the power electronic converter. This paper considers an alternative to the operation at maximum power capture. It considers variable speed operation at a tip speed ratio, which ensures that maximum shaft torque is captured. Moreover, it compares the performance of a small PM wind generator operated at maximum power capture to that of maximum torque capture.
author_keywords: ['Wind energy conversion systems', 'PM wind generators', 'energy capture']

abstracts: (Member): Dealing first with Mr Claydon's paper, I will try to make my remarks as brief as possible, though it is difficult for me to do so on a paper dealing on winding engine problems, in which I have a particular interest.

Professor Buchanan (Past President): This important paper is marked for final discussion, and I can only express my disappointment that members who have winders under their charge have not come forward to give some results of their work We are frequently told that owing to the high price of electricity charged with low load factor supply, the steam winder is more economical than the electric, but no figures have been submitted with the exception of those which Mr. Clayden gave, showing what steam and what electric winders can do. On a previous occasion when this subject was brought up, I suggested that the motor of a Ward-Leonard combination should have windings on the stator, which might be connected in series when the load is light, and in parallel when the load is heavy. By such means the light load losses would be materially reduced.

The paper describes a first attempt at using reactively loaded, pwm converters as fast dynamic filters in a power network. The principles used are described, the current fed pwm converter used discussed and experimental results given as obtained on a variable speed drive as a non — linear load. The simulated and experimental results compare very well, and the technique appears promising for further investigation.

This piper describes the development of computational aids for Electricity planning in ESCOM. It explains how a planner can progress from the forecasting of demand and supply parameters to the proposals for a necessary expansion of generation and transmission facilities. Finally, the paper explains the analysis required for the proposed system expansion feasibility study from the point of view of corporate financing.
ieee_keywords: ['Power systems', 'Computational modeling', 'Planning', 'Mathematical model', 'Load modeling', 'Power system stability', 'Economics']

abstracts: The computer aided modelling of an injection locked microwave oscillator, intended for active array applications, is investigated. A simple feedback oscillator is designed and optimised for operation at 8GHz. Frequency and time domain simulations of the free-running oscillator compare well with measurements. The injection locking behaviour is described and measured, but stable and accurate predictions are difficult to achieve. Modelling limitations are discussed in the light of experimental results.
ieee_keywords: ['Oscillators', 'Injection-locked oscillators', 'Bandwidth', 'Harmonic analysis', 'Microwave oscillators', 'Microwave communication', 'Integrated circuit modeling']

abstracts: Reasons, involving efficiency and manpower saving, are outlined for the development of Centralised Traffic Control on South African Railways towards computer based systems. The general operational facilities of computer-aided CTC are discussed, followed by the specific control areas, hardware configuration, and back-up philosophy, for the first implementation. Software for this project, as well as system development and proposed system maintenance, is covered broadly. Future computer applications in this field are listed.

If it is to survive, manufacturing industry must exploit and advance those emerging technologies which can provide the flexibility and versatility required for the efficient production of small batch quantities. These new technologies are shown to follow from a marriage of information engineering and production engineering. This paper describes the new technologies being developed, analyses their potential application in small volume production and suggests how they can be exploited by industry. It is concluded that for long-term survival, all phases of the manufacturing process from part design to delivery of the end-product must be united into a single integrated system.

This paper describes a computer program for the prediction of radio path loss over irregular terrain in the frequency range 20 to 10 000 MHz. Propagation modes modelled are line of sight, diffraction and troposcatter. The operation of the program it described briefly. The prediction accuracy has been analysed and the deviation between the active and predicted loss is shown to be of the same order of magnitude as the natural signal level fluctuations. Typical uses of the program and an example of system analysis are presented.
The first steps towards computer control of Britain's electricity supply system have been taken at the Central Electricity Research Laboratory at Leatherhead, Surrey.

Arbitration was provided for in Roman, Roman-Dutch and English law, and has consequently been a feature of the South African legal system from the earliest times. Today it is covered in the Republic by the Arbitration Act (No. 42 of 1965), The settlement of disputes by means of arbitration confers certain advantages over litigation proceedings, as the arbitrator can be selected on his intimate knowledge of the type of work over which the dispute has arisen. In addition it should be appreciably less costly.

In large bipolar transistor power switches, conduction losses are critical as a design and decision parameter. Darlington power stages, compensated Darlington power stages and directly driven bipolar power stages are investigated, with the latter two analysed further as the lower loss possibilities. Losses as function of base drive current are investigated and shown to have a minimum value in both cases for very specific operating conditions. Control criteria for controlling both switches to operate at the minimum loss point are derived. It is shown that both have approximately the same dynamic characteristics, with the directly driven bipolar power stage being less complicated in this power range by a small margin.
At the invitation of the Engineering Institute of Canada, the conference met in Montreal and Toronto from the 9th to the 21st September, 1962, inclusive, and held ten sessions.

At the invitation of the South African Engineering Institutions, extended at the first meeting held in London in September, 1946, the second meeting of the Conference of Engineering Institutions of the British Commonwealth was held in Johannesburg from the 11th to the 20th April, 1950. The following Institutions were represented :

In 1946 a conference was called in London of the national engineering institutions in the Commonwealth and it was then decided to hold similar conferences every four years, alternately in London and in a commonwealth country. The 1950 conference was held in Johannesburg and this year it fell to me to represent this Institute in London, owing to the most unfortunate illness of our President, Mr Anderson, who would otherwise have gone.
The Jubilee session of the International Meeting on Modern Electrical Power Stations is to he held in Liège 22-26 May, 1978.

After the successful 1st World Hydrogen Energy Conference of March, 1976 the 2nd World Hydrogen Energy Conference is now being planned. In the tradition established by this earlier meeting, it will provide an event worthy of an important energy/environment topic: Hydrogen energy.

The IEEE 802.1D Spanning Tree algorithm operates autonomously in the nodes of an internet to ensure that no loop paths exist. The algorithm enables a particular bridge to be selected as the root and a logical tree imposed on the internet. The algorithm also allows the tree to be modified if internet links fail. Poor positioning of the bridge which will be selected by the algorithm as the root can result in an internet tree which is sub-optimal. The Internet Tree Analyzer, ITA, enables the effects of failure on the delays and the resilience of the internet failure to be investigated. Spanning Tree operation is outlined as background and then the methodology used in ITA is explained. An operational, campus-wide internet is analyzed to illustrate the applications and benefits of applying the method.

The President: You will remember that we published on our agenda that the evening of the September meeting should be set aside especially to deal with matters under “Items of Practical Experience,” in view of the Conference which was held in April, on the initiative of the Witwatersrand local centre of the South African Association for the Advancement of Science. This announcement could not take effect by reason of our meeting being held at the City Deep Hall, and to-night we propose to dealt with, first: — (a) The introduction of the Metric System of Weights and Measures. (b) The introduction of a Decimal Coinage.

The President: Will members kindly note that in view of the Conference which was held in April last on the initiative of the Witwatersrand Local Centre of the South African Association for the Advancement of Science with reference to (a) The introduction of the metric system of weights and measures; (b) The introduction of a decimal coinage; (c) And the official adoption of daylight saving measures; it has been decided to afford an opportunity at the September meeting to members interested to discuss these subjects.

The President: With regard to this item, gentlemen, Mr. Val Davies found that he would not be able to attend the meeting this evening and to give us an exhibition and description of some specimen spare parts used for electrical machinery.

(Associate Member): I am not prepared to discuss it to-night. The only two countries that have not adopted the metric system are America and the British Empire. I think the weight of evidence is against the English system. I think it would be surprising if we knew the number of British firms that are adopting the metric system to-day.
I have received a letter from Mr. W. Elsdon-Dew, a Past President of this Institute, which I will read to you
The President then called on Mr. K. G. F. Collender to submit an item under this heading.

Voltage waveform distortion on the power grid increases commensurately with sophisticated solid-state energy conversion due to the rapid development in power electronics. Harmonic distortion directly affects the revenue and operating costs of a utility and customers. Traditional energy rates do not reflect these costs. Tariff strategies to allocate the cost of waveform distortion are considered. It is proposed to be one solution to regulate the total harmonic pollution in a power system.
The paper describes the work of the construction and commissioning of 66-kV transmission lines and substations of a network connecting the power plants of the Copper Mines in Northern Rhodesia.

The President : 1.0 The work of the Electrolysis Committee brings to the fore prominently the impossibility of obtaining an earth connection as generally understood and the recent paper on earth-leakage protection in underground working has also served to emphasize another aspect of the matter.

The standardization of high-voltage insulators and connected questions within the IEC is handled by Technical Committee No. 36 and its three sub-committees. During the last decade, a sub-division of its work according to the field of application has been made which allows the main committee to delegate work to specialists in separate fields whilst being able to deal with questions of principle as they arise.

In the March, 1932, issue of The Transactions of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers is published a very interesting contribution to the discussion on “E.H.T. Switchgear,” by Mr. Charles C. Garrard, M.I.E.E., and in which is levelled certain criticisms to the solenoid type, of contact for oil switches.
May I follow in Mr, Charles C. Garrard's footsteps and make some more remarks in connection with the most useful papers which have been read recently on switch-gear research and design?

I should like to be allowed to make some remarks in connection with the very interesting papers which have been read on modern tendencies in E.H.T. switchgear research and design. The various authors have at least demonstrated once more that in engineering problems there are generally several methods of arriving at any desired end. We may take it that the various designs of multibreak, explosion pot and other types of circuit breakers put forward by the great engineering firms all perform the duty they are designed for reasonably and satisfactorily.

During the last two years we have had very interesting contributions dealing with high capacity circuit breakers. There is hardly room for saying anything that is new. What I should, therefore, like to attempt to-night is to give a brief survey of the different methods of are quenching, and to express the prevailing ideas on the physical properties of the are; in conclusion, I will draw attention to the important development of grid-control rectifiers and their application to the control of energy.

It is customary for the incoming President to review the particular branch of electrical engineering in which he is involved and forecast future developments. This was done very comprehensively three years ago by Dr Boyce and if I were to follow the tradition I could only repeat much of what was said then. I feel free, therefore, to please myself and should like to take the opportunity of highlighting the contribution made by South Africa to the art of telecommunications.

A new version of the resonant pole inverter includes a saturating inductor and a current feedback winding. The standard resonant pole inverter becomes a special case of this inverter and design degrees of freedom increase significantly. In this paper the focus is on the control of this new type of inverter, and switching frequency variation and dynamic response is addressed. It is shown that a saturating inductor can improve the stability of the switching frequency while very fast dynamic response is possible in case of an inductive load. Experimental results are also presented.
ieee_keywords: ['Inductors', 'Resonant inverters', 'Control systems', 'Switching frequency', 'Switches', 'Pulse width modulation', 'RLC circuits']

abstracts: The body of revolution moment method can be used to determine the backscatter of a long, perfectly conducting cylinder with flat end-caps. The travelling wave lobes in the backscatter pattern are predicted successfully if the criteria described are satisfied.
author_keywords: ['Body of revolution moment method', 'backscatter', 'long cylinders', 'convergence criteria']

abstracts: A method for the calculation of corona threshold voltage on twin wires is developed. This leads to an optimum value for twin-wire spacing. In practice spacings of about double this value are common.

Corona on wires is discussed in relation to the recent determination of ionization and attachment co-efficients in air. On the assumption that breakdown occurs when the electron multiplication reaches a figure of roughly 1000, a fair approximation to measured values is found. It is shown that an empirical relation similar to that of Peek gives good results, but that a lower exponent should be used to give realistic values for large wires.
It is with pleasure that members are advised, that the Institute has been honoured by the award of the Coronation Medal to its President. Mr. A. R. MuUins.

Corporate planning has become a widely discussed concept in modern business life and many papers and text books on the subject have been written during the last ten to fifteen years. Numerous definitions have been formulated in an attempt to describe in general terms what is in practice a very difficult and complex process. The problem of definition is further aggravated because organisations differ in their fields of activity, their objectives and in the time-span for their decision making. Simply put, an organisation depends on corporate planning for its continued existence and even survival.

A new decoding scheme based on the Viterbi algorithm is presented, that can detect up to n-1 homogeneous bit insertions or deletions in an n-bit code symbol and re-establish synchronisation for a rate R = k/n convolutional code sequence. The reversal errors occurring during the resynchronisation process can be corrected by an outer Reed-Solomon code, which is often concatenated in practice.

The paper by Messrs. Boyce and Paola marks a milestone in the development of long distance telephone communications in the Union. It will be of interest throughout the British Empire, where open wire line construction methods have their origin in early British Post Office work.

This paper deals with measurements made on the Pretoria-Johannesburg microwave radio system in order to establish the crosstalk margins at repeater stations between signals in the two directions of transmission of the system. The investigation was necessitated by the occurrence of what appeared to be excessive and variable noise-levels on the speech channels provided by the system. The methods of measurement, the measures taken to increase the crosstalk margin and the conclusions in regard to siting of repeater stations of this type are given.
Mr. Machanik's contribution to the discussion has raised some interesting points in regard to revolved routes.

The subject of rural telephone provision is of great current interest. Such a service is costly to provide in relation to the traffic that it carries so that it can be difficult to justify on purely economic grounds. Often, considerable extra costs are incurred in upgrading elementary facilities to bring crosstalk up to the standards expected of normal urban or business systems. This note considers the small expected duration of crosstalk within any call period and, accepting that even brief intelligible crosstalk is untenable, discusses possible alternative strategies.

In the Union of South Africa the development of the communication network depends on the extensive use of carrier telephone systems which operate over open wire metallic circuits for distances up to a maximum of 1,000 miles. The range of frequencies employed extends to 150 kilocycles per second, and the successful operation of the systems at these high frequencies depends almost entirely on the attenuation, crosstalk and impedance characteristics of the open wire routes.

It is generally accepted that the type of control obtainable with the Ward-Leonard drive is the most suitable for mine winder operation and all developments on other electrical drives for winder have striven to achieve a similar control. There are, however, a number of other factors which affect the decision on the type of drive to use on any particular installation. The most important of these, viz power consumption, voltage regulation, maximum demand, capital cost, heat dissipation and harmonics, are considered in the paper and a comparison is made between Ward-Leonard, rectifier and a.c. drives in relation to these factors. For many years, open-loop control of winders has provided adequate control characteristics but the more stringent operational requirements for modern electric winders have resulted in the development of closed-loop control systems. Two such systems, one for a Ward-Leonard drive and the other for a rectifier drive, are described and the arrangements for obtaining automatic retardation of the winder as the conveyances approach the terminal points of the shaft are discussed. Operational results obtained on winders employing these systems arc given and attention is given to the means for stopping the winder in emergencies. It is concluded that the results obtained with the closed loop Ward-Leonard system are sufficiently accurate to meet present requirements but that some improvement is still desirable on the rectifier winder. Future developments would, therefore, appear to be aimed mainly at the application of new techniques to achieve similar results.

Reply to Mr L. L. Brinkworth It is appreciated that the interest in the graphs in the earlier part of the paper would have been greater if they had covered a larger range. However, a restriction was imposed by the available information as insufficient cases had been considered to indicate the trends beyond the range.
ieee_keywords: ['Rectifiers', 'Power system stability', 'Transient analysis', 'Circuit faults', 'Power demand', 'Market research', 'Harmonic analysis']

abstracts: A brief historical introduction and a description of the Salisbury-Umtali system is supported by a discussion on investigations carried out by Rhodesia Railways personnel before embarking upon the first main line railway conversion to diesel-electric motive power. Characteristics and design details of the Class D.E. 2 locomotive are considered and compared with those of steam motive power operating previously on the system. The discussion includes operating data over a period of five years, details of maintenance schedules and a brief comparison of operating costs.

This paper considers the function and performance requirements for dc current transformers in typical HVDC schemes and gives details of the types of current transformers that have been developed, their method of operation and their performance characteristics.

This work considers the performance of Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum Multiple Access (DS/SSMA) transmission with space- and time diversity for the uplink of a cellular Indoor Wireless Communication (IWC) channel. Due to fading associated with the IWC channel and the asynchronous arrival of the received signals a coherent reference is difficult to obtain and hence Differential Phase Shift Keying(DPSK) is assumed as modulation scheme. The indoor communication channel, which is multipath faded, is modeled by a discrete set of Nakagami faded paths which has been shown to fit empirical data of the IWC channel better than other distributions [1]. Instead of using the commonly assumed Gaussian Assumption to describe the Inter User Interference (IUI), the Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt) method [2] is used to infer the IUI distribution accurately [3]. The average error rate and capacity of a DS/SSMA system under typical IWC channel conditions is therefore accurately calculated using the IUI distribution obtained by the MaxEnt method. Numerical results reveal that for non-diversity receivers, Nakagami fading is very hostile to the SSMA signal. However, using space diversity with Maximum Ratio Combining (MRC) and time diversity (in the form of convolutional coding) at the base station, the average error rate can be reduced dramatically, allowing for reliable communication.
ieee_keywords: ['Nakagami distribution', 'Diversity reception', 'Receivers', 'Differential phase shift keying', 'Transmitters', 'Time division multiple access', 'Rayleigh channels']

abstracts: In this paper, the design and simulation of a Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS) system employing a class of modulatable complex spreading sequences is presented. Several digital signal processing design problems are highlighted, and a novel constant-amplitude filtering procedure for a class of complex chirp-like spreading sequences is proposed. A proposed receiver block diagram is given, and some simulation results are shown to verify correct system operation in both single and multi-user environments.
author_keywords: ['Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS)', 'Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA)', 'Bandwidth-constrained modulatable polyphase spreading sequences']

abstracts: The problem of dangerous voltages in fences near faulty high voltage lines is analysed mathematically.

A decentralized control methodology for automatic generation control (AGC) of multi-area multi-machine overlapping interconnected power systems is proposed in this paper, based on the restriction and aggregation algorithm of the Inclusion Principle. The state space model for the multi-area interconnected power system is decomposed as a group of pair-wise area and/or subsystem models. The decentralized controllers designed by the LQG / H ∞ control schemes are placed at each pair areas and/or subsystems acted effectively in improving frequency and tie-line power bias stabilization. The effect of the subsystem interconnection described by the tie-line power on decentralized controls is exhibited in each pair subsystems. The application of the decentralized controllers to the system is presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed methodology.
ieee_keywords: ['Decentralized control', 'Power system stability', 'Frequency control', 'Observers', 'Hydraulic turbines', 'Frequency measurement', 'Automatic generation control']
author_keywords: ['Decentralized control', 'automatic generation control', 'overlapping interconnection', 'power systems', 'inclusion principle']

abstracts: Delta modulation is a careful analogue to digital conversion system using a single bit code. In contrast with pulse code modulation, a difference signal is here transmitted, instead of the total sampled signal. In certain instances this method can provide various advantages as compared with pulse code modulation. Satisfactory results have been obtained from practical experiments. The method can be used advantageously in a number of applications.

I have studied, with much interest, Mr. Malan's able description of the substation equipment of the Glencoe-Maritz-burg railway electrification, because to me it presents valuable information of a method of operation of plant with which we are not very familiar on these fields.

Mr. President and Gentlemen,—I will endeavour to reply to the points raised in the various discussions on my paper read before the Institute last April. Not having been associated with the operating side of the “electrification” during the last few years, I am unable to give you first-hand information regarding the latest developments on the system and operating experience. It is, however, hoped that Messrs. West and Primmer, in their forthcoming paper, will bring us up to date.

The Delta Sewage Disposal Works, which were put into operation on the 21st April, 1935, will deal with the domestic sewage and trade waste from that portion of Johannesburg comprising the northwestern drainage basin. The flow at present is approximately 300,000 gallons per day, but it is estimated will eventually be 2,000,000 gallons per day which these works, with extensions, will be capable of treating.

The purpose of the drive is explained and details of the drive are given. A simplified diagram of the amplifier arrangement is produced. This diagram is broken down into specific functions. These functions are then discussed in detail. Again, from the main diagram, the individual servo loops are explained, and block servo diagrams are given. One loop is discussed in detail. Some traces are shown to indicate the performance of the special circuits.

(Member): Mr. President and Gentlemen — You will remember that the paper under reply was read for the purpose of acquainting the members of the Institute with the main features of the Kleinfontein Power Station Plant prior to their visit to the same. It, therefore, lent itself but little to general discussion without raising questions on the details of all types of power station plant, a range of discussion obviously outside the scope of the paper.

THIS PAPER IS INTENDED TO PROMOTE DISCUSSION on the widest possible aspects of the design of transmission systems for countries other than Great Britain. It is believed that a companion paper for British conditions is also in course of preparation. In order to assemble the many factors involved in a reasonably logical sequence, the various sections of the paper follow, generally, in the same order as the chronological process of analysis, design, engineering, testing and finally proving a high-voltage system. No attempt has been made to deal with the equally important subjects of the specification, testing, construction, inspection and testing of plant, although it will be readily appreciated that modern systems designed for high circuit loadings are made possible only by the use of the best equipment available.

This paper describes the design, construction and implementation of a personal computer controller adapted for the use of the lower leg. Strain gauges are attached to the ankle and interfaced to a PC via the games (joystick) port where ankle movement is used to control any number of joystick games and applications, thereby providing a motivational means of exercise and rehabilitation. A flexible diagnostic tool, for assessing the condition and rehabilitation of a patient, was developed. The feasibility of the device was investigated in the laboratory and with clinical experiments and was shown to be a viable tool capable of giving accurate indications of injury and movement limitations.

AUTHOR'S REPLY TO DISCUSSION Replying to Mr C. Ryder, generators controlled by the latest type of automatic voltage regulator, which has no ‘dead band’ and a high speed of response to voltage, load, and power-factor changes, can be operated much closer to the stability limit than is possible when they are controlled by the older vibrating contact type regulators. This should make it possible to use generators with lower short-circuit ratios than were previously required to deal with leading load conditions.

Summary The paper deals with some of the problems encountered in the design of the larger turbo-type a.c. generators which were built during the last 15 years, and those under construction at present. The main problem is to produce reliable, efficient machines with long life and requiring the minimum maintenance, at an economic price, and of weight and dimensions which are within the available transport limits. In many cases the latter item presents the greatest difficulty because it conflicts with the other main requirements. It is regretted that in many countries transport facilities have not kept pace with the demands of the times. Basically a turbo-generator consists of a stator, with its frame, core, and insulated windings, a solid steel rotor with its insulated windings and means for removing the heat losses from these parts. Most of the new problems encountered have been concerned with conditions which have arisen due to the increased capacity of units and the introduction of hydrogen cooling.

This paper presents the design of a turbo encoding scheme with embedded Walsh-Hadamard (WH) codewords, and a suitable decoder structure based on an iterative decoding technique, akin to the work on “superorthogonal” turbo codes presented by Pehkonen and Komulainen. The main contributions of this paper are a detailed design of the turbo decoder structure required to perform the required decoding steps, and theoretical analysis to provide upper bounds on bit error rate performance. Attention is focused on an 8-state rate 2/64 coded QPSK DS/CDMA system, in agreement with the rate offered by the IS-95 coding scheme. The bit error rate performance of the proposed iterative turbo coded DS/CDMA system operating on the AWGN channel is studied by means of simulation and compared to that of a DS/CDMA system employing the IS-95 front-end coder for the reverse link channel. Both single and multi-user system performance are considered.
author_keywords: ['Concatenated Coding', 'Soft-Input Soft-Output Decoding Algorithms', 'Iterative Decoding', 'Code-Division Multiple Access']

abstracts: The finite element method is used to design an etched microstrip balun for transforming a 100 ohm balanced impedance to a 50 ohm unbalanced coaxial cable. Design curves for determining the required impedances along the balun are presented. An etched balun was incorporated into a planar Archimedes spiral antenna and the performance of this antenna is compared to that of a second spiral antenna fed by a tapered coaxial line balun. Examination of the VSWR, patterns, axial ratio, squint and gain shows that the performance of the two baluns is equivalent with the etched balun having superior squint properties.

After a brief introduction to nuclear power generation, Part 1 of the paper describes the basic concepts of the two types of light water reactors under consideration for Koeberg Power Station and discusses in more detail some of the important design aspects of the boiling water reactor (BWR). Part 2 describes the safety criteria employed in nuclear stations in general and in the BWR in particular, with emphasis on the containment of the fission products under normal operation, the limits adopted in connection with radioactive effluent and waste and the safeguards provided against melt out and release of radioactive material under disaster conditions.
Mr W. J. Gibbons provided some most interesting information in his remarks and we are pleased to have this information, which does not seem to call for detailed comment from us.

Accurate equations are presented for the design of narrow-band E-plane waveguide filters. The equations are simple to implement and enable the designer to design filters with relative bandwidths from 0.2% to 2% in a fraction of the time needed for accurate numerical procedures.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Microwave filters', 'Filtering theory', 'Numerical models', 'Information filters', 'Chebyshev approximation', 'Resonator filters']

abstracts: This paper is based upon a thesis submitted to the University of Natal for the degree of M.Sc. in the Department of Electrical Engineering SUMMARY This paper deals with the investigation into the causes of radio interference radiated from power lines on the Natal Central System of the Electricity Supply Commission. It is shown that the interference is due to the ionization of small pockets of air associated with insulating material. The occurrence of highly-stressed air gaps on power systems is considered with respect to line insulators and transformers, and methods of testing for radio interference are suggested.

Based on a discussion of the aspects governing the design of the first stage of a transistorized domestic radio receiver, it is shown that the proper utilization of some basic properties of transistor circuitry will lead to the design of a simple circuit suitable for both high-class portables and receivers operating from an outdoor aerial.
A general survey is given on a recommended design procedure to be followed in the development of feedback control systems. Particular reference is made to missile control systems.
This paper describes the design, construction and operation of an instrument that records:
