Given a control problem, informations (e.g., measurements) of the state gathered along time are described by a informational tube. The detector associates with any current time the (possibly empty) subset of states that can be reached by a evolution from the initial time up to the current time “detectable” in the sense it satisfies the given measurements. Once defined, this detector is characterized and studied with the tools of viability theory. In particular, the time derivative of the detector provides the regulation map governing the evolution of the detectable solutions.

Conceptually, a broken rotor bar in a squirrel cage induction motor would imply an open circuit in one of the bars. On the contrary, research [1] has shown that in most, copper cage motors, the contact impedance between bar and core is small, allowing current to continue to flow into the broken bar. This current enters the broken bar, and flows through the core to the adjacent healthy bars, as interbar currents. The paper shows that these interbar currents produce an axial force, and by monitoring the associated frequencies - interbar current and consequently broken rotor bars are detected at an early stage of development such as a high resistance joint (bar-end ring joints) or one broken bar. Experimental measurements in part II of the paper verify the theory presented in this paper.
author_keywords: ['Squirrel cage induction motors', 'broken rotor bars', 'interbar currents', 'condition monitoring', 'preventative maintenance']

abstracts: Experimental measurements on three squirrel cage induction motors are presented to verify the theory developed in part I of this paper. The axial vibration and stator current spectra were measured on all three motors. The first is a 55kW motor having large interbar currents, while the remaining motors are two, identical 75kW motors, one with a broken bar (having small interbar currents) and one with a healthy cage. A comparison between the axial vibration and stator current measurements are made, showing that while the stator current technique uses the magnetic disturbance to detect the fault, the axial vibration technique relies directly on the interbar currents present in the motor. As interbar currents are present in the initial stages of the fault, early detection of broken rotor bars can be achieved by monitoring the axial vibration. This correlates with the theory presented in part I of the paper.
author_keywords: ['Squirrel cage induction motors', 'broken rotor bars', 'interbar currents', 'condition monitoring', 'preventative maintenance']

abstracts: Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL) is a high speed access technology which can be used for asymmetric multimedia and Internet applications. A common problem facing telecommunication service providers (Telcos) is to determine beforehand how many customers could be upgraded from existing plain analog voice services, or any other service, to ADSL(+voice) over the same local loop. In this paper the ADSL downstream throughput rate for a specified part of a network, which includes additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN), near-end crosstalk (NEXT) and far-end crosstalk (FEXT) between adjacent lines, is determined. Services being considered are: ADSL, ISDN and El. A bit loading algorithm [1], as used in practical Discrete Multi-Tone (DMT) ADSL modems, is used to determine ADSL downstream data rates.
ieee_keywords: ['Signal to noise ratio', 'Loading', 'Encoding', 'Wires', 'Frequency division multiplexing', 'Crosstalk', 'Transmission line measurements']
author_keywords: ['Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL)', 'Bit Loading', 'Campello', 'Capacity', 'Downstream Throughput Rate', 'Generic Exchange', 'Optimization', 'Twisted-pair channel modelling']

abstracts: An alternative method to determine the parameters of a single-phase induction motor is investigated. Present methods are complex and do not give accurate results. The method is based on connecting the single-phase induction motor as a two-phase machine. Calculations are then done with the two-phase measurements to compute the parameters and finally the performance of the motor. A comparison of predicted and measured performance values shows a very good correlation.
ieee_keywords: ['Windings', 'Induction motors', 'Current measurement', 'Voltage measurement', 'Electrical resistance measurement', 'Air gaps', 'Rotors']

abstracts: A simple, reliable, robust and accurately controllable (0,2 per cent) variable speed drive using a resistively loaded electronic rotor chopper circuit has been developed, The general system concepts, the models used for a first order analysis and design, the power electronic circuit, the information electronic subsystem and the actually realized system are all briefly discussed.

A simple, reliable, robust and Accurately controllable (0,2 per cent) variable speed drive using a resistively loaded electronic rotor chopper circuit has been developed. The general system concepts, the models used for a first order analysis and design, the power electronic circuit, the information electronic subsystem and the actually realized system are all briefly discussed. It is shown that a simple two pole approach to the system leads to acceptable controller design, while the simple Tröger chopper circuit yields a very reliable force commutated chopper. The system operates reliably from standstill up to maximum speed (1 45D/r/min) at full load torque and is applicable to variable speed drives such as cranes, extruder drives, pump drives and other variable speed process drives. Work continues on the further dynamic characterization of the system, the influence of harmonic interference torques and extensions of operation to the over-synchronous, reversing and braking regions.

The expression ‘dc transmission’ is an all-embracing term with many facets, including power system engineering, converter stations design, special equipment design, and like all engineering it is greatly influenced by economics. In essence, a dc transmission scheme will draw its power from some ac source — either directly from generators or alternatively from a power system which in itself can have varying degrees of complexity — and after rectification, transmission and inversion feed the power into another ac system, again of varying complexity, or into another part of the same system. The dc transmission system has to be assessed in terms of economics and reliability compared with alternative ac methods of transmission.

This paper aims to present the basic theory of a Rogowski coil used to measure lightning current impulses. A model of the Rogowski coil and the associated passive integrator circuit is presented and a technique for designing a Rogowski coil for a given application is described. The design technique requires the designer to specify the required gain, winding former dimensions and permissible measurement error for a given current waveform. These are used to obtain the number of turns on the coil and the values of the passive integrator resistor and capacitor required. The implications of these specifications on the voltage stress applied to the coil is also discussed. The procedure is used to design a Rogowski coil which can be used to measure three different standard current impulses.

Small locomotives are extensively used in South African mines for transporting material from the mining face to the tip. These are typically 4 to 10 tons in weight. The majority of them are used in gold mines at depths down to almost 4000 meters.

It has recently been shown ∗ that in the lightning discharge a preliminary discharge from cloud to ground occurs before the passage of the main stroke in the reverse direction. The luminous intensity of this preliminary discharge is much lower than that of the succeeding main stroke, and its velocity of propagation is considerably smaller. The main stroke begins at the moment the preliminary leader reaches the ground and follows the leader path in the reverse direction.

The paper reviews the engineering problems that must be solved in the future if complete automation of the local, national and international telephone service is to be achieved. New subscriber facilities and fully automatic billing are described. A theoretical proposal is developed and switching systems described which it is suggested provide a practical solution to the problems previously staled.

During the last few years there has been a tendency, both in the Transvaal and in the Orange Free State, to install a greater proportion of three-phase a.c. winders as compared to the Ward-Leonard types and some of the reasons for this change are given; these include improvements in dynamic braking and the use of twin a.c. motors of large b.h.p. outputs. This paper reviews the theory of uncompensated and compensated d.c. dyanmic braking, the question of load sharing of twin motors and describes some changes and refinements in rotor control gear specifications which concern primarily a.c. winders.

The paper discusses the current developments of stored program control, digital switching and common channel signalling. Whereas these techniques can be used separately in conjunction with more conventional approaches, an increasing number of systems now integrate these techniques into a new generation of all-electronic exchanges. These new systems arc characterised by very large reductions in equipment sizes, large potential reductions in necessary procurement times, improved maintenance facilities, and a far greater inherent flexibility to meet the increasingly varied facility and operational requirements of both subscribers and administrations.

World energy consumption and its electrical part are indicated. Choice of transmission voltage with regard to distance, load and other factors is discussed. Technical problems in connection with extra-high voltages, especially Insulation, corona losses and radio interference, reactive power and voltage regulation, and stability are considered. A description of the Canadian 735-kV system and the experience from the field tests and operation are given. Future development in the extra-high tension field is forecast and some comparisons between ac and dc are drawn.

Diamond, as the hardest material known to man, is playing an increasingly important role in modern industry. It has proved itself the most efficient material for the shaping and fashioning, to an extremely high degree of accuracy, a wide range of materials normally extremely difficult to machine. The electrical industry is no exception to this general advance of diamond technology. One of the most important uses of diamond is in the wire drawing Industry where only diamond is able to produce the finer gauges of wire. From electric light bulb filaments to 5 micron diameter wire for computer applications, diamond is used as the vehicle for drawing the wire. The growth of the semi-conductor and transistor industries has greatly accelerated the use of industrial diamond as a tool for the forming of electrical components. Diamond in its own right can exhibit interesting electrical properties and, In certain circumstances, functions as a semi-conductor.

An introductory courte on linear discrete time systems can conveniently be offered before or together with one on continuous time systems, and furthermore it is desirable that such a course should be presented as early as possible in the syllabus. Such a course could start with a description of a linear discrete time system in terms of difference equations, followed by a discussion of the Z-transform without the students having to know anything about the Fourier Transform. Stress should be laid on the connection between difference equations, transfer functions, pole-zero diagrams, frequency responses, impulse responses and convolution.
ieee_keywords: ['Finite impulse response filters', 'Minimization', 'Ice', 'History', 'Fourier transforms', 'Discrete-time systems', 'Digital signal processing']

abstracts: The influence of conductor roughness on radio interference at various gas pressures is investigated. The roughness took the form of notches, and it was found that interference started at lower voltages, but beyond corona limit voltage the interference decreased.

Die ontwikkeling van 'n 50 A I 000 V p-v-n drywingsdiode met behulp van 'n ioonplanttegniek word behandel. Die gepaardgaande teorie vir die diode onder gestadigde toestande word kortliks bespreek. Daar word veral aandag gegee aan die invloed van die planêre-proses op die deurbraakspannings en die invloed van nie-lineêre rekombinasiemeganismes op die voorwaartse spanningsval. Uit die eksperimentele resultate volg dat so 'n drywingsdiode wel suksesvol vervaardîg kan word mits voldoende beheer oor die draerleeftyd en oppervlaktoestande gedurende vervaardiging gehandhaaf word. SYNOPSIS The development of a 50 A I 000 V power rectifier with the aid of ion implantation technique is discussed. The accompanying theory for the rectifier in steady state conditions is discussed briefly. Attention is given, especially to the influence of the planar process on the breakdown voltage, and the influence of the non-linear recombination mechanism on the forward voltage drop. From the results obtained it follows that such a rectifier can be manufactured successfully, provided there is sufficient control over the lifetime and surface conditions during manufacturing.

Hierdie artikel bied 'n nuwe en unieke lasvloei-algoritme aan. Gewoonlik word lasvloei gevind deur die oplossing van 'n stelsel van gelyktydige netwerkvergelykings met 'n matriksoplossingsmetode soos Gauss-Seidel gebruik. Die metode wat hier aangebied word, maak gebruik van netwerkreduksie deur middel van konfigurasieherkenning. 'n Opvou- en oopvou-algoritme word gebruik. Die opvou-algoritme is gebaseer op die Norton-metode van netwerkreduksie. Dit verminder die netwerk tot een ekwivalente element. Dit maak gebruik van 'n reeks kleinerwordende stapnetwerke. Reduksie word verkry deur serie- parallel- of deltakonfigurasies te identifiseer. Reduksietransformasie word met standaardformules gedoen. Identifisering vind plaas deur oorweging van die topologiese eienskappe van die verskillende konfigurasies. Die kragvloei in die ekwivalente gereduseerde element word bepaal. In bogenoemde proses word merke gebruik. Dit lei die oopvou-algoritme terug op die spoor van die opvou-algoritme. Tydens die oopvouproses word die ooreenstemmende kragvloei in en die spanningsvalle oor die boë van die oopvouende netwerke bereken. Die voorgestelde metode kan gebruik word in die iterasies van lasvloei-algoritmes, vir foutstroombepalings en in betroubaarheidstudies.

Die geskiedenis en wetenskaplike grondslag van kernenergie is kortliks opgesom en verder is daarop gewys dat daar drie belangrike maniere is waarop ontwikkelings in die vredestydse aanwendings van kernenergie die mens in die geheel en die wetenskaplike en nywerheidslewe van ‘n nasie in die besonder kan beïnvloed: Sekere grondstowwe het ‘n nuwe en spesiale aansien verwerf; ‘n nuwe kragbron is tot die beskikking van die wěreld gestel; en ‘n nuwe tegniek wat die gebruik van radioisotope behels, is beskikbaar gestel vir die oplossing van wetenskaplike en tegniese probleme.

A charge controlled model of the transistor in the active region is defined by a non-linear differential equation which expresses the base current in terms of the charges in the active base region and in the two depletion regions. The parameters associated with the differential equation were determined by a set of small signal a.c. measurements covering the active region of the transistor. Integration with respect to time of the equation mentioned above yields the total charge which must be delivered by the base current in order to change the quiescent point of the transistor, and also shows the distribution of this charge in four components, viz. Q a the charge added to the active base region, Q r the charge lost through recombination and Q tc and Q te the charges necessary to change the voltages across the depletion regions. Calculated values of these charges (for a specific change in operating point) were verified experimentally by means of a pulse test proposed by Sparkes3. Two transistors were considered, viz. a planar diffused Si switching transistor (BSY 25) and an alloy junction Ge transistor (OC 44). Good agreement between calculated values and pulse measurements was obtained for the BSY 25. The poorer agreement obtained in the case of the OC 44 is attributed to the fact that the construction of these transistors is such that charges can be stored in the base material in regions relatively far from the active base region immediately between the two junctions; as shown by Verster 4 a more complete charge controlled model is necessary to describe the operation of such transistors.

The influence of the wavefront of positive and negative impulses on breakdown voltage in air is illustrated by means of the results of tests done in Pretoria. Rod-rod and rod-plane gaps with spacings between 0,5 and 1,5 m were used. A few theories have been advanced to explain these and similar results obtained overseas. Some of the latest international developments are the emergence of difficulties concerning withstand voltage, as well as a proposed new definition of the front of an impulse.
The process of manufacturing bipolar transistors, field-effect transistors, resistors and metal-oxide-semiconductor capacitors in one monolithic structure by means o ion-implantation is discussed.

The monograph includes the results of extensive field and laboratory tests over a six year period in South Africa, as well as a theoretical treatment, of the effects of lightning on overhead telephone lines from both the damage and signal mutilation aspects.

The disadvantages associated with the classical methods of simulation of non-linear transfer functions inspired the development of a digitally controlled function generator (DCFG) to provide a versatile, easily programmable and multi-channel processor intended for the dedicated task of user defined function generation. The design, operation and performance of the DCFG are described in this paper.

A digital position servo was constructed in which a stepper motor is used as the prime mover and pulses provide the source of drive, feedback information and computation. The system is designed such that the position of the shaft (pointer) is known at all positions and the movement to any position takes place in the shortest time. Tests were made to determine the fastest time of movement and of computation that the given system can handle and the conditions for unstable operation were investigated.

Imperfections in practical lines or other transmission media make it necessary for digital signals to be encoded in certain preferred ways to optimise transmission with respect to error rate and transmission speed. Factors influencing this preference are the code radix, spectral shaping and, of course, efficiency of transmission in terms of useful bits per second. Ternary codes of bounded digital sum have become popular In systems of major commercial Importance such as the lower order pcm telephone systems, but interest is now being turned to codes achieving higher efficiencies but having unbounded sums. One such proposal is examined and a mathematical technique for calculation of the probability distribution of its digital sum is given. From the rms value of this variation art assessment of error rate due to low frequency line cut off can be made.

The fundamental definitions of power are critically reviewed on the basis of establishing proper measurement and deriving proper distortion compensation criteria, in power systems with non-sinusoidal and in general aperiodic currents and voltages. A time-domain definition of power, using correlation techniques, is proposed. A combination between digital- and analogue signal processing techniques are proposed in the measurement and analysis of the components of power. Adaptive estimation of network parameters is investigated in the control loops of dynamic power filters, necessary in compensation of fictitious power. Results of simulated and practical power measurements and on an experimental electronic Pulse Width Modulated power converter, used in fictitious power compensation, are included in this paper.
ieee_keywords: ['Voltage measurement', 'Distortion', 'Reactive power', 'Power measurement', 'Time-domain analysis', 'Current measurement', 'Power harmonic filters']

abstracts: The point is made that increasing complexity of modern electronic systems has made the provision of automatic ten systems mandatory in medium to large scale manufacture and maintenance situations. A brief history is then given of automatic test system development leading to the conclusion that modern test systems should use computer power to replace complex test instrumentation. As an example of this process the single sideband radio measurement problem is discussed and it is shown that simple digital processing techniques can be used to replace complex and expensive spectrum analyzers and distortion meters in automatic test equipment for radio measurements.
ieee_keywords: ['Amplitude modulation', 'Frequency measurement', 'Radio frequency', 'Frequency modulation', 'Receivers', 'Power measurement', 'Digital signal processing']

abstracts: A short overview of the development of digital signal processing is presented. This is limited to classical areas of processing in the time or frequency domain using Fourier transformations, spectral analysis, filtering, correlation of convulation. Prior to the introduction of the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), digital signal processing in engineering applications was limited mainly to time domain solutions. The FFT opened up the whole field of frequency domain processing for digital techniques. This in turn stimulated the development of new algorithms or methods for solving of problems which in the put were not possible with analogue techniques. After a brief review of early developments and means for information reduction, the FFT, the chirp Z-transform, the Cepstrum, Fast Number Transform, linear prediction and adaptive filtering, are discussed.
ieee_keywords: ['Program processors', 'Frequency-domain analysis', 'Signal processing', 'Fast Fourier transforms', 'Time-domain analysis', 'Correlation', 'Spectral analysis']

abstracts: Over the past few years, digital computers have played an ever-increasing role in the field of process control, in a supervising as well as a direct controlling capacity. Direct digital control applications have not been common in electrical engineering applications, owing to the fast sampling rates required. The use of minicomputers specifically for direct digital control purposes may well change this situation, particularly as the cycle time and price of such computers is decreased. This paper describes an actual example of the use of a minicomputer to effect the speed control of a separately excited dc machine. Digital data input and output facilities were used, with a hard-wired interface to effect the phase control of a thyristor bridge, and a digital tachometer. The system was analysed using z-transform methods, and a degree of compensation, based on the sampled-data nature of the system, introduced. The algorithms developed were found to be economical of computer time, because of the use of the hard-wired interface. Two machines were controlled on a time-sharing basis, indicating that this type of application could be considerably extended to use one computer to perform a number of control functions.
ieee_keywords: ['Thyristors', 'Control systems', 'Digital computers', 'Transfer functions', 'Voltage measurement', 'Digital control', 'Computational modeling']

abstracts: Investigations of a particular type of failure of 11-kV oil/rosin impregnated belted cables are described. These failures, encountered both in South Africa and other countries including the United Kingdom, have invariably been found in a vertical run of the cable close to an end box and the cable papers in the region of the failure have usually shown severe “pin-holing“, without charring, together with waxing and loss of compound. In addition, corrosion products have frequently been found on the copper conductor strands.

Although the necessity for Nyquist filters in radio equipment is well understood, implementing such filters using discrete elements remains difficult. In this regard, several approximations to Nyquist filters have been proposed, mainly focussing on the removal of InterSymbol Interference (ISI). In this correspondence, it is shown how a true Nyquist filter with arbitrary roll-off can be implemented using discrete analogue components. Furthermore, the importance of phase equalization is described mathematically and by simulation. Finally, some filter design tables for raised-cosine and square-root raised cosine filters are presented.
E. J. Middleton (Associate Member) : I would like to congratulate the author, not only on the comprehensive nature of his paper, but also on the way he approached a very controversial problem.

I would like to congratulate Messrs Kinberg and Martin on a very interesting and informative paper. I fully appreciate that the scope of this subject is so wide that not much time could be devoted to lubrication, but it is on this aspect that I have a few comments to make.

The President : Ladies and gentlemen, before calling upon the speakers to pass a vote of thanks to Prof. Bozzoli, I am sure you would like me, on your behalf, to thank him for his paper to-night which has been to me, and I am sure to all of us, of absorbing interest. He has traced back the historical background of electrical engineering from its very beginning, in a way that I, personally, have never heard done before. It makes us realise, I think, that the beginnings from which our profession comes had their roots very far back, and that the light and heavy current men have intermingled their roots and branches right through the picture. I think, the inauguration of this light current section to-night has opened a new chapter in the work of this Institute.

I should like to congratulate Mr Botha on this very well prepared paper, and I must also congratulate him for being the first speaker I have ever heard on the subject of weather who has not made the well known quotation: ‘Everyone talks about the weather, but no one does anything about it’.

L. H. L. Badham (Past President): The subject of the paper takes me back about twenty years, when I was engaged on the design of turbo-generators. The problems mentioned by the authors were our problems, and we were investigating the hydrogen-cooled generator at that time ; the possibility of this development being stated in a paper that I read in 1933. It would be appreciated if the authors would state the economics of the case for hydrogen cooling, as that was the factor which deterred us from developing the scheme into a commercial proposition.

J. T. Allan (Vice-President) : It gives me great pleasure to speak to this paper. The subject of noise in machines is one which I tackled many years ago — unsuccessfully it must be confessed ! I excuse myself by saying that the apparatus for measuring noise and isolating harmonics has improved out of all recognition since then.. In saying so however, I do not in any way wish to belittle the efforts of the authors. I feel that they are to be very heartily congratulated on the results of their investigations of a typically noisy machine.

As the authors themselves have stated, the paper is a fairly general review of its subject and I find nothing to dispute in it. I wish, however, to offer a few comments on aspects of the paper which have occupied some of us in South Africa.

I would like to congratulate Miss Potgieter on her paper and thank her because I believe that there is not enough communication between engineers on the particular subject of telecontrol. As you are all aware, the South African Railways Administration is an extensive user of telecontrol systems for the control of substations, pipelines and other types of plant. Some of these systems are very similar to NATELE and some comparisons are unavoidable.

The President : About two years ago, one of our assistant engineers experienced a rather disturbing occurrence. He reported that he had been travelling in a cage when the hoist tripped out. Although the hoist had been travelling relatively slowly, the decleration was such that he was thrown on to the floor of the cage. We studied the winder circuits and the braking system but could not find a suitable explanation. We, therefore, borrowed from our friends of the Goldfields their Cambridge decelerometer, and tried to reproduce these conditions. One of the authors and two other officials got into the cage with the Cambridge decelerometer ; they were travelling at a relatively slow speed and, after two or three tests, which were quite innocuous, the driver did something which reproduced the original conditions. The author was thrown on the floor, and the other two passengers fell on top of him. After that, it was decided that engineers, in spite of popular opinion, are not expendable, and that steps must be taken to find an instrument suitable for doing in safety the routine and experimental tests which are required to prove what hoists will do under all circumstances. The result of these decisions is the instrument you have seen demonstrated to-night.

The Apollo project with its complex global communication satellite support network represents the most significant programme yet planned in space exploration, and bearing in mind that it will be only ten years in October this year since Russia launched the first satellite, it serves to highlight the tremendous achievements in science and technology of the past decade. It is pleasing to communications engineers that the paper presented this evening deals with the provision of global communications via earth satellites, which will be one of the greatest benefits to all nations that has emerged as a result of the space research programmes. Further, the emphasis is on the design requirements of earth stations for operation in conjunction with earth satellites, a subject which is becoming of increasing interest to many Administrations not yet committed to the establishment of earth stations.

A. H. Durr (Associate Member): The authors have given a very complete account of the various types of stationary and portable batteries in commercial use and I should like to add a few remarks, especially in regard to the pasted-plate type of battery used for vehicle starting and lighting.

THE PRESIDENT : We believe that over the years many frills have been added unnecessarily to the electrical systems of winders. This stemmed largely from the selling set-up wherein the large firms supplying electrical equipment had close financial arrangements on tendering. Once there was no financial competition the rivals competed by the inclusion of frills. As an example there were prior to the war, many and various controlled electrical braking systems. These have exercised our ingenuity over the years in devising how to get rid of them. Amongst the frills, however, there have been many sound advances in the art which have proved their worth. I suppose we must countenance the inclusion of frills otherwise we should not achieve the advances, the difficulty is to assess whether an innovation is an advance or a frill. In many cases practical experience only can determine this.

G. A. Dalton (Past President): It is becoming quite a habit for Mr Williams to give of his time and leisure and come here to regale us with the results of enterprises and engineering accomplishments of the department over which he presides. In this we are indeed fortunate.

1 General Papers on major pipelines for the conveyance of water, oil products or solids are usually read by civil and mechanical engineers. Mr Gordon Jack's excellent paper demonstrates very clearly that electrical engineering plays a prominent part in pipeline technology. Mr Jack is to be congratulated on a paper which not only sketches a concise bird's eye view of the whole crude oil pipeline project but also publishes a valuable contribution to the theory of forced drainage to dc traction return rail cathodic protection.

J. K. Gellett (Member): Mr Powell is to be complimented on bringing to our attention the vast amount of calculation and labour that is needed to construct a modern power line for a working voltage of only 132 kV. In the early thirties, I remember reading in the Journal of the American I.E.E. about the enormous amount of preparatory investigation and experimental work that was undertaken before the 287-kV Boulder Dam line was built. That, of course, was a long time in the past, and the working voltage was then considerably higher than any that had ever before been attempted; to-day it is quite a commonplace transmission voltage.

This paper is a valuable addition to the literature on both the causes and the prevention of overspeed and Mr Randall is to be congratulated on setting down important considerations in such painstaking detail.

During the past twenty-five years revolutionary changes in regard to the provision of trunk circuits have occurred in the Union, The most important of these changes has been the development of the three-channel system followed some years later by the twelve-channel system. In 1935 route design was completely modified to accommodate these systems and to-day a heavy backbone route consisting of four 8-wire arms, if fully exploited for carrier operation, can provide 256 channels.

Professor C. Jacobsz: Mr Braae states very definitely that ‘this paper has been prepared for the purpose of introducing members ... to tensors and to bring up for discussion the impact of tensor analysis on electrical engineering practice.’ Anyone with active or passive experience of teaching will know that it is precisely this process of introduction that places the highest demands on both teacher and student; almost inevitably it leaves both hanging somewhat in mid-air. This is as it should be, because the sensible man then gets down to earth as quick as he can and proceeds to stiffen up the scaffolding before climbing higher.

P. S. Doepel Mr Thuries has presented a very interesting paper which outlines the main problems associated with switching operations in EHV systems. Of necessity he has dealt with each topic in a somewhat brief manner, and for this reason I would like to make a few comments on the problems associated with the calculation of transient voltages due to circuit-breaker operation.

G. Goedhals (Associate Member): The importance and necessity of earth-leakage protection can no longer be doubted by any man with electrical knowledge or responsibility. The principles are so well known, that no comment in that direction is necessary. However, when it comes to assessing the relative merits of the various methods of earthing and obtaining the tripping media, that diversity of opinion exists.

J. D. N. van Wyk: We must credit the author with the courage to tackle such a diverse and hence difficult subject. If he had all the time necessary at his disposal, we feel sure that he would have been able to give a most comprehensive and excellent article on this subject. Abbreviating this to a paper to be read in a limited time, however, has complicated matters and a few points need illuminating.
I congratulate Mr Raynal on the excellent and comprehensive paper he has presented on this very controversial subject

(Member) The author has covered a wide field in a most lucid manner, using simple examples which were easy to understand. In fact, he makes mathematical modelling sound easier than it often is. This is a tribute to the author's expertise and experience in this field, and I would like to thank him for the excellent presentation which we heard tonight.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Data models', 'Feeds', 'Predictive models', 'Computational modeling', 'Complexity theory', 'Temperature measurement']

abstracts: Mr. President and gentlemen, Mr. Monks has dealt with various aspects of a very wide subject and has drawn attention to many of the factors which have led to improvements in design and to increased efficiency in the steam power station. I propose, however, to confine my remarks to the part of the paper dealing with those factors affecting overall economy.

The Escort system described by the authors provides a particularly elegant solution to the problem of achieving a controlled rate of braking under widely varying load conditions. The effectiveness of the system is proved by the extraordinarily good decelerometer traces which have been produced for the difficulty case of a single-drum hoist.

T. Harvey: The film which Mr Symes has shown probably shows up more clearly than any verbal description the outstanding ease of control of the differential locomotive. The most convincing experience of all, however, is actually to drive the loco as a number of people have already done. Being privileged to assist Mr Symes in the long series of tests which were carried out I have been able to observe the reactions of these visitors. Invariably the pattern was the same; an extremely sceptical outlook when first told about the loco and what it could do; a smile of contempt when they first saw the strange contraption in its shed; and finally overwhelming enthusiasm when they had put it through its paces. The treatment it received was unmerciful — and we encouraged visitors to try the most vicious driving tricks they could think up. I have lost count of the number of times the controller was thrown from full speed forward to full speed reverse while the loco was pulling its maximum load — often on a downgrade at that. The fact that the experimental loco is still running without any need of an overhaul is more revealing as regards its inherent ruggedness than all the theory in the world. I hope that the prototype and production locos will never be driven the way the experimental loco has been, but if they are they will take it in their stride.

T. G. Baird (Associate Member): Mr Stutterheim has produced a paper which should be of interest to those engineers who are concerned with the design of overhead lines. The determination of the load-carrying capacity and voltage drop of overhead lines are essential for the economic design of lines particularly in these days of rising costs.

J. K. GILLETT (Member) : From an academical point of view, Mr Hunter's paper has several interesting features ; as a serious contribution to the methods suitable for getting us out of our difficulties with regard to power shortages, I find it singularly unsatisfying. The most glaring omission, of course, is the amazing lack of figures or curves to show why centralized load control should ever be resorted to. If it is decided to instal such a system, how much is it going to cost for capital and maintenance charges, and what benefit is it going to be ? There is nothing in this paper to induce a hard-pressed municipal electrical engineer to coax a large sum of money from his Council to purchase such a load-control device ; I am given to understand that for a moderately sized town, an injector costs about 7 000 and each relay about 5 plus the erection and maintenance charges, but I contend that the actual savings to be effected are ephemeral.

Professor J. M. Meek: I am exceedingly glad to have had the opportunity of hearing the paper to-night. It is only within the last two weeks or so that I heard about this paper, and have since had great interest in reading it.

(Member) Mr Flux has presented a very interesting paper on large EHV transformers, a highly specialised subject on which we have been fortunate to have heard an address that so succinctly sets out the present position.

A. M. Jacobs (Past President) : It may be accepted as axiomatic that descriptive papers do not readily lend themselves to discussion except insofar as readers or listeners may be interested in knowing the reasons for particular choices of processes materials, types of plant, and so on. Nevertheless, descriptive papers have great value as records and as future sources of reference data. Ever so often it happens that a milestone has been reached in technical developments in this country : and the record then assumes very special value.

I should like to correct a very common mistake in Dr Tunmer's paper — she talks of electro-luminescence having an efficiency of one lumen per watt. Of course what is actually meant is efficacy of one lumen per watt; since efficiency is a factor of 100, lumens-per-watt ratios cannot be so expressed.

As an invited contributor, one has a preview on the written paper for study. Based on that study, my contribution tonight has two objectives. One is to highlight some of the points already covered and so to provoke further thought. The other objective is to present some of my own thoughts in order to provoke further discussion and comment. For this last reason, I would make it clear that I speak tonight as a private individual and not as an ESCOM engineer.

Mr Mondal has given us a most interesting paper on a subject that is normally taken for granted but not often clearly understood. I believe that the synchronising equipment described in the paper was actually developed by Mr Mondal. He is to be congratulated not only on his paper but also for the original thought and development that resulted in the equipment he has described.

Professor Heymann has previously made a valuable contribution to our knowledge of corona on wires, and now adds to this by his well-rounded study and experiment on bundle conductors. His method of calculation is simple and the correlation achieved between his calculated and measured values is most impressive.

One of the fields of medical practice, mentioned by Mr Milner, which relies heavily on electrical technology is that of radiology. I would like to say a few words about some of the electrical techniques applied in the use of X- and gamma-radiation in medicine.
Almost every year papers are given to the SAIEE on some aspect of the subject of mine hoists (or winders). These are usually well attended and the interest shown helps to develop the subject further.
I wish, to thank Mr Gillett for submitting a paper on a town that has had and still has such a high rate of growth that it must be unique in the history of this country, particularly the Free State.

In areas where telephone routes are very costly to build or maintain, or where conditions are such that physical routes are impossible, various forms of v.h.f. radio circuits are very attractive. They have, however, several disadvantages, amongst these being the necessity for building repeater stations on high points which are often difficult of access, and the difficulty of obtaining reliable power supplies for these repeaters.

Mr. A. R. Blandford: It is indeed a very great honour that has been bestowed an me to let me open the discussion on this ecellent paper. I must confess that I had ot come prepared to contribute to the discussion.

J. T. Allan (Past President): It gives me great pleasure to join, once again, in the discussion of this important phenomena. It is one we are apt to overlook, so the present item is of very great technical interest. It deserves careful consideration by all users of induction motors and their control gear.

May I congratulate Mr. Birrell on his interesting paper which illuminates the various problems in connection with telegraph codes and automatic error protection systems. Since the 7-unit code has been internationally standardized for error protected lines, we in industry have now to develop and produce reliable instruments and equipment and I feel sure that much has already been achieved in this field.
ieee_keywords: ['Data communication', 'Telephone sets', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Printing', 'Printers', 'Market research', 'Error correction']

abstracts: H. P. Alexander (Member): It has been most interesting to hear Mr Heymann's remarks but, from what he has said, I am inclined to think that he has over-simplified his problem. To say that the cost of a line is a function merely of the height of the pole or structure is, I think, making it too simple.
In opening this discussion I would like to anticipate what our President will say by thanking Mr Peck for preparing his paper and delivering it in person at our Institute in South Africa.

Mr Thorén has presented a comprehensive review of world trends in e.h.v. and u.h.v. transmission covering a wide range of topics. I would like to comment briefly on topics of most interest to ESCOM's System Planning Division.

As far as I can remember, very few papers have been read to this Institute on power system analysis and very little indeed has been said on power system stability. To many electrical engineers, even when engaged in the power supply field, the concepts of steady-state stability and transient stability are rather vague. Nevertheless, stability considerations are of paramount importance, and furthermore, form a most interesting and entertaining subject for study.
ieee_keywords: ['Ions', 'Transient analysis', 'Circuit stability', 'Artificial neural networks', 'Voltage control', 'Oils', 'Integrated circuits']

abstracts: Dr Harley graduated at Pretoria University in 1960, when the Department of Electrical Engineering was only a few years old. I was at that time senior lecturer in the department, responsible for the final year machines course. Since that date Dr Harley has advanced to the post of a professor of engineering. I will thus be excused if I feel pride in the achievements of a former student of mine.

The author has a great propensity for presenting his subject with force and enthusiasm, as well as an imagination for foreseeing every possible failure in his electrical and mechanical signalling equipment.
I would like to compliment Mr Harvey on his courage in so adequately tackling a subject with so large a scope. His suggestions provide considerable incentive for further work and investigation.

G. A. Dalton (Past President): To most people, from adolescence to old age, lighthouses, lightships and visible aids to navigation hold a peculiar fascination. To all of these the paper has a very definite appeal. To the engineer, and particularly those who are, or who have been actively associated with navigational aids, the paper is not only replete with interest, but is of considerable value technically, high-lighted throughout by the standard of its prose.

The preparation of papers of this type is of great importance, since they show that behind the facades of good management, innovative design, meticulous planning and construction and sound operation, our technological world, including ESCOM, is full of human beings on which our high ideals of competence ultimately rest, whether they be engineers, technicians or operators.

K. A. H. Adams (Associate Member) The authors have produced an excellent and timely paper on a problem which will be facing many engineers in the future. The problem is how to scale up existing distribution practice to meet the requirements of the exceptionally concentrated loads required by the tall multistory buildings which seem to be necessary today.
I have listened with great interest to this paper and offer a contribution which relates to the practical usefulness of the apparatus in the Rescue Organization of the Chamber of Mines.
The use of bundle conductors on transmission lines is becoming more widespread as transmission line voltages increase and large blocks of power have to be transmitted over considerable distances.

A. NUTT : I wish to add my congratulations to the authors on the manner in which they presented their paper. It was intended to give Post Office and other light current engineers an insight into the complexity of submarine cable engineering which it was felt was not fully appreciated, not having been publicized previously. In the paper they have achieved this object without being too technical.
THE PRESIDENT : Before calling upon our contributors, I would like to make one or two remarks regarding the Union Corporation Group's policy in regard to the development of this equipment.

J. G. Brummer: I have found Mr Carrick's paper very interesting. The clear and concise way in which the rectification process is explained should appeal to engineers and perhaps stimulate them to delve with greater assurance into the field of semi-conductors. In order to emphasize the importance of the application of junction rectifiers for power applications, I propose to relate a few of the developments that have taken place recently in the United States of America.

I am very sorry that Institute duties in Cape Town have made it impossible for me to be present in Johannesburg tonight. Mr Rattray deserves congratulations on his lucid and informed guide to the legal complexities concerning rights in inventions; but he deserves a further commendation because he is working towards finding what is best and fairest and hoping to get those principles embodied in South Africa. This will be most valuable since South Africa is on the brink of very rapid engineering expansion. Mr Rattray's paper will interest the young engineer, who is a potential inventor, as well as the older engineer who may be called on to administer disputes in connection with inventions.

C. H. W. LACKEY (contributed) : The chairman and members of the committee who have produced the code under discussion have indeed had a very unenviable task and even if we cannot entirely agree with all their conclusions we should be grateful, that through their zeal and their persistence they have managed to get so far. At first sight it might well appear that there could not bo anything really difficult about the protection of such simple electrical circuits as exist in mines but this is not so; the subject is indeed fraught with many unexpected difficulties, for example the contending requirements of quick fault clearance and discriminative tripping. Then there are the conditions under which the equipment is required to work. Most supply-system engineers would not be surprised if their equipment refused to function under conditions of temperature, humidity and cleanliness- to mention only a few of the hazards

W. M. de Boor (Associate Member) : I should like to make a few remarks regarding two innovations in the design of electric locomotives successfully introduced in railway practice on the Continent and which might also prove to be advantageous under local conditions.

The authors have provided a lucid and detailed description of the application of operational research techniques to the planning of generation expansion. This is of particular interest to those Municipal Supply Undertakings which generate part of their requirements and purchase the balance from ESCOM.

My Company has been interested in the scope and economics of HVDC for some time and has teams active in this field. The progress of HVDC as outlined in Dr Calverley's comprehensive survey is providing the impetus for the study of more and more application possibilities. Equally, the competition of HVDC is stimulating new developments in ac transmission. Therefore, no enthusiast for HVDC can afford to neglect the considerable ac system development potention which still exists.

W. J. Gibbons (Member): I would suggest that from the standpoint of the operating engineer there is no virtue in the use of switching resistors. To him, resistors and their associated breaks are just additional items to be looked after and I think that if they could be avoided then the more pleased he would be, provided always, of course, that the circuit-breakers were satisfactory from all points of view.

The insulation problem of large high voltage motors is indeed a very important one and I would like to submit my congratulations to Mr Roberts for his fine interpretation of the known facts and for his interesting conclusions.

The paper presented so ably and so interestingly this evening by Dr Jancke will find a place of reference on the bookshelves of many electrical engineers in South Africa who are concerned in the rapidly developing power industry of this country.

W. L. King (Member) : Mr Williams' paper is essentially a practical one giving due weight to the important subject of providing effective maintenance for track equipment under the difficult conditions which are peculiar to this work.

Tue Chairman: It is fitting that the two important papers on this topic prepared in our neighbouring country should be presented in this Institute. They have had worthy forerunners in the papers by Rendell and Gaff in 1933, Schonland in 1933 and 1934 and Perry and Jobling in 1936, and you will agree that a most significant contribution to our knowledge has been made to-night.

Today the new interest in the electric vehicle is undeniable and this review paper is valuable in highlighting the basic or fundamental problem of battery weight and power. Governments in several countries are now sponsoring R & D, as this is a matter of national importance.

The importance of adequate automation for large generating plant and equipment representing considerable capital investment, and in particular the necessity to safeguard against accidental damage, has become axiomatic.

It has been pointed out in Mr Raynham's contribution that the problem of closing overvoltages attains more significance with increase of rated voltage. In the case of a single-phase fault followed up by three phase auto-reclosure it may happen that at the instant of closing of the healthy phases an inverse polarity will prevail between the voltages on the line and supply sides of the circuit breaker. With respect to the magnitudes of closing overvoltages this closing operation at inverse polarity yields substantially less favourable results than that of switohing-on to a de-energised line. It is therefore primarily a task of attributing this switching case to closing on to a de-energrised line.

The object of this stimulating and admirable paper is to promote a detailed investigation of the hydro-electric potential of the Tugela River. It does so by indicating that the introduction of hydro power into Escom's Natal system might be justified only on economic grounds. Other possible benefits arising from the control and regulation of the river are mentioned, such as water supplies for industry and domestic use and for irrigation. The economic value of flood control and recreational facilities would be difficult to assess in the early stages of development of the Tugela basin and do not seem likely to be significant.

It is agreed that rigid specifications in directions other than performance often inadvertently favour one design while ruling out consideration of another fundamentally capable of giving equal or better service. The most detailed design and material specification cannot cover all the little items which go to make sound design and reliable manufacture. For example, some years ago a particular transformer would not stand up to the impulse level the designer believed he had built into it. Briefly, all that was necessary to make the transformer behave satisfactorily was an apparently insignificant modification to the layout of the tapping-switch leads.
(Genoot). Die referent moet gelukgewens word met ‘n omvattende en deeglike ontleiding van oordrakapasiteit van ‘n transmissielyn.

In various parts of the paper much reference is made to the question of the r.r.r.v., but no help is given to risers for determining this. The majority of users have no idea what values of L, G, and R to assume for circuit para meters. The author admits, in Section 2-5, that this is not easy, but it would be inter esting to know what standard capacitance values could be assumed for reactors, trans formers and generators to enable the pur chaser of switchgear to make some assess ment of system severity, which should be specified when ordering modern high-speed circuit-breakers, whether of the oil or airblast type.

It is sometimes advocated, in the case of intermittent duty cycles, that the limiting factor is the equivalent heating over the period of the cycle. Thus, in the case of the example of the rotor circuit in which the current is 520 amps, for a period of 116 seconds, followed by an interval of one hour, equivalent heating would be produced by a sustained current of 91-5 amps. This would require, in air, a cable size of approximately 0-04 square inch compared to the size of 0-1 square inch as determined by the method advocated by the author.

In the United States and Scandinavia distribution transformers are routine impulse tested which, in addition to proving that the transformers are capable of withstanding the surge levels, serves also as a check of workmanship. We are far from reaching this stage in this country but more regular impulse testing, e.g. batch testing, as mentioned in one paper, may have to be considered for large orders of distribution transformers in this country when adequate impulse testing facilities are available. One author suggests that impulse testing might replace what he calls ‘the onerous induced-voltage test’ which seems to presuppose that this test is more severe than the impulse test. This viewpoint is not entirely shared and I think that it is true to say that for disc-coil designs, at least, the impulse test is more onerous.

H. H. Jagger (Member): Mr Chairman, I would like to thank Sir John for his very interesting talk. It has been most interesting to me personally and I think we have all learnt a great deal from what he has told us this evening. I was a little disappointed that Sir John didn’t just touch on the spreader stoker. We, the Cape Western Undertaking of the Electricity Supply Commission, have embarked on the installation of spreader stokers and in two years of operation at the Hex River Power Station our experiences have been quite satisfactory. We have heard that the spreader-stoker installations in Great Britain at Kearsley and Staythorpe have not been, I understand, as successful as we have experienced at Hex. I should be glad if Sir John could just digress a little and give us some information on the spreader-stoker installations at Kearsley and Staythorpe.

D. Wadland (contributed): I am pleased to have had the opportunity of reading such an interesting paper. It covers quite a general field and I would congratulate the author for presenting the information in such a clear and precise manner.

H. G. Val Davies (Associate Member): In this country some 6 000 miles from Europe in general and Great Britain in particular, we are somewhat detached from developments and Mr Baird's paper on modern switchgear installation in Great Britain is a generous contribution to the cause of bringing us up to date.

A. W. Richards This paper will be of great assistance in clarifying what is often a confusing problem. It will perhaps help in avoiding that situation, not unknown in the past, in which some type of hazard was known to exist and flameproof equipment was installed, not necessarily because of its technical suitability for the application, but because it was felt that the user would then be protected against action by the authorities in the event of an accident. The clear definition of Division 2 areas will be particularly useful, as it appears that this classification will be common to many plants. Unfortunately suitable Division 2 equipment is not readily available but it is hoped that with the stimulus being provided by the SABS in writing new standards for this type of equipment, the local manufacturers and agents will become more active in this field.

C. R. Hall& (contributed): This excellent paper by Mr McDonald is the logical outcome of the zeal and enthusiasm he displayed when, as my Assistant Electrical Engineer, he had to overcome the serious difficulties due to the copper shortage impeding our abnormal post-war electrical development.

In his very interesting paper presented tonight, Mr. Davis has described a device which to many of us is completely new. He has touched upon the various applications of the device, and it may be instructive to look at the application of the maser in the field of telecommunications in a little more detail.

A E Day It has indeed been a pleasure to listen to the talk by Dr Leakey, who is obviously an authority on the subject of the future technologies in public and private telephone switching. We are, therefore, privileged to have been afforded a look into what we as users can expect in the years to come.
The President: We have listened tonight to something which is a little different to the normal type of paper presented to our Institute.

abstracts: (Member): Section 4.3.4 of the paper deals with the use of series capacitors on high-voltage transmission lines and I would like to refer to a protection problem which these introduce. This problem arises with distance protection which is, of course, widely applied on high-voltage circuits. As stated in the paper, a series capacitor is usually fitted with a shunt spark gap which is set to flashover and thereby short circuit the capacitor at a current of 2 to 3 times full-load current. It follows that the series capacitor is, or is not, in circuit according to whether or not the spark gap is flashed over, i.e. according to the magnitude of the fault current. This means that the impedance seen by the relays can lose its proportionality of distance and also that the phase angle of the fault current may vary over a wide range. The value of the capacitance used varies according to requirements but it may be of the order of 50 per cent on the line inductance. The position and number of series capacitors used in a line may also vary. Diagram (a) shows a transmission line with a series capacitor at about

R. E. Leyman : I wish to thank the Council of your institution for its kind invitation to attend this meeting, and to listen to such a well-prepared and presented paper. As a metallurgist, I am particularly interested in the influence exerted by oxygen on the properties and microstructure of copper wires.

The authors have succeeded admirably in conveying the complexity of the control and protection of the h.v.d.c. link. Perhaps certain of the concepts would not have seemed quite so difficult had the authors included an appendix defining the unfamiliar terms which abound in the text. I hope they will consider including such an appendix in the printed paper.

Electromechanical switching techniques, which have boon developed to a high degree of efficiency and perfection have been the basis of automatic telephone exchange switching ever since the commissioning of the first automatic telephone exchange in 1892. The advent of the transistor some 45 years later, however, heralded the start of a new era, for from then on it became clear that now and improved switching techniques for the future would be possible and a fully electronic automatic telephone exchange became an ideal to strive for. Vast sums of money, scientific and engineering effort, have to date been spent on the development of electronic switching which has become a highly complex operation. It is certain that Dr Bauer, in preparing the paper which we have been privileged to hear tonight, must have had considerable difficulty in deciding how much detail to include.

R. B. Anderson (Associate Member) and R. D. Jenner (Associate Member) (communicated): It is indeed an honour to have been asked to contribute to the discussion on this very important paper on lightning protection of communication systems, particularly as, having perused the information presented by the authors, we consider that the work is a most valuable contribution to both our knowledge of lightning and to the application of protective measures. This paper illustrates, once again, that whilst lightning is undoubtedly the most formidable enemy of both the power and communication engineer, the more information which is sought and obtained on its many vagaries the more confident engineers become in applying measures to minimise its damaging effects and the authors are to be congratulated on a very thorough study of the subject and on the manner in which this has been applied. We also consider that the large amount of detail and fundamental data incorporated in the paper make it a most useful reference for those many who are concerned with lightning generally and with its effects on power or communication circuits in particular.
A. Birrell (Associate Member): The application of the principles described by Mr Wadley makes possible the design of a receiver which possesses ideal characteristics for communication purposes

I am honoured to be asked to offer some comments on the excellent paper delivered by Mr Paola and prepared by Mr McAinsh and Mr Paola. This will probably be the last paper delivered by Post Office engineers on the subject of open-wire carrier systems as this latest development marks, I think, the ultimate in the exploitation of open-wire routes.
O. Brune : Asa visitor I want to thank you on behalf of the National Physical Laboratory for inviting mo to speak this evening.

A paper of this nature is always a difficult one because of the very wide field covered and the limited time for its presentation. I must congratulate Mr Clarke on giving an excellent paper meeting these two conditions.

P. Machanik : The art of telecommunications, now about 100 years old, was initially based on the transmission of pulses over single-wire lines. The intervening period has witnessed some remarkable results. Development has crowded on development and it has needed sound judgment to determine which systems of communication should be introduced because of the fear that in a few years they would be replaced by some new discovery. The original discoveries utilized simple techniques but successive developments became more and more complex and required staff of higher intelligence and training. The first telephones and exchanges installed in South Africa were crude affairs judged by modern standards, just as the first motor-car — the horseless carriage — looks strange against the high-powered streamlined vehicle of to-day. In the urgencies of the present moment we perhaps fail to realize how hard the struggle was to set out a policy in order to give the Union a modern and dependable system of communication. The engineers of an earlier generation than mine were beset by conflicting claims by the sponsors of many systems and had to make difficult decisions. We would be false to our profession if we believed that modern telecommunication practices have crystallized in their present form and that great changes are not in the offing. These changes will affect us to a greater extent than in the past when we had a relatively small plant. Within a few years' time we shall have half a million telephones in use and it will not be such a simple matter to alter our methods. Hence it behoves all of us who have entered this interesting electrical field to be ever-vigilant and far-sighted and it is ever increasingly necessary for the Department to follow up this desire by providing a sound laboratory system.

G Brown The author has gathered together the reported causes of the TMI accident and presented a set of design principles which would reduce the likelihood of a similar occurrence. This is a useful contribution to engineering philosophy. The range of ideas covered is wide and certainly some of these will challenge engineers in both the application of technology and economics of design.
Joseph White (Fast President) : We are greatly indebted to Mr Alexander for his comprehensive review of the development of standardization both nationally and internationally.

In 1959 Texas Instruments developed the first IC, a laboratory model. In subsequent years, ICs were used mainly for military and space application, and did not really become widely used until the middle 1960s. I feel that the authors of this excellent paper must be congratulated on mastering a sophisticated technique in such a short time and with relatively modest resources, by producing a working logic circuit. This achievement places South Africa amongst fewer than 12 countries in the world where IC manufacturing facilities exist.

We have listened with interest to the contributions from the five contributors and would like to enter into the discussion with regard to those contributions from Mr Raynal and Mr Stocking concerning fault location it power cables.

T. G. E. Coclbain (Associate): Mr Vice has made a very real contribution to the radio engineering field in South Africa in his paper on the ground constants in the Union, with its accompanying map of soil conductivities. I am not capable of commenting on the theory of Mr Vice's paper, but from the practical viewpoint, I see that the task of engineers employed in medium- and low-frequency work will be made considerably easier by the availability of this ground constants map. Happily the propagation in the low- and medium-frequency bands is less affected by the dielectric constants of the earth than at higher frequencies, and in any case this factor appears to have a sufficiently close tie-up at m.f. with ground conductivity for a satisfactory value to be deduced therefrom.

First of all I would like to thank the author very much for this interesting paper. This paper could well develop into a symposium and be even more useful if appropriate contributions from designers of machines, quite apart from the thoughts of the user, could be added.

Because I am a legal assistant in the Town Clerk's Department I am in quite a good position to respond to the statement in Mr Marks' paper that there seems to be an indifference to the enforcement of noise-abatement legislation. I hope to show that local authorities are not entirely uncaring about the problem; but before doing so I should like to support Mr Marks' remarks on the value of publicity.

(Associate Member): In reviewing Mr. Townsend's paper I must say at the outset that the coverage and general approach to a somewhat involved subject is most refreshing. Although admittedly not a historical review, he has said enough of earlier designs to enable us to see what now appears to be logical development and he has also made it quite clear that we cannot avoid the necessity of redesign in keeping with scientific development.

H. W. Tattersall : If I could make one slight criticism of the paper, it would be that the field is too wide to be adequately covered by one paper, although no doubt the author will amplify various points in his reply to the discussion.

(Vice-President): May I congratulate the authors on a most informative and excellent paper which, to many engineers, will provide the explanation of some of the problems South Africa has been experiencing. Cable failures have been with us for years and, with the growing importance of the electricity supply industry, the demand for a more reliable product naturally has increased.

O. Rau: I am pleased to have the opportunity of contributing to the discussion of this comprehensive paper which has been presented by the authors before your Institute. The authors have covered their subject so thoroughly that I find little to add in my discussion.

At the outset I think I should remark that when Mr Bathgate undertook the work which forms the subject of his paper he was in fact pitchforked into a situation of some difficulty. The calling rate had doubled in many places, large quantities of essential equipment were outstanding on overseas orders for a variety of reasons and people were clamouring for service — having assumed that as soon as war ended Utopia would return, being either oblivions or blissfully ignorant of the fact that Utopia disappeared before the war began.

Professor Heymann has drawn attention to an interesting and useful modifying factor in determining the onset of corona due to attachment of electrons to oxygen and water molecules. The effect has been considered as a possible means of conveying charge along a pipe to a capacitor, in the manner of a Van do Graaff generator, for purposes of building up a high potential on the capacitor. The effect was considered too small to be worth further consideration, but this work may well now be restarted with the water vapour content in mind.

The President in proposing the vote of thanks said: We have been privileged this evening to have a paper on a subject which impinges on practically every user of electrical power. It is based on experience and records, dating back a very large number of years which, in effect, cover the period since the inception of the gold mines.

Gewoonlik word die ontwerper van transistorstroombane aan die begin van sy loopbaan sterk onder die indruk gebring van die gevaar van te hoë spannings vir 'n transistor, en 'n maksimum ,veilige werkspanning' word ook deur die vervaardiger gespesifiseer. Vanaand het professor Heymann en mnr Van Biljon egter die einskappe van transistors in juis hierdie hoë-spanningsgebied, die sogenaamde lawine-gebied, bespreek en aangetoon dat nuttige stroombaantoepassings daaruit kan volg.

The author has described the two principally different types of electromagnetic rope testing techniques viz the ac and dc methods and decides that, of these two, the ac offers greater advantages. I do not share this view because the two methods detect different types of defects and a direct comparison is not therefore possible.

Major G. A. Harvey : We in aviation circles, who are responsible for the provision and engineering of communication circuits and navigational aid facilities, have a requirement for the recording of air/ground radio-telephone transmissions. This requirement has several features which are peculiar, due to the circumstance under which we operate and consequently differs in many ways from the broadcasting aspect outlined by Mr Middleton. The necessity for recording these air/ground transmissions is due to the fact that the post-war trend in aviation communications between the aircraft and ground stations is to use radio telephone in place of manual morse continous wave telegraphy. In the latter case a longhand log record is kept of all messages. Thus in the case of an inquiry into say an accident complete records are available with legal standing. In the ease of radio telephony if the higher speed-message capabilities of the system are to be realised normal longhand methods of message recording are impossible. Hence some form of automatic recording is an essential requirement. For legal reasons the present longhand records are retained for 90 days and then destroyed. It is thus easy to see that a recording system with erasing facilities is particularly attractive, from the point of view of cutting down recurring expenditure. After 90 days the impression on the tape can be erased and the tape re-used.
