abstracts: L. L. Brinkworth (Member): An important outcome of this paper is that it reveals how difficult it is to obtain measurements that are sufficiently accurate to determine the torque/slip curves of an ordinary induction motor.

J. M. MAGOWAN (Associate Member) (contributed) : Owing to the limited time at my disposal from receipt of the copy of Mr Arnot's paper, I have not been able to study its contents to the extent I should have liked before making this contribution. Nevertheless, it is clear from a cursory examination of the paper that the writer is to be congratulated and his review of the work undertaken by the Northern Rhodesia Power Corporation Ltd closely follows transmission line-construction practice in Southern Rhodesia.

D. Kennealy (Associate Member) I would like to thank the authors for their comprehensive survey of the available methods of producing variable speed electric drives for industry. So often in our very technical papers we get lost in a welter of detail on a particular drive and the student of electrical engineering and also the not-so-well versed industrial user quite often cannot see the wood for the trees. A wide-ranging paper of this nature from time to time therefore does a lot of good by refreshing everyone's memories. I think the paper's value would have been enhanced if the authors had not only described the numerous systems, both past and present, but had gone into greater detail as to why some of the methods have found limited application whilst others have been more and more applied and refined.

Both this paper and the previous one by the same authors, (their Ref 3) are the result of co-operation between industry and university which have resulted in meaningful and interesting results regarding the performance of a large induction motor. It is interesting to note in paragraph 4 of the paper just mentioned that the rotor bar impedance is of the same order as its resistance, whereas on the usual much smaller university laboratory machine the resistance would have been substantially greater and the results would have been significantly different and would not have been accurate if extrapolated.

G. D. G. Davidson (Member): Thank you Mr Chairman. It is a pleasure to be able to second the vote of thanks which Mr Dalton has proposed and I am sure that I am voicing the sentiments of everyone here this evening when I say that we have listened to Mr Williams’ paper with great interest.

The subject matter of the paper is one that has caused considerable concern here in New Zealand for many years. While the corrosion of pin-type insulators on d.c. systems is a matter of concern to all traction engineers-and I have discussed it with many in various parts of the world-this is the first printed matter that I have seen on this subject.
The author has presented the meeting with a very comprehensive paper. The long list of references indicates that the author has made a thorough study of the academic problem of glare calculations.

R. R. GILMOUR (Associate Member) : Mr Boyce has indeed presented a paper which is of interest to any electrical engineer regardless of the branch in which he has specialized. Although the practice of earthing is relatively old the matter is still a problem and engineers are not generally in agreement on the methods which are considered to give the best results.
D. G. Malan (Associate) (Contributed) : The authors are to be congratulated on their very thorough investigation and their very lucid presentation of facts.

J. Monks (Member) (communicated): The author in his Schedule of Contracts tor the Station has very conveniently detailed the capital costs of the plane and buddings. In Fig. 1 these costs are shown diagrammatically on a “Cost in found's per kW. installed basis,” so that they can if desired, be readily compared with those of other stations, including Klip, Port Washington, etc., which were previously detailed and discussed in my paper 1 .

I was interested to read this paper in which an account is given of the utilization of the steady and transient currents in an earth-connected aerial to provide an audible warning of the likelihood of nearby or distant lightning discharges. It may be of some interest to draw attention to a device developed in Great Britain during the last war for use in the operation of the balloon barrage which formed an important part of the aerial-defence system of the country. The device was fitted to the flying cables of certain selected balloons at the periphery of most of the balloon barrages, and was meant to provide an audible warning of an approaching thunderstorm to a barrage controller so that orders could be issued for the close-hauling of balloons if circumstances permitted.

H. A. K. Weihe : The method of calculating sags of transmission lines under broken conductor conditions as derived by Mr Scholee and published in the December issue of the Transactions of the Institute was found very interesting but his claim that the accuracy is sufficient for practical purposes is not fully supported.
Dr H. D. Einhorn (Member): By using Mr Allan's assumptions and data' the lines in Fig. A have been calculated, which serve as a further illustration of the merits of different starting methods.

C. M. Foust (communicated): The eight year summary of lightning investigation by Anderson and Jenner is an interesting report of lightning current measurements in power line structures. These measurements were carefully planned and made and well analyzed and reported along with important related information such as lightning storm severity and geological formations.

abstracts: M. Benjamin (Associate Member) (contributed) : It appears to be a feature of all the test results shown that the most violent fluctuations of deceleration occur immediately after the drum comes to rest. As a matter of fact, that is a feature of sharp braking generally-on trains and cars, for example. The bump that throws you out of your seat often occurs just as the speed reaches zero.

The authors are to be congratulated on having set out in a very clear manner an extremely useful review of some a.c. winder developments, much of which is fundamental and will find ready agreement. On some of the points, however, there will be value and interest in further examination and discussion.

Higgs (contributed): In his paper Mr Bosch has undertaken to cover a very wide field of specialized electro-technology, and because this subject is so vast the paper can only deal briefly with the various problems involved. Mr Bosch is to be congratulated on his industry and research into this subject, but has made several positive statements on matters which are very controversial and by no means as simple as he seems to think.

I have been greatly interested in the study of lightning problems in the above-mentioned papers and have found it particularly useful to compare the statistics submitted by the authors over the two lightning seasons referred to with data obtained in other countries. I should like to draw the authors’ attention to two publications on the same subject summarizing experiences as obtained in Great Britain and in the United States I am referring to the paper read before the Institution of Electrical Engineers in London, entitled ‘Lightning protection of high voltage overhead transmission and distribution systems,’ by H. M. Lacey, Proceedings I.E.E., London, Vol. 96, Part 2 No. 50, April, 1949, and the publication entitled ‘Modem Concepts of lightning protection for transmission and distribution systems,’ by H. M. Towne, of the International General Electric Company, U.S.A.

R. T. Jones (Associate Member): A point which has been overlooked in the discussions which have taken place on Mr de Beer's paper is the difficulty in obtaining from various municipalities up-to-date copies of their by-laws.

R. E. Street (Associate Member) : Mr Downey's paper contains a wealth of information on the subject chosen, and he is to be congratulated on the method of presentation. The paper may well be adopted as a standard to be used by engineers for the design of street lighting systems.

H. G. Val Davies (Member): Mr Downey's paper on street lighting is so comprehensive as to leave little room for contributions. The important points have been covered in detail. I have available, however, a short film entitled ‘Light the Street’ which I now propose to project. The projection will occupy some twenty minutes and I believe will help to emphasise most of the principles outlined by Mr Downey and provide the animation so desirable in illustrating the principles of street lighting.

S. Austen Stigant (communicated): I welcome the appearance of this paper because it shows that there is, at least, a small kernel of activity in South Africa in the field of engineering applications of matrix and tensor analysis, and in giving a brief insight to the power of the method as Mr Braae has done (particularly where intricate circuits are concerned) I hope that other mathematically-minded engineers in South Africa will take up what is not only an absorbing study but also one of extreme practical value.

L. E. Thompson : The question of ageing of rectifiers has arisen in Mr Good-yer's paper and in the discussion. Since the introduction of the selenium rectifier, the use of the copper-oxide rectifier has been restricted largely to modulators and demodulators, and to moving-coil instruments for a.c. measurement. In both these applications a change in the rectifier characteristics will be serious. Modern copper-oxide rectifiers for, these applications, made by improved processes, are artificially aged during production so their characteristics are stable and no subsequent ageing is to be expected.

Dr O. Brune: I must first thank you for your courtesy in asking me to join in this discussion. I feel that we should all like to thank you for inviting the authors to present this very timely and very interesting paper at this meeting. Not only is this a subject of interest to electrical engineers whose technique is so largely used in building these machines, but to all engineers to whom it offers a means of solving problems which would be too unwieldy to tackle without their aid. It is a subject of interest also to the general public which I hope is represented here. I understand that the largest of giant electronic brains are at present to be found in science fiction; it is well that we occasionally make contact with solid fact.

H. L. Dawe (Companion): Having read through Mr McDonald's interesting paper again, I would like to make a further contribution mainly from the insulated-cable aspect, where aluminium is not only being used for conductors but also for mechanical protection.
S. M. Pierson (contributed): The paper is very complete and well founded, and I am in full agreement with Mr Rippon except for the following.

Professor A. F. P. J. Heydorn (Member): Mr Rippon's paper takes the reader into one of the fields of heavy current engineering newly explored during the past two decades. Impulse testing of transformers is, like many other recent subjects of electric power research, accessible to the equipment and the material available only in the biggest of industrial laboratories and undertakings. This is in striking contrast to the light current field, where a laboratory arrangement comprising comparatively cheap and simple equipment may have equal scientific and technical importance as a heavy current set-up costing many thousands of pounds. Perhaps it is this remoteness of the battlefield of heavy current progress which causes students in electrical engineering to follow the lure of the light current side to such an extent that some overseas power undertakings complain of being starved out of the rising generation of engineers.

M. Hewitt: Regarding Mr Weaving's reply to Mr G. D. Walker's remarks on transformers with their windings screened by metallized paper, it is my impression that this reply is based on some misconception formed as a result of Mr Walker's wording, from which Mr Weaving apparently inferred that the individual turns had metallized paper applied to them, which is not the case, at any rate as far as multilayer cross-over type coils are concerned. For such coils “the unit” as far as shielding is concerned is a whole layer or even groups of layers and not individual turns.

Dr J. A. Louw: I am one of a staff of three Radiologists at the W.N.L.A. Ltd. Depot, where I have been reading the miniature and full size radiographs for the past four years. The reading of miniature films is not easy and I have no doubt that it is essential to know a lot more about it than is ordinarily considered necessary. A considerable practical experience is required. Guidance by a trained radiologist is of even more importance. I was able to obtain both the above at the W.N.L.A. when I started there, thanks to Dr Charles Hurwitz.
Dr. H. D. Einhorn (Member): In comparing mercury and sodium street lighting an interesting problem arises.

These faults are most likely to occur in the manner described by the author i.e. destruction by electrical discharges of the conductor insulation within the main insulation system.

This paper, by C. E. R. Langford, Prof. D. C. Midgley and H. Olivier, appeared in the October, 1963 Transactions. It discussed a preliminary study of the possibility of developing the water resources of the Tugela river for hydro-electric purposes.

Mr. H. Wrench (Associate Member) : Mr. President and gentlemen, Mr. Travers's paper has dealt with so many aspects of Telephone Distribution methods that it is difficult to determine where comments should begin.

That a paper mentioning so many phases of the subject of distribution networks in this country should evoke comment from several of the author's colleagues was inevitable, for it has naturally been a subject of close concern for many years past, particularly the years of unprecedented development on which so much stress was laid in the paper, and it was only natural that those concerned with providing for this development in different parts of the country should have varying ideas based on local experience.

Twenty-four years ago, the late Mr. Thomas Pearson, of the Post Office Engineering Branch, read before this Institute a paper entitled ''Fundamental Principles Involved in the Layout of a Telephone Exchange System.” At that time the provision of telephone exchanges in the smaller towns of the Union was being gradually undertaken, and Mr. Pearson confined his paper to an exposition of the methods whereby the telephone centre and initial cable layout of a proposed new exchange are determined, taking as his example the town of Mafeking, in which an exchange installation had recently been completed.

Industrial computer control systems are analyzed in order to develop a theory which describes the distributed control of real-time dynamic systems. Simplifying assumptions are identified and justified, and the principles of data ownership in real-time distributed control systems are examined. Assumptions which may be valid in specific practical implementations are ignored. The resulting theory describes the unique properties and requirements of industrial computer control systems with respect to the representation and communication of information. It is used to develop a conceptual framework which facilitates the development of software for real-time distributed computer control. Methods which support reliability and maintainability enhancement are proposed, and recommendations regarding real-time response and software engineering are made.
ieee_keywords: ['Real-time systems', 'Digital control', 'Task analysis', 'Dynamical systems', 'Decentralized control', 'Software engineering', 'Process control']

abstracts: An account of the development of self-contained radio navigation aids for aircraft using the doppler principle. Certain design problems are discussed and the leading features of some equipments described. The operational use and future applications of the technique are considered briefly.

Parametric studies are applied to a doubly curved reflector antenna shaped in the elevation plane to firstly examine the far-field elevation pattern ripple as a function of the feed tilt angle. The beam angular peak position as a function of the antenna shaping parameters is then examined

abstracts: The effect of small sinusoidal torque variations upon the load angle is investigated. The Individual effect at various frequencies of excitation, steady load angle and damper windings is presented.

The paper presents a method of analysing induction motor dynamic behaviour in a multimotor system. This investigation, unlike previous ones, represents the motors as well as the distribution network elements in terms of their two-axis equations in order to illustrate the effect of using different mathematical models for the motors especially when they are supplied by series capacitor compensated feeders. The results show that the simplified models of the motors do not ‘fail-to-safety’, and that conclusions drawn from a single-machine-infinite-busbar investigation are not necessarily applicable to a multimotor system. A computer program has been developed which allows the user to simply specify the network topology, loads, motors and motor busbars of the system together with the location of any one of four possible disturbances. The program then automatically configures the network, sets up all the equations, carries out a load flow solution for steady initial conditions, and calculates the transient response. The size of the multimotor system to be investigated is limited only by the size and accuracy of the computer.

The author was most interested to have confirmation by Mr. C. A. Marshall (with his wide experience in Mining Engineering practice) of the usefulness of dynamic braking for A.C. hoists both from the control and financial viewpoints.
Dynamic braking of induction motor drives has, for a considerable time, played a vital role in the control of haulages of different kinds.

That this work has reached its eighth edition shows that both the matter treated and the mode of presentation are eminently adapted to meet the requirements of junior students in electrical engineering colleges If the subject is primarily a practical one, theory is well enforced throughout the chapters by general explanations, by differential equations and by problems for solution. It would have been a decided help if answers had been given to the numerical questions appended to the chapters. Exercises of this kind contribute to a clear apprehension and firm grasp of fundamental principles they can, however be fruitful only when the youthful toiler has an answer before him with which to compare the result of his own calculations Such an addition in a following edition would tend to increase the usefulness of the work as a text-book. — Electrical World, December 22, 1910 p 1490.

A review is made of the present status and future prospects of e.h.v. and u.h.v. power transmission. The limits, in terms of voltage, of overhead power transmission are discussed. The choice of insulation levels, as well as the possibilities of coping with amenity effects, such as audible noise and induced electric fields and currents are treated in some detail. A review is made of e.h.v. and u.h.v. apparatus development. The paper ends with a short description of the u.h.v. test stations in operation today.

The purpose of this paper is to present a very brief review of one of the most overlooked pieces of equipment In the electrical and electronic fields for combating Electromagnetic Interference (mains supply borne) namely, the transformer, and more specifically, the double-wound or isolation transformer.

Current-source inverter fed induction motor drives suffer the disadvantage of exhibiting torque pulsations which are particularly troublesome at low speeds. This may be overcome by selected harmonic reduction of the machine currents. This paper presents a method of implementing selected harmonic reduction by means of an inverter switching routine stored in an EPROM, thereby simplifying the electronic sub-system and enhancing the adaptability.

To appreciate the present development of the system as well as the future expansion plans, it is important to have some idea of the location of generation with respect to the main load centres. It is therefore proposed to first broadly outline the system geographically. The map of Fig 1 shows the present EHV system (220 kV and above) and the probable expansion for the next ten years throughout the country. Also shown are the more important power station locations and the main load areas.

With a predicted growth rate of 9,2 per cent per annum over the next decade ESCOM will need to design and construct very many substations in order to meet the load distribution requirements. This vast expansion programme coupled with a general shortage of skilled staff has prompted the development of new design techniques to cope with the anticipated workload.

The Electricity Department of the Johannesburg City Council is confronted with problems similar to those reflected in the paper presented tonight. In an endeavour to arrive at a solution two separate, but mutually dependent studies have been made concerning the technical and economic (1) aspects of the problem. Consequently a new approach to power control has developed within the department which, hitherto, has been associated only with self generation.
The Natal undertaking of ESCOM covers an area of some 106 700 km 2 . About 10 000 GWh were supplied to consumers in this area during 1976.

In view of the fact that faults to earth represent the most frequent type of failure to which electrical apparatus is subject, an earth leakage protective system fulfils a most important function and localises the trouble by rapid isolation of the faulty apparatus. The core balance and residual current systems of earth leakage protection were discussed in a paper entitled “Neutral Earthing and Earth Leakage Protection” in this Journal for March, 1940, and the object of the present paper is to consider various specialised forms of protection for particular types of apparatus.

Present day methods of earth-leakage protection are outlined together with different systems of neutral point earthing, with special reference to installations on some Witwatersrand Mines. Some comments on multiple earthing by supplier and consumer are added.

The paper attempts to explode the myth that a cheaper relay is the most economical since the overall cost of the relay, engineering and other incidental expenses must be considered. The most economical scheme may well be the one where the more expensive biased relay is used instead of the less expensive unbiased relay. The biased relay should be preferred as long as it is of simple construction and avoids complicated circuits with a multiplicity of contacts. Its high-speed feature, due to inherent stability, affords bettor protection. Engineering time and, therefore, money is saved if calculations can be positive and reliable in the first instance so that finality can be reached immediately without the need for any special proving tests. Standardization of relay elements, cases, etc., can help to reduce maintenance time since this avoids a wide knowledge of many different types of movement. The ease of testing is discussed in relation to special test facilities. All those factors must be taken into account if the most economical scheme is to be chosen.

The attention of Students is drawn to the Institute's Education and Bursary Scheme which has been established for the purpose of assisting Students of the Institute. Institute Bursaries are made available each year to selected Students with the primary object of affording them some financial assistance in their technical studies. Full details of the scheme appear below and those Students wishing to apply for a bursary may obtain the necessary form from the Secretary of the Institute, P.O. Box 5907, Johannesburg. All applications for 1957 bursaries must be in the hands of the Secretary not later than the 31st July, 1956.

I have taken as the subject of my address ‘ Education and industry-a general survey.’ I know that the subject is vast and that I can deal with only certain aspects. Many of the ideas put forward are not by any means new, but they are the result of practical experience and personal observation. Some attempt has been made to formulate them into a coherent whole — a skeleton scheme for technical education. Perhaps a more accurate title for this address would be ‘ Some aspects of the relation between technical education and industry.’

Review of Symposium held under the joint auspices of The South African institute of electrical engineers, The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research and The Rand Afrikaans University, in welvin House, 2 Hollard Street, Johannesburg, on Wednesday, 26th May, 1971.

ELECTRA' 65 is the title chosen for a combined electrical and electronic exhibition to be held between 16th and 22nd September in the Empire and Cafeteria Halls at Milner Park, Johannesburg. Seventy stands with frontages varying from 15 ft to 140 ft will be built and provided with lighting and power ready for the exhibitors to move in.

With 300 companies expected to exhibit — 60 of them from overseas — September's Third International Electra and Mining Exhibition at Milner Park will be 20 per cent bigger than the 1976 show. Size considerations aside, the most striking feature of Electra and Mining '78 is the variety of electrical, electronic and mining equipment which will be on display.

abstracts: Ever since I can remember, the solution to the electric car concept has been seen in the development of light-weight exotic batteries such as sodium-sulphur, lithium-sulphur and zinc-chlorine, all of which contain incredibly dangerous chemicals.

The Engineers' Association of South Africa, in conjunction with the National Electrical Engineering Research Institute and the South African Bureau of Standards, staged discussion sessions on 16 February, 1978 in Johannesburg and on 25 May, 1978 in Durban on the subject of the correct interpretation of the Standard Building Regulations which states that no current may flow through the reinforcing steel of a concrete building. The discussion sessions were well attended by electrical and structural engineers and out of them a clear picture of the problem developed. The following article gives a short survey of the outcome of the discussions.

The object of this paper is to describe in detail the present methods of producing calcium carbide and ferro-alloys by means, of electric furnaces. As the historical aspect is dealt with in many text books on electro-metallurgy, it will be only briefly outlined herein.

The paper deals with electric melting furnaces mainly from the view point of the electrical engineer. It describes the seven main types which have become established and standardised. It covers questions which are often raised by electric supply engineers in relation to the kind of load which these furnaces take from the electric mains. Some notes on working conditions have also been included. A special protective system for high frequency furnaces has been described in some detail; also an all-electric regulator for are furnaces with an indication of the historical background in the development of this apparatus. The paper does not dealwith the electrical theory on which the various furnace designs are based, nor with metallurgical matters, refractory linings, thermal efficiencies and such like; these matters have already beenwell covered elsewhere, especially with respect to high frequency (coreless induction) furnaces and arc furnaces.

The traditional method or protecting bathing beaches from sporadic shark-attack is reviewed in terms of its problematic efficacy and environmental incompatibility. The shark-repellent electric-barrier concept capable of overcoming these problems is reviewed. An experimental application of the barrier for the purpose of determining field strengths and electrode-cable endurance under conditions of 2 to 3 m sand movement is described. The results demonstrate that the minimum field-strengths necessary to repel sharks can be maintained. The range over which the field strength varies along the length of the barrier, on the water surface, was from a low of 4 V/m in deep water to 14 V/m in shallow water. The electrode-system offers a high ratio of inductive reactance to resistance at its terminals. A method of efficiently producing large current pulses in such a load is described.

Prof. R. A. Lehfeldt, in explaining the construction and action of a thermostat, which was exhibited, said: — In making a few remarks to-night in connection with this thermostat, I am reminded of another subject which has been touched on this evening, namely, the drying out of electric machinery in order to improve its insulation. I do not know whether you will regard this as a suitable tip, but in doing that sort of work, I should not only put the instrument to be dried into a box and heat it, but I should also pass a current of air over it, say by making a hole in the side and attaching a fan. If my experience in the physical laboratory can serve as a guide, I think you will find that this will save time and expense.

Some three decades ago the aeroplane was a comparatively small and simple machine in which electrical circuits — apart from engine ignition — were nonexistent. The enormous advance in the design of aircraft made since these early days would never have been possible had not electricity been called upon to a greater and greater extent to perform innumerable functions, which not only facilitated but permitted the modern aeroplane to take the air with the full confidence of its crew.

This paper is a concise description of the equipment installed at Drakensberg Pumped Storage Scheme as well as some of the considerations which influenced the choice of equipment used. In particular the operation of a modern pumped storage scheme places severe demands upon the equipment which must be designed to provide a greater than normal, degree of reliability. Considerations of starting methods are given as well as the criteria under which electrical stability is maintained. A brief outline of electrical protection is also provided. The emergency systems are described together with the philosophy which leads to their use. A brief description of the generator transformer is provided.

The paper begins by defining the basic objects underlying control system design. The historical background is covered briefly and this leads on to the principles of feedback control system design. A description is given of the types of power sources, components and control schemes found in heavy industry, reference being made to the means of attaining the required performance. Both static and rotary equipment are considered. The fundamental chain of command and control is then described this being linked to the theme of fundamental control and the developments of the present and not too far distant future where the operator is moved further and further back in the control chain. This covers the storage, sequencing and measuring equipment which is used for this purpose. The authors conclude that the trend towards completely controlled processes will continue. Systems will be developed which are sufficiently reliable and economic but their adoption will depend to a large extent on the close co-operation of designer and user.

Equipment for dynamic balancing and for electrical testing of the armatures of traction machines is now being supplied to British Railways and to manufacturers. The balancing machine rotates the armature at 700 rpm in bearings which are free to vibrate. The amplitude and phase of such vibrations depend on the amount and the position of unbalance. The vibrations are therefore converted to electrical form by ‘pick-up’ units, and the outputs are mixed in such a way that the actual weight that must be applied to two pre-selected planes to achieve balance is indicated on the control panel. The operation, which takes only 45 seconds, is started by hand and is then automatic. The machine can balance rotors up to 48 in. in diameter, up to 7 ft 6 in. long and weighing from 336 lb to three tons.

In the abundant literature of electricity there is certainly a dearth on this very vital aspect of engineering work. The author has been well advised in bringing together a mass of information on the theory and practice of distribution system in so accessible a form. While covering the whole subject from consideration of general principles to a discussion of the merits of underground and overhead systems, insulation, protection, capacity and inductance of cables, to the localisation of faults and repairing; he has done this with commendable conciseness and simplicity of treatment. It is eminently a book for the student and the busy practitioner. — The Electrical Engineer, August 12, 1910, p. 190.

abstracts: A developing electrical system in an emerging country has much in common with isolated industrial complexes and larger remote municipal systems in more developed countries. For the purpose of the lecture all these systems are classed as ‘developing’.

The steadily rising demand for electrical energy in the industrialized countries and in industrial areas continuously poses new problems which can only be solved by maximum effort in the engineering sector. This applies particularly to the power supply of conurbation areas, where the no less difficult problems of power distribution are now being added to the well-known problems of power generation. The purpose of this paper is to deal with the special aspects of power supply in conurbation areas. I will therefore start by outlining the present situation and its problems, follow up by describing the major technical facilities available to solve these problems and close by presenting a fully up-to-date concept for a conurbation area by reference to West Berlin.

When I heard that next year this Institute is to celebrate fifty years of existence, during which it has grown to more than ten times its original size, and knowing that it would not be possible for me to be with you on that occasion, although I very much hoped at one time that that would be possible, it seemed to me not inappropriate that we might devote our time this evening to a consideration of the past one hundred years, during which the remarkable electrical technology which we know today started from quite simple beginnings. Therefore, Mr President, with your permission, that is the theme of my talk tonight.

Die Suid-Afrikaanse Spoorweë (SAS) het in die tweede helfte van 1973 'n aanvang gemaak met geëlektrifiseerde treinbedryf op die seksie tussen Ermelo en die nuwe seehawe van Richards Baai. Dit was die eerste seksie wat met 25 kV/50 Hz enkelfasige wisselstroom elektrifiseer is. Hierdie referaat handel oor die toerusting van die eerste reeks van tirisioriokonmotiewe wat op hierdie belangrike seksie vir die steenkooluitvoer bedryf is. SYNOPSIS The South African Railways (SAR) started electrified train operation in the second half of 1978 on the section between Ermelo and the new seaport of Richards Bay. This is the first section electrified with 25 kV/50 Hz single-phase ac. This paper deals with the electrical equipment of the first series of thyristor locomotives operating on this section which is important to the coal exporting industry.

Present day techniques for the design and construction of electrical apparatus for use in explosive atmospheres are discussed. Distinction is made between apparatuses for use in localities where gases and vapours, flammable dusts, or flammable fibres can occur in the air, and also between apparatuses for localities where an explosion hazard can occur under normal conditions or under abnormal conditions only. Static electricity is discussed, as well as problems of installation and maintenance of equipment.

This paper is not intended to contain any new information, Since flameproofing is relatively unknown in South Africa, this paper is intended to cover, as a, survey, the underlying thoughts and principles embodied in such equipment. An attempt has been made to define the problem of using electricity in hazardous locations and to briefly indicate the three possible solutions as well as the circumstances under which those solutions would be moat suitable.
We wish to take, this opportunity of thanking Messrs. Cooks, Badham, Bind and Heydorn for their kind remarks concerning our paper, and for their very able discussions on it.

The property of the East Rand Proprietary Mines, Limited, lies between the townships of Germiston and Boksburg, and comprises an area of 7,375 mining claims. During 1935 the tonnage of ore milled was 2,303,500 tons, and the reduction works are being modified to increase this tonnage. During this period 629,448,000 gallons of water were pumped to the surface, and a further quantity of 208,588,000 gallons were pumped from lower levels to reservoirs higher up for mine use.

abstracts: With South African conditions in mind, this paper reviews Insulation in electrical apparatus and some problems associated with it, as far as it can be assessed by a study of the more recent literature, by observation and by experience. To refresh the memories of those who are not in day-to-day touch with the subject, definitions are given of those terms commonly associated with the general behaviour of insulation and dielectrics. The more important insulating materials and some of the chemical terms associated with them are also discussed briefly.

The majority of telemetry systems installed in (old mines rely on at least a pair of wires as the transmission medium. The wires are generally part of a mullicara armoured cable which often there the same cable duct at 6,6 kV, 520 V and 110 V power cables. Other cables in the vicinity may carry telephone or control signals. The stray coupling of electric currents between these cables, and in particular between pairs in the tame cable, results in interference with a telemetry signal. This paper indicates the likely interference sources and the magnitude and frequency spectra of the induced noise measured on various types of underground cables.

The impact of modern electronics, so apparent in many aspects of everyday life, is equally influential upon the business of designing, building and using rotating electrical machines. Modern controls and power electronics have supplanted some machines, but greatly enhanced the versatility and applicability of many others. Powerful interactive computer methods are invaluable in machine design and manufacture. Electronic instrumentation provides new development tools of great refinement, and means of monitoring the quality of machines as manufactured and their conditions in subsequent service.

My first contacts with the South African industry go back to 1945 when my employers in Switzerland sent me to this country to investigate conditions, to talk to people and on my return to submit recommendations for the future activities of our company in Southern Africa. I presume that this assignment would in today's language be defined as ‘in-depth market research’. To complete my task, 1 visited a great number of factories and had long discussions with their managers and staff.

The electrical research division of the Electricity Supply Commission is concerned with investigating engineering problems encountered by the main engineering departments. The work of the division is indicated by describing briefly a number of current investigations.

(Member of Council) : There being practically no discussion on my paper, my reply must be necessarily brief. I certainly agree with Mr. Nicholett's remarks about simplicity of operating gear, etc., where the apparatus is erected in out of the way places. Since the original paper was written I noticed an article in the Mining Journal in which the makers of a magnetic separator state that the different conditions as specified in my paper are fulfilled in a type of separator now being put on the market. If possible, I intend, at a future date, to give particulars of this machine and also particulars of another type of separator designed by Mr. Curtis, of the Crown Mines, and myself for use in connection with the separation of iron from tube mill pulp.

On page 373 of the Transactions, and in paragraph 2 he says — "For example, a two zone machine having two cross belts will have an output of approximately 2.5 cwt. per shift of 10 hours, working on one grade of ore."

(Hon. Treasurer) : In a country like this, with propositions so widely distributed and so isolated, I think this subject, which Mr. Woodworth has brought up so ably, is one deserving of discussion by every member. I hope before the discussion closes to have something more to say about it myself, but in the meantime, I should like to ask the author if he would kindly give us in his reply some information relating to the class 5 machines — separators using static electricity. He refers to the fact that in the United States and Mexico particularly, such machines are very largely used, and are very successful. Many of you know that Professor Dobson, some time ago, carried out a number of experiments with a static separator in the laboratory of this College, but I do not know that any practical result came from them. At any rate, many points were brought forward which were of great interest. Personally, I know very little about these static separators and bow far they have been successful in other parts of the world, but 1 am sure that if Mr. Woodworth would give us some figures in connection with them, they would be much appreciated. The static machine, which was used in connection with the experiments I have mentioned, is in the laboratory now, and members will have an opportunity of seeing it working at the close of this meeting.

(Member) : The author in his paper on Electrical Separators, has opened a most interesting subject, although one that has not yet been gone into very thoroughly by electrical engineers on gold mines on the rand. I have only had a passing acquaintance with electric magnetic separators, but my experiences in erecting and operating a two-zone machine of a type mentioned in the paper, under classification 3, i.e. separators for feebly magnetic minerals (dry process), may be of interest to the meeting.

This paper is a general survey of some of the more important electrical services provided in modern civil aircraft. It deals briefly with the main electrical power system and its associated equipment. The means of generating the power, controlling its voltage and the protection of the system are discussed. Included, too, are descriptions of an automatic electric propeller control circuit and two types of aircraft ignition systems.

The Union of South Africa covers an area of 742 000 square miles and lies between the latitudes of 22 degrees South and 35 degrees South. The climatic conditions over such a vast area, covering as it does tropical, sub-tropical and temperate zones, are subject to wide variations in such a short journey as the 1 000 miles covered by the Blue Trains in their normal journeys between Cape Town and Johannesburg. The extremes of temperatures may be taken as 26° and 110° whilst the relative humidity may range from as low as 20 per cent to as high as 90 per cent. The train travels from the winter rainfall area of the Cape Peninsula and the Boland to the dry winter of the Karroo in the short space of 36 miles in 85 minutes with a change in altitude of 2 352 feet during the passage of the Hex River Pass.

Lieut.-Col. Dobson (Member): Mr. Bernard Price's paper contains an enormous amount of statistical information and interesting conclusions as a result of his experience on what may be regarded as a pioneer scheme of high voltage transmission of power generated on a large scale. Mr. Price and his staff have brought a wealth of information to the technical societies of the Witwatersrand, and they are to be sincerely congratulated in having overcome the enormous initial difficulties which are inherent to the inception of a large power scheme and in the elimination of most of the disastrous effects which accompany the characteristically severe lightning storms of the Witwatersrand. The attention given to the minutest details of organisation forms excellent reading, and no doubt has had a great effect on the achievement of satisfactory running of the system. In the words of the author, the paper reviews the scheme as a complete entity, it being pointed out that it would be impossible in a single paper to deal with the characteristics and behaviour of each individual class of apparatus. For this reason it is difficult to find points upon which comment or criticism is possible. As a result of reading the paper, and with the object of drawing further from the author's wealth of valuable' information, I would like to ask a few questions.

(Contributed): The South African Institute of Electrical Engineers is to be congratulated on having presented to it such a paper as that under discussion. As far as I am aware it is the most complete and detailed account which has been published anywhere of the layout, operation and organisation of a large electric power distribution system, and it will be read with interest and profit by electrical engineers in all parts of the world.
(Member): The importance of this paper is, I am sure, recognised by our members, and I expect as a book of reference on this important subject our November Journal will maintain a high place.

(Associate Member): Mr. Price, on page 6, discusses the considerations which led to the location of the generating stations. There are not many suitable sites on or near the Witwatersrand for large generating stations, and hence there is little choice in the matter. The distribution of generating plant here, however, probably calls for more forethought than is the case when the power company is called upon to supply a purely, industrial area. The gold mines comprise nearly the whole of the power company's consumers, and the gold mining industry, is, as we all know, more speculative in its nature than what are known as industrial concerns. There is always a termination to the operations of a mine, and although there is no doubt that the mining industry will continue and even increase on the Witwatersrand for a good many years, the areas of greatest demand for energy will change. This being the case, what is now an ideal distribution of generating plant on the Witwatersrand may not be so favourable in a few years time. I do not suppose, for instance, that at the inception of the V.F.P. scheme the engineers could form any reliable opinion of the developments which we now know will take place on the eastern end of the Witwatersrand. For this reason, it is perhaps unfair to criticise the location of the stations and lay-out of the system. Mr. Price gives us the considerations which led to the selection of Vereeniging for the site of a generating station. Viewed from the standpoint which we now have, would it not have been better to have concentrated a much greater proportion of the plant on this site than is the case now ? As the centre of gravity of the load travels eastward, transmission losses with the present lay-out of the system will increase, and it is interesting to note that the furthest east consumer is very little further away from Simmerpan than it is from Vereeniging. Later on, again assuming that the present lay-out is permanent, the losses in transmitting power from Rosherville to where it is required will probably be as great as if it were transmitted direct from Vereeniging, where the cost of coal is less. It is true that as we get further east the freightage on coal from the Witbank Collieries becomes less, and if this were the only consideration, it would be better to increase the capacity of stations located on the east end of the system than to transmit from either Rosherville and Simmerpan or Vereeniging. Unfortunately, the water supply at the present time constitutes a difficulty, and taking all things into consideration, it appears to me that if the capacity at Vereeniging had been considerably increased and that at Rosherville correspondingly decreased, it would have resulted in more economical generation than is the case with the present lay-out.

Instruments and apparatus depicting the earliest application of electricity, and the development of its uses up to the present day, were on view at the electrical historical and scientific exhibition, which was opened yesterday in Kelvin House, Johannesburg.

The President : Those of you who have read Mr. McCann's paper will notice that he confines his remarks to two-stage compressors, either large compressors direct coupled to steam engines, large compressors belt driven by motors, or small compressors belt or gear driven. Apparently he is considering only those types of compressors which up till recently have been general on the Rand. As you know, there are now some very large compressors here of the turbine type being put in both at Rosherville and at the Robinson Mine, and if any gentleman present has anything he can tell us about that type of compressor, as compared with reciprocating compressors, I am sure it would be a valuable contribution.
In considering the different methods of driving compressors, the proposition at once resolves itself into the one question of cost of power delivered at the drill.

(Member): I should like the author of this paper to tell us how he proposes to govern the compressors which he describes. I should also like to know how — when he has put down the hundred compressors say 10 on each of 10 levels — he is going to obtain pure air. I should think that the dust of the mine would very quickly clog up the machines. There is further the question of water for cooling purposes; the water from the mine itself would not be of use owing to its acidity.

I am deeply conscious of the honour you have conferred upon me and I wish to give you my assurance that 1 will serve our Institute to the best of my ability.

The first all-electrical exhibition to be held in Johannesburg was opened by the Mayor, Mr. G. W. Nelson, in the City Hall to-day in the presence of an admiring and representative gathering. It was organised by the City Electricity Supply Department, with the co-operation of the commercial houses, in commemoration of the 21st anniversary of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers. It will be the principal attraction in the “Electricity Week”.

In an integrated iron and steel works a chain of processes is involved in turning Iron ore and other raw materials into finished steel. Electricity has a major part to play In every step, and a large works having an output of say 5 million ingot tons a year may require an electrical supply of 400 M W capacity.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen: At the outset, permit me to thank your Association for having asked me to address you to-night at this joint meeting of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers and the University of the Witwatersrand. It would, however, be taking advantage of the great honour you have done me, if I did not immediately disclaim any pretensions to a knowledge of electricity. My object to-night is to draw attention to that very limited knowledge on the part of the medical practitioner, and to the even more limited use of electricity as a means for determining the condition of the patient and for the alleviation of the sick.

In the year 1919 the South African Railways came to a crucial point of their development in Natal. With traffic on the main line between the Witwatersrand and Durban having increased to a point of track saturation the Administration ‘figuring the nature of the times deceas'd’ had to ‘prophesy with a near aim of the main chances of things to come’ and decided after receiving the consulting engineers' report to electrify a section of line at 3 kV dc between Glencoe and Pietermaritzburg. This decision was, however, made not without considerable opposition from several quarters who maintained that a bundle of string, wire and shellac' as the electromotor was then irreverently called could never replace the steam engine.

This paper is mainly descriptive. It deals in general terms with some of the many ways in which electricity enters into the production of crude oil from a particular oilfield and into the transport of this oil by pipeline to the coast. Orthodox plant is described briefly in order to devote more space to less commonly used equipment. Some mention is made of operating experiences.
It is a pleasure on this occasion t able to approach the subject of the p station at Colenso and its related par an atmosphere of calm and informed nical enquiry and criticism.

The maintenance of steady progress is the description given by the Electricity Supply Commission in defining its work last year—a description which may well be applied to electrical development generally throughout South Africa.

In the initial discussion on this paper attention was drawn to the generous plant capacity of the station in relation to the load which has actually materialised or in sight, and while there may be a good deal of justification for ensuring that adequate stand-by is available for so important a service as a railway traction supply, it would be interesting in the light of live years' experience to know what the authors now consider would have been an adequate capacity. There is perhaps a tendency on the part of designers of electric power stations and systems to overdo things in this respect, thereby unnecessarily burdening production costs.

When the Authors first suggested reading a paper, they did not appreciate that so much information on railway electrification in Natal had been given in other papers read before this Institute; further, there has been quite an appreciable amount of publicity given in the technical press in South Africa and elsewhere. The scope of this paper, therefore, has been necessarily curtailed, but it is thought that special reference to the operating and maintenance features of the Electricity Supply Comission's Natal Central Undertaking would be of further interest.

Probable electricity requirements of South Africa in the next half century are established as well as the economically optimum mix of conventional generating plant needed to meet these requirements. The effects of limited resources of fuel, water, capital and manpower are discussed and consideration is given to environmental aspects and possible alternative sources of energy for electricity generation.

Dit is vir my en my mede-outeur ‘n groot voorreg en eer om in hierdie saal voor die SA Instituut van Elektrotegniese Ingenienrs die eerste referaat van ons sestige jubileumjaar te mag voordra. Ons bydrae be-handel die voorsiening van elektrisiteit in Suid-Afrika in die algemeen. Daar is in die annale van die Instituut betreklike min referate wat op hierdie onderwerp betrekking het. Om dié rede ook beskou ons dit as ‘n besondere eerbetuiging aan die industrie waaraan ons verbonde is, dat ons toegelaat word om in hierdie sestigste gedenkjaar van die Instituut die eerste referaat te mag lewer.

This paper explains the role of Municipalities in the electricity supply industry in the Republic of South Africa and describes in detail the high voltage electricity supply network of the City of Johannesburg.

This paper deals with the exceptionally high load densities and rapid load growth to be expected in the central area of Johannesburg with the advent of all-electric high-rise buildings. The post-war development of the transmission and distribution system is briefly described, leading to the stage from which further development to meet the new conditions of loading is necessary.

In South Africa the mining sector and particularly the gold mines of the Witwatersrand have always been a major consumer of electricity and, in fact, it was as a result of the vigorous policy of electrification adopted by the mining groups that the VFP was formed in 1906. The early history and development of the gold mines is a fascinating story and, for general interest, a brief historical review in this connection is given in the first section of this paper. The remaining sections discuss certain aspects of mining loads and requirements to give a general indication of the points requiring consideration in providing electricity supplies to mines.
The Chairman: This is the final discussion. I have prepared one or two remarks, and I will ask our Vice-President, Professor Buchanan, to take my place in the chair while I read them.

The President: I hope, gentlemen, that you have taken note that this paper bristles with contentious points, and I think that, members of this Institute, if even they are not ready to put forward figures in contradiction to what Professor Buchanan has given us, should ask some questions to get some more definite information out of Professor Buchanan on several points. Professor Buchanan's paper is of special interest at this time, because the subject of electrification, as Mr. Kirland has pointed out, is one which is at present receiving such a lot of attention in other countries. I hope, gentlemen, you will join in the discussion at the next meeting.

(Associate Member): The thanks of this Institute are due to Professor Buchanan for bis interesting paper on this subject. My idea in these few notes this evening is not so much to criticise the author's paper as to endeavour to express a few thoughts that have occurred to me in reading the progress of the electrification of railways in various parts of the world. Early in the paper disappointment is expressed at the tardiness with which electricity has been applied to railways; this remark is especially brought home to us in this country when we remember that Africa is the only continent in which no rail way electrification or conversion schemes are actually in existence. The author rightly hits the mark when he says that possibly the authorities who postpone investigation of the subject until electricians agree upon the best system, have a valid reason for their conservatism. It is now for the Electrical Engineering profession to make out their case for the electrification of railways, and then for local conditions to prove the deciding factors in the choice of systems. The Railway Gazcttry in discussing this aspect of the question, says : “ Too much stress must not be laid on the disadvantages of lack of uniformity in the system of electrification adopted by different railways. …. It is better to put up with these disadvantages of electric working than to wai t until the best system is discovered or to put difficulties in the way of its ever being discovered by tying all railways down to rigid uniformity.” Nevertheless, in a country situated as we are 6,000 miles from manufacturing centres, it is well that before any electrification takes place the various schemes that have been worked out in other parts of the world should be well studied and considered so that when the time does come for the consideration of railway electrification in this country, our profession will be fully conversant with the difficulties that have been found in other schemes.

The President: Before calling on Prof. Buchanan to reply to the discussion on his paper, I have great pleasure in extending a hearty welcome to Mr. Mills, Electrical Engineer to the South African Railways. I understand he proposes to say a few words on this paper. As you are aware, gentlemen, the subject of the electrification of railways is dealt with by Mr. Hoy, the General Manager of the South African Railways, in his report of last year. He thinks the time is now ripe for a report to be made on this matter dealing with South Africa generally, and, as it is a very important matter, I hope some result will come of it for the benefit of engineering generally. Prof. Buchanan is to be congratulated on having brought forward this question. I was to have contributed to the paper, but, unfortunately, I have not been able to find the time. My intention bad been to touch on that very much wider application of electricity : the supply of electrical power hand-in-hand with the electrification of railways throughout the country. I can safely predict that this side of the question will also have to be considered when electrification is being discussed. I feel certain that the linking up of the water powers now running to waste will assist in this greater scheme — the supply of cheap power for railways, irrigation, manufactures, and every other expansion in this country ; this is possible now as we know, for the way electrical supply has recently increased is an assurance that this is the direction of progress. I now have very much pleasure in calling on Mr. Mills.

It is always a matter of some small difficulty to discuss a descriptive paper, and the difficulty is increased rather than diminished when the paper ascends to the height of nearly absolute completeness, as in the present case. It is not often that we are so fortunate as to secure such an abundance of detail as the author has collected, obviously at the expenditure of much painstaking labour. If, on the one hand. the would-be discusser experiences a difficulty in finding suitable points of departure for criticism either constructive or destructive, on the other hand he will find many reasons for expressing appreciation of the author's work, and of the work of the Railway Administration and that of their advisers. In view of certain developments within the last 18 months, it is well to remember that the decision to electrify was based on the recommendation of most highly qualified consultants, and that electrification offered the only solution to effectively cope with the traffic conditions obtaining and forecast at the time that the question was investigated.

At the outset let me say that a good deal of credit attaches to Mr. Dalton for the very full information he has given us. Many people, in considering what information to give and what to withhold, are animated by the thought, “Oh, I don't think I'll put this in, it's not sufficiently interesting,” but Mr. Dalton has realised that the best plan is to give as wide and complete data as possible, and leave it to others to pick out the parts that particularly interest them.
It gives me more than the usual pleasure to congratulate Mr. Dalton upon his very fine paper.

I have to thank Mr. Everett very much for inviting me to contribute to the discussion on his very interesting and able paper on “Electro Magnetic Waves” and the earth's electric field and the unsolved problems associated with this.

A short history of electro-magnetic testing is given. This is followed by considerations leading to the design of experimental equipment. Tests with this equipment and modifications are described. Interpretation of charts shows to what extent correlation between magnetic record and condition of the rope has been obtained.

In a paper read before the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers in May 1954 experiments were described which led to the development of an electro-magnetic rope-testing method. This method has been in regular use by the Union Corporation Group of Mines since September 1952. During 1953-54 service equipment was designed and constructed, smaller and simpler in operation than the experimental equipment, Model III, described in the first paper.

Mr. President, gentlemen, before actually replying to the many points raised in the discussions on my paper, I should like to express my thanks to the various gentlemen who contributed to the discussions for their kind words of appreciation of my efforts. I make no claim to anything original in the paper; all I endeavoured to do was to collect what information I could on electro-magnetic waves and present this to you in as compact and simple a manner as possible. In so doing I lost sight of the fact that I was opening the door to some aspects of discussion on electro-magnetic waves to which it would be extraordinarily difficult to reply, particularly as radio to me is a hobby and not a profession.

A functional review of imaging target trackers is presented, with a description of the techniques and technologies used in each subsystem. Target tracking algorithms are also discussed. It is very clear that electro-optical target trackers have unique advantages, have been thoroughly proven and are becoming very popular. Given the healthy interaction between component technology on the one hand, and system requirements on the other there is a dramatic and increasing improvement in system characteristics.

An attempt is made to integrate this subject by bringing together all relevant data from the fields of shark protection, shark biology, neurophysiology, electrical fishing and electrical fish screens. Further tests to determine the conditions for electrotaxis in sharks are described The details of an experiment are given wherein an electrical anti-shark barrier was constructed and tested in the shark infested waters of St Lucia. An account is given of the methods adopted in solving some unusual problems which arose. These include the generation of a uniform electrical field in sea water, corrosion of electrodes, high-efficiency pulse-generation into an inductive load and the low-loss feeding of a low-impedance electrode system at the end of a long transmission line. The entire installation and experiment were carried out with a view to achieving a successful barrier with the minimum wastage of power. A 250 m barrier in 3 m of sea water consumed 35 kW. The experiment showed that electrotaxis is a necessary prerequisite for an electrical field to act as a repellant of harmful sharks.

The Practical Electro-Deposition of Gold. August Hoffman. Metal Industry. April, 1910. 1,700 words (Serial). Describes method of preparing articles to be gilded and the production of the Roman gold finish.

The Practical Electro-Deposition of Gold. August Hoffman. Metal Industry. April, 1910. 1,700 words (Serial). Describes method of preparing articles to be gilded and the production of the Roman gold finish.
The paper is based on the work of the Wit-watersrand Electrolysis Committee during the period 1940 to 1948, and gives the author's personal views on the subject.

The use of radio communication in the South African mining industry has only recently become significant. It is, however, a subject which is now receiving considerable attention at a research and development level both in this country and overseas, and working systems have been installed in various underground mines. The techniques used differ quite markedly from those used for radio communication above ground and this paper describes very briefly the propagation mechanisms involved so that the significance of the effects of rock strata on both wanted and unwanted radio signal propagation are appreciated.

The use of radio communication in the South African mining industry has only recently become significant. It is, however, a subject which is now receiving considerable attention at a research and development level both in this country and overseas, and working systems have been installed in various underground mines. The techniques used differ quite markedly from those used for radio communication above ground and this paper describes very briefly the propagation mechanisms involved so that the significance of the effects of rock strata on both wanted and unwanted radio signal propagation are appreciated.

The mechanisms by which electromagnetic energy may propagate underground are identified and discussed. Particular attention is paid to the work done in this field in South Africa over the last thirty years by presenting both theoretical and experimental results over a range of frequencies from mf to UHF. The results of similar investigations conducted by workers in other countries are cited and fairly good correlation between the various theories and the experimental data is shown to exist at both extremes of frequency. Guided modes are shown to be of major importance, with natural stratification and incidental guiding structures playing significant roles.

The paper reviews the present state of the art regarding power electronic switching devices, power electronic converter topologies, and the present theoretical concepts underlying the analysis and synthesis of power converters. Thoughts on the present limitations in power electronics are then presented, concentrating on the problems of conduction losses, switching losses and electromagnetic limitations. Developments regarding the use of non-linear turn-off snubbers, resonant techniques, driving technology for bipolars and other switches and selfoscillating converters with magnetic feedback are discussed. The contribution concludes by discussing some new applications that we have investigated, incorporating a number of the new developments that has been discussed in the paper.

An operational description of the Tellurometer system of distance measurement has been published but gives only the minimum of electronic detail for a broad understanding of the system. This paper is intended to supplement the operational description and will be confined to the electronic aspects only.

abstracts: The main object of this paper is to present a bird’s-eye view of electronics in the industry as a whole, but certain specific items of equipment will be described in some detail, to illustrate how the various electronics techniques have been applied to specific mining problems.
The question was asked how timing is achieved in one of the low-voltage ignition systems mentioned.

The paper is a general review of the factors involved in the design of electrical equipment for aircraft together with the operating difficulties encountered and some methods of overcoming them. Particular stress is given to the need for weight and volume reduction, the effect of altitude conditions on electrical apparatus and the application of alternating current. The electrical fire hazard is discussed and the effects of lightning discharges during flight. Mention is made of the mechanical design factors and the paper concludes with a note on future problems.

Embedded fuzzy controllers enhance and complement existing conventional controllers with intelligent functions derived from human control operator experience. Whenever the system to be controlled is highly nonlinear, parameters time-variant with, and certain features are too difficult or cumbersome to model, fuzzy controllers circumvent the difficulties associated with conventional mathematical modelling. This paper discusses the recently developed embedded fuzzy controller of Spoomet's Class 6E/6E1 3kV DC locomotive, which was developed to prevent the damage during starting as a result of uncontrolled wheel slip and incorrect taking up of slack. The results presented herein were achieved by using locomotive and load models and verified by both simulation and exhaustive in-service testing on a real locomotive.

This paper summarises an experiment developed to show the difference in EMI emitted by a hard- or soft-switched converter. The experiment was of a comparative nature. Both the development of the converters and measurement of their EMI is discussed. Both conducted and field induced EMI were measured. The soft-switched converter (auxiliary resonant commutated pole converter) shows big reductions in all EMI along with the benefits of lower losses and possible higher switching frequencies. The use of soft-switching techniques instead of conventional hard-switched topologies are therefore preferable in new designs.

Die gebruik van hoë-drywing laserpulse om die ioongeplante laag in p-op-n silikonselle te restoureer, is ondersoek. Dit is gevind dat 12 percent minder energie benodig was om die selle te vervaardig, in vergelyking met konvensionele termiese restourasie. Sonselle wat onderskeidelik termies en met laserpulse gerestoureer is, is vervaardig. Die selparameters van die laser-gerestoureerde selle was vergelykbaar met die termles-gerestoureerde selle. Die laserpulsrestourasie kan nog verbeter word en die moontlikheid van beter resultate bestaan. SYNOPSIS Laser pulse annealing of the implanted layer in p-on-n silicon solar cells was investigated. It was found that 12 per cent less energy was needed to manufacture cells compared with conventional thermal annealing. Thermal and laser pulse annealed solar cells were manufactured. The parameters of the laser pulse annealed cells were comparable with the thermal annealed cells. Better results are possible since the laser pulse annealing can be improved.

abstracts: “LET US NOW PRAISE FAMOUS MEN,” SAID KIPLING, “who with toil of their To-day, Bought for us Tomorrow”. “For their work continueth, Broad and deep continueth, Great beyond their knowing.” We meet at this Tenth Memorial Lecture to commemorate the life and work of Dr Bernard Price. It is a meet and proper thing so to remind ourselves each year of a man whose personality impressed itself so strongly on the electrical engineering progress of the Union, and on the profession that this Institute represents.

On 11 and 12 October, 1977 a symposium on the above subject was held at the CSIR Conference Centre in Pretoria. This symposium was organised by the Institute of Fuel (SA) and The Fuel Research Institute of South Africa.

The Rand Water Board was brought into being by The Rand Water Board Incorporation Ordinance No. 32 of 1903. Subsequent legislation under which the Board derives its powers was contained in various Ordinances and Acts, all of which have now been consolidated as the Rand Water Board Statutes (Private) Act, No. 17 of 1950.
Engineering students from six countries attended a seminar organized by the South Africa Foundation in Johannesburg on September 17.

It is well known that partial discharge activity is responsible for the deterioration of electrical insulation. In addition, partial discharge activity is also evidence of a degraded insulation system. Despite these facts no significant correlation has been found between partial discharge activity measured at the terminals of a rotating machine and the state of the insulation. In this paper it is proposed that the anomaly occurs because partial discharge measurements at the terminals of the machine are dominated by surface partial discharge activity in the overhang of the winding. These overhang discharges are not very damaging and mask the effects of small, but very damaging, discharges within the cell insulation in the slot area of the winding. An instrument is described which can distinguish between partial discharge activity in the slot and in the overhang. This instrument is used to make measurements on a stator where the cell insulation in the slot area has been deliberately damaged. These measurements vindicate the proposition made above.

After the historical development of engineering has been outlined to arrive at the concept of ‘environmental design’, the chaos currently present in some countries is discussed briefly in order to define its multiple cause. Subsequently the multiple solution to the problem is indicated, stressing that it has mainly a philosophical character, without which the process of environmental impact control, which is also discussed in general, cannot be executed effectively. It is explained that the appropriate philosophy centres around the proper definition of ‘environment’, and that the issue at stake is really the maintenance of balance between nature conservation and cultural development. Finally, the matrix and mapping techniques for documenting data in the environmental impact analysis process are discussed briefly.

The increasingly stringent and wideranging environmental standards being set in the world today pose many problems for the power utility engineer in design of his works. This paper briefly reviews such standards in the principal areas of air, water and noise, and indicates how an ultra-conservative approach to the protection of the environment is placing a significant cost burden on power utilities, and thereby onto the community. It questions the validity of many of the standards and the basis for environmental control and emphasises the necessity for the engineering profession to be involved in the determination of rational standards.

The errors which occur due to volt and current transformers, used in three phase-three and four wire power end VAr measurements are analysed, taking into Account the volt and current transformation errors, supply volt, load unbalance and load power factor. It it shown that a certain choice of VT ratio leads to acceptably low errors in measurement, irrespective of the accuracy class of the volt and current transformer. It is also shown that the three phase-four wire VAr measurement has a considerably lower error than its three phase-three wire counterpart.
