abstracts: The communication requirements of an electricity generation and distribution authority are discussed with particular reference to the Electricity Supply Commission. The advent of a National Control is introduced, and distinction is made between the communication traffic requirements of the control, maintenance and administration functions of a power network. The requirements of communication on large construction projects are included. Some of the features associated with power line carrier on the 400 kV system are related. The problems associated with the reduction in channel width of mobile radio communication systems are also mentioned.

This paper briefly records Escom's experience in the field of telemetering and remote control. A decailed description is given of the power system control and load despatch facilities which will be provided and capabilities of the hardware and software envisaged. Reasons for the system philosophy adopted and a justification for the necessity of such a system are also covered.
ieee_keywords: ['Power systems', 'Control systems', 'Power system stability', 'Power generation', 'Security', 'Economics', 'Supervisory control']

abstracts: A presentation of refractivity gradient and K-factor variation, based on radiosonde measurements carried out over 3 years in Maun, Botswana, is reported. It is observed that the median refractivity gradient within 0-200 m height range is -20 N-units/km. The percentage of the time for which the refractivity gradient is lower than -100 N-units/km is found to vary from a high 32% in February to 13% in August. Similarly, ducting is seen to be quite prevalent in summer (23% of the time in February, and 17% in November), while it is less prevalent in winter (12% of the time in May and 6% in August). A comparison between recent ITU-R plots for refractivity gradient and ducting occurrence frequency for the region, with the reported measurements, shows fairly close agreement. When ducting values are excluded, the median K value is found to be 1.1, while the effective value exceeded 99.9% of the time, K E , is 0.7. On the other hand, when all data are considered, the median value of K is found to be 1.03 while K E is determined to be 0.61.
author_keywords: ['Radio refractivity gradient', 'K-Factor', 'Atmospheric ducts', 'Radio refractivity measurements in Botswana']

abstracts: Market-driven economies and deregulated electricity industry environment have stimulated the minimization of technical and non-technical losses (NTL) even though they do not constitute major operational or quality of supply problems. Their impact is economic and utilities often passed down the costs to consumers. NTL need to be addressed to determine the overall performance of power networks, as these losses are expected to be more dominant at the sub-transmission (132kV-33kV) and reticulation (22kV and 11kV) levels of the electricity supply industry value chain. In some national grid operations, NTL are estimated to account for up to 30% in revenue losses to electric utilities, and overhead expenditure in added maintenance costs. This paper discusses a method for NTL evaluation and an effective management approach to loss minimization and revenue collection.

In this paper several power quality compensator topologies and control algorithms are evaluated on both a simulation and experimental basis. The introduction of various international standards and recommendations on power quality at the point of common coupling the demand to develop cheap, robust multi-functional power quality compensators has emerged from industry. This paper discusses and compares these power quality compensators from an operational and application viewpoint. This is done with the aid of EMTP simulations and experimental results on a 100 kVA multi-functional power quality compensator. The evaluation has been performed on the basis of power quality devices of 2 to 10 MVA power capacity that would be useful on distribution power levels. The main focus of the paper is on power quality compensator topologies with an integrated dip/sag compensation capability.
ieee_keywords: ['Power harmonic filters', 'Harmonic analysis', 'Topology', 'Power quality', 'Active filters', 'Voltage control', 'Passive filters']

abstracts: This paper presents the results of a survey which investigated the level of magnetic fields in informal housing in South Africa. The construction and wiring of a typical informal dwelling was established and a test dwelling was built. The magnetic field in the dwelling was measured at twelve locations under different conditions. The effect of the construction materials, wiring practice and appliance choice is noted. A further survey of the levels of magnetic fields in twenty residences in an informal settlement in Ivory Park is described. The results of the survey are compared to those of previous South African and Australian studies which were performed exclusively on formal dwellings. The paper shows that both previous and future international and South African research can be applied to the informal settlement case as there is no significant difference between the informal and formal dwelling results.

The theme of the Lecture is the evolutionary nature of telecommunications, in particular the possibilities for economic expansion of the network and the introduction or new services that advances in system concepts and new technologies are making possible, and the impact these could have on man's ecology, i.e. his ability to control and Improve the environment – for example, by reducing the need to travel to exchange and process information. Technological trends, advances in system concepts and possibilities for new services will be illustrated by outlining a number of protects forming part of the British Post Office research and development programme. The Lecture concludes by examining briefly the challenges that evolutionary telecommunications present to Administrations and Governments.

There is no novelty in the use of direct current for municipal electricity supply, but the general opinion seems to be that this is an obsolete system, best relegated to oblivion. The engineers of many undertakings that have changed over from direct current to alternating current speak bitterly of their early experience with D.C., and regard with amazement the survival of certain direct current schemes in this country. The only reasons that occur to them to account for such survivals are conservatism, unwillingness or inability to scrap obsolete equipment, and lack of funds to effect a change over.
I should like to make the following comments in connection with Mr. Richfield's paper: —

The President: If there is no further discussion I will now describe some of the apparatus on the table. I described them broadly in my address, but am exhibiting the apparatus before you in order to verify the statements I have made.

An experimental and simulation facility for the conversion of wind energy into electrical energy for feeding into the supply grid is studied, by using an induction generator with wound rotor and electronic rotor cascade with supply commutated inverter. An experimental setup, including a laboratory system with extensive converter controlled dc machine as simulated wind turbine, a practical wind tower system with data capture facilities and a maximal, self-adaptive power controller, is discussed. Some results on all the systems are presented, the feasibility of the system is established experimentally and problem areas are pointed out.

Merged transistor logic (1) (MTL) also known as multicollector logic (MCL) or integrated injection logic (2) (I 2 L), is a very recent development. First announced in October, 1972 this digital circuit technique has made bipolar large-scale integration (LSI) a practical proposition and thus seriously challenged the technologies already active in the LSI arena. This note reports some initial results obtained on an experimental I 2 L chip, using a standard bipolar diffusion technology with compatible standard layout rules.

This paper covers the experimental validation of FEM calculations of losses in a planar inductor under high frequency operating conditions. Thermally controlled experiments are performed at different frequencies in the operating circuit to validate the losses calculated by the FEM.

Serious use of object technology involves a software development process based upon one of the various methods advocated in the literature and frequently supported by a CASE tool. The methods and associated tools rely on the use of particular notations during analysis and design phases: usually some form of relationship diagram to express a so-called static object model of the envisaged system; and state charts to depict a dynamic model. The dynamic model is meant to express object behaviour that results from inter-object communication (IOC). The intention is that these models should seamlessly carry over to inform and guide the implementation phase. In general, commonly-used notations for the static object model seem to serve their purpose well. However, there is some doubt about the efficacy of dynamic model notations, particularly the state chart variety used in OMT. The problem is intimately associated with IOC in which so-called inter-object conditions play a part. State-of-the-art mechanisms to handle such inter-object conditions at an implementation level appear to be inadequate. Several alternative solutions to the problem are proposed and evaluated.

Coding schemes for the (d,k) = (1,2), (1,4), (2,3) and (2,4) discrete input restricted channels are presented. These coding schemes incorporate an ancillary channel for better utilization of the capacity of the (d,k) input restricted channel. A matrix method for the computation of the above mentioned capacity is shown The synthesis of coding schemes without and with the ancillary channel is presented. Error propagation and error probability behaviour were investigated by simulation and the results are presented.
ieee_keywords: ['Encoding', 'Mathematical model', 'Maximum likelihood decoding', 'Channel coding', 'Frequency modulation', 'Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions', 'Viterbi algorithm']

abstracts: Existing loads continue to increase with little signs of saturation and new major loads are sited to suit their particular requirements, an ore bed, good transport, availability of labour (unemployment areas), etc. With hydro power the location for generation is fixed but with other forms of primary power there is usually some choice. Unfortunately, this is often restricted by the availability of water, transport facilities, or, at present, with nuclear stations, the avoidance of densely populated areas; more recently with conventional thermal stations the avoidance of air pollution 1 , rather surprisingly in the Los Angeles basin. A further problem is the increasing difficulty in obtaining wayleaves particularly near load centres.

The analysis of frequency selective surfaces (FSS) using the Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) technique is reviewed. Results are presented for FDTD predictions and measurements using a free-space Gaussian beam measurement system for both tri-slot and ring FSS flat plate samples. Some practical considerations affecting radome applications are discussed, including Floquet modes, thick dielectric supports (single-sided vs. sandwiched), slot fillings and surface waves. Other computational methods are outlined and some conclusions drawn regarding optimal methods for FSS analysis. Current work in progress on radome applications is outlined.
ieee_keywords: ['Time-domain analysis', 'Frequency selective surfaces', 'Finite difference methods', 'Transient analysis', 'Wideband', 'Stability analysis', 'Radomes']

abstracts: The problem discussed in this paper is the ability of a power system, fed by synchronous generators operating in parallel over tie lines, to retain synchronism during, and subsequent to, a short circuit.

Examination of a rotor winch shows “growth of copper,” generally indicates that there is a temperature gradient down the slot, with the maximum temperature at the top. The unequal expansion of the turns so caused, associated with the condition that the pressure of individual turns is due to the integral of the centrifugal forces on the number of turns from the bottom of the slot, give rise to variation in “permanent set,” which is a maximum at the top of the slot.

This paper describes the difficulties associated with predicting and correcting the commutation of a D.C. machine. A theoretical model of the well known “black band” test is proposed. Further research on factors arising from the theoretical model will be considered in an effort to predict the commutation performance of the machine by the use of finite element analysis.

The first three power stations of the Victoria Falls and Transvaal Power Company, Limited, were located on the Reef, at Brakpan, Simmerpan and Eosherville. These stations were adjacent to the load centres and long distance transmission lines were not necessary for conveying the power* from the stations to the various load points. In the early days, the distribution network on the Reef consisted of 10 kV and 20 kV overhead lines and, at a later### date, 40 kV distribution feeders and interconncctors were adopted. “With the growth of load and the general extension of the system, it became necessary to construct further power stations and, for reasons not relevant to the subject matter of this paper, these stations were located some distance from the Reef; the first of these was Vereeniging, 35 miles to the south of Johannesburg, followed by Witbank, 64 miles north-east of Brakpan and, later, Klip was installed, this station being about 32 miles to the south of Johannesburg.

Mr. President and gentlemen, Professor Goodlet's paper deals with a subject of considerable interest to all power system engineers. However, very little detailed information has been published about actual cases of system instability and I, therefore, feel that some practical experience of two occurrences may be of interest to the members.

In a review of the influences imposed on the design of large HV transformers by the dimensional and weight limitations of transport, consideration is given to the alternative approaches: (a) three-phase units of conventional design, (b) site assembly, (c) single-phase construction.
ieee_keywords: ['Windings', 'Transformer cores', 'Oil insulation', 'Propagation losses', 'Power transformer insulation', 'Legged locomotion', 'Temperature measurement']

abstracts: All the machinery for a 11·8 mW diesel power station in South Korea was installed and running within eight months of the contract being awarded to a United Kingdom company.

It is a very long time since I addressed a gathering of electrical engineers in this hall, and I must say that I experience pangs of nostalgia when thinking of the many memorable meetings that I attended here and the many enjoyable functions that my wife and I took part in. So when I was asked to speak to you this afternoon, I jumped at the opportunity of renewing old friendships and associations, always tinged with the sorrow that so many of them were with people who have now passed away. Although my address to you is by no means intended to be a service in memoriam, it is inevitable that if I am to talk about the growth of electrical engineering in South Africa I should be thinking about the men we knew who promoted and fostered its growth. However, the letter inviting me to speak at this function suggested an address ‘of a light-hearted nature’, and so I will content myself with remembering our many friends and associates of the past and believing that in spirit they are with us in this significant year of the 150th anniversary of Michael Faraday and Joseph Henry.

An electronic system that gives realistic visual demonstration of complexor (phasor) diagrams on the screen of a cathode ray tube is described. One complexor is used as the reference and shown as a horizontal straight line from the centre of the display screen, while the other phasors can be displayed either as a dot on the screen or as a straight line. The dot representation permits the display of complexor loci as test-circuit parameters are altered. The system is designed to work on 50 Hz only.

abstracts: Before dealing with the problems in regard to the localization of faults on submarine telegraph cables, a little should be said about the physical nature of such cables.
The rather unusual type of telephone cable failure reported by Messrs. J. K. Gillett and H. Nevill is of more than ordinary interest.
Mr. Chairman and gentlemen, herewith are a few notes relating to a series of faults on a telephone cable during a lightning storm.

I was considerably interested in a review in the June 18th issue of “The Electrician,” of an article presented before your Institute by Messrs. Gillett and Nevill on “Faults on a Telephone Cable during a Lightning Storm,” and I thought the authors might be interested in knowing that another similar fault, under similar conditions, had been observed in this country.

The concept of a fail-silent processing module makes it possible to take advantage of the ease with which redundant processing modules can be included in a cluster of processing modules of a distributed computer control system in order to implement hardware fault tolerance. The issues involved in implementing a fail-silent processing module by employing a set of sub-processors and a solution to the Byzantine generals problem are analyzed. It is concluded that this approach appears to provide a feasible basis for future practical implementations of a fail-silent processing module.

A cost-effective device for determining pressure contours under a human foot has wide application in medical diagnosis, rehabilitation and sports medicine. This paper details feasibility study and prototype development of such a measurement system. The system scans a grid of quasi-discrete pressure sensors formed by pairs of electrodes and a sheet of Teledeltos paper and provides a numerical output with graphical representation. With a resolution of 6 mm and a speed of 10 frames per second the system provides a low-cost solution to determine pressure contours under a human foot and could provide dynamic pressure measurement of a runner.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, — I am the “prologue and chorus” of the show to night — by accident. (Laughter). I realise that the prologue and the chorus are very unimportant parts of any performance, and I let you know in advance, so that any fears you may feel that you are to listen to a lecture may be laid aside.

A feedback filter employing a parallel-T network in the forward loop of a feedback amplifier is described with a cutoff frequency continuously variable over a range of 2·3 to 1. Theory of operation and design equations are presented.
Magnetic cores made of ferrite are nowadays irreplaceable in many spheres of telecommunications.
Magnetic cores made of ferrite are nowadays irreplaceable in many spheres of telecommunications.

Culminating over a decade of laboratory research into devices and material for wideband communication over optical fibre waveguides, the decision was made to stage a field trial system in 1977 in the representative environment of an operating authority, the British Post Office. The system was installed in a standard duct system, employed underground repeater housings and used a transmission bit rate as high as the current stage of development allowed. The object of the experiment was to assess installation and operating experience and to evaluate performance using live telephone and television traffic. The results of experiments are reported and comments made on the practical experience gained during installation and in use in a national telecommunications environment.

I would like to thank those gentlemen who have contributed so much useful information to the discussion. Mr. McDonald is to be congratulated on the testing set evolved by him to meet specific requirements when no commercial sets were available. It would be interesting to know if it has been used to test bushings other than the 6$md6 kV ones for which it was built, and if so, what results were obtained. It can be agreed that “a 20 per cent. power-factor bushing need not necessarily be nearer breakdown than a 15 per cent. bushing,” as this is largely conditioned by what portion of the composite structure comprising the bushing is giving rise to the high power-factor, and by the stress distribution. Actually, it is not a material point whether a bushing is 15 or 20 per cent., as it is difficult to consider any insulator with a power-factor of this order as other than a potential hazard.

The paper is of great interest to us and should be extremely valuable in directing the attention of maintenance engineers to the desirability of making regular dielectric loss measurements on important insulation. Nowadays, continuity of supply must be assured, and any reasonable additional means to advance this end should be employed.

Mr. A. E. Yal Davles (Member): Mr. President and gentlemen, I enjoyed read ing Mr. Fenwick's paper; it is a dispas sionate statement not so much of the methods of field-testing high voltage bush ings as of the causes which led to the necessity to test high-tension bushings, and the theme of my contribution to the dis cussion is that a really good bushing should not require testing.

The defects which occur in condenser type bushings are discussed and examples of the consequences of unchecked deterioration are given. Methods of detecting such defects in their incipient stage are considered.

Mr. Fenwick has presented a most interesting paper on a subject which is of first importance to the supply industry in peace and war, and which I feel sure will encourage other power-supply companies to study the important subject of field testing of insulation.

Mr. Fenwick is to be congratulated on his very interesting and timely paper setting out so clearly his experiences on field testing of high-voltage bushings. It reflects well on his Company that these tests were commenced some time before the issue of B.S.S. 1086 — A Code of Practice for Maintenance of Electrical Switchgear — which states the desirability of routine power-factor testing of switchgear insulation in preference to routine high-voltage testing.

This paper presents 15 years of measured data of lightning strikes to a 60 m tall research mast situated in the Transvaal Highveld in South Africa. The peak amplitude, charge, and action integral, and rate of rise of current are analysed and compared to global data as analysed by other researchers. The paper concludes that there is no significant difference between the observations on the 60 m mast and data obtained from other areas of the world.

This film was lent by Messrs. Hubert Davies & Co., Ltd., and proved to be of great technical interest. It had been prepared especially for exhibition before engineering societies, and covered all the major technical points in this type of plant. The spectacular glass-blowing scenes were particularly appreciated, and it was obvious that bulb making technique has developed on scientific lines to a very efficient and reliable manufacturing process.

South Africa's very first Antennas and Propagation Symposium took place from 16 to 18 May 1983 at the CSIR's Conference Centre in Pretoria. One hundred and thirty delegates attended and highlights included the opening of the symposium by SAIEE President. Mr J D N van Wyk, the wide-ranging and interesting keynote address by Prof P J B Clarricoats of Queen Mary College, London, a cocktail party sponsored by Protea PNI, and a visit to the CSIR's newly-established antenna test range at Paardefontein, north of Pretoria.

abstracts: The first animal dinner of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers was held on Friday, December 8, 1911, at the Grand National Hotel. Mr. John H. Rider (President of the Institute) presided, and there were also present : — Messrs. G. V. Adendorff, A. N. Aikman, J. W. Anson, T. J. Armstrong, R. C. Atkinson, Major the Hon. W. L. Bagot, Messrs. G. E. A.

To be invited to give the Bernard Price Memorial lecture on the occasion of your Golden Jubilee is indeed a signal honour for which I am most grateful. In coming here I too can pay my respects to a great engineer and benefactor to science. I recall showing Bernard Price some artificial lightning discharges of one to three million volts in the High Voltage Laboratory of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company and describing to him how our studies of the spark discharge had been of direct help to Dr Schonland in developing ideas of the mechanism of the lightning discharge. His visit occurred at the time when he must have been contemplating the creation of the Geophysical Institute here, and I collaborated in further research with Dr Schonland after he became director of the Institute, so I feel my links with Bernard Price are fairly strong.

When bringing forward this paper I intended to draw the attention of the local electrical engineers to the great field they had before them in South Africa for applying their knowledge and forces. I did not think, however, that much discussion would arise out of it, as this industry is unknown as yet in South Africa, and probably very few had any practical knowledge of it. In my opinion, it is not men who create an industry, but an industry that creates men. As soon as the rulers of the Union realise what riches are hidden in the first ten inches of the soil of South Africa, and as soon as South African agricultural products appear on the European markets—to conquer them—the manufacture of artificial nitrogen must and will spring up locally, and the new industry will then create those electrical engineers who will take a keen interest in this question. I hope in five or ten years time my paper will be more commented upon and discussed than it has been at the present time.

Importance of Problem. — In 1906, in my book entitled "Explosives as vised in European Mines," I described at length the efforts of the great French chemists of the eighteenth century to prepare on a commercial scale nitrate of potassium, which was and still is used for the production of gunpowder, in that time being of greater interest then nowadays. And indeed, at that time nitrate of potassium or saltpetre was known only as a spontaneous formation on the surface of the earth in certain regions of Egypt and in India, and also nitrates of Ca and Mn which are formed on the walls of stables due to fermentation of urine and the action of the products of fermentation on the constructional materials. The problem was a very difficult one.
The aims of this examination are to verify the theory of the shaded-pole principle and to investigate the conditions existing in the air gap under a partially shaded pole.

Nineteen-sixty-three was a momentous year for the world. It was the year the stork passed the plough; the year when baby-supply started to pass food-supply. But the babies that fed on their mothers' milk in 1963 now have lusty appetites; their mothers have continued to churn out children; and it is reckoned that the production of babies is currently beating the production of food at the rate of 2:1. This is a world problem but it can't be solved simply by the have countries sending emergency shipments of grain to feed famine-stricken have-not countries. The problem is too basic for ad hoc solutions.

The Tenth Meeting of the C.I.G.R.E. (International High Tension Conference) will be held in Paris from Thursday, June 29th, until Saturday, July 8th, next: it will be a continuation of the nine former meetings, which have been held regularly every two years since 1921, at which all the important problems of electro technical art come up for periodical discussion.

The functional top-down design approach and structural deficiencies of FORTRAN are strong contributing causes to structural decay in engineering and scientific application packages. Many programs become unmaintainable after several years of user-requested developments and executional environment changes. This paper consideres how such packages may be practically and economically renewed (instead of discarded) by recovering the original design information, respecifying and reimplementing using object-centred design techniques. The approach will be described and illustrated with reference to experience acquired during the renewal of LINSIM, an electrical network (circuit) design, simulation and optimisation package and HEX, a program for analysis of PIXE X-Ray spectra. The impact of CASE tools on the design recovery stage, the need for on-hand application domain expertise and the rewards of software reuse, are all emphasized.

The paper outlines briefly the developments leading to modern modulation techniques, and presents an approach to the theory of frequency and phase modulation, using as a basis the e.m.f. induced in a loop rotating in a uniform magnetic field. This approach overcomes the common difficulties in understanding the differences between the two methods of modulation which arise from the conventional text-book treatments.

This paper describes a full-wave computational electromagnetics model of a longitudinal slot in the narrow wall of rectangular waveguide coupled with an internal thin E-plane fin inside the waveguide. The waveguide wall is assumed to have finite thickness. Appropriate Green functions are used in a method of moments solution of the magnetic current distributions in the waveguide slot, and the electric surface current on the fin. Results obtained with an implementation of the model are verified by comparison to measured results, and illustrate the ability of the E-plane fin to affect the radiation characteristics of the waveguide slot.
ieee_keywords: ['Electromagnetic waveguides', 'Testing', 'Transmission line matrix methods', 'Surface waves', 'Numerical models', 'Method of moments', 'Current distribution']

abstracts: When I landed at East London from the seventh voyage of RMS Windsor Castle, I was assisted by the use of the passenger ‘basket’. On disembarkation at Durban, when no one came to meet me, I used a Zulu rickshaw for transport to my agent's office in Smith Street. I introduced myself to the manager who then asked me ‘when was I going back?‘ After controlling my reaction to his enquiry, I made my hotel booking from his office.

The increasing demand for underground high power electric transmission systems has stimulated the development of new insulating media. Sulphur hexaflouride (SF 6 ) has found wide applications for metalclad switchgear up to very high voltages and can also be used to insulate high voltage cables. The SF 6 molecule tends to form negative ions, which, in turn, leads to high breakdown strength. However, in practical applications considerable reduction of the breakdown voltage may occur due to the movement of free particles and to the shapes and surfaces of the unavoidable insulator spacers. Three-phase gas insulated cables have very favourable electrical parameters and high power transmission capabilities which can exceed 1 000 MVA without artificial cooling. First installations started operating only a few years ago. High voltage testing of gas insulated cables is a special problem because it has to be done on site. The high capacitance of the test object makes it necessary to develop new test techniques to ensure high reliability in service. Finally, attention is given to practical installations of SF 6 insulated transmission systems and expected developments of this very promising new technique as a means to improve the transmission and distribution of electrical energy.

Research is a process of probing unknown areas. By its very nature it prohibits the worker in this field from laying down precise specifications for the instrumentation required. What may seem to be of relatively little importance at the outset may become a major factor as work progresses. This dictates that the instrumentation must be adaptable and ideally be almost chameleon-like in its character.

abstracts: The President: Under this heading, gentlemen. I am going to seize the opportunity, although I was precluded from being present at the wonderful visit the members of the Institute paid to the General Post Office, of making special reference to it. I understand that this visit was quite unique in the history of the Institute, both in so far as the numbers present were concerned, and also the wonderful manner in which the visit, which was in the very capable hands of Mr. Griffith, the Chief Engineer of the Post Office, was organised. We feel very grateful to Mr. Griffith, the Postmaster-General and the whole of the Post Office staff who gave so willingly of their time to conduct the several parties round the Post Office. I was in Pretoria yesterday and called on Mr. Griffith to thank him personally, and the opportunity was also afforded me of personally thanking the Postmaster-General on behalf of the Institute for the very successful visit they afforded us. We feel very grateful, and I am sure the Institute as a whole will remember the visit for many years; to come. During the course of conversation, the Postmaster-General mentioned that he quite appreciated the fact that the time afforded did not allow those particularly interested in any phase of the Post Office working to thoroughly investigate, analyse and appreciate the technical value of the work that has been put in, and he authorised me to tell you that at any time a small party wishes to go round the Post Office, he felt sure, Mr. Griffith, the Chief Engineer, would be only too pleased to take them to any portion that might specially interest them. (Applause.)

The paper develops a generalised mathematical formulation of basic power system reliability concepts. A unified presentation of the concepts of probability, transition rates between states, frequency and duration of event occurrence, in respect of state and cumulative conditions, is derived in a mathematically rigorous form as integral or differential equations. The interconnections of components is presented in the form of general results and the general forms of conventional power system reliability criteria are derived.
ieee_keywords: ['Power system reliability', 'Generators', 'Probability density function', 'Probability', 'Mathematical model', 'Stochastic processes', 'Power transmission lines']

abstracts: When modelling converter circuits one is faced with the problem of modelling the non-linear switches. A piecewise linear model of a switch is used to develop a generalised method to model most converter circuits in the time domain. This model uses a null current source and a null voltage source to model the on and the off modes of the switch respectively. This model allows one to formally derive the state equations, the output equations and the switching function of most converter circuits. Limitations of the method as well as improved models of the switches are discussed. A model of the auto sequential current inverter is developed to demonstrate the techniques used.

It seems a far cry from the science of metallurgy to that of electrical engineering, each in itself being a specialist study, but, as in all forms and branches of science overlaps inevitably occur, often where least expected.

Geothermal energy is the heat of the earth's interior created by vast sources of energy from the hot magma of the interior. Heat releases through radioactive decay of minerals, interior friction, etc. The most obvious surface indications are hot springs, geysers and fumeroles. With present technology the earth's heat can be used only through water in the form of steam and hot water under pressure. In four of the six presently known types of geothermal resources, nature provides us with both the heat and the water together. It is for this reason that I predict the early and large-scale development of these four types of geothermal resources whereas the other two types may require longer development periods.

By germanium power rectifiers is meant rectifiers giving outputs that can be measured in kilowatts. A great deal of work has been done in Rugby on this subject and this paper endeavours to give some account of the present position.

In this paper we parameterize the Gilbert channel model for Gaussian Minimum Shift Keying, as used for example in the GSM cellular system, on a flat Rayleigh fading channel. The generation of the appropriate data for the derivation of the discrete channel model, is done by means of a simulation. In the simulation, we assume that the fading is slow enough such that the receiver may perform perfect carrier recovery and synchronization. We find analytical expressions for the parameters of the model as a function of the average signal-to-noise ratio (for a fixed Doppler shift), and as a function of maximum Doppler shift (for a fixed average signal-to-noise ratio) by means of a curve fit.
ieee_keywords: ['Mathematical model', 'Channel models', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Doppler shift', 'Markov processes', 'Rayleigh channels', 'Numerical models']

abstracts: Proposed CIE recommendations for glare in sports lighting are reformulated and their implications for practical design are analysed. Mounting height is crucial for limiting glare and other aspects such as floodlighting characteristics and aiming angles are also important.

This is an integrating paper on glare, a serious problem in many otherwise well-lit interiors. Means of minimising glare are described and a survey is given of numerous methods proposed during the past fifteen years for assessing direct glare quantitatively. The British Code method and the DGF-method proposed by the author are explained in detail. Some uncertainties discussed show that our understanding of glare is incomplete and that the intricate relations are not easily condensed into a simple specification rule. Nevertheless, prediction of glare by one of the existing methods can prevent serious design mistakes.

The most frequent use of coaxial cable is to prevent electrical noise adding to signals passing between equipment. Ground voltage differences exist and appear in series with the signal. The screen of a coaxial cable grounded at both ends induces a voltage in the inner conductor which starts cancelling ground voltages at about 2.5 kHz and can produce -60 dB cancellation at 10 MHz. The signal current also produces a flux external to the screen, which induces a loop current through the screen and ground path. Above 2.5 kHz, the loop current starts opposing the returning ground current, redirecting it from the lower impedance ground path to the screen, thereby reducing the external magnetic field. An equivalent circuit explains the phenomena and the extreme sensitivity of coax and oscilloscope probes to short pigtail leads. Experiments and data are described which justify the theory. Remarks are made on pigtails, cable trays, and feeding power via coax.

The world is currently in the midst of a revival phase with computers and communications some of the main drivers of this revival. Although this general statement is not surprising, the specific influence that it has on the lives of the Electrical and Electronic engineering fraternity as well as the world as a whole can only be appreciated by contemplating the size of the industry and its impact on our lives. For instance, the electronics industry is currently the the worlds third largest industrial sector by revenue and 12 of the world's top 50 industrial companies operate in the Electrical, Electronic and Computer industries. What is even more important in terms of this special issue of the Transactions on CDMA Technology is that six of the top 10 Electronics companies in the world are involved in the wireless access business in some form or another. Clearly the business of wireless access is becoming increasingly important in world terms, but perhaps even more importantly, in terms of the development of countries like South Africa.

abstracts: The appearance of this Special Edition of the Transactions of the SAIEE coincides with the dawning of a new era in multimedia wireless access. Not only is the third generation (3G) wireless systems in the process of being deployed, but also broadband Personal Communication Systems and Networks (PCS and PCN). In those areas where the 3G roll-out is still being contemplated, interim 2.5G extensions of the existing 2G (GSM and IS95) cellular standards, such as GPRS, EDGE and cdma2000, are already under way. Elsewhere, especially in Europe, Asia (Japan and China) and the USA, 3G cellular standards (UMTS/3GPP and 3GPP2) are already operational in many main centra.

Abstract With the rapid expansion of the Internet and packet switched networks, combined voice and video communication via packet switched networks is becoming a reality. Two major technologies are currently implemented for real time voice and video communication over IP: Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) and the ITU-T's H.323 standard. In order to bill for voice and video services delivered via the Internet, billable information needs to be extracted from the packet flow. The H.323 standard incorporates various protocols for voice and video communication purposes the most important being the RTP/RTCP media transport protocols, the H.225 call signalling protocols, and the H.245 call control protocol. We firstly determine whether the H.323 suite of protocols contain extractable information for use in billing. This paper then shows how sufficient information can be extracted from the IP packet flow for billing and service level agreement purposes of H.323 Internet-based calls.
author_keywords: ['H.323 Standard', 'Session Initiation Protocol', 'IP Packet Flow', 'Service Level Agreement', 'Packet Switched Networks']

abstracts: An instrument capable of performing time-domain electrical power analysis is proposed and practical results achieved with it are presented. Moderate cost was one of the main criteria as there are several dedicated instruments, currently available, at high costs, which could compete with several of the features provided by this unit. The design of the TDPMI (Time Domain Power Measuring Instrument) has however been optimized for power system measurements and is linked to a host personal computer. The personal computer performs the signal processing and mathematical analysis, while the hardware system performs the data acquisition. This technical note further describes some of the on-line operational characteristics of this measurement system which has excellent industrialization prospects.

Part of this paper will deal with harmonics in general and part will deal with magnetising currents in A.C. circuits. I have divided the paper into three sections: the first deals with the causes of harmonics, the second with effects, and the third with the elimination of harmonics.

When the United States launched its first unmanned two-seater Gemini test vehicle in April the South African tracking station was unable to take part in the operation. It was in the middle of a major changeover during the expansion of the Hartebeesthoek station, north-west of Krugersdorp, Transvaal.

In this paper, which is partly expository, hash functions, in their cryptological applications, are considered. In particular, functions which use squaring modulo the product of two large primes are discussed and it is shown that of the sixteen easily implementable functions, at most two may be suitable for hashing. Since even these remaining two have inherent weaknesses, it is concluded that hash functions of the type considered here cannot be used on their own, but may be suitable as components in more elaborate structures.

Electric energy at a moderate cost is one of the fundamental prerequisites for the development of any community. The supply of electric energy to decentralized communities is however associated with long, low power transmission lines, highly distorted supplies, high capital and maintenance costs and low reliability. Renewable energy sources are proposed to overcome the above mentioned limitations. Typical photovoltaic solar panels, small wind and hydro turbines and non-renewable diesel generators can be utilized as complementary energy sources, which can be combined in a cost effective manner with major savings on capital expenditure and thus with overall energy cost savings. This paper describes the topologies, cost analysis, computer-aided design and control of these hybrid energy systems.
ieee_keywords: ['Topology', 'Artificial neural networks', 'Wind turbines', 'Batteries', 'Reliability', 'Pulse width modulation', 'Hydraulic turbines']

abstracts: For the specialized application of transistors, some knowledge of their electrical and physical characteristics is required. As is the case with valves, transistor manufacturers supply a limited amount of data about their product to serve as a guide for the design engineer. However, with the transistor art at its present state of development, there still exists some controversy about what the most relevant data is that has to accompany the device into the hands of the experimenter.

This paper describes the development and design of high performance, matched, double pole, double throw UHF PIN diode switches. It features very small reflection coefficients at all four ports in both switch states with low insertion loss and high isolation. The switch design is based on a compact distributed filter, resulting in small size for the realized performance.

This paper investigates the fabrication and novel application of high permittivity ceramic materials for use in power electronic circuits. Manufacturing of materials with a wide range of ∊ r values and the influence of dielectric permittivity on the circuit behaviour of a converter, employing planar connections, are investigated.
author_keywords: ['High permittivity dielectrics', 'Planar structures', 'Low impedance power transmission lines']

abstracts: The paper deals with simultaneous compensation of all components of non-active power: reactive power, higher harmonics and an asymmetry in a three-phase network. A new control method which allows to eliminate any non-active components without any delay time is proposed. In this paper a new configuration of a compensator power circuit is also proposed. The compensation ability of the new system was verified experimentally.
ieee_keywords: ['Harmonic analysis', 'Control systems', 'Current measurement', 'Voltage measurement', 'Power harmonic filters', 'Thyristors', 'Switches']

abstracts: A high-efficiency boost converter for converting the output voltage of a solar panel array, to the required dc bus voltage, feeding a battery bank and an inverter, is described. The series inclusion of this converter necessitates a high efficiency converter. This is attained by effective drive circuitry, implementing a regenerative snubber, using low loss core material and utilizing Schottky diodes. A comparative investigation between bipolar transistors, and field effect transistors as switching elements, is made towards total converter efficiency. Maximum power tracking is achieved by measurements of the output current, maximizing output power. The batteries, which serve as an energy storage are expensive and therefore necessitates charging and discharging protection. This is achieved by limiting the maximum allowable charge current to a value which depends on the battery state of charge.
ieee_keywords: ['Batteries', 'Switches', 'State of charge', 'Renewable energy sources', 'Logic gates', 'Snubbers', 'Field effect transistors']
author_keywords: ['Power electronics in generation and transmission', 'Maximal power control', 'Battery characteristics', 'Renewable energy sources']

abstracts: The Power Division of the Institution of Electrical Engineers is arranging a one-week conference on high-voltage dc transmission, which will take place towards the end of September, 1966.
In the Museum for Science and Industry, Didacta Building, 211 Skinner Street, Pretoria on Thursday, 26th and Friday, 27th October, 1967

Different meanings may be attached to the term high structure depending on the reference level from which the height is measured. To make this statement more explicit let us consider three specific examples of high structures for which lightning data are available. The first of these is the Empire State Building, New York, which has a height of 380 metres (1250 ft) above ground level, the ground being approximately at sea level. The building is not isolated but is surrounded by other tall buildings, so that in effect there is a grouped complex of high structures with the top of the Empire State Building forming its peak.

A novel n-GaAs Hall sensor is investigated. The sensor structure is grown by liquid phase epitaxy on a semi-insulating GaAs substrate. The sensor is characterised by an absolute magnetosensitivity S DL = 1 V/T, nonlinearity not exceeding 0.05 %, and offset voltage not exceeding 20 μV for a magnetic field within the interval [-1.5,1.5] T at room temperature. The influence of the technology and the design on the characteristics of the sensor is investigated.

A control system is described which controls the power factor of a motor close to unity by an adaptive technique. The technique is also successfully used to tune a radio frequency filter to give maximum output.
ieee_keywords: ['Reactive power', 'Noise measurement', 'Perturbation methods', 'Generators', 'Current measurement', 'Control systems', 'Synchronous machines']

abstracts: An interesting visit was paid by some 21 members, wives and friends to the historical village of Pilgrim's Rest over the weekend of 14th—16th November, 1980. The visit started on a somewhat unfortunate note. It was discovered at a late hour that the bus which had been hired for the trip had bench seats which are not very comfortable for a long journey. The good news was that the renting company had a more comfortable vehicle available which was promptly hired, but at an increase in the cost for the trip from R25,00 per person to R40,00.

Following the general worldwide trend of de-regulation and privatisation of the telecommunication market, the South African Government issued an Invitation to Apply for the second Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) licence. The Second National Operator will be issued with a PSTN license to provide competing services. The entry of such a New Entrant Operator (NEO) into the territory currently occupied by a monopoly Incumbent Operator (10) will be built on a sound case for doing the business.

The accepted 50/60 Hz current, human electro-physiological threshold responses of feeling, let-go, difficult breathing, fibrillation & convulsions are reviewed, Similar response thresholds are required for the safe design of electrical shark repellents where the relevant parameter measured in sea-water is volt per metre. An experiment is described which hypothesizes a simple proportional relationship between the two sets of electrical conditions. This involves the use of a single test subject as a “transfer standard” between the two. The transfer coefficient was determined at the threshold of feeling and used to predict where the let-go threshold field strength in sea-water should lie. The equivalent ‘let-go’ threshold case was determined. This estimate confirmed the predicted value. The same proportional relationship is consequently applied to indicate the threshold field strength at which difficult breathing, fibrillation and convulsions may occur. Useful data on 50 Hz fields in sea-water is also derived.

A tutorial review of hybrid computational electromagnetic methods suitable for radio-frequency electromagnetic radiation and scattering problems is presented. The emphasis is on the method of moments (MoM), physical optics (PO) and the uniform theory of diffraction (UTD), and in particular on methods for hydridising them. Such hybrid formulations permit computer simulation of problems sufficiently large electromagnetically to have prohibitive computational requirements using purely the MoM, but not sufficiently large to reliably apply asymptotic methods such as the UTD. Several examples using a commercially available hybrid code are presented, to highlight the advantages of hybrid techniques. A case where the hybrid MOM/PO formulation failed is also reviewed. The industrial use of such codes is discussed, emphasising both the potential power of the approach for complex problems, as well as the advisability of understanding the underlying formulations
ieee_keywords: ['Method of moments', 'Finite element analysis', 'Integral equations', 'Antennas', 'Wires', 'Surface waves', 'Mathematical model']

abstracts: A preliminary study of the possibility of developing the water resources of the Tugela river for hydro-electric purposes has shown that Introduction of about 500 MW of hydro plant into the Natal system by the year 1975 would be both economic and technically feasible.

When the IEC Committee for standards covering electrical equipment in medical practice (Technical Committee No. 62) held its first meeting in 1968, the acting Chairman of TC 62, Professor F Wachsmann, stated that ‘radiation protection can be better achieved by one gram of human brains than by a kilogram of lead’. This statement signalled the future direction of TC 62 in preparing standards for radiation equipment used in medical practice. Through the work of medical experts from all corners of the world representing the views of manufacturers, the medical professions, hospital authorities and other interested parties, thirteen standards covering radiation aspects have been issued and have become widely used in the medical world. But the work of TC 62 has not only dealt with radiation — it has been expanded to cover the total needs of medical electrical equipment. Some 20 standards have been issued to date including Publication 601-1, the comprehensive general safety standard thai applies to all types of medical electrical equipment. Work in hand covers some 40 other medical electrical standards. In a soon-to-be-published article in the journal ‘Middle East Health’, Mr Gerrit Gaikhorst, Secretary of IEC Sub-Committee 62A: Common Aspects, expounds the work of his Committee for medical equipment for the patient, operator and equipment, and on the safe application of equipment. The IEC Bulletin presents these extracts from Mr Gaikhorst's article.
On 31st May, Dr G F Gainsborough retired as Secretary of the IEE after 18 years of distinguished service to the Institution and to the electrical-engineering profession.
On 31st May, Dr G F Gainsborough retired as Secretary of the IEE after 18 years of distinguished service to the Institution and to the electrical-engineering profession.

The IEEE Region 8 AFRICON series of conferences started in Nairobi in 1983. This was followed by conferences held in Abidjan (1987). Mbabane (1992). Stellenbosch (1996), Cape Town (1999), and George (2002). In recent years the IEEE South African Section has been responsible for the organization of the conferences in cooperation with a number of other South African Higher Education institutions.

abstracts: This paper describes an investigation into the use of a modern multivariable controller design technique which improves the performance of a voltage-source-fed induction motor. It presents the induction motor nonlinear mathematical model from which a linearized model is deduced. The Inverse Nyquist Array controller design method is then applied to the linearized model to generate a control scheme which uses airgap flux and motor speed as outputs and source voltage and frequency as inputs. The scheme is then implemented software-wise on the nonlinear simulation model in order to assess its dynamic performance. Results from these simulations demonstrate that the motor's transient performance can be considerably improved by using a multivariable controller.
ieee_keywords: ['Induction motors', 'Mathematical model', 'Voltage control', 'Atmospheric modeling', 'Rotors', 'Transient analysis', 'Transfer functions']

abstracts: This paper contributes by providing a linear differential equation which captures the response of residential dial-up subscribers to a tariff function. South African data was gathered on residential subscribers who were making use of cheaper off-peak rates for dial-up Internet service outside business hours. Traffic intensity was found to be heavily dependent on the call tariff, with the steepest increase in traffic occurring at the time of rate changeover. It was also unexpectedly found that the traffic intensity dropped off exponentially as subscribers completed their tasks. The subscribers' response to a tariff change was then treated as a dynamic system, with input x(t) being the excitation function, representing the tariff imposed by the single network operator, and an output y(t), to represent the function of the traffic resulting from the imposed tariff. The response to the sudden tariff decrease was thus captured in a linear differential equation. Using the equation, the subscribers' response to a set of interesting tariff scenarios has been predicted. As a result, recommendations for superior tariffing are made.

A difficulty in constructing dependable, fault-tolerant distributed computer control systems is the problem of preventing faults in one part the system from spreading to other parts. A theoretical solution is to design system components so that when they fail it is ensured that they produce no output. Techniques such as graceful degradation, standby redundancy and active redundancy can then be used at the system level to compensate for such failed components. The implementation strategy used in an experimental prototype fail-silent processing node intended for use in real-time distributed computer control systems is discussed and issues that arise are analysed.

Unique challenges face the implementer of novel advanced technology in industries. This is even more so when the industry in question is located in a third world country. This paper reinvestigates this problem from a technology / industry system point of view and presents a new model for understanding these challenges.

I propose to take the opportunity which is offered me by my obligation to present a Valedictory Address to present to yon a brief summary of what I saw and heard about, in an engineering way when I was recently in the United States.

In this paper we introduce the construction of new families of error-correcting codes based on irregular low-density parity-check codes (LDPC), which we called generalized irregular low-density (GILD) codes. GILD codes are constructed by replacing each single parity check in LDPC codes with the parity check matrix of a small linear block code called the constituent code. The average weight distribution of GILD codes over all possible interleavers is derived as a function of the component code and the code length N. We also study iterative decoding of GILD codes for communication over an additive while Gaussian noise channel. The high flexibility in selecting the parameters of GILD codes and their better performance make them more attractive than GLD codes and hence suitable for small and large block length forward error correcting schemes.
ieee_keywords: ['Error probability', 'Maximum likelihood decoding', 'Block codes', 'Upper bound', 'Iterative decoding', 'Data models', 'Turbo codes']

abstracts: As the subject of meter testing is highly specialized, the paper first classifies and reviews the various methods of measuring the errors of a.c. kilowatt-hour meters. A description is then given of new equipment for rapid and precise testing in which decade counter tubes, controlled by a rotary sub-standard, are used to indicate the error. The substandard runs at the same speed on both unity and 0.5 power factor. Starting and stopping of the counter is effected with high precision without any mechanical movement. This is accomplished by optical and electronic means involving clip-on mirrors which are attached to the meter spindles by special tools. Push-button load selection, error tables and meter connecting plugs are employed. The results obtained and costs involved are given. A new device for preliminary setting of the quadrature and low-load adjustments is described; also a new dial-testing machine. Starting load-tests, creep tests and warming facilities are briefly discussed. Finally, the application of the electronic test method to the calibration of rotary substandards is mentioned.

According to the remarks of Mr. Badham, any type of alternator with normal end windings is not capable of giving uniform surge distribution. The speed of propagation of a surge through the end windings of an alternator is about 600 feet per microsecond, while in the slots it is only one-tenth of this value. Knowing the length of one turn of the winding, the time for a surge to traverse one turn can be calculated, and when taken in conjunction with the rate of rise of voltage will give the voltage between turns, the maximum value so obtained being on the end turns.

I think it may be of general practical interest to members of our Institute to have a brief description of the design of the electrically-operated shaft lashing engine which was used to re-capture the world shaft sinking record from the Russians in September, 1959, and to establish the present standing world record of a shaft advance of 1,118 ft. in 31 days at Western Reefs No. 4 Shaft.

Expressions are doveloped for the fields established by the Hertzian dipole and by the magnetic dipole in terms of dipole moments. The expressions hold when the derivatives of the dipole moments are continuous for all values of time. It is then assumed that the moment M obeys a hyperbolic tangent law M-tanh(kt) and an insight into the nature of impulsive fields is obtained by considering the condition k-in when the function becomes a step. General expressions for impulse fields are then formulated, and an example is worked to illustrate some properties of impulse fields. It is found that the ‘static,’ ‘induction’ and ‘radiation’ fields have different shapes. Theory also shows that it is meaningless to consider the relative importance of these fields unless a receiver frequency is specified.

In electing me your president for the first year of the existence of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers, an honour has been conferred on me of which I am very proud, and for which I have to thank you. Feeling strongly as I do that this Institute is even now, at such a young stage, fairly representative of the Electrical Engineers of South Africa, I feel doubly honoured by such election and I will endeavour to further the interests of the Institute as far as my ability, enthusiasm for the profession, and the time which can be taken from a somewhat busy life, will permit.
Gentlemen, I feel that we may look upon this first meeting of the newly-formed Students' Section of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers as an auspicious occasion.

Results are presented to show that the impedance bandwidth of a microstrip patch antenna can be improved substantially by adding a single parallel LC resonator in the form of an open- and short-circuited stub to the feed structure of the antenna. Computed and measured results are presented, demonstrating a bandwidth improvement of more than 100%.

In this paper the method described by Schroeder et al. [1] is employed to halve the bandwidth of a speech signal. Such a “rooting” system was implemented and the results indicated that a doubling of the information carrying capacity of, for example, a SSB radio channel or an increase of 3 dB in the received signal to noise ratio is possible by employing practical filters. It is also indicated that “noise shaping” takes place and that the subjective increase in signal to noise ratio may even be more.
ieee_keywords: ['Bandwidth', 'Signal to noise ratio', 'Band-pass filters', 'Finite impulse response filters', 'Real-time systems', 'Power harmonic filters', 'Amplitude modulation']
author_keywords: ['Bandwidth reduction', 'analytic signal', 'single sideband', 'signal to noise ratio']

abstracts: This paper introduces the concepts of the Theory of Constraints as developed by dr. E. M. Goldratt and others. When applied to a portfolio of projects, the value that an organisation realises from successful delivery can be maximised. A new value metric is introduced that effectively accounts for the flow of money in different time periods. An approach to portfolio management that strives for maximising organisation performance, given limited organisational capacity, is also introduced. Critical Chain project scheduling and synchronising projects around the schedule of a heavily loaded (drum) resource are used as the methodology of finite capacity management that enables leveraging value with scarce resources. A new set of buffers is introduced to enable the integration of portfolio management and Critical Chain scheduling.

This paper describes the manner in which induction heating of an oil pipeline was accomplished at Richards Bay. An equivalent circuit for the pipeline configuration is deduced, and techniques for determining the values of components in the circuit for unsaturated and saturated magnetic conditions are given. Predictions are compared with measurements made on the pipeline.
This paper describes an investigation into the derating of induction motors supplied from unbalanced three phase voltages.

This paper presents a transputer based induction motor flux control method which is independant of machine resistance parameters and does not require flux transducers. The system is based on the fact that the reactive power consumed by an induction motor is a function of flux in the main magnetising circuit and the leakage paths. That is, flux amplitude may be found if inductances are known. The field orientation control is derived from control of the voltage vector. The computation method as well as experimental results are presented.

Mr. Cocks, apart from being a brilliant engineer, has served this Institute for many years, both as an ordinary member and as a member of Council; for the last two years he has been a Vice-President, and we all know how well he has carried out the duties of that position. I am quite confident that Mr. Cocks will carry on the honourable traditions of the Institute, and I am sure that he will bring added lustre to the presidential office. Mr. Cocks, in handing over to you, I feel that I am handing over to a man who has the interests of the Institute at heart, and may I wish you a very successful year of office. (Applause.)

The successful implementation of a real-time expert system on an industrial chemical plant was managed as a collaborative project. After investigation of knowledge requirements, a rule-based knowledge representation language was defined and the expert system implemented using the POPLOG development environment. The final expert system provided recipe recommendations to the operator of the batch plant. Extensive evaluation was performed on the system.

In opening this paper, which deals with the characteristics and uses of one type of cell only, it is desirable first of all to review briefly the characteristics of the three classifications of photo-electric cells which exist, and to indicate the section to which the Photronic Cell belongs.

The author has put together the widely scattered information available in the literature on electrostatic precipitation and moulded this together with his 20 years of experience. The result is a comprehensive treatise on the subject, from a somewhat abbreviated presentation of Townsend's theories of ionization, original and modified, through a much fuller treatment of the electric field relationships for a wide variety of typical electrode arrangement, to a comprehensive description and analysis of modern precipitators.

The prototype nuclear power station based on the fast breeder reactor which is to be built in Scotland is ‘the system of the next century’, according to Sir William Penney, chairman of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority.

The industrialisation of any new technical system requires the establishment of the required industrial infrastructure and supplier base for the system. This paper describes a methodology for the determination of industrialisation guidelines for such programmes. The methodology considers three types of considerations. They are 1) Strategic & Operational Requirements, 2) Market Considerations, and 3) Current Industrial Capabilities. These are evaluated and the scores are combined to calculate the recommended industrialisation guidelines. There are four possible outcomes or guidelines that this methodology produces. They are for 1) Local procurement, 2) Overseas procurement, 3) Partnership procurement, or 4) Competitive procurement. Two examples of the application of this methodology are given. These are for the armaments industry and the Pebble Bed Modular Nuclear Reactor project.
author_keywords: ['Industrialisation guidelines', 'procurement', 'armaments industry', 'Pebble Bed Modular Nuclear Reactor']

abstracts: Experience shows that it is difficult to select, from an ever-widening set of software tools, those appropriate for a given project. Complicating the choice beyond mere vendor selection is a proliferation of open source offerings. An abstract model is proposed to assist in this selection process. In this model, generic elements of a rational decision making process are identified. The model is realized in a matrix in which rows represent tools and columns represent tool properties. This tool matrix is developed iteratively, starting off with an initial attempt to articulate those tool properties perceived to be important in the project. The criticality of each property is also estimated. This information constitutes the column headings. Tools described in available information sources constitute the rows, with their compliance to the required properties indicated in the appropriate cells of the matrix. Rows are grouped together in functional categories — e.g. version systems, modeling tools, etc. Columns are grouped in terms of properties typically associated with a given functional category. The result is a visual representation of the extent to which identified tools meet properties. This serves as a basis for selecting one or more tools to meet the desired requirements. Iteration of the model consists of evaluating the coverage of these requirements, refinement of properties and trade off between alternatives. Experience in using the model in a number of industrial contexts is discussed. The case studies show that the process forces one to consider as many alternatives and prerequisites as are necessary, and to systematically make ones reasoning explicit. This experience leads to the conclusion that the discipline demanded to construct the model has rational decisions as its payoff, based on well-assimilated information summarized in the tool matrix.

The 106th GENERAL MEETING OF THE CAPE WESTERN CENTRE was held at Electricity House, Cape Town, on Thursday, 17th May, 1962.

The General Meeting of the Centre hold on Thursday, 18th October 1953, Mr L. A. Grierson, Transformer Engineer of the Brush Electrical Engineering Co., Ltd., Loughborough, England, presented an interesting and informative paper on Transformer design. The paper covered aspects of the design of transformers in relation to conditions likely to arise in the operation of transformers in practice with particular reference to heating and insulation life. abstracts: The Council specially invites Country Members to submit written discussions on papers. The papers still open for discussion are listed in the agenda for the Ordinary General Meetings.

In November 1949 a symposium of papers covering research on magnetic materials was presented by the Measurements Section of The Institution. A complementary symposium dealing with the selection and use of dielectrics in electrical engineering has now been arranged and will be held in the Institution Building in London from 16th to 18th March 1953, when about fifty papers will be presented.
The following letter from the President of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Researchhas been receivedby the Institute.

The Council of The Institution have decided to bring into force from the commencement of the next volume of the Journal in January, 1949, certain changes in its division. From that date any of the material in Part I of the present Journal which is intended specially for the use of members of The Institution, for instance, the Foreword and “Institution Notes,” will appear in a new monthly “Journal” to be circulated to members only.

The 173rd general meeting of the Centre was held on 12th September in the Newbery Hall of the Athenaeum in Newlands. There were 48 members and visitors present. The Chairman, Mr J. F. Uys, welcomed Dr D. G. Torr of the CSIR and Mrs Torr who had come to Cape Town especially to present the paper.

The 125th general meeting of the Cape Western centre was held on Thursday, 9th January, 1964 at Electricity House, Strand Street, Cape Town.
