Knowledge of the thermal conductivity of hydrating concrete facilitates more accurate thermal modeling. This information coupled with thermal management techniques, reduce the risk of crack formation during the curing phase in large concrete structures. In this paper, the thermal conductivity probe method of measuring the thermal conductivity of hydrating concrete is described together with the design considerations necessary for the successful implementation of the technique. The design of a portable instrument capable of performing thermal conductivity measurements in-situ and the algorithms used to automate the measurement process are presented.

This paper reviews the existing state of the art in the economic use of aluminium in place of copper In power cables. It deals with the basic characteristics of aluminium, the general extent of its use in cables, and reviews the extent of national and international standardisatien en the subject. A brief description of the salient points of aluminium cable manufacture is followed by censideration of conductor sizing, continuous and short-circuit current ratings, and a discussion of installation factors and jointing practice. A brief mention is also made of the use and experience of aluminium in wiring cables to date. The occurrence and metallurgy of aluminium is briefly summarised In an Appendix.

The paper reviews the present state of knowledge regarding oil/paper dielectrics and analyses the factors that reduce service life. It is found that insulating oil in contact with air absorbs oxygen which attacks hydrocarbon molecules under the Influence of heat, producing the well-known oxidation products — organic acids and sludge. Organic acid has long been considered a major contaminant of transformer oil. But research and experience indicate that its most harmful effects are not the erosion of metals below oil level, which is negligible, nor the degradation of oil and paper insulation but Its effect in raising the hygroscopy of oil. Although humidity has practically no effect on oil oxidation, an Increase in oil's affinity for water accelerates the absorption and transfer of moisture from air in contact with the oil to the extremely hygroscopic paper insulation immersed in it. The combined effects of temperature, oxygen and humidity lead to polymerisation of oil and oxidation products, and decomposition of paper insulation leading to the eventual breakdown of a transformer in service. Modern methods of conditioning and testing insulating oil, as well as the economics of oil purification, are reviewed.

Insulation co-ordination implies the selection of the electric insulation characteristics of equipment with regard to its application and in relation to its surroundings. Consideration must be given to the voltages which can appear within the system, to the location and characteristics of the overvoltage protective devices, to the continuity of service desired and to the safety of persons and property, so that the probability of undesired incidents due to voltage stresses is reduced to ensure an economically and operationally acceptable performance. In recent years, the IEC set up Sub-Committee 28A: Insulation Co-ordination for Low-voltage Equipment, to establish an international system for insulation co-ordination within low-voltage systems. This would eliminate present problems caused through existing standards which specify diverse design criteria for dimensions of clearances and creepage distances. For equipment, it would also enable designers to specify insulation performance criteria for electrical equipment and installations and systems which are becoming more complex. SC 28A was assigned a ‘safety pilot function’, which meant that its recommendations would be taken into consideration by other Technical and Sub-Committees when specifying creepage and clearance distance requirements for products for which they are responsible.

Lightning is by far the most frequent cause of power interruptions on rural distribution lines in South Africa's Highveld. Flash density varies between five and twelve flashes per square kilometre per year [1, 2]. Eskom (South Africa's major generation and bulk transmission utility, responsible for most rural distribution) currently operates some 150 000 km of rural distribution lines (11 kV and 22 kV, woodpole construction) throughout the country.
To complete the remarks I have already made I wish to answer the outstanding items raised at the discussion in the order in which they were contributed.

This paper describes how leakage current measurements were done in a salt fog tent with variable salinity and creepage distance. Consequently, an empirical model is developed to relate the required specific creepage distance of a porcelain long rod insulator to salt fog salinity. This model is based on the I-max theory as applied to a simplified representation of an arcing insulator.

WHEN A DIRECT LIGHTNING STROKE OCCURS FROM A cloud to a transmission line conductor the usual result is a flash over along the surface of the insulator without permanent damage to it. Occasionally, however, the insulator punctures despite the fact that such insulators have passed the normally accepted insulator tests.

This paper addresses the application of intelligent adaptive control in an industrial process. Implementation of the technique in a practical system should lead to gaining confidence and acceptance of the methodology. An important rationale for the work is the potential of an intelligent adaptive control technique to overcome some shortcomings of conventional control approaches. An intelligent adaptive control (IAC) technique, which is analogous to conventional model-referenced adaptive control (MRAC) is presented. This scheme uses a fuzzy knowledge base and an inference mechanism for making tuning decisions of a lead compensator in the control loop. As a case study, IAC is implemented on an industrial fish processing machine. In order to show the effectiveness of the intelligent scheme, a conventional MRAC is implemented on the same machine, and the performance under the two techniques is compared. It is found that IAC is able to perform as well as MRAC, while possessing better flexibility in design, ease of implementation, and computational efficiency.
author_keywords: ['Intelligent adaptive control', 'model-referenced adaptive control', 'lead compensator', 'fuzzy logic', 'industrial fish processing']

abstracts: Photography of lightning strokes with the Boys camera has shown that each separate stroke is of a dual nature, consisting of a leader and a return portion. It has been shown that the return stroke travels from ground to cloud, passing outwards along the brandies when it reaches branching points of the leader. The charge on the leader branches passes in this manner to ground. It has also been shown that there is a marked diminution in the intensity of light emitted from the main channel after the return stroke has passed a prominent branch.

abstracts: The 44th Annual General Meeting of the IEC was held this year in Sydney, Australia, from 21st May until 2nd June — the first of such meetings to be held in the Southern Hemisphere.
The development, object and achievements of international standardization, with special reference to electrical engineering, are reviewed.

Internetworking standards have enabled designers of internets to use devices from multiple vendors. In the design of an internet, two of the major technical problems revolve around the optimum selection of links between nodes and the location of the root of the tree which spans the configuration. The tree and its root form a heirachy of branches which link all nodes in an internet such that no loop paths exist between nodes. This paper describes how an Internet Descriptor can be used to assess effects on performance and reliability of the location of the root and configuration of the tree in an internet. In the two design examples, internet trees are examined in terms of their compactness. Internet throughput, end-to-end transmission time, configuration balancing and cost are all directly related to the degree of compactness of the tree, as is shown.

The set of Walsh functions form a closed orthogonal set which, by their binary nature, lend themselves to processing using modern LSI logic circuits. This paper presents an introduction to the theory of Walsh functions and transforms, and discusses areas of application.

abstracts: The post-war years have seen thfe growth in overseas countries of a new sphere of knowledge which shows signs of affecting mens thinking in diverse fields of activity and which is of importance to telecommunication engineers. It is known either as Communication Theory or the Theory of Information. The statistics of languages, the study of the human nervous system, the behaviour and design of self-stabilizing mechanisms and digital computers are examples of its wide field of application. In electrical communication, it is of specific interest because it permits a fundamental assessment to be made of the performance of the various types of present-day communication systems and thus promises to help in the design and development of future ones. It introduces the engineer himself to new and interesting concepts which, although clearly part of electrical theory, do not follow The post-war years have seen thfe growth in overseas countries of a new sphere of knowledge which shows signs of affecting mens thinking in diverse fields of activity and which is of importance to telecommunication engineers. It is known either as Communication Theory or the Theory of Information. The statistics of languages, the study of the human nervous system, the behaviour and design of self-stabilizing mechanisms and digital computers are examples of its wide field of application. In electrical communication, it is of specific interest because it permits a fundamental assessment to be made of the performance of the various types of present-day communication systems and thus promises to help in the design and development of future ones. It introduces the engineer himself to new and interesting concepts which, although clearly part of electrical theory, do not follow the classical pattern.

abstracts: One of the most important milestones in the growth of electronic engineering is undoubtedly the appearance, in 1950, of the transistor for whose development J Bardeen, W Brattain and W Shockley received the Nobel Prize in 1956.

In order to discuss the question of how to get started, the role or application in which, a microprocessor is to be used has first to be decided. Microprocessors are today used in a wide spectrum of applications, ranging from dedicated control on the one hand to general purpose data processing applications on the other hand.
An invention that has assumed practical importance in the field of communications after lying dormant for 25 years was recently discussed by its inventor, Mr Alec H. Reeves.

The right of employers in the inventions of their employees is a subject which has received considerable attention in the more developed industrial countries and this is especially true of the United States of America, Germany and Great Britian. South Africa has very little developed law on the subject and it would be in our interests to borrow the best from elsewhere. In this regard the United States has something of real value to offer and development of our law by the absorption of the ‘shop right’ doctrine is not only recommended but appears possible within the framework of our common law.

Mr Alec Harley Reeves, who delivered the 1969 Bernard Price Memorial Lecture to The South African institute of electrical engineers, was given a special award of $5 000 and a trophy, by International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. “In recognition of his contribution to the progress of telecommunication technology through the concept and development of pulse-code modulation.“

Since an electronic inverter is not far removed from the ‘chopper’ modulated dc voltage controller, it has bean suggested that the dc motor be replaced by an ac machine in a battery vehicle. The advantage of using a more robust and cheaper motor hat to be weighed against an increase in the complexity and cost of the additional electronic equipment. It may also be possible to achieve a better motor characteristic with respect to the requirements of the drive. A system is described which employs a synchronous motor driven by a transistorized inverter. The experimental results of the combination show a promising torque-speed characteristic with a large starting torque provided armature reaction is reduced. The inverter is arranged to incorporate voltage control so that the motor may be operated at maximum flux per pole over its entire speed range. The results show that it is necessary to control voltage and internal angle to retain the advantages of the system.

An analysis it developed which describes the existence of substantial inter-bar laminar currents in large three-phase squirrel cage induction motors with broken bars and/or rings. Also, results of experimental measurements are presented which verify the theoretical model for two cases.

This paper reports an analysis of hourly oblique ionograms made in a winter month (August 1975) and a summer month (January 1976) between Sanae and Grahamstown. The maximum observed frequency (MOF) and the lowest observed frequency on the low-angle ray (LLOF) were scaled, and inverse transmission curves were used to estimate the equivalent vertical frequency (EVFO) for the ordinary ray. The data are used to show the frequency ranges and times of day for which transmission in the different modes may be expected.
